review_title: [Optum] Great Culture, Great People. That's where it ends.
job_title: Applications Developer in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros:
People are great! Through all levels everyone is very approachable and people do not act 'fake', that is they will be frank with you if they need to and will not send you on a run around. Culture when concerned with people is good.

Also a lot of paid time off, way more than most companies.
cons:
Everything else.

-People working for 20 years get laid off with an email with no warning and have to leave within 2 hours.
-Company, UnitedHealth Group, pretends it is successful but lays off people in groups every month like it's no ones business.
-There is no innovation here.
-Reorgs are frequent and do little to nothing to improve anything.
-The chance of your project losing funding or being canceled is around 95%.
-Stagnation
-Laughable 'Raises' of 1%
-Communication between different parts of the organization seem disorganized
-Everything is disorganized in general
-Managers are just as blindsided as their subordinates
-Projects that are burning the company's money still exist.
-Mediocre Health Benefits.... at a Health Insurance company
-Work Life Balance: either you are extremely overworked or extremely under-worked, there is no such thing as 'balanced'
-New projects or direction based off buzzwords the business does not understand like "Machine Learning", "Blockchain", "Agile". These are used out of context constantly and are clearly not understood by the people saying them.
-Employees are a resource. We are not individuals with concerns or feelings. In business planning and actions we are not considered ever.

pros: Work in a diversity of cultural, socioeconomic areas. Complex chronic conditions.
cons:
They tell you you make your own hours, you have autonomy (and you do to a point). You set your hours in the schedule. They insisted on 8 weeks. 6 weeks is reasonable when trying to plan around family.  Pay is ok. I was misinformed how to get reimbursed on mileage, so they didn’t pay it.  People to be seen were sometimes scheduled against their will. Members never knew the purpose of the visit of why a practitioner was coming to their home. A great deal of time was spent explain this. 
Expections included calling the members the night before, if you had time to work this in with family when you got home— great. You order and maintain your own inventory and you have to keep it in your house. I don’t have a lot of room. Smokers had no regard for you as a visitor. You are in THEIR home, boundaries of redirecting the member  was difficult. Assignments were regularly overbooked and you have to justify to the member waiting to see you as to why you are late. Members have no regard for you, the next person to be seen. I was told a visit should only take 45 min. And I should be able to get to the next member on the scheduler’s time frame. Drive time between members varied from 5 min to 40 min. Routes were sometimes backtracking. It took forever to streamline the IT system for user friendly documentation portal, email, etc,...

review_title: All the bureaucracy of a giant corporation, some attempts at innovation
pros:
Massive scale.  They are one of the few massive incumbents with the financial resources to acquire interesting companies and drive large-scale change.  

This is a numbers-driven company and one that's pretty meritocratic in it's focus on performance (they have cultural values, but this one matters more than most). If you hit your numbers, you'll be rewarded. Conversely, if you don't, you'll be out the door pretty quickly.
cons:
Very large and bureaucratic. Doing things like booking travel, submitting expenses, or even navigating other parts of the company are extremely time consuming. 

The health insurance is laughably bad. It's hard to take the company's focus on innovation seriously when all you have are three versions of HDHPs as your health plan options (even when all the academic research shows that HDHPs are worse for your health in the long-term). Also, 4 weeks of parental leave may be generous for a health insurer, but it's extremely uncompetitive for hiring/retention in many parts of the Optum businesses. 

If you're going to work here, make sure to negotiate hard on salary. The benefits aren't great, so most of your overall package will be based on your base salary. Aim high on that.

job_title: Provider Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: For a call center environment its great because you're speaking with providers that work in doctors offices so there is a mutual respect. Very reasonable and achievable goals . Great bonuses and decent pay. I started at 15.15 hr. Easiest call center job I've ever had.
cons: They just recently changed their sick time to where you are able to miss 1-2 consecutive days and if you have PTO it counts as a sick day. If you are sick for 1-2 days and you don't have PTO it counts as an occurrence. It used to be every missed consecutive day 1-5 counts as an occurrence. If you have more than 4 occurrences you are put on what is called a cap. A cap you can not move up/work for another department, you don't get raises or bonuses. An occurrence is removed a year from the time you missed that day/received it. Other cons are speaking with what we call 3rd party callers with 20 plus claims. Some 3rd party callers are very hard to understand. This is a con because the add time to your AHT and your AHT is one factor used to get bonuses.

pros: Telecommute is about it for the Pros.
cons: Upper management is challenging. I was exposed to some very bad management in the way of no empathy for a new person trying to learn, snide remarks, micromanagement, poor communication, lack of guidance. There is not a way to truly learn the business without a good strong mentor that is encouraging, possesses strong knowledge, is eager to help, and has strong communication. The environment is extremely stressful. They offer no training of the business, it is expected to just jump in and sink or swim. review_title: Go in with your eyes open and your bottom covered
pros:
- Our United Culture (The Way Forward) is starting to gain traction and change behavior. 
- Reorg into UnitedHealthcare and Optum (benefits businesses, service businesses) means the silos are going away.
cons:
- Before joining the company I knew what bullying, bias and hostile-work-environment were from an intellectual and common sense perspective. Now I know from firsthand experience. If it's rotten up at the top of your part of the org chart, the bullying will not stop. 
- Human Capital (nee Human Resources) is centralized. For the average employee, there is no one to go to on site. You have to call an 800 number.On site Human Capital Partners focus on and serve senior leaders and executives. 
- A slice of the population talks Our United Culture, but, doesn't walk it. In practical terms these people will use cultural concepts like "assume positive intent" to avoid being responsible for bad behavior and, once again, if things are rotten up at the top of the org chart, there's nothing that can be done.
- Widespread layoffs every several years - right now, in fact (June 2012).
- For many, work/life balance does not exist (despite lip service). The hours can be brutal. 
- There is a general understanding that too often you have to leave to move up. In other words, far too little promotion from within; far too much promoting from the outside.
- The old addage that you work (about) 2 years at UnitedHealthcare and then go get the job you really want and are qualified for still holds.

review_title: The people are great, the policies leave a lot to be desired.
pros: Salary and compensation is market competitive if not better.  I am given the tools I need to excel in my job.  My specific manager is a very hands-off, anti micro management person, and lots of other coworkers of my pay grade report the same thing with their managers.  The benefits package is the best I have ever received in either contract/consulting or FTE  positions.  MY manager is always willing to be flexible with scheduling when situations arise caring for my special needs son.  My coworkers are pleasant and respectful, and there is a mutual willingness to help out when problems arise for myself or others.
cons: The size of the company necessitates an inordinate amount of compartmentalization.  This makes larger problems that are out of my realm of influence, often difficult to resolve.  It also removes ANY need for pragmatism in the workplace.  You do the letter of your job duties, whether they are needed or not.  It isn't up to you to decide what needs to be done, it is only up to you do do what you are told.  I have often had to do things that were completely unnecessary because it wasn't my place to say "do we REALLY need to do this in this situation?"  The answer always comes back to "corporate security policy states you need to, no matter what, in every case without fail, so do it".

pros: I am grateful to be a part of the UnitedHealth Group family.  It is a large company and, to me, that means much more stability than a small, privately-owned company where every cent for raises or overtime has to be wrested from the owner's hand.  We have a lot of autonomy on our job; no micromanaging (at least not by my boss.  I guess I can't speak for everyone)  The pay is excellent as is the time off.  I came from an inpatient coding job where we had to use PTO for holidays since hospitals operate 24/7.  That's not the case here.  I highly recommend this company.
cons: The hiring process is lumbersome.  I applied for my current position every time it was posted (probably 6 or 7 times over the course of a year) and every single time I almost immediately got back  form e mail telling me that I didn't have the experience they needed for the job. job_title: Case Manager LTC Medicaid in Cape Coral, FL
pros: Strong company, good values, flexibility.
cons:
LTC Medicaid case manager in Florida. Met with primarily geriatric patients and home, ALF, and SNF to complete clinical and functional assessments, quarterly face-to-face visits, monthly phone contacts, and coordinate needs to increase function.

UHC provides equipment for home office. UHC has competitive salary. UHC has a strong and positive work culture overall.

However, if you have worked as a case manager in the field before, this might not be the best job for you.
I have over 10 years of experience working as a community case manager. The equipment was outdated, the staff is too isolated, the caseloads are too high, and the amount of paperwork is triple anything I've seen before. 

If you are looking for a little bit of flexibility for the first time or an increase in salary this might be the job for you. If you already work as a case manager with comparable salary do not move to UHC. 

There are a lot of unnecessary spreadsheets to complete weekly and monthly, utilization management reports, coverage of other caseloads, large service areas, new projects, frequent changes in procedure, SOPs/trainings are not updated timely to meet the demands of the job, and limited contact with peers for support.

review_title: **"Iceberg!"** Failure to innovate, failure to communicate, not enough lifeboats!
pros: Great people (at least in my department), laid-back work environment, freedom to submit ideas (though usually unheeded), free coffee, all the soda you could ever ask for, super high deductible insurance, loads of sugar available in the kitchens, diet mountain dew, high-calorie lunch Wednesdays, fun company-wide guessing games, tons of denials stacking up, a once great holiday party...
cons:
No vision, lack of direction, little innovation beyond core products developed years ago, arbitrary goal-setting, inability to foresee impact of regulation changes on business model, complacent attitude toward position in marketplace ("the authority"), blithe and reactionary business practices, obdurate, foolhardy decision-making....

This company once had a very entrepreneurial environment.  They treated their employees with respect and valued hard work.  When the company was sold, the employees were left with an inexperienced management group that couldn't navigate off the original course when there was clearly a giant 1599-shaped iceberg in plain view.  Instead of proactively changing the business model while they had time to plan, the prevailing sentiment was, "I hope this doesn't happen, maybe it won't happen, but, if it does happen, they will still need our services".  Unfortunately, the services only provided value in a specific environment (if they did at all).  Now the hospital systems are leaving because they are done buying fertilizer.

Things could have been different, but too many factors are working against them.  I wish everyone still there good luck and hope they can make it out ok.

pros: Offers onsite fitness classes, nice building, generous PTO (if you are able to use it) ability to work from home when necessary.
cons: Salaried employees are taken advantage of. It is the expectation that employees be on call 24/7, especially in a sales support role. Sales team earn the commissions, but those in supporting roles must work long hours, evenings and weekends without being offered these same incentives. Expect to receive emails at 3am and reprimanded if you don't respond within the hour or 6:30am phone calls on Sunday mornings. Every deadline is urgent and has a short turnaround. Unrealistic project load. Who can really manage 11 projects with short turnarounds and competing deadlines all at once? Department operates with very minimal staff. Can't actually take PTO because there is no one to back you up. You'll have to make up your time on the weekend. We are told that we can work shorter days during non-peak season, but peak season lasts from Dec-Oct, leaving the month of November to only work a traditional 40 hour week. Employees are stressed, burned out and on the verge of nervous breakdowns.

cons:

pros: Telecommute was a nice perk in that it offered flexibility. Team members were really nice.
cons:
I wasn't there long enough to get a good overall perspective of the company from a growth and culture standpoint, but for my time there I did notice some cons.

Telecommute, while a nice perk, could make you feel isolated. Everything was done via phone/chat so it felt somewhat impersonal. 

The pay was on the low side, which is frustrating especially when you see posts on the corporate intranet site about how much more profit the company made this year over the previous year. 

The health insurance options provided to the employee, or lack thereof, is downright terrifying when you look at deductibles and out of pocket maxes, especially when you have to cover a spouse or family. All plans are high deductible, to varying degrees. When coupled with premiums on top of that, you're looking at losing a substantial amount of take home pay if you have any type of existing or emergency medical issues.

pros:
I perused some previous reviews and realized that some of what I have to say will directly contradict other reviews. I'll preface my positives by saying that I worked in the smaller of two offices we have and all of my positives probably can be directly pulled from just that one office's experience.

- Amazing support from co-workers. This probably has a lot to do with the office I was in, but I never felt an overly competitive nature from co-workers and knew where I could go if I needed help without exception.
- Access to senior leadership. I'd been to senior leadership's houses for after work gatherings, been out to eat with them, had them write me letters to go back to school. I never felt like my chain of command was not accessible to me.
- Great PTO. First job out of college and I had more PTO than my parents jobs combined.
- Upward mobility (to a point). At some point when you work for a company whose biggest client is the federal government, not having advanced credentials/degrees will hurt, but for the first few years there is some room for growth and growing responsibility at the company.
- Good hours. In the years working there I only worked 55+ hours a handful of times, and 43-47 was the standard for general time.
cons: - The only thing I didn't like about working there was the reliance on telecommunications and the web for project teams.

job_title: Project Manager in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros: Work from home was possible for me, the job was easy at the beginning then all at once they dumped stuff in my lap. Good place to fall back on if you need a job and there are no others. I would not advise anyone to consider working for UHG for very long. They have their core employees and depend on them to get the work done. Everyone else is basically used as a scapegoat when things go wrong so if you don't leave they will fire you, and they fire and hire about 2 people a month where I am. It is a total revolving door.
cons: Very decentralized management where workers are confused most of the time, and I have worked for for 10 years in compoines with a decentralized staff. Managers say you are doing a good job all year and then blast you on reviews for everything they didn't like. They ask your peers and leave out the praise and center on where you need to improve without warning.

review_title: Very stressful. Everyone does the work of 2 people. They refuse to hire more people a dept needs.
pros: For a paycheck, for medical benefits
cons: Women run most depts. They do NOT support other women not like men do. They treat their employees like you are in the military or treat you like you are a machine. You are not given the respect you deserve no matter how well you do your job.You are never thanked, praised or respected much.  No raises in years yet senior mgt gets their's & promotions. Some mgr's get away with harassment, bullying and intimidating you. You are not valued there. They drive out good employees. They do not wish to hear a better way to improve anything. You are just there to follow orders. You could do 100 things right and all they care about is criticizing you or harassing you over any minor mistake you make. Alot of harsh women managers work there. Upper mgt does a poor job as well as supervisors in communicating what is going on in the co. to employees in the co. Most employees work in a fearful environment. This is no fun job or environment to work in. No advancement and you are underpaid. Teams don't work together but against each other.

job_title: HEDIS Project Coordinator in Brentwood, TN
pros: It paid $22/hour and training was 2 months long. It was very easy money.
cons:
I worked as a contractor for the HEDIS Project. I was conned into the job by being told it was Project Coordination. I have years of PM experience and saw it as a way to get my foot in the door. The job was actually an outbound call center. They blatantly lied. About 20 of us were hired and we were all very upset. We came from careers with lots of experience (several PMs and former VPs). They lied about the position to get overqualified people in because the job itself is very complicated and a lot to learn in a short period of time. 

I quit because I did not want to spend time in a job that wasn't related to my education or experience. Nothing in this job was going transfer to my future job. Plus it was a call center and I HATE call centers. I wouldn't work in one for any amount of money. If they'd been honest about the job I would have turned it down. Because they lied they wasted their own money and my time.

pros: The good part to this location is that for training (6 weeks) and what they call Nesting (6 weeks) it is Monday through Friday schedule, weekends off so that a plus. The pay is decent  (12.00) but nothing to write home about, its better than a 8.50 or 9.00 and hour job, yet still not enough to totally survive off of. This is a start up site so everyone is from other locations so that part is nice, you get a mix and a variety. Also we were told that if we do well there are plenty of opportunities to move up with the company.
cons: Every employee comes in the door ( in this location and through Optum) as a "casual" employee meaning UHC has to hire us on. Which also means no benefits, no pto and no insurance which is ok if you're like 5 years old and your parents take care of you. Other lines of the business hire people right on and they have benefits from day 1. Also in the new Atlanta site the hiring process is too easy, they aren't selective at all and basically just hire anyone. Many people in my group have already left due to finding better more permanent jobs.

review_title: Unprofessional management of the pharmacy...Pharmacists are viewed as "over paid forklift operators".
pros:
Work hours are good (day shifts) except Jan-March(lots of mandatory OT), but we all knew that going into  the job. They pay time and a half for this OT work....great time to make your own bonus, because if you're not in the top 35% you will 
not get either a raise or a bonus.....welcome to the "great unwashed" that make up the lower 65%
cons:
Where to begin?
1. Employees are viewed and treated as fungible commodities, not valued, respected, and easily replaced... regardless of  Optumrx's printed hype to the contrary.
2. Healthcare insurance benefits are  3rd rate. Three yrs ago I heard  the on-site HR dude (OP,KS) actually brag that UHG is a Fortune 50 company that provides benefits, equal to a fortune 250 company, out of 500 companies reviewed...?????  
3. After 6 years of college and earning a Doctor of Pharmacy Degree, pharmacists are reviled and resented by management  from  Optumrx, from  CEO (Dirk) down to the facility level. They are irked at what they have to pay us.......The UHG insurance MBA's had to strive for 15-20yrs to make what we do right out of school. Well,  I say this to them....A) go back to school, I'll pay for your first semester,  B) I will guarantee pharmacists are held in much higher trust and esteem by PATIENTS ( NOT CUSTOMERS) than the MBA insurance bean counters

pros: Once someone is hired, I understand that there's a lot of job security as they make it hard to let someone go. (I was never turned into a permanent employee so I can't be sure.) Your work could theoretically benefit a lot of people since the organization is large (although you're work will be small relative to the large number of other employees). They have an office presence in a number of locations across the country, which means you can work for them from a number of locations, and some groups within the organization allow for remote work (at least part-time).
cons: The work environment is high-pressure with little compensation or recognition. Employees were often required to work overtime (including holidays like Christmas) with little or no notice. Quality of work takes a back seat to speed of delivery. Non-managerial employees are treated like expendable assets, or treated as an "expense" the company is trying to minimize or eliminate (which has lead to pervasive offshoring of work to India). There's a long hiring process involving long (I think mandatory) contract-to-hire situations, which seem to be extended at the convenience of the employer. The computing environment is very constrained (very locked down to the point of not being able to get work done, surveillance of computing activity, etc.). My location had an open office setup which was noisy and lead to frequent interruptions. Management frequently introduced initiatives based on concepts they clearly didn't understand—they seemed to be just co-opting buzz words and using them as labels to claim they were following an industry practice. Individual contributors were frequently not allowed to make a contribution to the direction a project was going (i.e. management frequently ignored advice from experts and the people actually doing the work).

job_title: Senior Appeals Representative in Dublin, OH
pros: The only Pro is the pay is decent.
cons:
They lie to get you in the door. Once you are hired everything changes. They are EXTREME micro managers. It started out bad and increasingly got worse. They beat you down with telling you to have integrity, yet they have none.  We were constantly being accused of various things.  Those who filed complaints were retaliated against. If you questioned anything they did or challenged them in any way they'd  label you as  "agressive" and write you up. If they didn't like you for any reason they manipulate the metrics so you didn't meet them. Then of course write you up for not meeting metrics.  Also, if they didn't like you they would pull extra audits on you and just keep pulling them until they found something. If they couldn't find anything they would charge errors for things that were done right and refuse to remove the error. Then write you up for too many errors. They would ride your back and pressure you everyday - but only the minorities.  Just before time for the annual reviews, almost every minority was put on a performance plan for something. Which made them ineligible for raises or bonuses. But all the while employees were given raises and some were promoted.  The environment is terrible They hired a TON  of people and within 9 months at least half of them had left because of the environment.  At one time some people were concerned about their safety because of another employees behavior. 
 They were yelled at and chastised for reporting their concerns.  WORST COMPANY TO WORK FOR!!!!

pros: Stock discount, 401K, Company Discount, Volunteer Opportunities, and HSA.
cons: Medical coverage could be a lot better compared to other companies.

pros: Coworkers make the job bearable.
cons:
What was once a cutting-edge, exciting, and promising company that showed constant and continuous appreciation of employees, is now (after being sold to a large corporation) a deceitful and unethical place to work.  They are abusive of employees' time, making promises that are never fulfilled, and are downright deceptive when it comes to the inner workings of the company, its future, and the work environment.  The sole emphasis is on productivity with little to no value placed on quality and professionalism of work.

Employees were promised a "great lifestyle" and instead were forced to work nights, weekends, and holidays with increasing weekend shifts--none of which were compensated.  They are also "encouraged" to "volunteer" to work unpaid overtime to avoid the inferred threat of future layoffs.  There is no opportunity for advancement, with no cost of living raises and increased out-of-pocket expenses for any benefits.  Constructive voicing of opinions, questions, or suggestions is not only frowned upon, but is penalized in performance evaluations.

The morale of employees is universally the lowest I have seen anywhere.  Despite more than ample knowledge of impending government regulations, there was no evidence whatsoever of the leadership planning for this.  The subsequent chaos and significant drop in business (to the tune of approximately 50%) within one month of these new regulations was a direct result of poor leadership and lack of organization, causing a series of layoffs whereby hard-working, diligent, loyal employees were made to suffer layoffs due to the completely inept leadership's lack of planning.

review_title: I was a Business project manager for 5 and 1/2 years with the financial areas. I worked with the General Ledger, Cash Mg
job_title: Project Manager in Long Beach, CA
pros: I liked the location, most people, the amount of work expected was challenging but not over-burdening. The training options were good. The reviews were timely, and there are oppotunities to move around within the company. The projects were fun and relative to the business.
cons: Small time mentality for management. Lot's of women hired out of high school with no formal college training had management positions yet had not worked elsewhere. It made for petty power struggles. Salaries for most of them was low and they resented it even if they didn't have the background to support a higher wage. The atmosphere was like at a high school where you would have catty cliches and even the manager would call out people to humiliate them in meetings. Very expensive subsidized overall benefits, including the health insurance premiums for the employees. They try too hard to skimp on spending and stingy on outdated computers, software, paper, and basic office supplies. Coffee was the worst ever!

pros:
-Great PTO (almost 4 weeks annually) but use it or lose it with a maximum of 5 day carryover.
-Excellent business development staff to help with navigating the proposal writing process.
-Flexible work from home policy.
-Decent salary
cons:
-Odd work environment. People are holed up into their offices (some without doors) and don't really mingle or socialize. It doesn't really build a sense of collaboration or creativity.
-While some consulting staff is friendly, others are hard to read and hoard work to increase their utilization rates. 
-Some long hours with no comp time. Senior staff encourages burnout amongst their staff to meet client needs. This might be a reason for high turnover rates across the board in the firm as the senior management does not appear to value work/life balance in favor of chasing money and billing time. 
-Most senior staff are remote and don't see how hard many of the consulting staff at the Falls Church work. There is a large disconnect between the middle management and junior staff.
-Related to utilization rates, there is no clear language for what qualifies for promotions. It seems that the same staff are overloaded on projects and move faster up the ladder.

review_title: If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is!
pros: Co-workers are professional and make work seem fun.  The theory behind what UHG is doing sounds good (helping people live healthier lives).  It is nice to meet people that live around you and provide health education to members in the community.  Overall, low level medical decision making skills and low level medical legal liability.  Good benefits but pay is lacking.
cons: Many of us housecalls NP practitioners were lured in with promised that were not kept (no raises, no bonuses and the pay structure is below national average).  Then the schedules were unreasonable causing us to work longer and longer days, sometimes well over what we were scheduled to work and driving many miles daily.  PTO is a use it or lose it "grant" (not benefit) so if/when one leaves the company, they don't pay out on the last check.  Some of the check list for physical exam and testing during the housecalls visit is not medical evidence based (monofiiament screen on everyone).

pros: free food and coffee at times
cons:
Everything Everything is wrong about this place.  The way they do things is not an effective way to keep up customer satisfaction.  The turn overrate is High on the kaiser permanent part  don't expect to stay there for more then a year.  Everytime they keep letting go of the old employees by end of open enrollment.... and then hire new employees a few months later.  I can only image the amount of money that is wasted of trying to get people to pass the health insurance exam. .... also the worst thing about the place is some of the supervisors know nothing about the product absolutely nothing.. Things can go wrong and the funny thing is when the customer asks for the supervisor, the supervisors start freaking out trying to do anything to not take a call. its sad because the amount of money that is being exchanged are large and always bringing in new representatives and firing the old year after year.  I can only imagine all the stuff that is going to hit the fan.  P.S. if you get this job make sure you get good car insurance.  the company location is prone to hail storms golf ball sized hail you work there hail falls and damages your car. then in less then a year they will most likely lay you off.
Also rules about food and water is super strict like a concentration camp.  A lot of older people end up leaving in an ambulance.  so sad because this company sees health insurance and working conditions are not healthy.

pros: It's a job. They try to engage employees, but with very juvenile games (Yo-Yo's anyone?)
cons: Coaches only promote their friends.  They like to be tell you one thing, but go behind your back and do another.  Management is fake.  Pay should be based on your competence, not just a flat rate across the board, because the people that do the bare minimum make the same amount as someone who excels and goes above and beyond.  If you're barely drinking age, male, and do not have a family, you will go far with this company!

pros: HQ has a nice building.
cons:
Micro-management plus.  If on a secret test call the person asks "can you help me with that? and you answer "I can help you with that" instead of "Yes, I can help you with that" you flunk the call completely.

On the Connextions corporate totem pole you are the part that is underneath the dirt.

In the North office on eCommerce Blvd. people have taken to defecating on the floor of the bathroom stalls to show their displeasure with the company.  

Be prepared to fight with Q/A if you want what little commission is offered.  There is a saying on the floor that Q/A needs to be Q/A'd.  

On the highest commissioned account in the building you might make $2,000 commission in a year if you are one of the top producers.  On the other accounts, much less.  On the Medicare accounts you can expect $1.00 per sale of a Medicare plan and 25 - 50 cents for prescription drug plans.

Your commission is extremely subject to your Q/A score and healthcare has a lot of government verbiage that must be said word for word.  

They specialize in offering a big commission picture and finding ways to take it away.

Once open enrollment is over: December 7 for Medicare, Feb. 15 for ACA plans there is a massive layoff that clears out the parking lot.  If you are kept on you may have to take VTO (Voluntary Time Off) when call volume is low.

pros: I was a long-term employee of UHG and, overall, enjoyed working there.  A major "pro" was the ability to telecommute, full-time.  Most of the teams I was a part of, the team members were great to work with (included the boss's).  The flexible work hours are also a big pro.  I felt the salary was competitive with the market.
cons: UHG says that they "pay for performance", but that is not 100% true.  They have statistics for rating employees within departments (so sometimes people are 'up-rated', but most of the time management is required to 'down-rate' employees at review time) -- to me, this is the biggest 'con'.  Senior leadership has been inconsistent, too; so, business direction is changed often, leading to lack of trust with upper management.  One other 'con' is the cost of health insurance; you'd think that working for an insurance company that it would be less, but it actually was more than my spouse's work group insurance (for the same coverage).  The company (Sr Leadership) used to "walk the talk" regarding Culture Values, but in the last 1-2 years, that has tremendously declined.

pros: Positions fade and are created all the time so  you will be shuffled around to different areas to support what is in need at the time.  No real worry about losing your job if your segment downsizes, usually management already knows where there is an expansion and shift workers to that new area as they phase out the old one.
cons: Promotions and awards are a popularity contest.  If you are good at your job and keep your head down you will not be noticed or promoted, If you complain you hate your job and continually threaten to leave you will somehow always be given spot awards to keep you happy. If you become crucial to your job function you will never leave if it requires others to learn new skills.  The company supports and rewards people for not learning new skills and accepts people who just want to collect a paycheck.  If your immediate management does not have basic Microsoft computer skills they will hire non clinical at half the pay to do their reporting for them and continually tell them to be happy they have a job even though they cannot function without their hired support network. Personal accountability does not exist in this company and you cannot hold anyone accountable for their work.

pros: Good compensation, flexibility, good benefits including a fair amount of vacation days compared to most companies
cons: I worked in the Medicare department. The leadership was lacking and they promoted people not based on merit, but based on "I'll do whatever you tell me to do even if it doesn't produce results." No room for creativity- everything had to be done the way it was done years before even if it wasn't going to work (compensation had a production component relying on the Independent Agents that worked in your hierarchy but not for the company so it affected us in the pocket directly when they chose to produce for a different company). They expected you to work harder, not smarter and not have a work/life balance. Made the job harder than it really was. The insane stress caused me to go on medication and I considered suing for a hostile work environment- I believe it was just the management in my area that caused all these issues for us because our colleagues in other states loved their jobs and bosses (this review may be strictly negative because of the location and not because of the company). In our area, our Agents knew that upper management was clueless to what worked and what didn't in the field. While they loved us, we understood they had to make money even if it was producing for another company.

review_title: You get what you put in
job_title: Provider Claims Resolution Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros:
There are monthly meetings so you know what is going on.

They have little inquisitive activities in training that seem like its silly at the time but will really come in handy on how the managers and executives treat you in the future.  It also gives you insight to yourself as well. 
 
If you want to do something else or want to broaden your horizon you need to say so in your monthly meeting. 

You are allowed to listen to music while processing claims, its amazing.
cons:
For someone that isn't willing to speak-up you will have a hard time. 

There really isn't a lot of help after training.  YOU need to rely on YOU.  This actual wasn't a problem for me however if you have people NOT willing to go ahead and put forth the effort and they WANT their hand held it will really be and issue for you.

pros: The pay is good but for what is asked for is not worth it. It's too much to ask. People leave and that's why United is always hiring.
cons:
The training is performed by same employee that trains UnitedHealth Outsource in India. Trainer would eat  while answering training questions and brag that there was no cameras on the training room. It's not a hands on training and it doesn't prepare you for the job. They don't offer shadowing with a coworker for a few days. They put you to answer phone calls right after a mediocre training. 
 It's an insurance for international students. Some employees seemed depressed with the demands of the job. Some customers  despair on the phone knowing their insurance doesn't always cover certain ER visits, etc and You can not show any empathy.  On the other side the insurance United offers their employees is not great either and you don't have sick days. You need to schedule for sick days, if not it's a occurrence, being repeated a few times can lead to termination. You also have work feedback twice a week. You have a score to reach.They listen to your calls and depending on what you did wrong you can lose more than 20 points per category.  They also have a new implement to avoid "customer Effort", which means they don't want us to put customer on hold while reading policies to get the right information. There are more than a hundred policies and sometimes you may average 70-100 calls on busy enrollment season. No Cell phones are allowed only on break rooms. There is no H.R on site at Student Resources in Plano,TX.

pros: Work from home after 6-9 months
cons: Almost everything else. Medical benefits are nauseatingly expensive,  bonus/raise is completely unfair! You can literally exceed expectations in every area but have one area that is average and lose all advancement opportunity. Nurses, pharmacy and crisis line are the only ones working evenings, nights, weekends and holidays but they took away being able to stack our pay (adding night AND weekend differential for example) for “equality across departments”. For some nurses this was their car note or hundreds & hundreds per month!! Their expectation of working hours isn’t equal to ours so these departments earned that benefit. I’ve never taken a pay cut as an RN

review_title: If you have another option, take it.  Otherwise start here and continue to look for other employment
pros: Some ability to work from home.  Pay to start is close or above the competition.  Office location in Houston for Community and State provides security, which is needed for the location
cons: Where do I start, it is the leadership.  There is a new cultural program being rolled out which sounds great on paper, however the executive leadership based in the Houston office from the top down do not practice the model.  They are rude to staff at all levels if they talk to them at all.  A good act is put on when Corp staff visit and we are all told to make sure we "look happy and satisfied"   People are discouraged to share ideas for improvement.  Staff is harassed to take the satisfaction survey and give money to a charity that finally they give in and do it.  Having a large response rate does not mean that staff are "engaged"

review_title: Just A Number, the epitomy of the uncaring Healthcare company you read about in the media
pros: Telecommuting is encouraged here, salary is competitive, advancement is possible if you survive the on going layoffs across the organization that come annually.  Lots of resources to get things done.  Good company to add to your resume.
cons: Tremendous organization, very segmented and hard to find people outside your division if you need to move across product lines.   You will only know the people in your area, very little interaction other-wise.  Corporate culture is very cold - comprised of former consultants and MBA's that take great pride in showing how smart they are.  No acknowledgement of life outside of UHC at all - not even a Merry Christmas to anyone before the holiday, its all about the business and only the business, alot of kissing up to the boss and tattling about others to get ahead.  They also love restructuring the management to put people with no product experience in that division to bring a new vision - which is just scary.  Imagine working for someone that doesn't understand the business - this causes unrealistic expectation levels when it comes to goal setting and business objectives.  Yes, the corporate culture here is very strange indeed.  I know many who have passed through here, if you make it past 2 years without getting job eliminated, consider yourself lucky!

review_title: Great benefits in terms of 401k match and stock purchase plan.  Very poor boss/ manager.  Very good to military/veterans

review_title: Connextions is the best place to gain knowledge in the health insurance industry.
job_title: Licensed Health Agent in Centennial, CO
pros: The company will do their best to help you earn a license as a health insurance producer.  Even though you fail one time they will keep coaching you until you pass.  If you can't understand something you will get more coaching vs. the company giving up on you.   Some of the insurance teams like United HealthCare will have pizza days.  After, their whole team eats their pizza they will share the left overs with the rest.  There is free coffee, hot chocolate, and tea provided in the break room.  Employees enjoy having potlucks on special holidays like Halloween.
cons: Sometimes items can be missing from your desk.  QA can give you an auto fail when you have made a mistake.  Some agents get the correct scripting handed to them while other agents do not.  This makes it difficult to get a 100% on quality.  When I arrive to work sometimes there is an agent already at my desk.  This makes it difficult to punch in.  Although it can be corrected, my timecard can come out incorrect.  It seems like only the favorites get the schedule they want.

review_title: Nurseline Health Care Decision Support Nurse
pros: Work from home, pay, yearly bonus. Loved my direct managers but senior managers did not seem to care. Learned a ton about technology that helped me in my personal life and due to what I learned professionally I believe that I am living a healthier life.
cons: Cut backs on bonuses from four times a year to once a year. Less then 2% pay increase. Continuous change in processes so hard to keep up with all of the changes. Metrics related to quality audits are objective re based on who is doing the audit. My measurable computer based metrics based on concrete items almost perfect but those related to the objective quality audits done by human very low.  Stress level very high. My average pulse down 10 beats per minute since I resigned. Changes made to initial  hiring contract agreement made with out discussion. When I resigned due to their breaking the hiring contract with me, no one seemed to care or tried to get me to stay although I was told there where big plans for me. They were given a heads up months in advance of my resignation.

pros: This job is very life-changing. The pay is more than reasonable for the job that you do. You get 18 paid vacation days, in addition to that you get eight paid holidays as long as you work the day before and the day after. Also you have the option to work from home. It's a wonderful place to start a career there is opportunity to move up if you work really hard. When the pandemic hit everybody that was employed here had a job the entire time. Talk about job security! Also they train you for six months and you have a ton a strong support the entire time you're training. The people that you work with want you to succeed. I am so blessed to be a part of UnitedHealthcare!
cons: Because this is a metric driven company it can be frustrating to stay perfectly in adherence. Sometimes it's frustrating because I have to go to the bathroom so I have to hold it until lunch or break and sometimes I can't wait that long.

job_title: Pharmacy Tech in Overland Park, KS
pros: Good medical benefits, 401K, decent hours. Great co-workers (for the most part). Free coffee, tea, hot chocolate. Free parking.
cons: Very poor middle management. Most Leads & Supervisors show blatant favoritism, if you are not a snitch you will be regarded as not being a team player or loyal. Supervisor asks what other associates are saying. PTO stands for Planned Time Off not Personal Time Off, you have to plan on being sick. No chance for advancement. Almost impossible to transfer from Fulfillment to Customer Service side. Outside hires are paid more than transfers (if you can get one). Middle management talks about associates in front of other associates.  Low pay and high turnover, have watched a dozen people quit in the past 2 months, mostly for the way they were treated. Poor raises, know people who have been there over 5 years and they are only making a dollar more than those that started less than a year ago. I could go on and on....

review_title: Ok, If you're not the primary bread winner
pros: Great co-workers, solid management, great work-life balance, good telecommuting and work from home policy.  If you can get benefits from your spouse / partner and can handle not making the market salary, then it's a good place.  Very good work-life balance and very accommodating for your personal needs.
cons: Low pay scales, Poor Medical coverage - only United plans are available and only high-deductible plans.  For anything not considered 'preventative', you have to pay 100% out of pocket until you reach your deductible.  The lowest deductible option is around $2,000.  This is the first place I've worked where I had to think twice before taking my kids to the doctor when they're sick.  It's insulting that they don't discount their own services to their employees.

review_title: UHC in Roanoke, VA is horrible place to work
job_title: Producer Help Desk/Medicare & Retirement in Roanoke, VA
pros: Nice lunch cafe.  This company makes me wish glassdoor had a "zero" or blank star on the rating scale!!
cons: Upper management is a very small minded, unprofessional little "crew".  If they like you, then you're safe.  But if they don't care for you personally, it doesn't matter about your stats, adherence or anything else job related, they're going to terminate your employment for absolutely no reason at all.  This is an ongoing practice and its pathetic.  i can attest to the fact that this Roanoke, Virginia, contact center is a detriment to the United Healthcare company.  This particular company site DOES NOT adhere to the core values of the company at all.  I am not a disgruntled employee; as I was a contractual employee that did  a phenomenal job (according to customers/fellow co-wkrs).  This was not a career move for me, however, I did plan to fulfill my end of the contractual agreement.  But again, Roanoke, Virginia UHC contact center is NOT focused on professionalism and the work.  The broken, lazy, petty upper management would rather focus on your personal life and whether they "like" you as a BFF.  Never encountered such an infantile management  crew in my entire professional career.

pros:
Worked with some of the top-notch nurses in the industry.
Lucky to have had a few good clinical managers.
cons:
Free OT for them you pay the price for the privilege of trying to reach their unobtainable metrics
Heavy-handed leadership-without clarity long after changes are made
Provide clearer tools/resources for better job performance (refer to the job aid) does not provide clarity
You may make a little above the market salary but they get it back with the high cost of of healthcare benefits that's a wash.
Be realistic with the caseload the more you give the heavier the load the higher the number of cases of breakdown (physically, mentally and emotionally)- higher more people.

review_title: Need to spend more time on training
pros: Good work/life balance and flexibility with schedule.  Decent pay starting.
cons:
Need to provide more time with training to match what is involved with real claims once you are on the floor.  So many complex claims situations that don't get explained in the class room setting.  Some claims are ridiculous and even when you get help from those who are supposed to know what they are doing, it can take over 30 minutes for one claim.  The expectations for quantity are ridiculous.  Luck of the draw basically.  

Not enough support provided once you are on the floor.  I could have made it if I had been provided more support and help when I asked instead of being told there wasn't enough time available with having to meet "quota."  Instead I guess it is easier to hire new workers than invest the time in the ones they have.   Constant turn around it seems.  Always hiring with new classes.  Out of 10 I believe 2-3 were left in my class.  They care more about quantity than quality as well by some of the things suggested.  I had 100% quality, but wasn't going to forgo it to reach quantity as suggested by some...  I was at about 85% ramp quantity when I was axed.

review_title: You're Just A Butt In A Seat!
job_title: Licensed Health Agent in Concord, NC
pros: Pay for licensed agent is $15/hr + commission
cons: Commission is very low compared to what they make off each application; ABSOLUTELY NOT FAMILY FRIENDLY & NO WORK/LIFE BALANCE! You are a number & a butt in a seat to the company. Nothing outside of their company matters to management. The turnover rate is EXTREME!! Now I know why.... I worked there for almost 4 years, always exceeded my metrics & goals, had great attendance & went above and beyond to help my customers. My son had a seizure and was hospitalized for 3 days. I followed all callout protocol, even emailed my supervisor several times a day with updates on my son's condition. I can back to work with doctor & hospital documentation to find that my system access had been revoked. I was walked to HR by my supervisor and let go because I missed 3 days of work and the last time I missed a day of work was 2 days short of a year prior. I was told that absences were kept on file for a rolling year and the 3 days immediately led to termination and that no verbal or written warnings were required to be given as primary or secondary actions before a final or termination. I've even witnessed a young woman go into labor and management told her that if she leaves, she will no longer have a job. I would never recommend working for such a company that cares nothing about their employees like Optum.

review_title: Trust Me, Always Have a Backup Plan!
job_title: Medicare and Retirment Advocate in Miami, FL
pros: Company promotes internally. Most people have started their careers with UnitedHealth at the lowest level (customer service rep). You are almost guaranteed opportunities to advance to a new department/corporate after the 1 year mark, if you have been good at your position.
cons: If you dress very sophisticated or come from a higher level of education than most, you will not fit in (as with most places with entry level requirements). Supervisors and management may dislike you because of this and keep a close eye until you mess up. Managements turns their head at employees that break policy, but when you do the same (even just once) you may be fired without prior warning and your personal belongings are picked up by security in a box and brought to you. Consequently, you are escorted out as though you never worked for the company.

review_title: Couldn't ask for a better place to work!
pros: Great opportunity to reach your goals if you work towards them. I've been here 5 years and just received a promotion to supervisor because I set goals and kept pushing towards where I am now. Amazing benefits, medical, dental, vision, 401k, and much more. Every supervisor I've ever had has pushed me to be the best I can be whereas other companies supervisors simply don't care. This job is very rewarding if you do what you're supposed to do and you work hard at it. Working from home is also awesome! I've been a telecommuter for 3 years and HR cares so much about its employees they bought me a new chair because I have back problems and couldn't afford a good one. I couldn't ask for a better career or more compassionate leadership. Proud to be an employee here!
cons: I wish there were more options for medical benefits, I would be willing to pay more in premiums for a plan that had copays rather than deductible. This isn't a huge problem for me though because the plans are affordable with the option for a FSA or HSA. I wouldn't take any stars off for this, the benefits are great for the most part!

pros:
Pros, i can't think of any here. 
You can work from home.
cons:
1. Absolutely No work Life Balance, these guys in the projects needs constant overlap with teams in US so you have to be on call in nights. They say you start late but they will put meetings in Morning and say you can take it from Home.
2. Variable Pay, you wont get your variable pay on that cycle, if you joined company after 20th Sep. So they will gulp your 5 months' variable pay. Also variable pay is never given more than 80% here, neither they will pay your arrier.
3. Dull people, absolutely dull people with no enthusiasm everyone is dead here.
4. Car Parking, they wont give you car parking if you are anyone less than Grade 29, so you can't even drive to office if you want park 1km away from office and pay 20rs per hour.
5. Outdated Technologies, the technologies used are from 2004.
6. Average age of people in this company is 40. I am having 8years of experience and I feel like a fresher here.
7. Notice period, ridiculous notice period of 90days. Seriously they call this a product based organisation.

This is my first review on Glassdoor.  And Optum is my 4th Company. I would like to tell you only join this company if you love absolutely nothing about your current job, because you will regret in every possible way after joining this company. Don't trust me if coming to give an interview have a look at yourself.

Company makes many many promises but they do not follow through. They treat you like your work is meaningless.  But give pep talks with empty promises. When asked about pay they always said. Company does not value diversity honestly or integrity, that is something that is said for looks. Highly unethical . There is no room for growth. review_title: Optum - Change for the Sake of Change
pros: Excellent salary and schedule flexibility.  IT department is very helpful and this is a good thing because if you are not office based you will be left to figure things out by yourself.
cons:
Company is too large and communications are very poor within the organization. The company has more than 1 EMR system.   Optum clinical services (a large subdivision under United) utilizes at least 4 maybe even 5 EMR systems alone, and none of them interface with each other so company divisions cannot communicate with each other.   

If you like change for the sake of change itself then this company is for you.  New programs are developed rapidly without a proper roll out to the markets it was designed to serve nor explanation to clinicians.  This leads to frustration and chaos.  

New employee orientation is virtually non existent.  Support from upper management is questionable.  

Medical benefits come with high deductibles and a lot of out of pocket costs.  This is surprising for a health insurance company.

pros: I heard it’s an amazing company. I have two family members who work for United for over 10 Years. Unfortunately not much on the Pros
cons: It’s was a total of 4 people who interviewed me, coming from a management role that is not a good strategy. I felt look down upon and judged from the moment I walked into the office. I was super excited about getting called for the interview and immediately felt out of place when speaking with these individuals. They didn’t want to shake my hand, I sat down and was asked if I had a copy of my resume I advised I did. One of the young ladies then asked me to slide it over to her as if she didn’t want to grad it from me. The interview started and it was very dry, they came off uninterested and never probed to want to know more. The interview took about 5 minutes and I was told the interview was done. I knew the moment I walked in the office with these individuals that I didn’t get the job! With 10 years customers service, senior quality and EMT experience. Very saddened at how I felt leaving that interview.

review_title: A great company to work for
pros: Lots of opportunities, Great work environment and Culture

pros: you'll get to learn many technologies and expand your skill set
cons: sometimes late night and weekend works

pros: I had some excellent colleagues!
cons: Culture of fear. No work/life balance. I worked consistently more than 60 hours per week, with my record hours worked having been more than 80 in one week. Raises are minimal (1-3%) even though profits are sky-high. My director's primary objective was protecting herself/her job and she cowered under the guise of being a Culture Ambassador. I worked for seven years and my first five were okay (due to my talented, collaborative team) until a forced reorg merged my little unit into a large cross-corporate unit, so I switched segments. The segment I joined was horrible and my incompetent, bullying new manager lost four skilled, committed employees in her first few months. Seeing I was her next target after having witnessed her abuse of my teammates, I went to HR because of the documented "non-retaliation" policy. UnitedHealthcare touts a non-retaliation policy but that does NOT PREVENT retaliation. HR is not there for the employees. My happiest day was walking out that door for the last time. And don't worry, there are many good, upstanding companies out there! UnitedHealthcare is known in the industry as The Evil Empire for good reason. They are headquartered in MN but can't sell insurance here, because they are a FOR PROFIT company. For profit and health care do not mix.

pros: They pay well and also eventually they will give you the things you need to be successful so i guess there is a silver lining.
cons: They are very unprofessional , I amongst many others have some horror stories about the hiring process they will not send you the drug test or the background check through your email like they tell you they are going too after days of waiting you still will not receive it  so make sure you call and tell them you need it i waited nearly a month for it and had to reschedule my orientation . They will also  tell you a day to come to attend the orientation and then with a mistake on their behalf you will be  escorted out by security like you are a criminal. Also once you are finally able to attend training they are very UN-organized so anticipate that you will be sitting in a training class for 2 weeks or more with no access to the training materials so you will be UN prepared for the mid term or the final that is given too you . Also keep in mind that you have to stay on top of your trainers if you want access some will go to bat for you but others will not

review_title: One of the worst jobs I have ever had.  Inefficient processes, information is all over the place, disorganized.
pros: work from home, decent paid time off, competitive salary, tons of job openings (good luck getting one though if you are trying to move to a different area.  i.e. customer service to claims)
cons: terrible health benefits if you live in certain states.  no work/life balance.  hard to move to a different position.  always changing processes.  the big thing now is to be compassionate towards members, but if the company offered better plans and paid/handled claims correctly in the first place we wouldn't have to feel bad for the members. This is so backwards to me.  Also you have to offer "health education" for diseases you can't pronounce and read off a sheet and hope to god the member doesn't ask you a clinical question. Mandatory overtime that goes on for months.

job_title: Clinical Administrative Coordinator in Austin, TX
pros: Work from home..... that's about it.
cons:
Projects itself as a caring, compassionate employer who is all about team work and growing their employees to higher positions.  They like to project an imagine of one big happy family where everybody gets along and helps each other out when needed.  The reality is very different. 

Sure they are all about teamwork....so long as you don't point out any problems.  If you do, your concerns will be ignored or you will get your hand slapped for not being a team player. 

Sure they are all about balance, unless you get sick and need to take time off.  Then no matter how good your attendance has been through the year, if its your 3rd unexcused absence, for any reason, you are subject to disciplinary action.  

Sure they are all about promoting from within so long as you develop the talent of sucking up to the right people and learning the art of stabbing your fellow employees in the back while appearing to be a team player. 

At the end of the day, you are just a piece of furniture to be moved around at will and kicked to the curb when they no longer have any use for you. 

If you have any other choices, take them.  This place will work you to death while sucking the life out of you.

The benefits are decent, there are lots of opportubities should you qualify, like help quitting smoking, maternity support, etc and the 401k is comparable to other places I've worked though I did start with as much pto as it took me to get after 5yrs at my old job.
cons: They're now in the process of implementing so many micromanaging programs and proceedures the management team doesn't have time to actually answer qestions we need to have to do our jobs properly. Theyve also taken away much of the flexibility options we had within our schedule like the option to work 4 10 hour days or 4 9s and a 6 and unfortunately they did not go about announcing these changes well at all. If you don't fit inside the little box of standard employee and go out of your way to, well... Suck up you're going to have a hard time getting a raise  as they will tell you at every yearly review they are a pay for performance company.

review_title: UHG only cares about what it looks like to the outside world and doesn't care about its employees
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Kingston, NY
pros: You get a steady paycheck, and the hours are nice, no weekends or holidays unless overtime is offered, which isn't too often in customer service dept. Pay is decent for the area, and a nice amount of time off.
cons: The company is so worried about how it looks to the outside world, and less concerned with its employees. They add awkward scripting to make reps seem "more compassionate".  They keep piling on work without very little increases in pay. They make the bonus more and more difficult to get. Make it more difficult to do our job by making us do all this extra work w/o proper systems or working systems. They do a yealy survey about the company and make all these changes to make the employees see oh ok this is good then as soon as the survey is over they take those changes away. Has happened the last couple of years. This year they did poorly on one about being proud to work for their company, so instead of finding out why the people are not, they are having people in meetings say why they are proud and if they can't come up with something they are to make something up. They offer more training on being compassionate than learning about our specific job function.

review_title: Pros used to outweigh the Cons, and now the Cons are just too big
pros: As many people have said, you will find some of the smartest, hardest working people at United.  The pace is intense, frantic, and urgent at all times.  The variety of jobs available, due to the size of United, is really great.  I think there is great opportunity for people from supervisors through directors.  Also, the company is doing well from a market perspective.  I was also very satisfied with financial rewards for high performers. I was United's biggest champion for more than 10 years.
cons: Above the director level, it is an old boys club. More concerning, over the past few years, I saw a culture of people being afraid to speak the truth to authority figures.  At higher levels, people are now operating out of fear and self protection.  United also has a strategy of pitting departments and companies against each other in competitions to try to get the best performance.  I guess this isn't a con if you like that sort of thing.  While it might work in the end result, it is really frustrating and inefficient if you're trying to get your job done.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: The pay is decent.  That's about it.
cons:
Training was 11 weeks of disorganized nonsense!  There were many instances in which we literally sat around and did nothing for hours on end!  Calls to the help desk would range from 30 minutes to an hour or possibly longer,  so if one associate had to make the dreaded call to help desk then the entire class would have to wait for the call to end.   Training was a bad experience to say the least.  

This company has a casual dress code so you can pretty much wear jeans everyday.   Unfortunately some of the associates in the building take it a bit too far.   There were times when I thought a prostitute was walking towards the building,  only to find out it was an employee.  The environment itself, on the actual floor,  has a very "ghetto" feel to it.   You look around and a lot of the female employees look as if they are going to a bar or club with the way they dress.  

There were many instances in which I said hello or good morning to many of the seasoned associates only to be either ignored or given a dirty look.   Yes you guessed right,  it was mainly the "ghetto trash" employees that were very rude!   

I tell everyone I know not to EVER consider employment here!

pros: They offered free coffee.... that's really the best thing I can say.
cons:
I really should have listened when everyone told me not to take the job there. I can't speak for all offices around the country, but the office in my city has a reputation for an exceptionally high turnover rate, unclean offices, bad management and overall miserable conditions. 
I thought that since the job I was taking wasn't in the call center, that this wouldn't be the case for me. 
The office was a mess. Leaking roof in several places, stains on the carpet (these can be controlled by building maintenance). However, the bathrooms were the worst part. I know that management and office maintenance can't control what people do in the restroom, but when feces are found on the walls or the toilet seat at least once a week in the ladies' room, that speaks volumes about the type of people that the company is hiring. 
The co-workers were rude. There was no advancement opportunity. The building is in an awkward place that is difficult to maneuver in and out of. 
The division manager came to the office to do an open enrollment season kickoff and proceeded to shamelessly and ruthlessly make fun of southern people (words, accents, foods, etc... even questioned every southerner's intelligence).
Overall, I look back on this experience with regret.

pros: It is a nice place to work
cons: I do not see any disadvantages

review_title: Full time position with benefits, but not very stable.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: It's full time with ok benefits, training varies per account, but Connextions is a third party so it's not always the best. You get the feeling that it's not even close to what it would be if you actually worked for the client. Sometimes it's a laid back environment but it can change very suddenly. If you're in health insurance then it's probably best to think of it as seasonal. They do offer a chance to earn your 215 insurance license, sometimes just your health though. It's free, which is by far one of the best aspects of this company.
cons: I believe a lot of the coaches do care, but you also get the impression that you're just a number. It can be a very rigid structure, with adherence strictly monitored, but that may be the same for all call centers. Once you hit the slow season, past performance can become very important when it had previously been a very laid back place to work, and quite a number of people can get the ax. Accounts can also close very suddenly if the clients do not choose to renew their contract with Connextions, and the higher ups are told to keep it a secret.

pros: Flexible, they are big on work at home. Decent pay. Stable if you do your job and do not play around.
cons: No unity, the staff will try to bring you down if you let them. Every man is on their own. Do not get too relaxed with staff members. If your new my advice would to be as low key as possible, do not be too nice. Be respectful but not overly friendly because that can backlash on you. Been with the company for a while and seen a lot of people come and go, best advice lay low and be strong and you'll survive. The key to getting ahead in this company is nepotism. About 95% of the individuals that ahead that way internally. Without nepotism the likelihood of getting ahead is very slim even if you have the educational background and experience.

review_title: Very Bad place to work for BPO job seekers. Politics are everywhere, here it's very much. Beautiful girls have Luck...
pros:
Heard...software employees are enjoying the work life than BPO's.
when UHG payroll changed to Optum everything has changed.
cons:
*Were use to have 7 seater cab home pick and home drop- Now 12 seater with semi AC or No Ac and cheap vehicle. No company provides such transport.
Company has decreased it's budget in terms of spendings on employees very much.
*8 and 30 mins shift plus 1 hour break. 30 mins extra.
*Salary definitely not up to  the market standards .
*Should beg and furnish documents for leaves. was good when it was UHG
Tooooooooomuch work pressure. 
*it's a health care industry and it won't let you take rest when you are sick (No leaves)

review_title: The Grass is Greener outside of UHG
pros: UHG has some good benefits (Medical, Dental, Vision, 401k, Stock purchase).  Time off grant is good.  Benefits start the first of the month after start.  Ability to promote from within.
cons: UHG is not where you go to have a career.  It's where you go to get experience then leave before you get complacent.  Organization is constantly about cutting costs however and where-ever they can.  Key planning areas have insufficient staff to be effective and time constraints that are always cut to exact moment.   If one thing doesn't go as planned then everything is in chaos and poorly executed.  Work/Home balance is a joke, except for execs who take time when they like but communicate to their reports that "they can't take time as it's too busy".    Lay-off' or displacement is a common occurrence.   Too many are supervising teams that they aren't equipped to lead and their leadership support is many times fragmented to the point of just being a name on an org chart, rather than a actual leader.

review_title: An enormous Corporation with all the good and bad that you would expect.
pros: There are a ton of possible career paths with UnitedHealth Group, something for everyone. You will find a great pool of experienced and professional leaders within every section of the company. The office settings tend to be easygoing but very busy. If you are interested in a leadership role be prepared to take on multiple projects with high quality demands, after all they are successful for a reason.
cons: Compensation is very poor especially when you look at the revenue that UHG generates. Oddly enough for a leader in the Health Insurance world the health coverage that they offer is very poor with huge deductibles especially for anyone in a leadership role. While the company "drinks its own cool-aid" and talks about it's new culture all of the time, it often feels like a white wash to cover over the ugly parts. Recently they have "off shored" a lot of positions that have resulted in lay offs.

review_title: Axolotl morphed into a Godzilla under UHG
job_title: Senior Technical Support in San Jose, CA
pros: The pay was pretty good, comp time was also good. I learned a lot about health care business in a short time.
cons:
Axolotl was small software company that was bought by UHG in order to convert their customers into users of their other software offerings. We saw rapid growth, then stagnation. During the first couple years there were constant crisis with the data center being down or other emergencies. We also saw a succession of managers, all with different  ideas of how the business should be run. By the time UHG committed the necessary money and  resources to stabilize the company, many of the key players had left.

UHG cut costs in big and small ways, such as getting rid of free snacks and putting in vending machines. (They eventually relented on the snacks.) They also provided costly healthy insurance and got rid of the local HR director. (They now use the self-service model.)

review_title: Total Chaos with no management structure
job_title: Member Services Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Not much positive considering it's a call center!
cons: Employees are encouraged to SELL SELL SELL when it comes to OptumRx, specifically when it comes to the Medicare D department.  Regardless of an individuals income, employees are encouraged to convince senior citizens to take advantage of automatic refills through mail service as opposed to retail pharmacy.  Bonuses are given to those that are successful in this goal, however, many employees fraudulently enroll members in the mail service program for this bonus.  Furthermore, key individuals in positions to mentor new employees partake in unprofessional behaviors such as gossiping.  Management, specifically mine, was at work for 2 weeks and I never saw her again (but she was still employed).  Several instances occurred in which I needed assistance and when she was there, she couldn't answer the question or help resolve the issue.  Employees are not encouraged to educate members on programs within care management for members with chronic diseases.  The office in Jacksonville is strictly about accomplishing goals to look good for United, but not truly providing in the most efficient manner for it's members.

pros:
401k,  pto days, "my" schedule is flexible, work from home lots of info to learn,
Glad to have a job
cons:
VERY difficult to move up unless you are a nurse or are in a specialized field, I.e. IT,  certitude coder etc
Seems they are not big on training you to do another position, if you apply for a position that you are qualified to do but lack some experience with doing the position, you are not a candidate for the job.  Now let me be clear, there are some instances where this would be true for any position.  I'm speaking of positions that your skill set matches perfectly, but missing, maybe, a platform you had not actually worked in.  A computer program,  you can be trained on.   just as you were trained on the other 5 platforms you operate in.  Crazy.
Request employee transparency but it is not genuine.
Often times, implement a program that the employees know will not work but mgmt has rose colored glasses on
Metrics and numbers   Quntitifying your daily work.
