pros: The benefits are great! Your co-workers are willing to help. You do get to help members which is the entire point. The company does great with promotion within as long as you fit the mold.The compensation is what keeps most of the staff not the work or the environment. The constant changing keeps you on your toes. The amount of caring from co-workers is amazing !
cons: The upper management is not very receptive. I came in thinking everything was fair however that has since changed. Everything is based off of the impression you make on your manager not your work. Normally, when you hear overtime you don't think it will be 10 hour days and 50 hour weeks that make the weekend seem pointless. The work life balance is only achievable if you have a 8-5 work schedule. Of course you have those nasty members who can't be satisfied. Although there is promotions within once you are in a department you are only going to move up within the likely hood of moving to another department is sadly rare. If you are quiet and keep to yourself you will not move up. You have to be in everybody face and an attention seeker in order to move up or at least your managers favorite.

review_title: A Decent Place To Work That, With Some Critical Improvements, Could Be A Great Company
job_title: Project Manager in Santa Ana, CA
pros:
-Part of UHG, with access to lots of resources.  If you need specific software or hardware or support, you just have to get the appropriate approvals and wait a few weeks... but you'll get what you need.
-Huge network of 80,000+ people
-Hundreds of open jobs to make a lateral or upward move to
-Fortune 50 company
-23 days of paid time off per year for most positions.  That does include all sick time, however.
cons:
-Lots of red tape
-Not enough communication at the appropriate level.  Everything is at a very high level
-Working extremely hard will rarely get you more than a pat on the back, if that
-Some employees are actively disengaged as a result of senior management turnover
-For an insurance company, you would think their benefits would be better, but they are about average or below (especially vision coverage)

review_title: If you have the right supervisor, it can be a great experience. My first year was hell. The last two were great.
job_title: Billing Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: The break room is amazing. The cafeteria is expensive but very good. The Starbucks downstairs isn't always true to Starbucks quality but you can swipe your badge to pay in a pinch. There are "decompression rooms" with rocking chairs for when you need a good cry and mothers rooms for nursing moms.
cons: The pay is not competitive. Although it is a health insurance company, employees face high insurance costs. Management does not communicate well and often expects employees to drop what they are doing for urgent projects, without giving extra leeway for existing deadlines. The availability of staff is simply not enough to meet the demanding workload.  Accuracy requirements are admirable but not always feasible when employees have to rush through in order to meet ever tightening deadlines.  They say quality over quantity but this is the opposite of what is demanded. Supervisors are often stressed out, impatient, unclear and demanding.

job_title: Sales Development Program in Minnetonka, MN
pros: It is a good company and benefits
cons: Poor pay overall and you are basically a customer service agent taking calls

pros: Good Benefits , salary, laid back environment
cons: No one cares about your ideas or want to improve the process

pros: Great benefits, friends, managers, salary and time off
cons: Customers can sometimes be difficult

review_title: Unbelievable workload, extremely smart people, somewhat brutal performance culture
pros: You can learn more here in a year than in 10 years spent elsewhere.  It is very fast paced and the people at all levels are extremely bright.  You will definitely develop yourself.  If you don't, you will be left behind.  UHG is extremely innovative for a large company and is willing to spend money to do things right if you have a business case that makes sense.  Very metrics focused Company, if you are analytical you will do well.
cons:
The health benefits are appalling.  Basically the cost is shifted entirely onto you.  I have a dependent who has a chronic condition and we paid $1,000s out of pocket for prescriptions each year.  Fortunately, the rest of my family is healthy.  It seems pretty immoral.  Management claims that they are providing incentives for people to lead healthier lives.  The reality is they are restricting access through cost shifting.  

They have a cost cutting culture that doesn't always make sense.  People are laid off and then rehired.  

The workload is unrelenting.  It doesn't compare on any level with anywhere else I have ever worked.

pros:
-  Good, financially stable company.
-  When people ask where you work, they've heard of UHC so you don't have to explain it.
-  Salary is decent.
cons:
-  Leadership in UHC Community and State is just awful.  Horrid.  It's the epitome of a "good ol' boy network."  A bunch of arrogant suits making decisions without knowing what's really going on.
-  The Chief Marketing Officer is ruthless, condescending and one of the most despicable people I've ever had to work for or even be around.  He had this reputation in Minneapolis long before they hired him.  Nice vetting process.
-  Senior Leadership have degrees from University of Chicago, Oxford, Berkeley...but don't let that fool you.  They believe that they are the only smart ones in the company and ignore others' input, making them as stupid as a community college night school dropout.
-  They say it's about "helping people live healthier lives".  In all of the leadership meetings I attended, it wasn't ever about healthier people...it was about "less costly people."  It's about the bottom line.
-  Unless you work in Minnetonka, you aren't taken seriously.

pros: There was a cafeteria on campus, but I never used it.
cons:
The training is really bad, and the job is impossible. You have to process  a large amount of claims using systems that are very difficult to navigate. 

The amount of work to just solve one claim is mind boggling. I'd sometimes spend twenty minutes on a claim and still have no idea what to do. The written procedures made no sense. Sometimes the instructor and trainers had no clue what to do either. I'm not joking. Yet, the company expected you to fly through these claims with near zero errors. As the class progressed, it became harder to get questions answered. Soon it came to a point where almost everyone was struggling, they had no clue what they were doing, and the trainers were too overwhelmed with questions to provide timely responses. 

The crazy thing is you only spend a small amount of time processing claims in the training. The rest of the time was spent learning about things that didn't matter or listening to the trainer tell stories/tell jokes. So by the time training was winding down,we were in no way prepared for the floor.

This job made me extremely stressed. Eventually, I just gave up and realized I wasn't gonna last. I didn't want to get the point where I'd get fired though. I quit before the training ended.

pros:
Pay check arrives on time
Holidays and weekends off
cons:
Nothing written here will ever be seen let alone somwthing done about it. Optum preaches how they value their employees and patient's. Yet they ONLY care about their higher revenue patient's (core services). They do t care about Makena patient's. They don't care that intake nurses do the bare minimum during a patient intake. Putting the field nurse and patient at risk because a full thorough history hasn't been completed. Management is mircomangaing. I shouldn't have to let multiple people know when I have to use the restroom. Management has no clue what they're doing, let alone what you are supposed to do, so it changes almost daily. Harassment of patient's by making way too many calls to patient AND all alternate contact numbers/emergency contacts within a short time period. Upper management only cares about metrics that are rigged daily to make the reports look good and seem that things are working smoothly, which in reality the new "process" is NOT working and upper management has too much pride to say it's failed. HCD's are left to do everything administrative that they have no idea how to do and definitely not enough time to do it. 

There is absolutely NO room for advancement. When you're over qualified and have proved it in previous roles, you get stuck answering the phone. No raises. Pay is NOT competitive for the same administrative roles with other companies.

pros: The company is very impressive.   You will learn a lot.  They are very innovative and there is plenty of room to move within the company.  They have tons of telecommute roles.  And they have excellent technology and resources.  The Regional roles and National roles are great jobs; many are telecommuters (work from home).  Salaries coming in the door are on par with the industry.
cons: Network roles in the local markets (especially Network Contracting) have a HIGH turn-over due to the amount of stress.  But these are the proving grounds in my opinion ; if you can survive in that environment, you can survive anywhere in the healthcare administration arena.   So stressful... but you will learn a lot.

pros: Quick hiring process for certain departments, decent starting salaries, easy entry level opportunity for recent graduates.  Mostly regular business hours.  Ability to work from home in many departments.  Quarterly bonuses.  The work was easy for the most part, lots of computer based work.  They used to host a fun holiday party at a very nice venue.  They host phillies games and like things in the spring and summer, offering discounted tickets. Every Friday management used to order lunch.
cons: Apparently bonuses were cut recently (I have friends still working here).  There are no performance based raises, you have to obtain a higher paying position.  They replaced the good healthcare plan with a high deductible plan.  There are some evening and weekend hours in some departments.  A lot of favoritism in terms of promotions, though this is not uncommon. They did use temps and often hired them, but they would hire them for departments instead of internal employees who wanted to transfer to in order to avoid weekends and make more money.

review_title: Good job, some annoying aspects though
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Concord, NC
pros: Good pay bi weekly, starting at $11 per hour, pretty easy going job. Full time job Monday- Friday. Pay for performance once you are considered a full time employee after 5 months (If you do your job well, you get a bonus on your check once a month)
cons: You work full time hours but are not considered a real "full time employee" until about 5 months. So until those 5 months you do not get PTO, paid holidays, or benefits. Also if you are an employee with less than 5 months under your belt, if you work holidays, you will NOT receive holiday pay for the days that you work. There is also a schedule bid to where you have to bid on your desired schedule. 9/10 times you will not get your desired schedule and the company WILL NOT accommodate your schedule needs due to child care, school, and other events.

review_title: How can I put this nicely...(I can't)
pros:
I like the fact that in my location, w/ my degree - the pay is decent
I like that there are options that allow you to work from home
cons:
I've had two different jobs with two different departments while working for UnitedHealthcare. I think I can accurately describe the company after 5+ years of working for them. 

-Very Disorganized - It seems as if we work in silos in every department and this does us no good. No one knows/cares what the others are doing and quite often we are stuck duplicating work or working on projects meant for others to handle (which we find out after the fact).

-Work Life Balance - Yes we have the option to work from home and this was one of the highlights in my decision to take on a new role. However, I work for someone that has no regard for work life balance. Not everyone is like this but a LOT of managers that telecommute do NOT know when to disconnect. I'm talking scheduling meetings well into the evening, asking you to work overtime weekly, sending emails at 2 am. It's quite ridiculous and really counterproductive in many ways.

-Benefits - trash

-Holidays - typical 8 days

pros:
-Free snacks lunches every now and then 
-PTO 
-401K
-Double pay for holidays if you work them 
-Reasonable hours 
-Minimum phone time mainly faxes only upon hire 
-Paid inclement weather days
cons:
-Unorganized management
-External hiring for consideration of internal positions 
-Scary management will talk to the whole floor about an issue with you instead of coming to you directly and  respectfully. 
-Forced to learn about other departments without pay raise. 
-Call center pharmacy especially during peak times of year. December-March every year! Back to back phone calls you will have cotton mouth every now and then. 
-Short lunch breaks 30 mins to be exact 
-Minimum opportunity for growth unless you do everyone’s work and keep your numbers up as well, then they will consider you. 
-Complete Prior Auth in less than 6 mins or you make company look bad. Used to be 6:45 seconds. Now they want you to add different perks to phone call in less amount of time. Felt like an AT&T call center representative “Hi would you like to add WiFi with your authorization today?” 😂🙃 Not exactly what I signed up for.

cons: Large organization can be hard to navigate

review_title: If you can avoid looking at the "bigger picture" it's an okay place to work.
pros: It's a stable job. Good benefits. I feel like I'm paid well to do what I do. Regular hours (overtime is very rare; almost never have to work weekends). My team is terrific. Well qualified people who get along, treat each other with respect, and have a good time working. I've talked to a lot of people in the organization, and everyone seems to think the same thing: good people to work with, friendly environment. The caveat being that many of the people I work with are sweet, decent, friendly and courteous; but are totally incompetent at doing the job.
cons:
It's a tough place to work, if you have a soul. It's obvious that health care is a big huge deal in this country. The fact that it keeps going out of the price range of the average citizen. You see a lot of waste and greed at the company. Not to mention that there are people in sales and upper management that get a ton of ridiculous perks.
Communication from upper management to the great unwashed masses is often muddled, condescending, and loaded with double-speak.
And the honest, horrible, nitty gritty? Apparently, no one in the building knows how to flush a toilet.

review_title: Not the advertised "best" place to work
pros: If you are looking for a stable, consistent job that will has good benefits, UHG is a good place to work.  The work hours are typical of most large companies, and have well-defined job roles for those looking for a specific set of responsibilities.
cons: As a strategy, the company is outsourcing much of their IT and work offshore.  Due to the financial strains and uncertainty in the economy and in the health care industry, budgets have been severely slashed, and "new" technology work is not being performed.  Administrative overhead is frightfully high, with more time and effort spent on tracking and monitoring than actual work.  Budget is usually spent on fragmented, smaller projects, rather than utilizing a larger budget to accomplish a true solution...which increases the cost of operations and maintenance, instead of developing the solutions to avoid the fragmentation entirely.

pros:
Salaries are competitive, but if you choose to go to work there, negotiate your best starting price up front, as increases are small and increasing salary through promotion is difficult as there are a number obstacles to internal promotion and policies to minimize increases.   

The amount of paid time off is very competitive, but the culture of work overload can make it challenging to use it.
cons:
The CEO is a former Anderson Consultant (A la Enron) and is all numbers and no heart.   Management takes the cue from the top and treats employees accordingly:   resources to  be used and discarded when they become too run down to make the numbers.      

Their mission statement, "Helping people live healthier lives"  applies only to their healthy premium payers so they can continue to pay for "protection".   It does not apply to employees or those who have their insurance  "coverage" and get more than a little sick.   

Not unlike their Association,  America's Health Insurance Plans (AHIP) , that can put a legitimate face on paying lobbyists to hijack the reform process,  these scammers are able to make you think they are truly concerned and compliant partners in the process,  while behind the scenes,  they are no better than extortionists.

review_title: UHG the name says it all "UGGGGHHH"
job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Sometimes good work/life balance, work is modestly interesting, good people even some managers are very good, and some are really, really bad. The chances you will get a good or bad manager is about 50/50. UHG is basic employment at its best, do not cause waves, ask too many dumb questions and you will do fine. If you think you can change the way the company was run the last 10 years, by transforming it out of having too many complex forms and processes which do not apply to the current work environment for everything, then you will be disappointed.
cons: Too many poor managers who are protected because they are managers. Benefits are 3rd world, vacation is used for sick and personal time. At my position, I was high on the technical chain, I was treated the same as a commodity worker 3 or 4 bands beneath me. I was not told of work I should have done for 4 or months after the deadline.

job_title: RN Care Manager in Denver, CO
pros: Good benefits and pay.  Professional environment.  Being able to work from home was a big plus for me.  Helping people with health issues was somewhat rewarding.
cons: Difficulty engaging participants over the phone with questions that were too route and dry, and often repetitious.  Much of the work seemed like waste of time to the participants, as well as the nurses. Little opportunity to use real nursing judgment or skills.  Impersonal management style with little opportunity to provide meaningful feedback. Work highly sedentary in a company that is supposed to promote health.  Therefore, very UNHEALTHY working situation.  Complex and ever changing computer systems.  Very boring work.  Not challenging in any meaningful way.

review_title: Solid company with lots of professional potential
pros: I'm going on 18 years at UHG.  The benefits are good, I take part in the employee stock purchase option, I'm socking away as best I can into my 401k with employer matching, I got a college degree using the tuition reimbursement program, I take advantage of the Health Savings Account and the opportunities available to lower my premiums.  There is a a great deal of emphasis from the top down on values - knowing them, living them.  Volunteerism is encouraged, as are team building opportunities outside work (e.g., Polar Plunge, National Volunteering Day).  The CEO and his knights of the round table are committed to improving healthcare for everyone and finding ways to be proactive in getting people the healthcare they need.
cons: Like any other business, there are some bad apples.  I've had a couple of terrible managers (micro-managers, ego trippers).  Thankfully, there are a lot of directions to go once you're in the door and I was able to exit those teams where I was destined to quit or be brow-beaten to death.

pros: You will get paid on time and can gauge how think your skin is
cons:
This is the place where you will be treated like BOXER in Animal Farm. Once you join this company you will be on a steady march to the "Glue Factory". OPTUM want to you work ACCENTURE but will pay you like TATA. The company will attrition all your technical skills by making your work on their age old  systems from IBM MF Era, they will not help or suppport you to develop additional skills and haul you to the Glue Factory once they are done with you like a disposable tissue.  If that did not happen you will be OFFSHORED. If that did not happen you will be outsourced to a fresh young Millenial on a work visa from a vendor at the Eden in MN. If that did not happen you will be victimized by manager sof "The OLD BOYZ CLUB" who will ask you to do work - of their friends. If you Object your manager from will remind you , you are "working at his pleasure". During Performance review period manager will project that you did not do any work.  UHG HR will never support you. Very soon  on a fine Thursday you will be asked to meet with your manager and handed over a letter thanking you of Your services. The onlyculture is profit , profit .. more PROFIT "ONLY" for top Honchos ! 
better to stay away and build a career some place where you are treated as individual rather than a number.

job_title: Senior Provider Data Specialist in Lakewood, NJ
pros: Ample training provided and resources
cons: Overload of work, time management is imperative

job_title: Executive Director in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: Well consolidated multinational company, with good reputa
cons: Still undertanding how to operate in brazil

pros: Multi-national company with a lot of vision and focus on innovation and growing in leaps and bounds. I've been working for UHG for 18 years and never had a dull moment. Started as a receptionist and now I'm building networks. In between, I've worked in Quality, Operations, Marketing and Business Development. What I'm saying is, there is room for growth and knowledge expansion once you get your foot in the door.
cons: For an insurance company of its caliber, health insurance is expensive for employees. However, employees get rewarded (premium discounts) for taking action on improving their health and making wise decisions, such as losing weight or quit smoking. So, if you are a person who doesn't like to be advised on what to do to improve your health and wish to continue living with risky behaviors, expect to pay the high premiums and deductibles.

review_title: Clique-ish, limited support and limited help
pros: free parking, no weekend hours. Many peers are wonderful people to work with. That is about it.
cons:
Limited training. 
Poor and very old technology with frequent outages, errors and no updates. Some employees have not had a working computer for 6+ months and still get paid to do.... nothing. Literally.
Cliques dominate the work environment with many employees who getting ahead because they know someone or went to school with someone. 
Limited merit advancement, 
Limited delegation of responsibilities and job growth
Micromanagement for many employees while others walk around and play with their phone, put on makeup or browse the web.
Oftentimes, these employees who do "best" do so for say 200 calls a month while others take 600-700-800 calls.
You will not have time beyond 30 minutes a week to complete your commitments you set for members who have complex issues.
They took our cafeteria away and replaced it with high priced vending machines.
We are moving to facility downtown to "be closer to the airport" and therefore now have to park for $70/month.
Management is invisible, selectively reply to messages and will generally be not available.
Support staff close at 5 pm while the main center stays open to 7 or 8.  This includes behavioral health and pharmacy. 2 aspects of care that are vital.

pros:
I am a telecommuter. There are many benefits to working from the home. I love that UHG has this as an option. 
I enjoy my job. It has some rewards as I really like overall, such as my current team. I love that there are many people that have a lot of knowledge and work as hard I think I do. I think I am paid fairly for the work that I do.
cons: I think there are a lot of "leaders". There definitely seems to be a bulky middle-management at UHG. I find also that my Director says she has an open door policy but she will avoid you like the plague. She does not want to hear from someone so unimportant. And even though I am a current employee. Getting an interview is very hard. I am not talking about advancement, I am merely thinking about a lateral position...getting an interview is near impossible!

job_title: United Health Group in Washington, DC
pros: Good place to learn new tools, great co-workers
cons: Low benefits, hard to get promotion

job_title: Appeals and Grievance Coordinator in Orlando, FL
pros: The company cares about employees
cons: Takes a while to change positions

job_title: Software Development Engineer In Test (SDET) in Austin, TX
pros: Decent compensation for my experience
cons: Nameless drone among literally thousands of employees

job_title: Senior Information Security Engineer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: good salary and rewarding work. Great people.
cons: Didn't feel valued as an employee.

review_title: Overall, it was good, just not great
pros: The recruiters and managers genuinely want to make sure that you have a meaningful internship experience. They are willing to meet with you and adjust your type of work to accommodate your interests and skills. Team members are more than willing to help you. You can easily work from home without notice, and you have the freedom to set your own schedule as long as you attend meetings and work 40 hours sometime during the week. Paid housing for those who don't live in-town.
cons: While people who directly manage you seem interested in your well being, they are shackled by those at the corporate level who don't care as much about their employees as they care about making money. Recruiters are unable to negotiate with interns on any aspect of their offer, so all interns are paid the same regardless of previous experience. It also took a long time to get into actual work; I felt like half my internship was wasted setting up my environment and waiting for an assignment.

pros:
UHG (including Optum) does an excellent job on retention.  They do really try and retain people and provide career paths.  They do act on a lot of the empowerment and culture aspects that many companies claim to care about.   If you are looking for a place that you potentially can last for a long time I'd seriously consider the UHG companies.  

While none of the benefits are spectacular there are a ton of them: seriously hundreds of types of benefits too many for any one person to know.  The total package is well above average.  

They also have a terrific program for first jobs called TDP.  If you are looking to get started and are a senior in college or finishing your masters this is one of the best first job programs I've ever seen or heard about.  Definitely worth checking out.
cons: Pay can be somewhat below average and raises are bad.  The bonus structure is good.  There is a non confrontational culture at UHG which means problems often don't get resolved and so the company is full of contradictory direction.  Training is deprioritized  and underfunded.

pros:
This company gets it. They treat employees and clients with respect. They live their mission and values. It's evident all over the company from communications to intranet to managers and upper management. 

They are picky and selective because they want the right people in there. They don't want just anyone. People truly care. I feel like I'm growing in my career again. I'm challenged and given tasks to take on. But I'm also very well supported. If I have a question or reach a stopping point I always has someone I can ask. I see such a huge growth trajectory for me. My teammates are so kind and supportive. 

I'm using my skills and growing! 

They also get that we're in 2017. I work from home full time. Amazing setup and IT support for telecommuters. 

Amazing PTO (23 days, goes up to 28 after 5 years or manager level job). 

Amazing healthcare plans. 

Amazing buildings.
cons: Recruiting. The online application system sucks and you can never talk to a real person. Some recruiters were great and moved fast but other jobs I applied for took 3-4 months before rejection email.

pros: Decent pay.  Work from home.  PTO is good.  401k has a good match.  Stock  options  The work is meaningful.  Holidays are standard.
cons: There is a culture here of supervisors not listening or responding to the employees who they supervise.  At least this is the case in my region.  They are too busy to deal with situations that are truly concerning to employees.  They pay great lip service, lots of general emails thanking employees for their work but when it comes to a true concern or request for help they are way too busy to stop and listen.   I don’t believe my supervisor knows me as a person at all or understands what I do on a daily basis.  My latest review praised me for things I have never done and left off my significant accomplishments.  I feel disrespected and I don’t feel valued as an employee.  It’s a shame because I like the work I do and feel like this company  is a great fit.  It makes It hard though when you don’t have trust in your supervisors. It’s demoralizing.

job_title: Claims Business Process Analyst in Green Bay, WI
pros: Lot of opportunity for growth
cons: No cons to share now.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Flexibility, PTO, work from home.
cons: Excessive leadership changes, favoritism for promotions not skill, salary compared to other businesses

pros: great communication, leadership, values, mission, cares for employees wellbeing
cons: benefits could be better for employees

pros: Fast growing organization in Healthcare Sector.
cons: All things are good there but learning process is limited there.

review_title: Make sure you understand what you are getting into.
pros:
High profile credential which is a positive for anyone's resume.

Work from home options are numerous.

There is an ability to move laterally within the company along with some upward mobility for those early in their careers.
cons:
Tasks are poorly resourced which results in missed timelines along with critical mass not being reached in order to accomplish goals and objectives.

Employees are not empowered to make decisions.  Even regional VPs and Presidents have little decision making authority.

Lack of clear authority lines leads to lack of accountability and finger pointing.

Long hours with unrealistic workloads are placed on employees at all levels in the organization.  Managers are not able to manage because they are busy with day to day tasks including clerical duties.

Health benefits are difficult to access and expensive.

Pay and performance policies are irrational.  Bonuses are available to a maximum of 60% of your bonus eligible people.  This may work if you have a department of 50 but not so good when you have a handful and they are may be performing well, meeting goals, etc.  At the individual level, bonuses are determined by managers and not against some predetermined formula.  Raises are similar and essentially contribute to the massive turnover as talented staff who have options leave.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Overland Park, KS
pros: Covered Parking & Free Coffee/Tea
cons:
Where to start....if your spouse/partner gets sick (cancer/major surgery) and you apply for FLMA - its takes forever for it to be approved, so you are told via phone by FLMA to take your time but once you return to work your supervisor informs you that you have been placed on a CAP (Corrective Action), which means no raise for one year due to your being gone. Oh, your PTO is a GIFT and can be taken from you at anytime (per one Supervisior). God forbid that something serious happens to your child or spouse where you have to make a life/death decision about them...your job may be in jeopardy. 
If a State of Emergency is called by the governer of your state due to massive blizzard conditions you are still expected to be at work, if not you will receive an occurance which counts against you. Their excuse is that they make available hotel rooms...which is good but what about employees who have children or parents that need assistance or people who have animals...its not like you can just leave them on their own for a night or two. Too bad is their response. "You need to make other arrangements for these circumstances": REALLY 
If you can get a raise you will be lucky if its 10 cents an hour.
Mandatory (new word Required) overtime hours up to 12 hours a day/6-7 days a week.
No room for advancement.

pros:
- Good company values
-  Work at home opportunities
cons:
-  Very high attrition in the non-exempt levels. Management does nothing to rectify, just keeps hiring more people who end up leaving a couple of weeks out of training because of  what mgmt calls "absenteeism"  Blind to the root cause that is  the extremely low employee morale across the call center.  (local problem)
-Healthcare insurance is a cluster that needs severe overhaul

-Resources are confusing, misleading, redundant and outdated. This causes associates problems on their calls, unhappy providers who get conflicting, misleading information. 

- My team was forced to change shifts to better support business needs  -  3 times in 6 months.   (3 hours difference in the start time) 
-  Ineffective call center metrics that do little more than measure the associates breathing rate on phone calls. Quality metrics are not measuring the appropriate behaviors or rewarding for excellence. 
 
- NY/NJ nightmare calls because of denied claims processes that are ineffective and severely inefficient. 

- Outdated systems that do not support the current state of the business.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Minnetonka, MN
pros: networking, benefits, employee stock buying
cons: Feel like just a number

review_title: I was a technical lead in sas leading 8 people in the project
pros: Professional,  employee friendly,  Well structured  organization
cons: Nothing worth mentioning to write

pros: Work from home was the main benefit
cons: Lots of office politics to deal with

review_title: No yearly raises and no bonuses for EAP counselors for successfully counseling  over 1000 employees a year.
job_title: EAP Counselor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Counseling employees of many large tech companies in the bay area regarding mental health and wellness issues, whose employers have chosen UHG OPTUM (formerly known as United Behavioral Health) to be there EAP vendor.
cons:
Business Intelligence Analytics  inappropriately tweaks parameters of automated algorithms and formulas up and down  to deny  benefits to its own employees,contracted  providers and customers in order to maximize united health group's  CEO's & board of directors profits. 
You don't get rewarded for high performance. 
The metrics are always being tweaked to do more with less time. 
Poor ergonomics set up. 
Under market value  wages.
The CEO decided to increase the usual and customary fees of physicians after a major law suit with Ingenix now known as Optum insight. He has not allowed psychologists and masters level clinicians  to adjust the usual and customary rate.  When our clients wants to see clinician face to face, most providers in the network who list accepting EAP in the UHG data bases, actually turn EAP members away because of the low compensation rate.

pros: Good Pay! 15.27 per hour. You get PTO of 144 hours but that includes sick days too. There is opportunity for career advancement as well as working from home.
cons: You are never going to be fully trained on everything because there are too many different situations members can call about. This was my first call center job and last. The training is alot but is not hard, it was about 14 weeks long. Members call about procedures they need to have covered or medications and sometimes they are not covered by UHC or just miraculously are no longer covered and having to explain that to the member is not easy.  If you are up to telling members a certain medical procedure they may need is not covered or medication is not covered then go right ahead and work for them. it stressed me out mentally. members would get so upset and look at you for a reason why and there is not one. They don't train you on how to deescalate a situation like that. This job was just not for me. In training my supervisor was excellent and hands on. But once i got out of training and went to nesting (you are not yet on the floor but you are out of training) i barely spoke with my supervisor.

pros: Large company, ability to change positions after a year. Some flexibility to work from home. Active in the community with lots of volunteer opportunities. Good technology. Knowledgeable employees with a few pockets of brilliance. Emphasis on their 5 pillars of culture. Great employee discounts
cons: If you are brought into a bad team or work with a poor manager you are locked in for a year. Depending on how bad he/she is, that might be unbearable. I am leaving after 7 months. Because so many people have been there 20-30 years, they are not always open to news of doing things. There is also a sense of complacency. Salaries are below market and even with promotions, raises are minimal. They don't look at the job you will be doing but rather what you make now. Very limiting and people leave often for better salaries.  Very few leaders engage in employee development. Coaching is practically non existent.

pros: Compensation according to work is good
cons: Lacks initiative in latest technology

pros: Respectful and great staff, high paying
cons: Long hours, shifts change, boring tasks

review_title: It all depends on what your goal is
pros:
1.  You are able to make your own schedule
2.  Pay is good / benefits are decent
3.  Gives you and the patient spiritual fulfillment as you are visiting disabled, retired, chronically ill patients who can be isolated at times and appreciate the visit and your company.
cons:
1.  An RN could technically perform this job.  You do not 100% utilize your nurse practitioner education.  
2.  Management not supportive and is evidently micromanaging
3.  Position is more about collecting data to close gaps in medicare STARS then actually helping the patient.  You are required to provide a lot of education in preventative screenings that, some of the screenings, aren't fully covered and the patient cannot afford.
4.  Expected to go to online meetings, complete online education, complete charting, and other tasks off time.
5.  You can make suggestions; however, typically that is as far as it will go.
6.  You do not get follow up on your referrals or you do not get to see previous years visit information so each visit is like a new visit.

pros: The managers and supervisors in my department are wonderful. I could work for more in another department, like care advocacy, but nearly everyone who does make that transition upwards seems to get fired in the end. Our team culture is supportive, and ethical decision making is  paramount.
cons: My starting salary back in the day was 45K, which was a lot for someone coming into the industry  from a not-for profit background. It has risen slowly to the current level, which is normally great for my field. HOWEVER, I recently learned that a new male hire, with the same license level as me, makes 9K more than me right off the bat. No offense to him, but he is making more than I am right out of the gate, and that irritates me to no end. My perception is that loyalty and experience are trumped by novelty and being the right gender.

job_title: Community Health Worker in Orlando, FL
pros: Excellent company to work for. Their pay structures are very aggressive with great incentives similar to military pay grade style. The training is second to none. It's so thorough that there is little excuse to be ignorant of any protocols and they pride themselves with information updates to remain competitive in the field. Not a boring job.  Not a company for the lazy.
cons: If you like things to stay the same this place is not for you. UHG is constantly changing their techniques and their approach which makes constant learning imperative. They overkill on meetings, again to remain razor sharp as a company but it has it's wear and tear. Requires High Energy as they always maximise employees time to get the most out of you.  The insurance they offer is similar to any other medium sized company even though they are an insurance company.

pros: Team spirit, discipline, unity, excellence and commitment
cons: Stress, work life balance, social pressure, expectations and fulfilment of the same

pros: Great company great people wonderful benefits
cons: Very limited breaks. 30 min lunchss

review_title: Company Culture Looks out for Its Employees
pros: EHR is a place that values its employees and wants to ensure that they are happy and rewarded for their hard work. Throughout the year, there are lunches, picnics and other events to celebrate and to reward the employees and to constantly say thank you for a job well done. I especially like the approach the company takes towards giving back to the community. This year so far, we have held company-wide events that have raised money and collected donations for The American Red Cross, the American Cancer Society, Operation Gratitude (supporting U.S. troops overseas), The Pajama Program (providing pajamas and books to needy families), and shortly will be starting a food drive.
cons: The commute is longer than I have had at previous jobs. Due to the route I have to take in, it is a lot of backed up traffic and potential delays. Not that bad most of the time, but still takes some getting used to. Luckily, I have been afforded flexibility when dropping off my kids at daycare in the morning, or if I need to build in the extra time to get through traffic to pick them up in time at the end of the day. Coincidentally, this actually helps me focus better during the day to make sure I have my work done in a timely manner.

job_title: Consumer Engagement Specialist in Providence, RI
pros: Location is great close to about 4 or 5 bus lines, a shopping center and a few fast food places. The eclectic mix of people does include a mix of LGBT which is also great. If you speak a second language you have the opportunity to make a bit more per hour.
cons: Everyone here is miserable and looking hard for another place of employment. It is very hard to get into other positions within the company unless you are a "favorite". They lie to you during the Training portion of how much your going to be recognized and how much you have the potential to earn- but more importantly how much the enrollments and and other items count towards your potential bonuses. The people who listen to your calls & watch your times on & off the floor are ultimately who decide if you get a bonus or not, they don't care if you got screamed at or if you made someone's day. People have had their lives threatened by customers, Cars have been vandalized, broken into or stolen. This place built it's structure based on Politics & whatever makes the company look good- even if they have to cut a few corners to do so. The amount stress in the Call Center is surreal & I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone- friend or foe!

pros: Forge great comraderie with team members after months training. Receive assistance with tuition for higher education at select universites. Somewhat flexible work hours.
cons: The pay is not congruent with the work. Even with a BS/MA, the compensation is not enough to pay for real world expenses. Employees are not paid enough to deal with micromanagement and the changing nature of company policy/procedure. Also, after leaving staining, there was no pay increase, as most would expect. What you see is what you get. You would think that working in health insurance would mean your benefits would be great, but they are extremely lacking. This position's duties change daily, which entails for subpar training from individuals who do not possess skill to train due to lack of knowledge of the subject matter or patience. You will easily burn out in this position and there is little hope in moving up within the company due to high turn over for this position. Knowledge of protocol is expected of employees despite not being informed of protocols by management. Even when communicating issues to supervisors, our words (as a collective group) fell on deaf ears and nothing was done to rectify issues.

pros:
- There are many great people to work with depending on project and market area.
- Depending on the market you work in, some of the work is interesting and meaningful.
- Exposure to new developments in healthcare payment models
cons: There is not enough work to go around -- some people are overworked and others have nothing to do. But those who have too much work are unwilling to share the load. Utilization is VERY important. Even if it's not your fault -- your underutilization will be used against you when it comes to promotions and bonuses. Favoritism is prevalent -- the employees who suck up to upper management keep getting promoted quickly. Poor managers are also prevalent and there is a major mismatch of skill set to projects. Talented people are sitting around twiddling their thumbs because they haven't been given project work. And yet the company keeps hiring people. It doesn't make sense. Work from home policy is non existent even though management says there is one. Work from home is used inconsistently across the company.

review_title: Provider Customer Service Representative/Provider Resolution Specialist/Intake Coordinator
job_title: Provider Customer Service Representative/Provider Resolution Specialist/Intake Coordinator in Houston, TX
pros: There are no pro's to working for this organization.
cons: Where do I begin? This company is awful they are constantly merging positions and not increasing the pay, they have thirty minute lunches, constant system issues, management is very lazy and sorry they put their responsibilities off on the team leads. Furthermore this organization cheats employee's out of raises, wrongfully enforces HR policies as they see fit and when you go report it to HR their no help they refer you back to your manager (useless as well). This organization should be ashamed as they do not offer sick time nor have a sick policy so if you get violently ill you will be punished for it and if it exceeds seven unexcused absences you will be punished by losing your job. They do not practice the values they state they do their actions show otherwise, and  there is no moving up as everything is determined by your incompetent manager who if they don't like you then your SOL. The health insurance they offer is horrible high deductibles it barely covers anything if at all. They offer other organizations better coverage then their employee's they claim they care about and appreciate. This is absolutely one of the worst organizations I have ever worked for and I will never ever consider coming back.  AWFUL!

pros: If you need balance your work life then you should join UHG

review_title: best company to work in NCR
pros: Maintained Good Work Life balance

pros: There are no Pros to this company.
cons: They installed software on all the companies computers and they can now see everything you do, major micro management.  Pay is not competitive.

pros: There are fixed projects and fixed work
cons: It depends on you how you take the opportunity

review_title: UHG-Good Place to work if you kow what to look for
job_title: Program Director in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros:
Flexable work Schedules - Work from Home was OK for me
Not 40 hours of work for 40 hours of pay
I think I am very very Lucky, because I have a very very good manager
If have worked for a large compnay you will fit in fine
cons:
Pay is so low the only way to make it worthwile is to work from home and 
not really work 40 hours a week, or work at another job at home while you are working for UHG.
Health Benefits are poor, but other companies will follow what UHG is doing to benefits.
If you worked for a small or mediam company you will be disapointed in the performance of every employee.
UHG is mostly in shock due to massive layoffs and consolidations, where it is difficult to find your way through the muck.

review_title: Acquisition by UnitedHealth brought on a whole new slew of challenges
pros:
The majority of people that I worked with were highly intelligent, dedicated, and very hard working.  Some I would even consider to be brilliant - and I felt fortunate to have the opportunity to work with and learn from them.

Work culture is fairly laid back.  Management tends to treat their employees as professionals, allowing them to manage their own schedules.
cons: When Lewin was bought out by Ingenix (a wholly owned subsidiary of UnitedHealth Group(, a lot of issues emerged from the rocky transition, including those related to benefits (ironic that our health insurance was worse after being acquired by an insurance company), confusion on business processes (HR and other support services were farmed out to UnitedHealth staff working at different offices), and the addition of 2 new layers of bureaucracy (Ingenix and UnitedHealth). The frustration we felt was compounded by the fact that so much of the decision making process was done behind closed doors by Ingenix/UnitedHealth.  Perhaps by now, most of these issues have been worked out though.

pros:
Work culture is good. 
New technologies available to learn.
Work/Life Balance.
cons: Sometimes management favor their closest ones

review_title: A company that allows me to grow and take on challenges
pros: Excellent Development Opportunities and support to grow
cons: Limited business units in the Letterkenny Office

pros: My job allows me to work at home & have some flexible hours.I wanted to be out of the hospital setting be closer to home so I could be with my kids. I am able to be home when my teenage kids are around.I am a single mother so it menas alot for me to be at home when they get home from school.I get about 5 wks vacation time & at 5 yrs another week is added.If my kids are sick I don't have to call in sick, I can still work.Miss less days of work because I work at home.
cons: My manager is a micro manager (like a babysitter).There is little information shared between upper & middle management to the front line.Money could be spent better on a $6 per hr babysitter than what we have.The health insurance benfeits for a insurance company is terrible in comparison.Upper management doesn't seem to ever want to listen to the lower level staff about issues concerning middle management. The program seems to have been thrown together overnight & not given much thought to the BIG picture.More thought should be given to the people running the behind the scenes.Poorly planned lauching of new department.

review_title: Lots of opportunity... within the right group...
job_title: Marketing Manager in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: The sky is the limit... it's up to you what you do with the vast amount of opportunity for development within the greater UHG, UHC, & Optum universe. Network! Great people, great culture at the surface, but at the team level it depends on the tone your management sets. Take an opportunity to seek out and participate in the Mentor program. Benefits are ok. Employee stock program is awesome! Having a front row seat to what's what in healthcare and driving positive impactful change is the best...if you can pull yourself out of the weeds.
cons: Though opportunity IS there, a means for connecting, or the support and encouragement to do so isn't always. It's not always recognized by mid-level management. They can get too focused on their specific area, or initiative, and lose touch with the big picture. This leaves them in somewhat of a silo from the rest of the organization. Some of them take pride in this, or blame "the rest" of the organization for this, but these attitudes ultimately hurt their teams.

pros: No pros for this company.
cons: They will buy your company, then lay off all the employees without options for repurposing the employees to different departments

pros: Flexibility, great culture, extra curricular activities
cons: No campus, bad transport, less parking slots

review_title: Expect to work overtime without compensation
pros: UnitedHealth Group has great benefit package, beginning wages are fair, offer broadbanding pay scales, flexible scheduling and they have improved their work-life balances.
cons: Despite frustrations and advice from management, senior management determines production levels that are constantly increasing and do not embrace the entire workload. Nonproductive work has to be be completed and for each hour spent on nonproductive work, employees are expected to makeup these hours with what manages considers productive work. For example, when claims adjusting department was in a severe backlog, our team was pulled to help. Each hour we were helping had to be made up by the end of the week. This type of work arrangement happened frequently. Also, there is no such thing as time off. When on vacation or leave, expect numerous hours to work numerous hours (at least they pay you for these hours!)  During five years of employment, senior management implemented several unsuccessful structure changes and transferred out of the company to another within UHG. This happened four times within the five years.

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Irvine, CA
pros:
- Decent pay
- Good benefits
- Good coworkers
- Friendly, casual environment
- Prime location in Orange County
cons:
- Very unorganized and lacks institutional guidance
- Poor management as everything is considered a "fire"
- People seem to work long hours due to inefficiencies
- A lot of redundancies in work, possibly for job security purposes
- Lacks focus on professional development when compared to my old employer
- Very tight deadlines without appropriate justification as to why
- Everyone's a workhorse and complains on the side but not to management to change

review_title: Great place to grow your career experiences.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Minnetonka, MN
pros: The different benefits are very nice. Along with medical/dental, you have access to a company 401k and also a company stock purchase program that is very advantageous. The culture here is very good for a very big employer. I see a lot of engagement from employees in so many different areas that it makes this place more than "work".
cons:
Promotions are very stingy here. Leaders hold to these preconceived percentages of people that can be bonused so many people end up falling on the sword and not getting a bonus so at least some others can. It's also hard to move internally without knowing who the hiring manager is. Many people leave here and then come back so they get their true value in pay. Seems like a risky way to lose good talent.
Also, even though there may be 500 jobs listed for an area or state, the truth is that probably only a quarter of those positions will be filled. Makes your search seem like guesswork when you're wondering if a job you like and applied for is even really going to be filled.

pros: * Company is trying to add good values but senior members are screwing it up.
cons: Team get scared to raise voice just because of its managers. Give individuals more responsibility of owning the system.

pros: Good company to start career
cons: Needs improvement in company's policy

review_title: helping us citizens on open enrollment
pros: good work life balance and high compensation
cons: too much overtime almost on a weekly basis

pros: Their benefits are decent.  The pay was okay for the job one does.
cons:
Ageism is alive and well at this company.  They offer nothing close to any kind of security.  This company will lay people off in a heartbeat, regardless of salary level, position or age.  Loyalty to its' employees is non-existent.  The company has grown through acquisition rather than creativity and offering a superior product.  The company says it cares for its' employees and customers, but not really.  They don't even have loyalty to citizens of its' own country, as they do not hesitate to outsource work to India.  This company doesn't even have loyalty to its' provider network, without which it would have no market share.  

Training is a bare minimum.  So, you better know your job when you start.  Cliques can be found throughout the company.  One department is competition with, instead of working with other departments.

review_title: Horrible Management at United health CARE employer and Individual
pros: If you are looking to be employed by a big company- this is your spot.
cons: Doesn't matter how good of a job you do they will never see it because all levels of Management are in clique and if you are not a part of it you are SOL.

pros: Pay's good, hours are pretty flexible, PTO allowances are very good.
cons:
The disparate parts of the company- from divisions, all the way down to the team level- never seem to meaningfully communicate or cooperate with one another. If you need something from anywhere outside of your immediate team, prepare for weeks, if not months of utterly fruitless wrangling. I've been trying to get various accesses since I started, and I am still waiting on some crucial items that I'm about to give up waiting for.

The hugely bloated levels of middle management who need to justify their existence leads to an insane number of redundant meetings, where very little, if anything, is accomplished- I have to attend, on average, 25-30 meetings a week.

Due to this, I can't get any meaningful work done, and I don't see anyone around me getting anything meaningful done either.

Raising issues, big or small, to management or anyone else usually gets a shrug in response. There are days when I wonder where the money to pay us actually comes from.

Most surprisingly for a health insurance company, the benefits aren't that great, and aren't really that good a value, with a pretty sparse network of covered providers compared to other packages I've had.

pros: You get the title of an administrator even though its call center work. You get all the benefits that come with full time, including time and a half. You also accrue 5.5 additional hours per check. Its a M-F job (sometimes you work saturdays too) and depending on the season you can dress down.
cons: Management (referring to the big honchos) would sometimes act as though you are not important enough. They would force you to change ypur schedule for a two hour meeting, not taking into recognition that you may have kids to pick up or make arrangements for a ride. You would have to come in 4 hours early or stay 2 hours later for a meeting that did not directly effect you or had much to do with your department. In addition to that, they will force you to on multiple Saturdays for a minimum of 6 hours, hit the same numbers you would hit if you worked your normal 8 hour shift, and then wont give you a lunch. Lunch is 30 minutes with 2 fifteen min breaks too. They only have full time positions. Almost absolutely NO snow days. If its a foot and a half of snow,  you're still coming to work.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros:
Lots of PTO time.
Pretty easy job, once you get the hang of it.
Not really stressful - you can go as fast or as slow as you want each day.
For the kind of job that it is - it pays pretty well
cons:
Very, very boring , very repetitive - you pretty much answering call after call - doing and staying pretty much the same thing
Some day that managers can micromanage you to death, as everything you do on the phone can be track, trace and recorded.
There are definitely worker bees and queen bees and the queen bees tend to have a lot of fun while the call queues just keep going up, up  and up. 
Easy to get into a customer service job but very difficult to move up unless you have a medical background.

review_title: Field Community Health Worker- Great team and company model
pros:
*Interview was very fair and well-structured. 
*PAY is excellent for the field. PTO starts at 18 days/year and I think after 5 years goes up to 24. Plus 7 holidays/year.
*Telecommuting and in-home visits. 
*Given a nice desk, computer monitor/mouse, laptop, and iPhone by the company
*Excellent management team. Open to suggestions and very positive.
*We use the "Jabber" instant message program which is a great alternative to phone calls and e-mails. 
*Excellent training. Great team atmosphere.
*The company doesn't seem riddled with bureaucracy and red tape like many do. Very forward-thinking.
*Many opportunities for growth in the company.
cons:
*In this position there's always danger of going to strangers' houses. I've also brought fleas home.
*Working from home presents challenges when needing to contact the helpdesk/IT. They can be slow to respond.
*Health insurance benefits are not great, but it seems that way everywhere now.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Minneota, MN
pros: WAH, 23 days of PTO, 8 holidays, hourly employee (eligible for OT) which I love because I've been salary and hated it. I love the potential for growth, home training, awesome trainers and  great staff in my team. Opportunity for growth but not too focused on that since I will be graduating as a FNP next year so I hope to work there doing house calls and traveling 😊. I have worked in many organizations and this is the best one by far. Unfortunately we have different personalities so lay low and focus on your goal and never give up. I love it here and my friend that referred me has been with the company for a long time and says she will retire from this company and never planning to leave, I feel the same, great culture and I love working in pajamas, attending meetings, and training. United is in the entire United States and over 125 companies. I encourage nurses and anyone interested to apply and nor give up.
cons: None that I can think of but to the rest of the world, please hang in there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: 401k match, PTO, employee stock purchase. If you are in Optum IT, some groups are much slower pace than others. Financial development/support is a good area to get into versus areas of IT that support operations. Same pay, but few projects and much slower pace. You need to charge 9 hours a day to projects so even if a project doesn’t need overtime hours, you need to put time to it.
cons: Lots of paperwork and 5 chiefs to every 1 worker (everyone from the worker to the VP charges time to projects so the price is inflated and the business segments get upset at the worker as the cost can be 10 times higher than what the worker charged). Lower levels of management (manager through director level) are not needed and do not know how to do the work. This can cause them to create roadblocks on project documentation – Nothing else for them to do, but at least they can feel good about entering time on the project!

review_title: Terrible Pay, Terrible Benefits, Micromanagement, Poor Management
pros: Work at home is the only strong positive left after the change of management a litle more of a year ago. The work at home and culture were the positives, previously. .
cons: The pay is dollars below local wages. The health benefits are useless, amounting to catastrophic insurance only. From the VP down to local managers it is poorly managed, unresponsive to rank and file other than glossy corporatisms. The daily work has shifted to high hassle, team members so scared to meet relentless metrics that they no longer help each other in a pinch. High performing members of the team are summarily fired with no signs of trouble or reason. A very small core group of workers have been brought along for seven years, and assignments of interest not democratically offered out to the incredibly talented team.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Westerville, OH
pros:
I worked with good, caring people
Company was great when it started as Progressive Medical
cons:
In the 10+ years I worked there, the company went from a small everyone knows and cares about each other, to a pay performance company after being bought out by Helios (now Optum).

Supervisors are clueless and are only concerned about how they look to upper management vs. help with the ever changing job duties and customer care.  They give you a manual or e-mail link and basically tell you "good luck!"

The company is finding ways to force senior employees making $4-$5 more an hour out of their jobs in order to hire cheaper labor, sacrificing knowledge/customer familiarity for shortcuts/robots.

job_title: Licensed Care Advocate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Base pay is competitive to start, and ample opportunity to make additional $$ "IF" you are willing to sacrifice home/work balance, and work crazy grave yard shifts. Telecommute was a plus, but after a while, overrated, unless you are able to stay motivated with very mundane work, and no excitement or face-to-face interaction EVER.
cons: No respect for work/life balance. You will definitely make decent $$, however, you'll spend your days off trying to catch up on rest, so won't be able to enjoy your $$. Company snitches get ahead, while others who follow rules but don't get caught up in company politics, will never get noticed. If you enjoy providing true therapy, this job is not for you, NO THERAPY, you are basically an overpaid Insurance agent with a license. Constant rule changes. No consistency. More LPCC than LCSWs or LMFTs, which makes no sense, in the real world, most reputable companies, especially government, would NEVER choose an LPCC over an LCSW or LMFT, but remember, this job requires no clinical skills, so that explains it!

review_title: Stressful Environment and No work Life Balance
job_title: Tier II Claims Specialist in Greensboro, NC
pros: The pay was nice and the team I worked on was excellent. Perfect if you have no life and no children.
cons: There is no breathing space between calls, they want you to solve the problem within 7-10 minutes but it may take that amount of time for the member to tell you what they are calling about and then you HOPE that the claim will reprocess with no issues, supervisors play favorites, penalized for having FMLA and using it, job was so stressful that I ended up with manic depression when I have gone my whole life without it and it caused me to have a nervous breakdown, supervisors complain when you take your FMLA and say you must not really want the job which causes more stress, VTO is a joke because you have to ask permission and then by the time a supervisor responds all of the slots may be gone, they expect people who cannot drive in icy condition to drive in them to work or get penalized for worrying about their safety, they want you to lie for the company and if you have a family emergency, you are penalized for putting family first. UHC does not care if your family is sick or dying because you better show up for work and you better not let it interfere with your job performance because if it does then you are going to get a write-up.

pros: Able to work from home when not in the field visiting members.  Great co-workers who are supportive. My immediate manager is awesome and is a great advocate for us, but it falls on deaf ears with Senior Management.
cons: The workload is not manageable with high caseloads and compliance expectations. The stress level of our team is soaring and at least 3 of us are actively looking for other jobs. Processes are constantly changing and the computer systems are horrible. Nominal pay increases even when you are rated as a high performer. We have literally begged Senior Leadership for more help to reduce caseloads and improve compliance. We are always being told that things are getting better but we don't see any direct action.  I have given up hope that the workload situation is going to improve and have made the decision to start actively looking for another job. I have over 30 years of experience and cannot work like this anymore.

pros:
I have been working at UHG for a few years and I have known through other people within other departments that this is a great company. It all just depends. 

-Quarterly Incentives 
-Attempts to celebrate employees
cons:
I have now worked at two different sites in two different states and it really is like night and day. The smaller sites seem very unprofessional and all about making their own rules.

-Leadership is unprofessional 
-Not willing to be flexible 
-Kind of a high school environment 
-Tech equipment is old and slow and leadership isnt willing to do anything about that

pros: Telecommuting is the only pro.
cons:
Proposal writer position: Unrealistically overtasked while other team members are not properly utilized. No career development, management allows other team members to take credit and incentives for work, telecommuting is an excuse to work from home day, nights, weekends, and holidays. Punitive environment with rude and degrading senior leadership. The culture within proposal development lacks respect for writer/ editor positions and they are seen as disposable work machines. Mid level leadership lacks experience that provides knowledge and insight to conduct a more efficient process, and the overall technological infrastructure to complete the work is severely behind. Avoid these kind of positions at UHG, and perhaps this company all together, it is falling behind in the industry and it shows. 

Healthcare benefit: cost efficient, but behind in wellness programs.

401k: out of date- matching and vesting period too long, only 100% match- other competitor companies do better

Tuition reimbursement- completely outdated, have to owe time for two years and there are strict guidelines to get it. Organization does not appear to hire for education anyways. Better at other major competitor companies. 

Culture: toxic, and too rigid. A culture of continual lay offs makes people possessive over their jobs and threatened by others. It’s a ‘keep you in your place’ environment. The organization is so huge the culture varies drastically, you just have to hope you are hired into a good place.

pros: Awesome place to work from
cons: Way too many in leadership roles with less workforce executing orders

review_title:
Demonstrate compassion and appreciation for employees.

.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: I had a job with a steady, weekly paycheck. I was given the opportunity to do a job that I had no proir experience in. I Iearned new skills to provide excellent customer service.
cons: It's not well organized, they exploit there employees, don't care about employees well being, the company only cares about the company and not about the employees that helped the company progress to where it is today. There is no loyalty or compassion for employees.

pros: Great co-workers, work from home option for certain positions, good PTO accrual rate after 5 years, on site cafeteria
cons: The company used to be the employer of choice for pharmacists in the Kansas City area until 3 years ago when new executive management was brought in.  Everything and everyone has since been reduced to a number.  A manual tracker has to be used to document all work, and even bathroom breaks, etc.  Discussions that aren't work related are not allowed on the processing floor at any time, so it's quite draconian. The main computer system is extremely complex and unstable, so there are constant upgrades and workarounds that seem to only make things worse.  Pharmacists are expected to verify more and more scripts per hour, and if you don't meet the goals you are put on a corrective action plan, with your job in jeopardy.  There is a lot of mandatory overtime here, which makes a work life balance a challenge. In 3 short years, OptumRx has gone from the employer of choice for pharmacists, to the employer of last resort.

review_title: Horrific boss, crappy insurance, but decent pay
pros: You can come in late or early, as long as you work your hours, which helps for those pesky appointments during the day.  The pay was decent for the job, and the training was very thorough.
cons: Management is not on the employees side.  Managers do not know the job, they only know the numbers, so I watched people continuously fail because of not meeting numbers but management had no way of offering advice because they only knew the basic idea of our job.  Management also didn't like when an employee knew laws, and knew that the insurance company had to legally pay for certain procedures.  When questioned or pushed back because of federal laws management had major issues and then wanted to cause issues for the staff.  It is a very immature group of people who are in management and they don't have the back bone to stand up for what's right.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Fast vacation accrual and ability to purchase paid time off.  Supervisors are very helpful to the extent the company will let them be and will often treat their team like an extension of their family.
cons: Benefits are horrible for this being an insurance company they are overly expensive and deductibles are sky high!  constant system problems that mess with your stats, no time off and shift trades are extremely hard to come by, the quarterly shift bid is more like an ever 6 month bid and the determination of ranking changes each time, and those you qualify per your metrics for your bonus there is always some reason it will not pay out!  Not employee oriented, no picnics, holiday parties etc!

pros: The work was fairly easy, there was not a huge amount of responsibility for the employee.  There are very intuitive guidelines for every process. It seems as though it is very easy to move up in the company. It is very easy to be hired; I never even spoke with anyone in person before my first day.
cons: Every single thing you do is micromanaged. The management does a thorough job of making the employees know that they do not trust you or think you are smart. Every single thing you do has to be monitored. You are not allowed to have any personal items on you (no phones, wallets, keys, food, etc.) Their reasoning for this is 'HIPAA' regulations, however, their measures greatly exceed the actual regulations. Absolutely no one is happy; even the management appears to be treated about the same way. Lunch is only 30 minutes, which is severely cut down due to the fact that you must get your lunch from your locker or the fridge before eating, as well as having to clock in and out at the exact right time, so it ends up being only about 15-20 minutes. There is a major issue with communication and bureaucracy within the management; there were many times the employees were promised something and did not receive it.

review_title: Great place to intern for techies and business folk alike
job_title: Technology Development Intern in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
Ability to do good work that scratches any moral itch
My manager was very hands-off and cared a lot about his team
Lots of room for growth and cross-movement throughout different roles
Ability to work from home often
Great work computers and almost all tech was at the very least decent
Quick and helpful IT people
Free housing for interns!
Company outings, often with free food
Tons of opportunities to train in different fields you might not see otherwise(I'm a techie and I got to train in business development just for kicks)
Good work-life balance
Beautiful offices
cons:
Red tape. There's so much red tape and so many barriers blocking you at what seems like every turn.
There are some pretty bad developers. It's not the norm, but I saw some code in my time there that made me physically ill.
Far from the city. Maybe not a deal breaker for everyone, but for 20-somethings who like urban life the commute to Eden Prairie can be brutal.
No "big 4" type perks like free daily lunches but honestly it feels nit-picky to even mention this as a con
Gym kinda sucks, but at least it's free

cons: This opportunity started off being billed as a 3 week training course, that went to 4 weeks and then "suprise!! some of you will need to stay an extra week" for a different level of training. Ok it was paid training no problem. We found out that we would be doing medical billing and Prior Authorizations, wouldn't be getting paid any more money than the jobs we applied for but it would be more intense work with specific drugs and then "suprise!!" again instead of that one specialized area we would be doing both regular calls and "high touch" calls and nope no additional pay raise. pros: Telecommute is a good benefit.
cons:
The philosophy of "helping people live healthier lives" is reflected in the membership. It is the    generally healthy people who are left. The others have died or wisely decided to find other health insurance. A case managers yearly review rating is partly based on how many of their patients are readmitted to the hospital. The lower the number the better the rating. The company is about profits and stock value. 
Clinical policies take on different meanings depending on the member's plan. I do not understand how a company of this size can continue to be so amoral and not be investigated.
As far as treatment of employees, that depends on your manager. My experience is both good and bad.On the bad side is: dishonesty, micromanagement, unfair one sided reviews. Company issues are, very poor benefits the worst in the industry. All employees are not offered the same choices in health care coverage. Department managers can make their own policies. Bad managers make bad policies. I personally have witnessed verbal abuse with threats of termination toward employees who made some errors. Non-exempt employees work overtime without overtime pay.  There is no education there is retaliation

review_title: Helps People Live Healthier Lives except....the Employees
job_title: Project Manager in Overland Park, KS
pros: They hire inexperienced or entry level positions. Can advance to better work if you network properly.
cons: The customer service advocates work harder than anyone in the company and are led to believe that they are getting paid the best in the market. Having been in upper management and wanting to find ways to help the advocates, I learned quickly that it was not my place to make their lives better. It was my place to help the company find ways to get the advocates to work harder and faster while seeing it as a good thing. They get candy bars and pizza for doing good work. They are required to work overtime all year round and there are very few ways of rewarding them outside of food. While they do have bonuses that can be earned if the stats are good, there is very little to reward the day to day work.
