If you have a family that you enjoy spending time with, do NOT work at OptumRx. You will be told that "needs of the business" are more important.

pros: Pays fairly well and you can listen to music on SOME days. Benefits are nice but for a health company, our insurance should be significantly better.
cons:
Tour days, you aren't allowed to listen to music. We get the same pay as other packers although we have a significantly larger amount of responsibility. On top of this, the work is almost non-stop. We get judged by how many packs we do an hour and if we have ice orders, they take at least a minute each if you're really trying to go fast and if you're lucky that it's an easy ice. With this in mind, we're supposed to be putting out close to an order a minute which means we're very worked. We also send medication which means that if we are rushed, we're more prone to make mistakes which can be fatal. Lastly, depending on the shift you work, you'll probably enjoy it more. Night shift that works closes close to midnight gets paid more AND has less ice orders since morning shift does about 90% of them. 

You probably won't get promoted either.

review_title: Company progress and employee benefits going down, No HR, Great transport
pros:
1. In case of emergency they offer work from home
2. Excellent transport facilities.
3. Offers to learn new technologies and move to different teams
cons:
1. Manager say is final and he/she has HR responsibilities. No preference to real HR and also no. of HR's are less. 
2. Employee pay is not private. Managers can literally view the employees pay and decide how much to increase. So high chances of bias.
3. Company progress is declining as the company has become product based to service based company resulting in cost cuttings effecting employee salary benefits like hikes, Variable pays, awards, team outings, company celebrations year by year. They used to be great and this decline is now resulting in increase of attrition rate.
4. Not good at retaining talent.
5. Poor foreseeing of basic infra requirements. Failing to provide basic necessities for employees. No place to sit as well park own vehicles.
6. Company works hard to improve itself but unable to prioritize the primary ones that employees look for
7. Company budget problems causing employee careers downfall

pros: Salary and working environment is good
cons: Working in night shift is tough

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jeffersonville, IN
pros: there are none i can think of
cons: if someone doesnt like you there you dont stand a chance

pros: Improved my knowledge and company
cons: I have accept every challenges

pros: Some great professional and resources
cons: Job insecurity and outdated solutions

job_title: Subject Matter Expert in Houston, TX
pros: I really enjoyed my time with this company. It a great place to work for those who do not have a degree. You aren't micro-managed. In fact, more than likely, you supervisor is in another state so your communication with him or her is by telephone. The work is easy to manage and easy to learn. A lot of overtime work, which I enjoy. Because of so much overtime, they allow you to work from home. There's always other positions available to apply for. There is a lot of flexibility in your schedule. You pretty much tell your supervisor what your schedule is. Decent benefits. Relaxing environment. Especially if you work from home.
cons: If you are coming in as a Resolving Analyst, this position is for someone without a degree. The pay is hourly and is minimal. Also when it's time for a raise, don't expect too much. Just like in my pros, there's lots of overtime work, so that is what you are depending on to make up for the low pay. While there's always other positions to apply for, the HR department isn't very good. You'll be lucky if you hear from them for an interview. A lot of times they'll remove the job requisition without alerting you. You don't have much contact with management.

pros: Great place to work. Great people.
cons: Constant force reductions. Lots of pressure.

review_title: Good company trying help people in a complex healthcare enviroment
pros:
- Job autonomy, flexibility, independence
- Creating a new culture that rewards employees based on integrity, work ethic not tenure
- Solid benefits package (vacation, discounts, health plan premiums)
- Honest employees all driven toward 1 goal: helping people get healthier
- Upper management is extremely engaged
cons:
- As with any large company, you need to make sure you talk about your accomplishments with your manager/leadership or else they will never know
- Obtaining data for reporting and analysis is complicated, inaccurate and often challenging
- Upper management engagement slows projects due to competing schedules and resources
- Company culture is evolving and not yet concrete - not everyone is on the same page as to what is expected of an employee
- Heavy amount of meetings each day (mainly on the phone due to hugely a virtual environment)
- Virtual environment can be challenging (time zones, schedules etc.)
- The healthcare environment is ever-changing and extremely complex; some may not excel without the ability to be resilient to change
- Employee Health plans have huge deductibles that out way low premiums advantage

review_title: Great benefits, negligent management-Monarch Healthcare/Irvine, CA
job_title: EHR Implementation Specialist in Irvine, CA
pros: Above standard PTO, above average pay for geographical area, employee engagement.
cons: Let's just say senior management never gets their hands slapped. In fact they can do wrong. As much as the company advocates non-retaliation and a positive employee/management relationship through their Employee Engagement Committee; it's all smoke and mirrors. UHG is a very large company with lots of tentacles. They've acquired many local care delivery establishments via divisions such as Optum, but have not yet been successful at implementing the culture that the employees in MN enjoy elsewhere in the country. It's not for the lack of trying, it's just not an immediate concern. And as such, management goes about documenting lies about you, if you happen to bring up an impediment, and write you up whilst you are going along with your day, happy as a clam thinking you are being a productive and contributing member of the department. Keep to yourself-ers, and those with no opinion are most welcome!

review_title: TDP can be very hit or miss
job_title: Technology Development Program in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
Awesome perks for an out of college/entry level job (salary is decent-good, vacation time etc.)
No matter where you end up, you'll learn a lot simply because it is your first job.
Development opportunities are pretty good and depending on your location, you can attend conferences, summits, leadership panels etc.
It's a huge and well known company
cons:
It's a huge company -- coming from college you may be used to fast paced projects. Nothing here goes fast... ever.

TDP is really dependent on your role (technical or non-technical), luck and your location. 
--Technical folks seem to have a good time and there are lots of opportunities to improve your skills. Non-technical TDPs get the short end of the stick when it comes to choice of rotations.
-- Your luck matters too since you don't really get to choose your first rotation. Some teams are just better than others. 
--Finally, location is so important in TDP, if you are in a smaller branch office, your experience in TDP will NOT be the same as in MN, NJ or another large office. Keep that in mind.

pros: Company has great vision, great team members. 401K match is ok. Rally
cons: A lot of micromanagement, being track like a slave by Omega in the claims related department and perhaps other departments. Favoritism, having supervisors who only are supervisors because of working with the company for long but basically unqualified to be supervisors. Lack of internal promotion in the claim or appeal related department because they do not want to release too many staffs. Be ready to be in one position for eternity. Turnover rate is very high in my department. Pay is very low. Greedy upper management who will not give raise because they want it all. Unrealistic expectations of having 1 error per month and closing 3-4 cases per hour. No work and life balance, that is a lie. More likely to get cases due over the weekend. Great company, suck management. In the Employee and Individual department, it is known that once you are in, getting out is hard because they will not release you. Will not recommend at all based on current experience. Mental health may be caused by working in my department and I look forward to a study to prove this.

pros: If you live in NJ and don’t want to commute to NYC, the location is good. The office is in the center of NJ. The culture is laid back, which is a good and bad thing. Good place for new grads that are not too technical.
cons:
-Cost savings and finance are the main priority, lot of people got laid off (“voluntary” retirements)
-Complete disregard for software engineering as a whole. Quality is the last priority. I would not come here unless you want to waste the prime of your life. I’d recommend spending the time and studying for better companies. Fortune 6, the stock is rising, cool? That doesn’t mean anything if you take your career as an engineer  serious. Those aren’t metrics for success as a software engineering organization. 
-Don’t be fooled by the ads saying that there is data science or AI/ML here. No one will work on that. Even engineers with phds are scavenging for that kind of work.
-No real projects to work on.
-Technical leadership is mediocre at best. Barely any tech leads.
-Food is awful, they downgraded quality 10 fold.
-Too many young kids that don’t have the basic technical skills to get hired elsewhere.
-office is in the middle of nowhere.
-amazon or Oscar will eventually David and Goliath this company
-HEALTH INSURANCE at a HEALTHCARE company is worse than other companies I’ve seen.

pros: Environment culture creative transport cafeteria
cons: Salary shift ratings demographics flexibility

pros: Growth opportunity. Stock program is AMAZING.
cons: Insurance is pretty high, not the best.

pros: Used to be the people, but many of the high integrity leaders have been forced out.
cons: Poor leadership. Moved away from process discipline and quality to a culture of chaos.

job_title: Customer Service Representative, Claims, Dental, Vision in San Antonio, TX
pros: good pay, incentive to work from home a plus,
cons: Very hostile supervisors, unfeeling for the teams they oversee. Only the stats matter, if you fall below then you are humiliated verbally and in front of peers. The supervisors are heartless and the puppets of upper mgmt.  Most of the workers are of Hispanic origin and if you are any other color your are discriminated against. Heard over and over, " your white you will go no where here". Refuses to blend work and personal life to the point of making health risks for some employees. Employees have been humiliated in front of training classes, many employees made fun of in a language they  do not understand to their faces and  to a sup and they just laugh. Employees feel targeted, abused, disposable. The expectations change so much no worker can keep up a good score. Each CSR has to know every plan by heart and if you say one wrong word you have a deduction and can be held up to company ridicule. I wish the CEO would come do this job one day....no safety net...just put on the phone and given the abusive people we deal with all day and smile and be empathetic no matter what. If you can work anywhere else do it its not worth the headache to work at this company.

review_title: Great people, Poor Training, and Poor Communication
job_title: Health Consult Coach in Bloomington, MN
pros: I work with a team of amazingly talented individuals who are interested in helping people improve their health.  Great pay and benefits (4 weeks of PTO from the start).
cons:
The call center environment at Optum is extremely micro-managed.  Management says they trust us, but doesn't back that up with providing actual trust.  Each minute of your day is micromanaged for you, with no time provided for reading emails or catching up on trainings.  There a huge focus on quantity (how long are your calls, how much time do you spend documenting after a call, how many referrals have you made) over quality (are you connecting with the members on the phone?)

The health consult position is very complicated, and the training for the position has been inadequate in every way.  We often roll out new systems after having been trained incorrectly on how to use them.  Management would say things like, "Oh, it's easy, you'll get the hang of it," yet they weren't the ones live on the phones with inadequate training.  

Overall, there has been a huge theme of poor communication and "pass the buck" mentality at this company.

pros: Alere Health offers opportunities to work from home, which is a huge benefit.  I work with many great, caring people.  PTO is generous and you are able to have a work/life balance.
cons: While I enjoy the people I work with, I have never seen such disfunction in relation to the IT departments.  Horrible, horrible service due to the actions of upper management.  HR is another example; totally absent and shows no care or empathy for employees. Additionally, upper management is always reactive vs. proactive.  I think one of the reasons coworkers support each other is because we all realize how challenging it is to work for such incompetent upper management.  Hoping Optum will provide better management leadership and we can all do what we have a passion for, which is changing people's lives for the better - our clients and our own.

pros: nice working environment in the Cypresss, Ca Office.  Reasonable benefits/pay.
cons: In client service opertations handling small and large group issues, there is no real team spirit. The Supervisors have their favorites who can do no wrong.  This call center, like others, is all about meeting metrics.  If you dont meet average talk time, spend too much time on resolving issues after a call, spend too much time placing the member on hold, not getting quality scores of 94 or above, not getting customer surveys of 95 of above, not going to breaks and lunch as sceduled you will be written up.  There is no guidance on how to improve your performace just a note that your are on corrective action.  Supervisors are only there to critique performace yet they know nothing about what your do.  The company preaches customer  service but does not allow persons who are didicated to providing that service the time to do so.  .  If you want no less than five people looking over your shoulder- quality, corporate compliance, transactional  compliance, adhearance and workforce compliance, and customer service survey compliance, all reviewing and second guessing you on what you do, stay away from U ited Healthcare.

review_title: Not what I expected in a big enterprise
pros: I joined UHG as part of an acquisition and was hopeful but not positive about the transition. Quickly I learned that UHG was a land of opportunity for people hungry to bring the hustle daily (and hustle it was). There was a wide network of people all open to helping me grow my career, provide mentoring (from Director to SVP) and help me discover a path that was right for me. I believe that you get what you put in and if you are willing to put a lot in, then you will get a lot out of working at UHG.
cons:
I left UHG because I reached a point in my career to go any further I needed to be in MN at the main office. This was disappointing but totally understandable. When my management and I hit this point, we began planning my next steps which led to great opportunities.

For some people UHG will not be a good fit. Job functions are specific to your work but there are opportunities to explore outside your job on your own time. Compensation is not as high as other places but I found the offset of support and opportunity more than making up for it.

pros: Good work environment and senior management
cons: Growth is a bit slow

review_title: Great job if you enjoy helping others, not so much if you expect others you work with to be professional.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Roanoke, VA
pros: You get to help those on Disability and/or Senior Citizens with their Prescription Drug Plans. It's very rewarding to speak to a member who needs help and to be able to provide them the assitance they need so they are happy and comfortable.
cons: Hardly anyone that works there has pride in themselves, or the job they do. Extensive training for this job, but you still don't learn everything and they expect you to know everything once you get out on the call floor. If you mess up just a little bit you can lose your job, if you get sick - you could lose your job. I do not feel comfortable going to work each day that I will leave still having a job.

review_title: Opportunities to move around and try different jobs
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros: UHG tells you up front that your career is your own.  They promote it and expect that you will move around as much as you want to.  If you take a new job you have to stay in it for year and then you are free to go - anywhere -  you can apply for new jobs in any aspect of the company - internal recruiters help hiring managers and employees through the process.  You can move anywhere your skills can take you. the company is a pay-for-performance company so they expect that 20% of bonus eligible people which is almost every one do not get bonuses and those who are eligible and are the high performers get an additional amount.
cons: If you are a person who wants your manager to give you a promotion, that rarely happens at UHG.  Compensation is fair however as you move around your promotional $$ is limited to 10% so incoming hires can make more than those who are moving around in side the company.  Benefits are middle of the road - I've seen better and worse.

review_title: Worst benefits and thankless upper management
pros: Work at home two days a week
cons:
They hire people with little to no experience and who has no work ethic, so professionals in the same level work in difficult situations all the time.

Pay is horrible! If you move to another position internally, you will not be paid as much as if you are an external applicant. So no room for growth in pay. 

Even if you have created an entire department's process and have done more than what is expected for the success of the business, including managing an entire program by yourself which is usually managed by at least 10 people, they will not compensate you nor will get an appreciation from the upper management. However, since you have been exceptional with your projects, they know your name. They will use that to keep you on their radar so you don't work so much overtime to finish the projects that nobody else in the entire business segment knows about and for working at home so much for medical reasons they know about and make those an issue.

job_title: Prior Authorization Nurse Medicaid in Miami, FL
pros: Previously there were many benefits however all have changed. Work at home is no longer a pleasure with big brother breathing down ur neck
cons: Terrible insurance with high deductible even for one person. Micromanaged to the minute. Several people as well as my self have left the prior authorization Medicaid team becasue there was very little respect for nurses they were questioned about every minute of the day. It did not start out this way and unfortunately some nurses stole time however this ruined it for many people that were doing things the right way. They took the virtual environment to the next level and treat employees like robots. Even working from home you can only take a 30 min lunch. If your mouse does not move for 60 seconds you are recorded as idle time they want to squeeze every minute out of you. I was a high performing employee that worked lots of over time and trained many employees in various states. There is also only all white people in leadership roles.

job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Las Vegas, NV
pros: guaranteed job, really hard to get fired unless for attendance etc
cons: everything, I would never work here again

pros: great good company nice management
cons: Nothing to complain about the company

review_title: Better than been Un-Employed.... Not much more than that.
pros: Between having NO job, at least this place will pay 13$ dollars for any license agent. If you speak spanish then maybe $13.50 or $14. NO more than that. Some accounts have great PFP, where you can earn an additional $400 per month, but other account's PFP might be as low as en extra $50 dollars or nothing. Depending on which account you are placed, you might work nights and/or weekends.
cons:
WARNING !!!, the HR department will tell you ANYTHING, just to get you hired. When they are in need of licensed Agents, they will tell you that you can make an extra 1000k per month, an extra 10 or 12 dollars per hour.... just to get you in. I had MANY Co-Workers who were lied about the bonuses.... Sucky part is that you don't find out until you come out of trainig which is like 4 weeks after. 

There is very little room for growth. If you do get promoted to COACH.... then you might make an extra 2 dollars, but work a lot more per day or week. Is not worth it.

review_title: Got an Offer from UHG , Just be prepared for getting screwed Up
pros:
No Formals
Work From Home 
Brand Name
Above Average Leave Policy
cons:
1. All the PE Directors are best in Playing Politics
2. They don't have the minimum etiquette of how to talk to there employees.
3. Managers here are worst than school head masters , They monitor , monitor and monitor.
4. There are people who came from CTS and started creating service based work culture here.
5. If you are trying to join Phoenix hyderabad location , Then re-check yourself. Better be wherever you are.
6. No Matter what your situation is you will have to work from 11 to 8:30 Pm , No excuses.
7. They give you work from home just to stop you from taking any leaves.
8. Not a employee friendly organization (Works in PE so can talk about PE)
9. Worst than a Service based company , will hear UHG laying off there employees soon.
10. There is 20% of variable pay paid in Feb , you never knew you will get it or not.
11. If you leave before Feb 28th then that whole amount is gone.
12. Hikes are very minimum , that too not confident whether you get it or not.
13. Managers here would be silent even if a 2 year experienced guy yells at 8 years experience resource. 
14. After all this , you still want to join ....... Welcome to Hell :)

pros: This company is definitely going places.  The ability to work as a full-time telecommuter is a wonderful option.   There are definitely advancement opportunities within the company.  Innovation is encouraged.  Employees are encouraged to think outside of the box to come up with new solutions to issues.   Volunteering within your community is greatly encouraged.  UHG supports the communities the employees live and work by donations, volunteering, etc.
cons:
I have worked in several different positions with UHG and had several different managers.   The only opportunities I have had for a decent pay increase was by moving on to a new position on a different team and asking for more money.   As typical with a large matrix organization, communication between teams can be lacking causing a duplication of efforts.  

I also have to agree that the health plan options for UHC employees is the worst I have seen for families. It is very frustrating to work for a health insurance company and have such an expensive plan.

pros: I was able to save up this little bit of money and quit to find a better job. Thank goodness I moved away from this company. I put too many years into this company and it has just gone downhill with every time it gets bought and sold.
cons: Where to begin... Supervisors are a joke and clearly lied to get their position as they are no where near qualified. Management is drama ridden and does nothing to resolve issues in a timely manner. They don't care how much experience you have, you will get the same pay as a person with no experience, and then you'll be forced to train them for no extra money in your pocket. Oh and you'll even be expected to train upper management, talk about a joke. Train them so they get more money , yeah because that's ethical...This company is downsizing and shutting down departments one by one since they have been sold but they are lying and saying that your department will not be shut down, but the lie detector test determined that is a LIE.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Denver, CO
pros: Many Work From Home Opportunities
cons: Typical large corporate organization.  I was part of a mass layoff,no hey, thanks and let's try to find you a new job in the org.  People in my group where there for 10+ years and they were not provided any assistance or shown any goodwill.

review_title: The Gray Area of Quid Pro Quo
pros: The best reasons for working at Ingenix are the opportunities to meet skilled and educated individuals that you wouldn't usually have much contact with if the company was larger.
cons: On the flip-side of the best reasons would be the people who joined the ranks because they were/are buddies with the boss or they share an alternative lifestyle or they give good hairstyling tips.  The worst offenders are the people who have been with the company for a few years but back-stab if they think you are going to get something more from the company than they did.  The employers are too impressed with titles and grade levels rather than checking on whether the individual has really risen to that status. A more thorough background check needs to be done to check the credentials of the people holding investigator jobs.  Just because someone claims to have 30 years of experience, does not necessarily mean they are any good at the job it just indicates they are complacent and found an comfortable job niche.

review_title: Over worked, stressed out, and underpaid.
job_title: Clinical Intake Nurse in Newtown Sq, PA
pros: Telecommuting from home was a big plus. No commuter costs for gas or parking. Free online CEUs for licensure renewal.
cons: I worked for a small,friendly company that was bought by UHG. Our HR policies changed, everyday office life became so much more complicated, and morale plummeted. Our health insurance costs increased greatly, for a lower level of care, with high deductibles. There was no hope of a cost of living raise. Our quarterly bonuses were cut to virtually nothing, if anything was given at all. There was constant pressure to meet certain production numbers, but quality seemed to take a backseat. Everything was about money, and the pride we once had in our jobs was no more. Approximately 300 physicians and RNs combined were laid off via a conference telephone call one week before Thanksgiving, with all benefits to cease on New Years Eve. What a wonderful present to all of us. The majority of those who were laid off are still seeking full-time employment, myself included. Production requirements, motivated by greed on the part of upper UHG management ruined the culture of one of the top 5 companies to work for in the Philadelphia area. They also took away the financial stability of over 300 families, as the layoffs continued into 2014.

review_title: Its been a never ending display of watching sub par managers promoting those that are subpar to make them look good
pros: Hard to say, good schedule that helps balance home/work, allow for flex time if needed.
cons: Insane work load, managment that seems to promote those that are subpar and overlook those with the most knowledge and ability. Divert the easier work to those that they want to promote to make them look better and help support their decision to promote them so that it makes it look like they were correct in thier pick, what a joke. The worst college reimbursement program I have seeen in the business world. I would never reccommend this company to a friend, and enemy...yes. The compensation for the amount of work is absolutely a disgrace, considering the CEO was paid 102 million 2 yrs ago after telling the rest of us "no soup for you" (no raise), then the next year give him a 40% haircut, only to give him a 26% increase the next. Sorry, dont find that acceptable.

job_title: Licensed Health Agent (Bilingual) in Richardson, TX
pros: Easy work in call center, no high pressure sales, always need professional bilinguals (Spanish), you can submit internal job applications in the United Health Group system (although you need to be persistent). If you have your insurance (health and/or life), you can always find seasonal work in this area & recruiters will offer bonus and company will offer referral bonus.
cons: Plan on working weekends (Saturday or Sunday) and/or some evenings - depending on time zone of clients served; schedules will change on the client company's whim (without much notice either); Only keep about 10-20% of agents after January - until August or September when training for new annual open enrollment begins. If you do a decent job, you can get another position in another campaign but your first year, likely get a pay cut (unless you're bilingual). If you're ambitious - probably not for you (too confining). Everything is scheduled (breaks, 30 min lunches). Management doesn't care about your past experience unless it's directly related to the job, even supervisory.

job_title: Care Coordinator in South Florida, FL
pros:
Learn new job skills
Learn to work under pressure
Good salary
cons: There is no end to the amount of work a salaried employee is given, there is definite favoritism not all employees are treated the same way and working hard is not the way to advance in this company, only employees who are friends with supervisors are given special treatment.  Also be ready to pay a lot of out of pocket for medical bills since annual deductible run between 1500 to 3000 a year. When the workload is dobled or triple and you work late day after day to try to keep up you may still get a poor evaluation and bonuses are very rare, í had one in 6 years. Complaining or asking for help will only make it harder for you to work in this company, you will forever be labled a complainer and your life will be that much harder

pros: Some people who work here are great...but that has nothing to do with the company as a whole
cons:
This company lumps together sick leave and vacation time. They say "it's to use your time how you see fit". However the total you get is much less than most companies who give you both sick and vacation.
NOW for the kicker. They will only let you carry over 40 hours of TOTAL leave at the end the end of the year. Both your "sick" and "vacation" One week only. If you happen to have 60 or 80 hours saved on December 31st the "poof" the take it away from you and you have only 40 hours on January 1st. 

It's less if you are part time.
So, let's say you like to go somewhere warm in January or February. You will only be able to go for 1 week because that's all the leave you have. 
Now let's say you happen to come down with the flu, and you are out for a week...well, too bad. You only get those 40 hours and if you have to use them because you got the flu in WINTER, then you don't have leave for your vacation...because it's all lumped together and taken away from you.
This is truly the single most draconian, terrible leave policy I have ever encountered in my career. It certainly makes me realize that the company doesn't care about me...and so, I don't really care about the company.

job_title: Manager Healthcare Economics in New York, NY
pros:
Top of the line data warehouse, and business intelligence tools from SAS EG, BI, to Cognos Cubes. Fantastic internal knowledge base. 

Company is positioned to be THE big data warehouse of administrative claims and health outcomes for decades to come.
cons:
Incredibly large and bureaucratic. The company finds incredible strength in diversity but at the same time not everyone is on the 'same page'. Everyone is working towards their ideal company and sometimes those visions do not jibe with each other.

Benefits are not great. 

Pay is competitive to begin with but is capped once you are an employee. This means that people can come in after you at higher pay and at a higher position, but not be as capable as you. 

Some toxic employees ruin the 'broth'.

pros: You get a paycheck I guess thats the only good thing this company has to offer. Oh and a work schedule
cons: I can't even begin to start with the cons.....the list goes on.  First its like a prison with a ball and chain around your leg.  The supervisors don't know what they are doing, they are only in that position to get off the phones.  God forbid if you try to get off the phone 3 minutes before your shift ends and then you get that one call that drags past your leave time.  They promise promotions but that is false hope so you can work your butt off just to get yelled at for a bad survey a member did because of the way the company is in not paying claims like they should and oh wait that a write up for you because they listen to the call and nit pick at every possible thing you did wrong.  The list goes on and on.   Stay away from this place.  The pay is not worth your sanity.  I got laid off at the beginning of February after being there 4 years and still have depression from that place.  Oh and as you can tell seniority dont make a difference either since I got laid off.

review_title: A great place to start a career
pros: There are about 38 job areas with tons of departments and a wide range of roles. If you want to be able to do something different you likely will be able to at some point in the future, it might not be the near future but maybe some day. You get paid on time. In some departments you can work a ton of overtime which is perfect for telecommuters. If you are telecommuting we have an internal social media site for the company so you can get chatty and get to know the other people around the company.
cons: Tuition reimbursement is probably declined more than it is approved. The coursework has to enhance your current role according to the rules so if you are an undergraduate or Graduate student taking Core Courses don't look for reimbursement for any of your classes.

job_title: Community Events Coordinator in Tacoma, WA
pros: You feel you're doing great work reaching communities, building relationships and making a difference in the field.
cons: There is no clear management. You are asked to do your best but there is no one who really cares how you get there as long as you make them look good and increase their numbers in Salesforce.  You suddenly realize just how expendable you are as a human being regardless of your track record.   You ask for opportunities and they tell you there aren't any until you suddenly see a new member on the team in a position that was never posted.

pros: Good salary and good benefits.
cons: can be a stressful position at times.

review_title: Just like any other Contract placement agency they take  30% of your salary and in return do taxes for you.
pros:
They don't ask too many questions and don't bother you as long as you are employed and make money for them.
You don't have to remember their names and they never make mistakes on your paychecks, which is a good thing...
cons:
They pay no bonuses now and try to renew your contracts without reviewing your pay-rate. They never do anything for you other than take chunk of your paycheck. You will only hear from them when they need you to sign something. Their Health Insurance plans come form their masters at United HealthScare and represent the worst Health Insurance plan I have ever seen. It is basically amounts to a Medical discount card ,as you would be paying pretty much everything out of your pocket.
They will find your resume online and present it to their clients as if they know who you are. Basically throwing it against the wall and see if it sticks.

job_title: Research Consultant in Falls Church, VA
pros: Great place to learn the industry landscape and build consierable knowledge of the drivers of change. Occasionally interesting projects that really expose you to thought leadership and allow you to take ownership of your work, and allow you opportunities to learn new skills or demonstrate leadership.
cons: Few managers both at mid-level and at senior-level have managerial capabilities. Most have never managed before and so make terrible mentors and project managers. There are a lot of egos, and a lot of cronyism that one must learn to deal with. Many managerial level people feel insecure to the point of not wanting to delegate responsibility (unless it's responsibility for errors) and not willing to listen to fresh perspectives from younger employees. There is evidence of ageism amongst certain managers which is unfortunate. Working at Lewin is much like working in a government agency, but without the perks of working in a government agency - in other words, this is a highly bureacratic and inefficient work place.

review_title: Good Place to Have a Luxurious Life. Cabs, Work From Home,Much Leaves. But a lot of upper Management Politics.No onsite
pros:
Nice work life balance. 
Pay master- best in industry.
Work from home.
Cab facility.
Employee friendly policies. No login hours.
A lot of Extra curricular and Social Activities.
Fun at work- Outings, Parties, Townhall meetings.
Provides Laptop to all employees.
34(7 CL, 7 SL, 20 PL) + (10 public) annual Leaves.
Nice office infrastructure.
Good place to sit and relax, no client fear.
cons:
Annual review and ratings are not done properly.
Lot of Politics and favourism at upper level management which is present for more than 7+ years.
Not much growth in Role after 1 promotion.
Negligible or very very little scope for Onsite Opportunities in US that too after minumum 3-4 yrs of stay in company where 7+ yrs people are already waiting to start VISA process.
Managers and Leads at upper level do not work. Only approve leaves and timesheets and ask for status, do not cooperate in work.
Poor hike since past couple of years as compared to earlier.
Salary revision only once in March.
15% variable component in salary which gets paid only when you remain till Febraury.

job_title: RN Call Center in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: This was a very supportive environment, good pay, and opportunities to advanced.
cons: Metrics overload caused a lot of mental stress, there was never enough time to get everything in that they wanted done on the calls and still provide top quality customer service. Constant pushing on promoting programs, and poor quality IT products.

job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Phoenix, AZ
pros: There is not a limit on call handle time. Being able to meet with members face to face.
cons: Sadly, Optumcare is no longer what it use to be when it was formerly Lifeprint. Leadership is more concerned about "new business " and "growing " when they can not even fix the issues that they have right now. Sadly, the Service Advocates  and most importantly the members are taking the toll. The service advocates do not have the time to call the members back to help them because they are hounded to get back on the phone and take a call. This is someone's health, a serious issue, and meeting there numbers has become more important. Also, in order to move up, you will need to be a very good friend, family member, or dating someone in leadership. The quality team is never on the same page and base your call off what they would have done.

pros:
Some positions offer opportunity to telecommute. 
Matching 401k isn’t too bad.
cons:
Working in a sub-delegate if United HealthCare, I can only speak to that. It is horrible. Managers and executive leadership play favorites. People they like are getting promoted, moving on, etc. others they don’t care about. 
I’ve been told one thing, their actions are another.
They go on and on about culture and growth and innovation. All you hear is no, this is how we do it. 
They advertise promoting from within, but, again, unless you’re a favorite. So much goes on behind closed doors .. your daughter works here.. she will go far. Your son wants a job? Great. You knew me on my mission, you’re hired!
I’m not saying all hires or promotions are unwarranted, but, it is so obvious when certain things happen, then they have the audacity to lie about it. 
Leadership and management constantly talking poorly of others.

review_title: Chaotic environment with weak middle management
job_title: Business Analyst in Costa Mesa, CA
pros:
3 week PTO when pay grade 25+
Bi-weekly telecommute option
Flexible work schedule when non-peak season
cons:
Very vague direction from middle mgmt
Mgmt preaches "don't work here if you don't like it" attitude
Mgmt uses excuses such as "self-motivation" "limit is self-imposed" "personality flaw" to dump unreasonable amount of work to employees
Middle mgmt does not even know how to use MS Office applications
Supervisor over promises customers before consulting with team and blames team member for not delivering
Supervisor over-allocate team resources for repetitive tasks and criticize on delays on other deliverables
Supervisor preaches "delegation" so they dont have to do the actual work and not stay engaged with subject matter, but when escalation is required, supervisors are clueless about what to do

review_title: In short, I was assigned a very poor manager and had a terrible experience here
job_title: Research Consultant in Falls Church, VA
pros:
If you get lucky and are assigned a great supervisor, this place could be highly rewarding, excellent with work/life balance and one of the best places to grow and develop professionally. 
*Focus on employee engagement. Management started to keep a keen ear to workplace issues. Morale has improved somewhat, although the structural problems that created problems in the first place are still there, and ignored for quite some time.
cons:
*Their offices are noisy and cramped so that the corporation can save money. We were told this $2 million in savings, along with an incredible year for revenues, would get passed on to workers. 
*Huge disparity in management ability to develop employees. Some are great while others (like mine) have no people-building skills. My manager only knew how to impose mental stress, resisted all attempts for me to develop my skills, and never provided feedback for my performance unless in some bizarre emotionally abusive rant.  
*Although managers are supposedly interested in employee issues, they aren't able to make the changes necessary to fix the problem. 
*Zero accountability for managers.
*While the pay is okay, it's definitely not in line with how hard they will work you and your responsibilities.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Overland Park, KS
pros: It's a guaranteed paycheck in a rough economy. Good stock options and 401K. If you want lots of overtime this is the place. Just be aware that it's mandatory and excessive.
cons: Upon being hired and completing training the first day on the floor was completely a different position than what we had even trained for. The employees are treated like work horses with very little assistance from supervisors. When ever a patient request to speak with a supervisor they scatter and let the call go straight to voicemail. Mandatory overtime is completely ridiculous so don't expect to have a balance between work & family time. And each week it continues to get worse.  Don't get too close to your coworkers because chances are they won't be there next week with the extremely high turnover. Once the economy turns around they're going to have a real mess to clean up. It's been a nightmare!

review_title: Optum Global Solutions India. You need to be a pet infront of Senior Managment. Not for self repected person.
pros: Party... Party and Party; don't know if quarterly budget is RS. 600 for each employee then how come budget will pass more than 1.2 lakh for 100 employee under one DM. This how senior managers make money from organization.
cons:
If You are good with oiling and buttering then obviously this compnay is the dream place for you to work. Managers will promise you something with policies and they will give others good benifits by changeing same policy. This is upto you how to be a good oil man or a butter man.

Worst place ever, where I have been worked for 3 years with lots of promise but outcome is 0 but my common review raiting was always 5 (this the best) for last 3 common review, but they gave promotion whom I taught all technologies and they got only for buttering.

pros:
very difficult to say now as OGS situation is getting worse and worse now.
if you are joining this company ask huge amount as after moving here you will get very less hike and 50% variable pay..if you are extraordinary then 80%.
cons:
In India you will be part of OGS(Optum Global Solution) which is just service provider for optum..
Very poor rating system i.e. Force to use bellcurve
Variable pay is nearly 50% for 3 rated employe..so for 4 and 5 rated employee its maximum 80%.
Poor insurence
Leadership target is cost cutting and get profit of employees share to their salary.
you may be thinking i am writing this review because i am getting less pay or not a high performer.. its opposite here...
you have target for innovation also..you have to innovate new cost saving process every month else you will be rated 2...
They hire in name of united health group and when you will join, you are part of OGS not optum also...very sad and bad.

review_title: EHR's President/CEO Parts Ways With Company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newtown Square, PA
pros: There really are no positive things I can say about the company at this time.
cons:
After several recent rounds of company layoffs (in excess of 200 employees each), EHR is a shell of an organization.  The company's President & CEO, Tom Mercer, was also impacted by the restructuring and downsizing and "parted ways" with EHR this week.  Those who were a part of the "old" company 4-5 years ago, when employees were valued and treated with respect, have only a distant memory of the better times.  With United Health Group's acquisition came a flurry of negative changes and the worker bees were the most effected, while the Director level management continued to fly under the radar, and continued to benefit in stock options, etc.  

This company is sinking ship and cannot get out of its own way to adapt to the changing needs of the marketplace, therefore will become obsolete in no time at all.  

If you're thinking of working for EHR, I urge you to think again.  If you are a hospital or health system looking to partner with EHR, DON'T!  Clinicians and support staff work in a sweat shop-like environment where quantity is measure and quality is not.  You're way better off giving Accretive Health your business since they have their client's best interest in mind and value their employees.

pros: Opportunity to work remotely, the "worker bees" who actually keep the company afloat, beautiful campus if you're fortunate enough to work at it
cons: So many it's hard to narrow it down. Advancement is based 100% on politics and never on job performance. Don't have ethics or opinions--they don't want to hear them. Don't think out-of-the-box--they don't want to do it. "Cut to growth" is their motto. They may hit the numbers, but it's always at the expense of good employees. You are only a number; there's no consideration for people. The leadership team is an absolute joke. It's like high-school; back-stabbing, gossiping and getting ahead based on whose rear end you've kissed vs. performance. Most leaders are completely unqualified to do their jobs and are there because they kissed the right behind. Work-life balance? Absolutely none. Culture? The biggest joke of all. They push "culture" down your throat. Employees receive "culture training" and values are preached like the gospel. Millions have been spent on marketing the "core values" and distributing "chochkies" for your desk to remind you what they are, but not a single leader lives them. In fact, they hide behind them and make some of the WORST business decisions I've ever seen. Human Capital is the biggest offender of all. There's ever a single decision based on culture or values, though that's the statement they hide behind.

pros:
- The training has improved. I heard stories about bad trainings that forced the workers into weird positions where they didn't know what to do. The training I went through was great, it taught me every bit of knowledge I needed to know. (There were some cons to it) It mostly meant I didn't need help. 

- The people there are awesome. Anyone you turn to will answer a question for you, or help you out. It's a friendly environment over all.
cons:
- A lot of times people aren't fired for doing a bad job. There are no repercussions for not doing your job. As long as you were there to pick up the phone it was ok to the management. That meant a lot of times customers didn't get the right service they needed. 

- The training did not prepare you for what you would run into on calls. It gave you the knowledge to answer the questions, but it didn't prepare you for how to respond when they had called previous times and their questions/concerns had not been answered.

pros: Great work hour flexibility, and hybrid telecommute. Plenty of career advancement opportunities, however management keeps you under their thumb and prevents transfers to other departments. Work life balance is great, but don't take too many consecutive days of PTO or you will pay for it with 70+hr work weeks to catch up. Culture and value of department is non-existent. Most employees work from home and your meeting point is bi-weekly webex meetings that are frequently cancelled.
cons: The team was customer based, and not team oriented. Very quick to pass the buck, and it is common place to throw team members under the bus. Poor teamwork, and leadership is flaky. Upper management are insecure and try to bark to keep team in line. Terrible way to manage and harbors a hostile working relationship.  Empire plan NYSHIP management team received alarming negatives in yearly review on overall department goals which alerted UHC human capital. Salary is comparable, and disappointing. Many other better opportunities out there, NYSHIP is not the only game in town.

review_title: Best job I have ever had
pros: So cliché but the culture at UHG is just amazing. You can see it all around you everyday being lived, it's not just words on a poster on the wall. Company has regular social/charity events to get employees building relationships, interacting, and giving back by holding charity events. It really starts from the top down, the senior leadership team really believe in upholding our values and making this company a great place to work - they really believe in their employees. I have always felt supported in my role, always felt like I have someone to go to if I need help and advice. Manager is very flexible with working hours, if I need to work at home due to family reasons it's understood.
cons: Being part of a huge global company, sometimes it can be tricky working with colleagues and teams in other time zones. Sometimes there can be a feeling of disconnect from other global sites because of this, communication can sometimes be hard

review_title: UHG is a solid company that has innovative ideas for healthcare products & services for Americans.
job_title: IT Manager in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros: UHG is a company committed to providing services and creative solutions in both the healthcare & services sector.  They leaders promote innovative ideas in many areas -- reimbursement methologies, benefit services & technology just to name a few.  Adopting a "culture" within the company from a top-down approach speaks to their desire to be a leading company were people have a want to be be employed.
cons: With all of the acquisitions over the past years, our customers really don't know who we are... The compnay need to strategically consolidate both business & technology functions to increase our 'brand' awareness.  The daily activities to accomplish projects are swamped with "process" -- it needs to be streamlines/reduced for more effective and efficient productivity.  More controls are necessary to limit the amount of off-shore resourcing so that the the knowlege stays in-house & on-shore.

pros: Good pay master, Fortune 17th Company, Laptop facility
cons: No parking, No Trasparency, No proper policies, Lack of communication from Senior management

review_title: Just Okay - Really Depends Where You Work
pros:
Large company with lots of resources for training 
Decent compensation
Nice offices 
Tried to make employees feel included in culture 
Opportunities for telecommute with most positions 
Good PTO Plan you were encouraged to use
Work was interesting due to range of different types of problems that needed to be solved
Senior leadership (CEO included) had regular meetings to speak to employees to make it feel like you were included at all levels
cons:
Very heads down, “corporate” environment (could be good for some) - depending on your office work environment could be uptight. Office was somewhat cold and lacking personality.
Tried to push UHG culture to make employees feel included but still a massive company 
Hard to know who to go to for what due to size 
Lackluster management
Office space wasted due to the amount of telecommuters 
Tons of org charts and names of people you’re supposed to care about but never really see or get to speak to
Amount of work went up and down. Some weeks were busy and some really were not.
Tons of internal guidelines that could make meeting certain goals challenging 
Depending on your department or role could receive very little support from management (again, this would work for some)

review_title: Pros/Cons from my experience at UHG
pros: There's a lot of opportunity to help this org manage change.  Not only internally/back office in how things are done, but externally given the economy and focus on the healthcare system. This provides a great opportunity for growth.  I also appreciated the ability to work remotely rather than move to MN or CT to manage my team.  Although we worked hard to complete projects, there was a concern on our team for work/life balance to avoid burnout.
cons: My most difficult challenge in my position was trying to drive change from a grass roots approach vs. a top-down approach.  In many cases, there's a fear of change below the Director level which slows progress.  People are in a job protection mode, especially given the current economy, and are less accepting to changing processes without stronger sponsorship.

review_title: Telecommuting was the best thing about the job
pros:
Offered ability to telecommute after working for the company for a long period of time.  The fact that I was doing the job at home, and that was really the only good part speaks volumes.  Still left.  
Flexible schedule.  
Good pay and bonus.
cons:
High deductible health plan to minimize company expenditure on health care unless you were VERY sick..  Then again this is understood seeing that they are in the business of profiting on collecting insurance premiums and paying as little as possible.  
When employees were surveyed about health benefits and rated them poorly, management was expected to 'sell' employees on the plan.
Inability to actually assist with claims issues and then still held responsible when the consumer is dissatisfied with your service.   
Constant addition of ways to drive more productivity out of staff.  

 I'll miss the bonus, but not the knowledge that it could have been used to pay someone's health care.  Tough world we live in!

review_title: Great Co-workers, nice location, out of touch Sr. Mgmt, no life balance, HIGH turnover
pros: Location (Orange County), Landscaping is nice, weather is good, free tea in breakroom
cons: Sr. Mgmt is out of touch b/c they have no idea how the work is done. They ask for your opinion but don't really listen. Middle mgmt is powerless and no real changes ever happen until everyone quits but then too little too late.

job_title: Associate Director Consulting in New York, NY
pros: Will get to work on mostly hewlthcare projects.
cons:
1. Entire organization works with a staff augmentation mentality. There is no "consulting" attitude.
2. No support for sales or business development though about 20% of performance goals is directly aligned to sales &  BD.
3.  Very high utilization expectation. Anybody less than 80% gets below average rating !!
4.  Random assignment to projects. Skill set is hardly evaluated. Staffing person who has no idea about the skill set randomly assigns project
5. Bench resources gets badly hit due to loss of utilization (which drives about 80% of the bonus). 
6.  Bonus is an imaginary number, nobody gets close to the target bonus forget about exceeding it
7. Management is happy to do admin work. Utilization goals and sales goals don't apply to them.
Overall I don't think anybody really understood how to make this run as a true consulting organization.  It's a sweat shop with very depressing environment

pros: My colleagues were the best part about working at UHC.
cons:
Management is incredibly disconnected. Leadership lives in Colorado and has no idea what is going on in New Mexico. This company is so huge and has many parts, no one knows how it all works together, which makes it very hard to work efficiently in Network Management. While there may be some people in management who know how to connect all the working parts. They are so understaffed that there is never enough time to learn anything. It's go go go. You can never stop and become familiar with anything. Even the on ramp process is rushed and then you are expected to know how to do your job because you "learned it all" via their online classes.

If you are Network Manager, you will get paid hourly. Which is a pain to deal with and at this point in one's career its unheard of. The Pro to this is that you can make overtime but you are killing yourself. 
If you are Senior Network Manager, you will get paid salary.

Because of the size of the company and their lack of budgeting, there are always lay-offs.

review_title: Excited about the company, not great career opps
pros: beautiful campus, decent benefits, people are very passionate about the mission
cons: horrible pay, not clear direction between upper and middle management, too many chiefs often, the politics game is rampant, although that's probably true at most major corporations

review_title: You are just a number....that is now going off-shore (OGS)
pros:
Telecommuting possible
Decent pay
Decent benefits
Awesome employee stock purchase program and 401k matching
cons:
Constant fear for your job
Senior leaders do not or will not listen to lower level employees
Unethical and dishonest leaders

review_title: United Health Group found MORE FOR LESS IN COLOMBIA
pros:
Great working ambience at Concentrix
Great trainers!
cons:
I was part of the 1st wave of the company in Colombia. The reasons why I quit are the next ones: We were promised a salary of 1,875,000 Colombian pesos and an 8 hour shift from Monday to Friday with Saturday and Sunday off. At the moment of signing the contract the conditions changed. We were to receive a salary of 1,700,000 with a bonus of 175,000 and we had to work for 10 hours from Monday to Friday plus 8 hours on Saturday. 

Also, US advocates make a salary of 2,560.00 dollars a month working for the same position while working 8 hours a day for 5 days a week. Why? Because the Fair Labor Standards Act law protects them and recognizes an 8 hour shift for 5 days a week fair. More than 40 hours a week worked in the US is considered Overtime. Colombians, on the contrary, are paid 560.00 dollars a month.

I made this clear on my quitting letter, but I was advised to change it to “personal reasons”. Obviously, so the company won’t get affected.

review_title: From Pharmacy Clerk To Bill Collector
job_title: Pharmacy Clerk in San Diego, CA
pros: For Me, The Short Commute. Beyond That...........
cons: Began Full Time On April 29, 2013, Trained To Be A Pharmacy Clerk. You Know, Verify Scripts And All That. In July, The Big Wigs Decided To Stop, Without Warning The Members, Their Ship And Bill "Courtesy" As They Called It. Basically, Optum Had Been Shipping Scripts Out And Billing Members. The Vast Majority Of Members Paid Their Bills, While Some Simply Didn't. I Had 1 Account With ZERO Payments Since December of 2012. As A Result Of No Ship And Bill, EVERY Account Without Either A Form Of Payment On File Or A Zero Current/Past Account Balance Receives An Automated Call Telling The Member There's A Problem With Their Latest Script And That Optum Needs To Speak With Them. That's When The Fun Really Begins! Can Anyone Imagine Hassling An Old Lady Over The Phone For A $5.00 Outstanding Payment??? I Bailed Last Week And Am VERY Happy I Did. Optum Is A Micro-Manager's Dream. Believe Me, Think Twice Before You Accept Their Offer Of Employment. What They Offer And What You May End Up Doing Could Be Totally Different.

job_title: Senior Director, IT in Hartford, CT
pros: There's no doubt that they're the dominant player in the marketplace, largely because they've acquired their way to 'too big to fail' scale.  Their financial and business combination acumen (both in house and retained by external advisors) is as good as it gets.  They have good front line people in many places.  Their ability to reach massive population scale and do significant good for the health care system is unparalleled.
cons: Where do I begin...unfortunately they're their own worst enemy.  I'll start with group think.  If you're even slightly methodical, even remotely deliberate in your execution, then watch. your. back.  If you're driven to get difficult issues out in the open to discuss, debate and get them behind you, then watch. your. back.  If you don't have the sponsorship of someone above you to help you get your agenda accomplished if it represents change and a possible exposure of less-than-acceptable execution on the part of organizational politicos, then...well, you know...WATCH. YOUR. BACK.  Even if you DO have that support, WATCH. YOUR. BACK. because your sponsor may fall out of favor with his/her chain of command, and then you need to stop watching your back and start looking for a job...before you're let go in the next wave of downsizing...

review_title: Horrible. Mandatory 10 hour days, no flexibilty for single mothers.
pros: Very rarely, the site may close due to weather.
cons:
They have no respect for work/life balance. 10 hour days are mandatory, they tell YOU when you must do your overtime. If you are unable to work the schedule they give you, it gives you an "occurence" which will accumulate until you are fired.  If you don't get burned out before you are fired that is.


Schedules change based on your "stats" at their whim.

They are always looking over your shoulder and micromanaging you. If you get up to use the restroom, you can bet your manager will be at your desk when you get back to question you. 

Training is a joke. You can ask one manager a question and another one the same thing and you will get 2 very different responses.  If finding an answer to a challenging policy requires any extra effort for a supervisor, they will put it back on you to figure out yourself.

Getting approved paid time off... ha. Good luck. they will grant it and take it back at the last minute.

Overall, this is more like a prison/labor camp, than an actual job. I would have to say this is BY FAR the worst company in the United States of America to work for.

review_title: Large Company gives you room to grow
job_title: Customer Service Lead in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Being a big company, you get lots of room to grow. If you want to become trained in something, you can do it (given management approval). There have been several new job postings every day I have worked here (3 years+), so there is lots of room to move around. 
Good job for telecommuters.
cons:
There are 25 layers of management that need to be weeded through to get anything done. If you have a good idea, it can take months to get started and years to get completed due to all the hurdles that you have to jump over. 
If you don't live in one of the big population hubs for the company (i.e., Minnesota), then you don't get some of the "perks" that the company offers, like discounts for goods and services. Also, most of the new jobs available are in those hubs, so good luck getting them.
Surprisingly terrible with data, considering the size of the company...

pros: Great management, awesome coworkers, relatively good pay, good stock purchase plan.
cons: DID NOT PAY OUT PTO TIME WHEN LEAVING COMPANY.  USE YOUR PTO BEFORE YOU LEAVE.  WAS LED TO BELIEVE BY MGMT THAT IT IS, BUT HR CLAIMS THEY ONLY DO SO IN STATES THAT REQUIRE IT BY LAW (MINE ISN'T ONE).  Company health insurance is bad in comparison to previous employers, which is counter-intuitive, being a health insurance provider.

job_title: Clinical Administrative Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros: Love being able to work from home.  Supervisor and Team Lead are compassionate about their employees.  Large selection of benefit plans to choose from and the amount of paid time off is very good even for lower grade positions.
cons: Changes, changes and more changes.  Sometimes mid-way through the day and you need to be able to adapt at a moments notice.  Hard to advance within the company as there  is little networking opportunities with other areas when working from home.  Wages could be better for the amount of work you need to crank out in a day; I'm a top-producer and my raises have been minimal.  Sometimes you will be asked to take on addition duties/work in other areas with no adjustment in wage for doing so; your working twice as hard as your teammates but not compensated for it.

job_title: Vice President Inside Sales in Durham, NC
pros:
Rock solid financially and employee friendly. 

Great pay and decent benefits. You can get rich there in no time.
cons: That said, United is an iceberg to its customers and the general public. They are shamelessly elitist. There are a whole lot of multi-millionaires running around those buildings that no one can figure out what they do.

pros: I got a good TL
cons:
Cons:I didn't get the shift I wanted, but only to back up those who want to come according to their own convenience

Its like I am the boss and do what I say

Alot of parameters/tricky to adjust, pressure cooker like work load, least pay, no meal, costly and under average food quality cafeteria, politics (as in every company) , they will ask you your problem and once you share the response and solution you will get back is "that's your skill problem, you have to fight your own, else you will be out...... We don't want people who can't work according to what we want."(I didn't get such words but many teammates experience this)

Early pick up and late drop, 

You will be asked to give a feedback, and the same question will fall on you(never give -ve feedback even if they asked, coz it will adversely act on you)

review_title: No room for advancement if you're good, No incentive if you're good either
pros: UHG as a whole is a great company to work for.  They're located all over the world and have just about any job you could possibly want.  Some positions pay great and you can go far.  Avoid Optum at all costs.
cons: My business unit was Optum.  If you're good at your job they will never allow you to go some place else within the company.  Oh, they'll tell you that they want you to succeed and tell you they will do whatever they can to help you move within the company but then they put a stop to your application once you internally apply.  Bonuses and raises are paltry or non-existent.  Upper level managers rarely say thanks or good job, it's always work harder.  Employee morale is LOW, basement level low.  Benefits for employees were pretty bad as well.  It's pretty sad when you work for a Health Insurance Company and your benefits are worse and more expensive than someone who works elsewhere and has benefits through your company.  Then again, it probably didn't help that 90% of my office was grossly overweight.

job_title: Recovery/Resolution Representative Senior in Franklin, TN
pros: Very difficult to come up with any pros.  Initial experience with hiring manager was great, but down hill from there.  Stay away if you value your health.
cons: Very unorganized.   Management not in tune with the lynch mob mentality on the floor.   They drove an excellent manager out on medical leave, she recieved no support from her  upper management.  Management set me up for failure from day one with a training program that is a joke.   No infrastructure in place and current manager over me is a joke.   No sick time anything you miss will be an occurrence no matter what the situation is.   At 4 you go on an a cap.  Quality management scores are a joke. Benefits are horrible.  They dont value there employees, the core values....yeah right.   Not even remotely a part of culture.  Run as fast as you can away.  You will enter the seventh circle of hell coming here.

review_title: Great Training Program, but under compensated
pros: Great Training Program. The Training staff really makes you feel like you are an important component to UHC/UHG success; You learn a great deal about Health Insurance and helping your clients on the phones. There are some really intelligent and caring people on the SME team and in management.
cons: Morale is low. Compensation for your work is low, even if you hold a degree upon entrance to the position. Raises are hard to come by and even though you are advised that it is easy to move up inside of the organization- this was not my experience, nor was it what I witnessed for others. More focus should be placed on rewarding employees for customer service and quality of information provided versus AHT or Handle Time. It appeared that those that did not "care" about the callers, were rewarded with how fast they could get callers off of the phone. Just be wary...

job_title: Claims Examiner in Sugar Land, TX
pros:
Very flexible
Very relaxed environment
Work at home privileges if qualify
cons:
Low pay
Unrealistic Expectations
Unfair Bonus Program
Super low raises
Hard to move up

review_title: Flexibility for those who are favorites.
job_title: Medical Claims Analyst in Buffalo, NY
pros: There are some great flexibility options when working for this company.  Most jobs allow you to telecommute some, if not all, of your hours.  However, there are no clearly defined goals or metrics to meet before being given that privilege.  Medical coverage covers quite a bit.  Most facilities have a nice cafeteria and gym.
cons: Medical coverage is extremely expensive, especially when considering deductible amounts, and co-insurance.  Management promotes and gives privileges to employees based upon favoritism.  Most HR policies are often thrown out the window, and management often makes up their own rules to play by.  Environment can get very gossipy.  Communication is terrible, and often too late.  Often the only recognition employees get is when something is done incorrectly.  Too much mismanagement and micromanagement.

review_title: 84.4% of employee respondents rate Optum as neutral or below...take heed!!!
pros:
*  Stock purchase plan
*  Generous PTO plan (5 weeks after 5 years)
cons:
*  Good old boy and girl network keeps the "old guard" in positions of responsibility; high performers are marginlized and pushed to the side while teams are begging for good people due to senior leaders wanting to protect their turf and their teams

*  Making the United Health Group budget numbers by slashing expenses (cut cell phone reimbursement for just about ALL employees but then told management in a call to find "creative ways" around this...not sure why we should use our personal cell phones for calls or email when on the road if the company isn't paying for at least some of it...) AND positions.

*  Over-focused on process, documentation, and colorful spreadsheets at the expense of actually getting work done and focusing on customer needs

*  Lagging behind other large vendors in this space; check industry newsletters...you don't see Optum listed as a "bleeding edge" vendor

*  Emphasis on form over function; marketing smoke and mirrors more important than securing the resources to move key projects forward

*  Ultimately destined to fail miserably due to being owned by an insurance company

*  If you don't care about job satisfaction and are just happy to get a paycheck, maybe this place is for you

pros: Up to this point there are none.
cons: At first I believed the problems in management were localized.  I have since discovered that it appears the problems are company wide due to upper and middle management.  Verbal abuse and hostile work environment are clearly visible.  Reports to the Ethics Department do not result in any changes being made. Direct contact with manager of on site supervisors does not result in changes.  When you do something wrong, you get berated, fussed at and made to feel like a looser. You enter the door defeated everyday, making it very hard to choose between coming into work because you need the job, or just walking out and never looking back. There are not enough employees to handle the amount of call volume.  The turnover of employees is horrible.  As soon as a new hire class comes out of training, tenured reps leave for other jobs. Most of the reps are constantly looking for another job, or the chance to transfer within the company to another department, because of the extreme negativity in their current department.

job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Richardson, TX
pros:
Pay is decent.
Laid back.
Hard to get fired.
Friendly environment.
Career advancement.
cons:
Horrible benefits, high deductible plans.
Things are always changing
I worked in Richardson site but now they are making a mandatory move to Irving with no raise, no compensation, or nothing...I hate it cuz I stay in mesquite so now I will have to drive for an hour just to make it to work.

job_title: Registered Nurse Case Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Employee Stock Options and 401K savings plans
cons: You are not treated with any respect.  You are expected to meet monthly performance metrics with NO excuses for your numbers to drop.  I worked for Optum for 5 1/2 years .  During that time I was assigned to a national account.  There are supposed to be 7 nurses assigned to this account.  Over 5/1/2 years I worked with 22 different peers that came and left and I had 7 supervisors as well.   The last manager was only there for two months and during that time put me on a final warning if I did not meet the minimum Metrics for the second quarter.  I met the requirements but was terminated anyway (NOT for poor performance, but "other" as stated on my separation notice.  Many employees were bullied by management and ruled with scare tactics. This often lead employees to  employ unethical tactics to meet the impossible metrics set before them.

job_title: Senior Recovery Resolution Analyst in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
-Work from home; part time or full time
-Company offers own University curriculum on Data Science and Engineering if individual meets specific requirements and getd management approval
-Great beautiful campus in Eden Prairie, MN 
-Employee stock options; 10-15% discount
-Overtime depending department
-Free Caribou coffee, tea and carbonated flavored water (new as of April 2019)
-tuition reimbursement 
-Meetings are held over WebEx; no need to show up in person.
cons:
-A very high deductible Health Plan for employees.
-Heavy workload in some areas of the company
-Difficult to move internally and/or advance unless you find a sponsor or know someone
-Low pay compared to competitors unless it is a senior leadership role I.e. Director, VP, CEO
-Constant change, all the time 
-10+ hours/week mandatory overtime in some departments. Work life balance is questionable. 
-PTO can be frozen due for periods of time due to heavy workload. No PTO cash outs at this company. 40 hours of PTO can be carried over.
-High turnover rate due to high stress and constant pressure to perform.
-Metrics bound, all about quantity instead of quality
-large corporation so relationships are difficult to build. 
-no one ever socializes, no social hours or team gatherings, everyone is into their work.

pros: This job offers wonderful benefits including PTO, medical, dental, vision, a 401k and employee stock purchase plan option. The pay is competitive with or better than what you will find in retail pharmacy. There is a lot of opportunity to learn new things with the constant change. If you don't have your license yet, the company will reimburse you for the cost of taking the test & also give you a bonus for passing/getting the license. Lots of OT...so extra cash (please also see this in cons!)
cons: Constant changes with the software we use, who is managing our team, and changes to procedure. Currently this situation is improving though and we're getting a lot more organized/unified. If you don't deal well with change or don't have a lot of flexibility in your character, working here might not be for you. Lots of OT...not a lot of spare time for your family/hobbies. Normal work days are 10hrs because of OT.

review_title: Okay, good PTO for entry level
job_title: Claims Representative in International Falls, MN
pros:
Okay pay, I made 10.50 starting
Easy to move up if you know what you're doing
Job isn't too hard 
Okay (but sometimes rare) bonuses 
18 PTO days a year
Paid holidays 
Full benefits with HSA
401K match
6 weeks short term disability for maternity leave, 8 if C section- 2/3 pay. After that, you can take family bonding to total 12 weeks off or FMLA if you've been there a year, also to total 12 weeks 
Flexible schedule, but only If it works with the calendar
cons:
Expect far more out of you than they're willing to pay for
Raises are minimal
Don't want you to get out of your desk unless you absolutely have to
Many people get carpal tunell, joint issues, and tendinitis from working at a sedentary job like this
Policies are constantly changing, which can be confusing
Health insurance doesn't cover much
Expect 100% accuracy, and make you feel terrible if this isn't achieved, even though you only need 97% to meet your personal standards 
Expect a lot of overtime out of 1 person when it's needed, but you are paid time and a half

pros: Financially sound, good benefits, nice employees.
cons: Poor training, intimidation,  lack of guidance.

review_title: UHG is no longer seeking sales reps. I felt forced to quit
