job_title: Field Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: There was a positive energy at UHG, hard workers, they put serious money into their facilities, the most excellent training I have ever received in my seven years of insurance sales experience. They care about the quality and level of customer service that their members receive (from their sales agents). I've heard conflicting stories in the claims department.
cons: They lacked a personal touch; poor communication skills. Our commission decreased from $70/per sale to $11/per sale. Instead of setting up a meeting to discuss this with their sales force, they printed out a memo and taped it to our computers. They decreased earnings so much that every sales agent (including me) decided to resign and become an independent agent. Although no one was fired, it was impossible to earn a decent living. I heard that after the sales team left, they did away with the captive field sales rep position and are just using contracted agents.

review_title: It was a call center, so stressful and time off is virtually impossible
job_title: Customer Care Professional/Provider Phone Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great company to work for.  They are a leader in the healthcare industry.  Benefits are inexpensive although high deductibles.  Overall a great company to work with.
cons: Unable to get time off to even so much as go to the doctor.  When you work and 8-5 job and so do the doctors, its kind of difficult.  To make an appointment I was on my cell phone during break at my desk on the phone with my providers office and I felt like I was planning battleship with which days they had open and which days I may be able to get off.

pros:
- Opportunity to get experience and move on to something better
- used to be "stable job" but they've been laying off people lately
- good vacation time after 5 years
cons:
- oppressive beauraucracy throughout company
- horrible medical benefits (what?)
- with over 100,000 employees you're just a number
- office politics and games are rampant 
- usual story for big co: most middle and senior mgmt underpaid while CEO is one of highest paid CEOs in the country
- most people I worked with were depressed. These weren't entry level employees - they were middle and senior management
- How long can you work for a company (UHC) that is a huge part of the healthcare problem?
- Lip service to culture and innovation - there's neither
- I've heard internal reports (unverified) that they train claims personnel to reject certain high-risk claims even though they should be paid

review_title: Loved the job, do not respect the company
job_title: Licensed Plan Specialist in Centennial, CO
pros:
I learned the position of being a health insurance agent.  I worked with many great co-workers.
I learned to be great in sales.
cons:
Things are always changing at this company, for example you move to different teams 4 times in 
one year.   The managers will promise you the world from training class on and not deliver on what
they promise.   You will not get the Pay For Performance that they promise you.    You do not have job
security here, no matter how good you are as an agent.   They will micro-manage you here and not
treat you like you have a brain in your head and there is a huge number of highly intelligent people
with diverse background that can be a real plus for the company.   Instead of paying for training
and keeping good employees, they would rather have an atmosphere of revolving agents.

review_title: Encourages employees to progress and become experts through licensing and education. Good supervisors/coaches.
job_title: Licensed Insurance Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: This company will help you to learn their business and become a professional if you do your part and put forth the effort that it takes to be a professional. They reward your efforts and listen to employee concerns for the most part.
cons:
Unprofessional attitude openly displayed by some employees, making transition into new employment roles difficult. The company at times, rewards and/or ignores bad behavior from employees who do not respect company policies. 

The professionals in the company are, at times, out numbered by those who are not professional creating an uncomfortable work environment.  Their unstable work environment stems from seasonal trends in business and the high rate of turnover in employee base. 
 
The Open Door Policy is not always respected by company officials. Their own actions do not transmit confidence in their own ability to maintain a stable workplace that will offer long term employment.

pros: If you like mandatory overtime for an unforseen amount of time, do not have a family life, and can handle favoritism in the workplace. This is golden for you
cons: The company is very innovative, however the training department is horrible. The company does not do well in training you for what you will experience on the job. It is a highly stressful environment and metrics are set so high barely anyone ever achieves them. This is to keep you from earning bonuses and raises that you are entitled to. In the Frederick, MD office supervisors delegate their work to employees without their pay. The supervisors do their  homework at their desks, leave when they want, and show extreme favoritism to certain employees. The supervisors are not compassionate and do not practice postive intent as this is the companies motto. The supervisors are unprofessional and will tell lies and different things to one person and not to another. I have never experienced such disregard and lack of professionalism at any company but this one. You are not valued at this company and it shows in their high turn over rate.

review_title: United Healthcare Military and Veterans Case Manager
job_title: Telephonic Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Low stress, great for people who aren't active, they have ok benefit package. All holidays off, no working weekends.
cons: Every minute is accounted for. You must be on the phone and in ready at all times. You are micromanaged until your head spins off. Communication is often an issue, you are given one direction and way , and then a few months done the line when the government does an audit everyone is told that they were never told to do it that way and they do not know why EVERYONE does that process. You will get a big butt because you are forced to sit ll the time. It felt like the place for career suicide, you have no opportunity for growth, a lot of nurses go there to ride out there time to retire

review_title: Terrible work life balance - Depends on division I think
pros: Decent amount of challenging work; good stock options; A lot of vacation days though a lot of staff lost theirs because it could not be carried over and they were not able to take it.
cons: Terrible work life balance; 24X7 environment without enough staff to support it without burnout; on call every 3 weeks and the calls are frequent; Expect to work a lot of overtime; Office environment does not allow conversations- even about work (This depends on the department.); People in my department cried and/or yelled after or during some daily meetings.

review_title: I’m current but i put former to speak it into existence.  RUN from the company.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Cypress, CA
pros: you get a pay check.  yay.
cons: The management is horribleeeee . They don’t even know their job to even help if you have questions. So far on my team 5 people have left and I’m a couple months in. HA. They each left because the job is stressful and the supervisor doesn’t know when she’s doing. They micromange everything like your a child, they just send emails saying what your doing wrong alllll the time, favortism exsist, if you need help with something... good luck,  they train you on a different systems every month with no more pay, and they expect for you to take calls back to back with about only SIX seconds to even breathe or take a sip of water. its just horrible. I don’t recommend this company AT ALL. they honestly need to be shut down. Even the providers and members who call in says the company sucks.

review_title: Management is good until upper executive management where detrimental policies are made without concern
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Good benefits
Wide variety of work
Immediate management ok
cons:
1. Accountants dominate how to save $$$ without any regard to the significant impact to product quality and employee morale.  Employees can see that offshoring significant portions of new development work, reduction in force locally, does not save but increases costs in loss of productivity, missed deadlines, and overworked local employees.
2. Executives without a care to the impact mandate policies that compromise productivity and employee satisfaction. For example, IT division set out to save company $4 million by giving all employees the same laptop with same specs whether in business or a developer. Developers finally got more powerful laptops, but IT hampered cpu and memory with full disc encryption and monitoring software, etc.  Developers had to choose being being out of compliance by secretly turning off the apps or getting work done and no execs cared about this impact, only about the stated $4 Million supposedly saved.

pros:
Great place to start your career in consulting (straight out of undergrad or grad school with little to no experience in an office setting)
Fairly good work-life balance
Depending on the type of projects you get, you'll be doing either real research and analysis or administrative tasks - but that's just like any consulting firm
cons:
Promotions are few and far between
Lots of turnover in junior staff
Siloed within the organization - not as much cross collaboration between the practice groups
Proposal management is the worst - incredibly short turnaround times, very little recognition of the 1-2 people that end  up doing most of the work

review_title: Looking to move on after 15 years total
pros: You have access to new technology (servers, security ...) with the exception of end user workstations. With the right manager, it is an incredibly supportive and flexible environment. It is a great place to get your feet wet in corporate America, but I would not look at this place as a long time employer.
cons:
So many levels of middle management that a decision takes weeks or months to be made. If a decision is made quickly, someone will come along soon to question/challenge the decision. The vast majority of these middle managers are looking to run someone over to make a name for themselves. 

It's easy to get stuck in a role/team. The benefits get worse and worse each year, is this Obamacare's fault or UHG just being cheap for the Shareholders? 

Optum has a terrible reputation for burning people out and the managers burning people are continually rewarded for it... that reputation is true and well deserved.

pros:
Just like any other US based company with operations in India - WFH, no formal dress code, flexible work hours.
The pros are good when compared to Indian IT service based companies
cons:
Almost little to no onsite opportunities.
Even if you get onsite, it will be maximum for 6 months and you will be paid in your India salary.
Works like a service based company when dealing with onshore colleagues. All major decision making is onshore.
Awkward shift timings. Mostly 11-8.30 or 2.30 - 12 pm
Hyderabad office facilities are really bad. Parking space issue. Cafeteria food quality/overpricing issue. Any event is mostly held in cafeteria which is already small. The lesser said about facilities, the better.
Really pathetic for a Fortune 6 company.
Non existent HR. You probably deal with them only on your entry/exit from the company.
Rest of the time in the company, they don't exist.
3 months notice period.
15% variable pay.
Totally manager driven company.  Your variable pay/hike and the quality of work depends completely on the manager. If you don't get along with your manager, you may be kicked out of the project or your life will be hell in the project.
Shared seating, your seat is not permanent and you will keep shifting every few months.

job_title: Provider Resolution Specialist in Frederick, MD
pros: Great environment, benefits and pay are Great! For people reading other UHG  reviews, where  it says that the health insurance and pay increases aren't very good, you need to take into account other things. First of all, regarding benefits, employees are paying a small fraction of the actual cost of our health insurance, so we have very low premiums, even though The deductibles may be higher. The same insurance would cost you 4-5 tmes the amount at a different company. Regarding salary increases, other companies may give higher yearly increases, but they dont offer quarterly bonuses between $1400-$2200. When you work for a company, you cannot take into account only your yearly salary. You have to take into account the extra amounts that it pays for you. UHG  is a fantastic company!
cons: My only con would be that we aren't given sick days. I have only missed 2 days from work, in the last 3 years, but I don't like the fact that I was given an occurrence for each of those days.

job_title: Senior Billing Representative in West Hills, CA
pros: It's a job, at the end of the day. For me personally, very close to home. It provides a paycheck and pays the bills. We get half the PTO that other companies offer but if your supervisor is cool, they let you come in early throughout the week to make up for a day off if you don't have hours. Set hours, mon-fri. paid holidays.
cons: You always get the run around to any questions or concerns starting from the supervisor to managers even to HR. One supervisor has had over a dozen-a DOZEN- complaints made against her to HR and she openly brags about how she is still here. HR's response is "perhaps you need to get used to her management style". They also micro-manage like we're in Kindergarten; no food, phones, no talking to other co-workers. they will literally call you out and tell you to stop talking. we've lost over 10 employees (found jobs elsewhere) in about 6 months.  Very, very difficult to move up. Seldom is there overtime.

pros: Great HSA. $1200 deposited on January 1st to help with deductibles.
cons:
Medical benefits are abhorrent. Considering we work for the insurer one would think we would have the best coverage. It is by far the worst Plan I have seen/had. 90% of our groups offer far superior coverage than we have. Last year, I paid $15,000 out of pocket. All in network claims. I updated my Plan this year to not pay so much out of pocket and pay close to $700 a month for my coverage. I feel I am only working for insurance coverage.
15 hours of business required overtime is not ok. The veteran employees now depend on that OT because they pay so low. The lowest in the industry. 
Needless to say, I am looking elsewhere and finding great opportunities. Please keep looking. There are other companies that pay better and offer better benefits.

review_title: Horrible experience unless you're a drone
pros: The peers, or peons that are on the same peon level as you are great people to work with.
cons: Micromanagement consisting of drones playing favorites. Ever since day one when i ended my "proficiency" and was released to the floor i had a weekly action plan, after i was let go from the company of 1.5 years, i had a total of 71 action plans. I was told i need to do my job a little bit worse because i was making other coworkers look bad. and then once that happened i was then given warnings for my performance. It ended up being a lose lose situation there. whenever i had questions i brought them to my supervisor and they would go unanswered for weeks at a time, if not a month or more, and if i had asked another supervisor i would get pulled aside and informed i am not able to ask other supervisors for assistance when i had already asked my direct supervisor. Or if you ask a question that consisted of a yes or no answer, management would give the vaguest answer possible leaving you more confused on what the answer would be then when you started.

review_title: Big company, if you can adapt, you will do alright.
pros:
- Great PTO (no sick time, that means you can take more PTO for vacation. If < 5 yrs = 23 days, if more = 28 days.
- Modern and clean office.
- Big company, fortune 100.
- 401K match up to 3.5% if you put 6% max.
- ESPP, 15% discounted
cons:
- As part of United Health Care, don't expect you'll get top of the line health insurance. HSA with outrageous deductible is a common option there.
- Company is a little top heavy. Change of management occurs quite often.
- Career growth is rather limited. Don't expect to jump 2 grade levels easily even if you qualify for a new job. They are notorious to hire outsiders than giving insiders the opportunity to move for another internal job.
- Happen to some people, when they found a better job offer outside the company, mgmt tried to retain you by luring you a little more money... but by that time it's too late already. They should have treated you better if you're a performer. But as many have said, most of the times if you do good work you're just an average person with so-so raise and bonus.

review_title: UHG has 5 Core Values: Innovation, Integrity, Performance, Compassion & Relationships. Financial Performance Rules.
pros: There are some very smart people here. It's the most powerful health insurance company in the U.S. The company has great name recognition. Accountability and proving performance with various layers of scrutiny are part of working here.
cons: If you are in a leadership position, you will be asked to do..., morally ambigious, things in order to save or make money. The company will goose their income statements by declaring no raise or bonus years, even though the company is making money hand over fist. As a person with direct reports, that's a hard story to tell. The work pace is crazy, you will work 50+ hrs a week here if you are grade 28 and above. Turnover is crazy, especially in the call centers and in leadership: grade 29 and above.

review_title: Unhealthy internal culture. Good benefits package. Average salary.
job_title: Management and Clinical/Professional in Houston, TX
pros:
Good stock and 401k.
Good vacation time and accrual for longevity of employ.
Allows for promotion into other insurance companies that offer career promise.
cons:
Extremely unhealthy internal culture upheld by lower/middle management.
Promotions are strictly political, not merit driven, at lower/middle levels.
Many departments highly understaffed at service / entry levels.
Raises are not competitive.

review_title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly of UHG
pros: The Good: I worked for UHG and Optum for 3 years and 5 months and learned a great deal about working in a large company and was able to hone some much needed skills to continue my career progression. The benefits are good for the most part, not great, but good.
cons:
The Bad: Working for a company with over 150,000 employees can be daunting at times. Employees were treated as a commodity for the most part. While they were trying hard to change its culture, it is taking very, very long for changes to take hold,

The Ugly: Speaking of taking a long time, this is possibly the worst thing about a company this size. The lack of agility in the company is mind numbing. When you think a change should literally be accomplished in a days, it drags on for months and months with meeting after meeting being called, each with 10-20 people, all wringing their hands over this change.

pros: Ability to work from home.
cons: WARNING! Don't try to make this a career. Hop in if you absolutely have to and hop right back out. Otherwise go ahead and get some meds from your doc for the stress/anxiety/lack of sleep you'll get while working here. I can only imagine what the employees go through who don't work from home. I'm a telecommuter and this has become the worse, most difficult, soul sucking job I've ever had in my life. I literally bite my tongue to keep from crying throughout the day. The supervisors talk to/treat you like crap because they can get away with it. Schedule changes weekly. Absolutely NO flexibility, be prepared to work any hours they decide to schedule you between 8am - 9pm or Do NOT apply! The supervisor also schedule your lunch breaks. Call center type work with calls non-stop while you're being listened in on and graded. Made up policies that only apply to certain situations/people. Low pay. Harassment. Micromanaged (even from home). And the list goes on and on. Atleast 1 person from my team of 10 is talked off the edge everyday. We cry together like we're in jail!

review_title: Overall very negative, sad, disappointing and glad to have left on my own.
pros: Pay. Good location from where I live. Easy parking.
cons: No respect for employees unless you have a brown nose. Intelligent thought not welcome. Just sit down, shut up, meet your metrics (even if you cheat to do it). Big brother was always watching, even checking your drawers and paperbasket after you left for the night. Intrusive. Intimidating. No support from HR for issues. Health Benefits stink, very very expensive. Supervisors and low level management poorly prepared. Lack skills and knowledge. Many barely able to speak grammatically correct English (yes, they were born and raised in the US). Again, butt kissing gets one where they want, doing a great job unimportant for getting ahead. Politcally correct culture, insensible, not of consistency, humaneness and caring for employees or consumers. Poor Poor enviorment for learning.  Repeatedly remined in staff meetings not to go above supervisors head or out of own team for answers to questions.

review_title: Top execs are so disconnected from the front-line, it's scary.  Co has potential but current mgmt is killing it.
pros: Good benefits, stability, PTO, and company has potential for greatness/market share if sr. mgmt. took a few minutes off the golf course to do their jobs.
cons: Out of touch (sight, and mind) executive management.  Bureaucracy is incredible ... rivals government.  So massive, they let entire divisions wither due to lack of oversight, inability to streamline management in any remotely effective way.  Almost no opportunity for advancement because no one who matters knows who you are.  Exceptional performers seem to go elsewhere.

review_title: Working at United Healthcare as a Field Nurse- Case Manager
job_title: Field Case Manager RN in Newark, NJ
pros:
Flexibility, Benefits, Direct Manager.
They offer opportunity foir learning and growth.
I think they try to promote a satisfication in the work place... the are accomodating; depending on who you have as a manager.
Overall I enjoy working here because I make a direct impact on the patients, I feel very happy to work here, I like my job, duteis, patients and I make my own schedule.  I rate it a 7 out of 10 (10 being the best).
cons:
Alot of changes and confusions.
They make changes, lots of them... so don’t get too comfortable, your title can change, your hours can change and if you can’t change they offer the door.
Often you will get many different answers for the same question.
YOU WILL LOSE YOUR PTO IF YOU RESIGN BEFORE USING IT- IN NJ And Other States.
It’s a job and they are going to do what is best for the job regardless of employee’s situation, so don’t come here with no sob stories.

job_title: Licensed Insurance Sales Agent in Denver, CO
pros: I love the fact that I was able to learn so many things about the healthcare and insurance industries in a sales capacity.  It is a great beacon of knowledge for any person who knows how to use thier resources wisely and actively seeks knowledge and opportunity.
cons: They have a very secretive culture.  Not good for a person who doesnt know how to move up the professional political ladder by learning and applying social practices as well as a little sucking up.  An outsider would never know the tricky things they do in order to promote selective internal employees.  I have seen multiple people secure positions before the position was known to other employees.  Cons include unfair business practices, select favoritism, and lack of growth and development.   P.S. ALL TRAINING IS AWFUL BEST FOR SELF LEARNERS

job_title: Software Engineer in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
The work/life balance is amazing.  I live a good jaunt from the office so if traffic is backed up in the morning I am able to either work from home, or sign on for a few hours in the morning and wait for the traffic to die down.

Compared to the companies my friends work at, the vacation time is great.  I am on the lower end but even I get 23 days of PTO a year.  If I get the promotion I am hoping for next year, that will jump to 28 days.

Managers are former (sometimes current) developers, at least on my project, so they understand the stresses and time constraints involved with delivering functionality or fixing a bug and do a pretty good job of shielding developers from overbearing business partners.
cons: You need to work a full year before the company matches any 401k contributions, and even then they only match 100% from 1-3%, and 50% from 4-6% of paycheck.

job_title: Clinical Coordinator in South Houston, TX
pros: Great pay, benefits, culture, atmosphere, co workers, easy job
cons: verification process during prehire,lack of communication amongst hiring team and verification department.

review_title: Top Heavy, Lack of Strategy, Extraordinarily Political
pros: Lower and mid-level staff are very smart and hard working.  A pleasure to know and work with.
cons: UHG takes corporate politics to a new level.  All organizations have some politics, perhaps the bigger ones the most.  But UHG excels in back-handed, dishonest politics.  Promotions and new responsibilities are totally based upon political affiliations instead of capability or merit.  This results in mid-level managers and staff getting re-organized constantly as the senior manager du juor wins turf.  The result is that you can never accomplish anything since priorities, teams, and staff are constantly shuffled.  Worse, there is no job security since your "boss of the month" often has no political affiliations with you.  So smart, accomplished people are dismissed constantly to make room for the new boss' cronies; this across the organization, so there is constant churn - of direction, people, and projects.   And the corporate-wide "culture training" mandated for mid- to  upper- level management is a joke.  While senior management pays tens of millions of dollars to outside consultants to "teach" employees compassion and integrity, they demonstrate neither themselves.

review_title: Good company but watch your back
pros: United is very supportive of telecommuting which is great. The company pays well and has great benefits.  They try to make the culture very inclusive although it's such a big organization, it's a bit difficult and sometimes falls short.  They have streamlined many processes that makes things very easy.  I think they really are trying to make it a great place to work.
cons: If you don't work in one of the Minnesota HQ offices, you're definitely expendable.  People outside of MN get dropped in a the blink of an eye.  There's a good chance you'll be more loyal to them then they will be to you.  Constant cutting of administrative support seems like a great cost-cutting idea but you end up having upper management spend time doing their own administrative work......that ends up being a much higher priced admin.

job_title: Preservice Review RN in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Office environment, potential to work from home, lots of overtime available.
cons: It sounds like an interesting job, but it's not. Absolutely no autonomy or ability to use clinical judgement, you just make sure the case matches the guidelines and if it doesn't, send to MD. Lots of phone calls, get yelled at all the time and no support from management or anyone else with difficult customers. Have to make phone calls for stupid reasons - ever heard of a GAP case? You'll learn to hate that word. Things change literally all the time. As soon as you're used to something, it will change for the worse. Management can't or won't do anything to help, everything is just the way it is 'because we say so.' You feel like a cog in a machine. To top it all off, they have literally the worst benefits package I've ever gotten from a job. Deductible was unbelievable. Just stay away from this place.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Fast Pace, excellent leaders if your willing to work hard. Excellent work life balance. Great co- workers. If you do your job well you can work independently.  The work from home opportunity makes this job perfect.! Most people with a good BPS Score can work from home 2 days a week after 6 months. The ability to advance is the company is excellent.  Overall I enjoy working for UHC and plan to be there for a while!
cons: The first 6 months can be very frustrating because there is so much to learn and not enough people available to ask a quick question.. Seems like everyone is  busy doing there own work.  Starting salary for CM is not high enough if you are Masters prepared. 1% yearly raise is not enough to compensate. Although you are  salaried employee there are weeks you need to work 45 plus hours to keep your BPM up.

job_title: Community Health Worker in Olympia, WA
pros: Part telecommuter/part field work; Interface directly with high needs members ; High job satisfaction; Great team; Positive work environment; Competitive pay; Good "starter" job with quality training program
cons: Non-Union; Disconnect between administration and field needs; Poor Medical benefit package; Large case load, Not enough paid hours allowed to take care of members' needs; Heavy emphasis on metrics, true job performance not reflected by accrued statistics; Constant inyterruptions of work flow with "glitchy" data submission system impacts workers ability to complete work and wastes an amazing amount of time. Frequent changes in work applications make it difficult to learn the change sufficiently before another is introduced.This creates a constant feeling of being overwhelmed in workers who make an effort to do quality work.

pros:
The ins
The  people 
They have a party for everything 
You can miss 5  consecutive days in only Get one occurrence
cons:
You are treated like a slave or is required 
No sick days so people are there sick as hell 
There is this kpi in which you must meet to keep your job 
Too many employees not enough communication 
Some of the pharmacist are stupid as  hell 
A lot of micromanaging 
You can’t do anything with auxin in to it 
You are watched by everyone like you are a thief 
Company is very  inconsiderate  when it comes to family issues and death 
You are only allowed x amount of days from work for pto 
The numbers you have to meet go up every quarter so you have to keep up if you want your job 
 Being pregnant  you have to get a  disability accommodation  to go to the bathroom. 
And you don’t get much recovery time after the birth 
They hire anybody

review_title: 15 minutes of fame with no future in Kidney Resource Services
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse Case Manager in Lisle, IL
pros: Work from home opportunities, decent pay, great tuition reimbursement, lots of training and CEU offerings
cons:
No retention plan for employees who obtain higher credentials. Poor communication between lower to mid management and staff. 
If you can figure out how to become a member of the "Good ole Nurse Club" GREAT! Other wise, I do not recommend a nursing position within Optum's Kidney Resource Services until you have completed your education and/or don't plan on advancing.

pros: Benefit Structure, opportunity for advancement
cons: Executive Level creates ineffective systems fraught with missing basics of management; issues with data analytic s, forecast modeling, meeting goals, training insufficiency,etc .  However, the line management WILL be blamed for any bad outcome. Employees are allowed to determine the Management's status with the company. As a Manager, you have expected to meet goals, however, you are not allowed to implement corrective action plans on employees.  The Executive Level will not support you.  If your employees complain about anything, the Executive Level will stab you in the back and offer them fluffy bunny kisses instead of a making them accountable for their job performance.   Basically, you must "Manage" in a toxic, negative, unhealthy environment, but be given no real power to fix the root source of the problems.  They appear to be happy with the status quo of tenured staff torturing new employees.

pros: The only Pro is I was able to quit
cons:
Horrible work enviroment
No Raises even though you are constantly given praises for good work but when review time comes you have done everything wrong in the book
I accepted a job with them at the the AARP Medicare Supplement Plans SALES in Allentown PA. I accepted the full time licensed SALES Rep job, Monday - Friday 9:00am to 5:30pm and one Saturday a month. 
My first day was a mess, Our trainer was like 18 years old and happily worked there a few months! The training left you unprepared for the floor and it is sink or swim. Many walked out. 
I stayed and then all of a sudden I was doing customer service work, talking to NASTY members ALL day, oh and my schedule was now 10-6:30pm. It didn't matter I was a single mom and had an infant in daycare! 
OH and if you want special treatment just sleep with your manager! I seen it happen. You get to come in late (15-30mins everyday) He won't say anything. Leave early too and degrade him too. You will totally get away with it. 
I toughed it out for THREE years. I had to leave college because of the horrible hours they would randomly schedule me when I had NIGHT classes, that I was paying for! 
Steer Clear!

pros: Flexible hours, Able to work from home, Good coworkers, Easy work
cons: All the managers micromanage you to insane levels. The rules are constantly changing as well as management itself. I had 4 managers in ONE YEAR. Managers come and go but they won't let employees change departments despite that being one of the 'perks' we were told about in training. Nothing short of 100% quality is allowed. Even if you have perfect attendance, work overtime whenever asked, make no financial errors, you can still be let go for 'insufficient quality'. This is only if your manager dislikes you though as its discretionary. The health care offered to employees is AWFUL. It's incredible how terrible it is considering its an INSURANCE COMPANY. You would think they could at least give their employees better benefits. More and more jobs are being sent overseas.

review_title: UHG Gurgaon- A mess in the making, or is it made already.
pros: Financially secure company as its in the top 25. (Just a facade for the poor frontliner)
cons:
Work life balance is poor, especially in India-Gurgaon.
No resource planning/backfilling, In one word-its under-staffed.
No career growth options. Internal promotions provide meagre salary raises as compared to an employee hired externally for the same position in the same department.
Internal promotion opportunities hard to come by.
Continous process churn, managers are like headless chickens(maybe just mine).
Involving a person extensively in non-core areas other than what he/she was hired for in the name of initiatives.
Unethical treatment of employees who dont suck up. And quick rewards to those who do.
Local mid-managers at India-Gurgaon have an 'agenda' of prioritizing trivial 'local' tasks/projects over 'Global UnitedHeatlth' tasks/projects, frontline employees are threatened not to disclose such two timing to the Global Team 'on pain of retrenchment'. This translates to overworked and underpaid employees. The burden of having non-technical managers adds to the circus party where you're made the joker, when you'd signed up to be the bearded lady or Evil Knievel(maybe).
IT work is archaic and anarchic at the same time. The whole world is moving North, but UHG is moving South, pray why, well cause they 'assume' that they are pathfinders. 
More time is spent on tracking and planning than on actual work.

job_title: Works With Claims in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: They do ask  your opinion a lot. The schedule is flexible. Salary is okay for this area.They are flexible with time off if you need it.
cons: They don't do anything with what you tell them. Upper management is a nightmare to get a hold of or deal with. Their error validation system is not standard. One our current validators actually has told people she dislikes my department and is out to get us. And they have kept her on to mess with people's jobs. There's no communication between departments it's a very much us against them system. They train you on a lot of things that are not important to your job but don't give you information about how your job is important to the rest of the company or how it fits in with what other people do. They are VERY disorganized. And their technology for their platforms is from about 1980. I'm not particularly sure how anything gets done correctly.

pros:
Opportunity to work on many and varied projects.  Most employees are easy to work with and try to be helpful, they really care about the quality of their work.  
Offers many courses to enhance your knowledge.
cons:
Extremely inconsistent, management changes course and leadership about every 3-6 months (in some cases complete opposite direction).  People have been promoted to Managment positions without background or knowledge of the division they are leading; bypassing more qualified candidates (tends to follow clique).  Senior management does not know how each division, purchased by Optum had created such as successful organization (why each company was purchased in the first place).
No work/life balance at this company.  PTO  allotted is nice, but extremely hard to utilize especially  toward the end of the year, even if goals have been attained.  Lots of stress and morale is very low.

review_title: OptumRx is a strong, growing company with plenty of growth opportunity for the employees.
job_title: Project Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: I have been with this company for over 15 years.  The growth of the company has been tremendous.  Lots of opportunities for growth and advancement if you are willing to take the chance.
cons: From rapid growth comes pain.  Over the last few years, we have had to grow rapidly adding new offices and employees all over the United States.  With this growth, we lose the small and intimate  fell of the company.  It can be easy for an employee to get “lost” in the business.  Management needs to remember we all are a part of the company.  Those who have been here 15 years and those only 15 days.

review_title: If you ever have an opportunity to work for this company... Run Far!  Run Fast & don't look back!
job_title: Medical Claims Adjuster in Greensboro, NC
pros: Good experience in medical areas such as terminology, HIPPA laws and regulations, medical claims processing and adjustments.  Average to good rate of pay.
cons:
Poor work life balance.  Endless mandatory overtime.  Top heavy incompetent management.  Unobtainable production and quality goals causing employees to be fired constantly.  High rate of employee turnover.
Poor employee retention and moral.  Modern day sweat shop.  Hidden policies not enclosed to employees during employment.  If you work there and are leaving, make sure to use up your PTO before you leave.  Company policy is NOT to pay PTO unless the state the employee lives in requires it.  I personally lost over 32 hours of accrued PTO.

pros: Insightful and full of potential to look at how health can change using IT - great people with a good mix of former health bods in the teams too.
cons:
Feels like the red company tape is suffocating the life of company that needs to remain local.  Very little appreciation for the wider picture of a health service that is severely broken that needs absolute TLC and for professional non public companies to tread ever so carefully especially when mistakes become political.  The effort spent on over engineering internal processes needs to swing back to figuring out suitable products and services for an ailing national service. "Solutions" don't cut it, dealing with such a delicate beast needs real tenacity and a considered approach. 

Senior management need to look up stop huddling and eat their own words "collaborate" with the teams on the ground - stop the hierarchy and secret meetings - it doesn't do anything but create a bigger wedge between the top and the bottom.

review_title: A great opportunity to learn if you can adjust to the culture of constant change
pros: Large employer with many smart people working there. A great place to learn and grow if you know how to network and connect with others who have information that is of value to you. If you can handle the culture of constant change that feels sometimes like it's just for the sake of change, you can learn a lot!
cons: LOTS of change - constant - organization, procedures, growth agendas. Really good ideas aren't given enough time to take root before someone comes in and changes things and stops good progress. Many companies are like this, but I've been with many of them and have never seen as much change as this.

review_title: Lots of room for true leadership & EQ development
job_title: Operational Excellence Consultant in Hartford, CT
pros:
1) Plenty of opportunities for those seeking to do what is needed to secure a paycheck (a reality for many juggling kids, parents, grandparents, illness in the family).
2) Openness to innovation
3) If you are in the right areas of the organization, flexible time schedules - including working from home to juggle more effectively
cons:
1) Health benefits designed for the very healthy
2) A substantial number of leaders and managers just don't have the EQ nor foundational skills to motivate and/or foster the work environments necessary to live United's core values.  The few that know better, don't have the guts &/or are afraid of negative repercussions to behave in enlighten ways.
3) As others have pointed out, making mistakes or failing will get you marginalized - usually without a conversation from your manager to facilitate lessons learned while encouraging innovation.

pros: Working on teams which helps establish work friendships as well as having a support team especially if it's a dedicated group.
cons: When I first started 2.5 years ago at UHC and people asked where I work it was embarrassing. Whether they had UHC themselves or dealt with it working in a medical profession, no one had a pleasant opinion of the company. The benefit packages offered to employees as well as the raises given are an insult. People not working for an insurance company have much better insurance plans than what is offered to us. The turn over rate is rather high and I have to question if some of that has anything to do with no one being on the same page or using the excuse of not having the proper training, that goes for supervisors and management.

pros: Room for career growth if you work very hard to get noticed. PTO starts at 144 hours per year (in addition to  paid holidays), work from home is available at most site locations.
cons: Pay could be increased a bit across the board in order to be competitive with other comparable companies, favoritism plays a bit part in promotion selection if you work in one of the office site locations, It is very difficult to move out of a phone rep position if that's where you start.

pros: Good company mission; good culture that is growing stronger; executive leadership is dedicated to mission and culture.
cons: I was in one position for over ten years and moved to another within a different division of United. I thought it was a good career move but it is now clear after a few months that the new job is a terrible fit for me and the new department. Unfortunately, United rules dictate that I must be in a position for one year before moving (again). In this case, that benefits no one. I can't wait one year and will be looking outside the company. That is unfortunate because I love this company.

pros:
Learning opportunities 
Feeling like your work makes a difference 
Employees are awarded and recognized 
Great team and department
cons:
Pay is NOT competitive compared to people doing similar jobs in other companies.
Health benefits are terrible

review_title: If you are a robot, you will excel at UHG or UHC or whatever their name is this week
pros: Great pay, some really good benefits. Competent managers and coworkers
cons: Change for the sake of change, the business divisions change their names by the week, you dont know the name of the company or division most of the time. . So many systems that are constantly changed and tweaked and usually broken and then abandoned only to be replaced by new systems no one knows anything about. When you work here, you are just like their website, health in numbers, thats what you are, a number. If you can be a robot and be within their micromanaged numbered outcomes? you belong here. Also, networking between departments is discouraged here. If you go outside their rigid way of doing things, you might still be working there, but you will go absolutely nowhere, unless you already know someone in the company. The only way you advance here is to know someone, or leave.

review_title: Company reluctant to invest infrastructure and resources in existing business lines
job_title: IT Manager in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
- Good learning experience for an IT person, really using some cutting edge technologies
- Good pay
- Good people at the front lines, for the most part
- Decent 401K options
cons:
- Lots of turnover for high performing IT talent, due to burnout
- Lots of churn at upper management, so there was no solid course to follow
- Company has money for acquisitions, but reluctant to spend money on infrastructure improvements & resources for existing businesses/products, resulting in aforementioned burnout as the same number of people try to cope with constant growing pains - perfect example of a "jobless recovery"
- Health insurance offering is uninspiring

review_title: Axolotl: a great company destroyed by Barbarians at the Gate
pros: Some of the most professional and knowledgable people I had ever worked with in my 25 years in Healthcare.#1 in the Industry by reputation even if the product was somewhat outdated,it worked.I was proud to work there and loved my teammates and my boss.
cons: Acquisition of the company by sinister forces that didn't share our mission was the company's fatal moment.Had a chance to sell the company to several others that would have left everything in place but given us working capital ,but instead went with the highest bidder who destroyed both the company and everything we worked for,as well as shafting some of the middle management out of hundreds of thousands of dollars.Couldnt have been any more poorly handled that it was.And to top it all off,the buying entity made our worst fears come true,dismantling the entire company,stripping away the asset that they wanted,all the while destroying everything that we had all worked for.Dunkirk and Gallipoli look like victories compared to this colossal blunder.

review_title: Health insurance benefits not so great - too many jobs being sent overseas
job_title: Client Services Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: PTO time and work from home opportunities
cons: Employees are treated like production machines.  People are not replaced when they move to new positions.  Management is afraid to vary from strict HR policies rules, or question HR decisions.  More work is given to people without thought for quality, quantity is emphasized in production environment.  Pay is low, raises are minimal except if you change jobs and move to a higher grade level - average raise is less than 2% each yr for over 10 years.  Bonuses are low for all but executives.  Bottom line matters more than employees or members than UHC serves.  People in US continue to be laid off and jobs moved overseas to save the company money with no regard to US citizens lives, economy or consequences.

pros: Great staff, work at home opportunities. Annual bonuses. They have a recognition program called Bravo where you can recognize colleagues across the company. Most are monetary equivalent, but management discourages those and would prefer just the thank you in an email.
cons: We lost the TRICARE contract & those of us working that line of business will lose our jobs. They are not helping to place the nurses nor are we going to be given priority. We will have to apply for jobs & compete with internal & external applicants. Also, most departments use a productivity tool to track the amount of cases you complete/day. Your #s are reviewed openly so everyone sees them. They have recently started using a spyware program called a Keystrokes to monitor all your activity. If your mouse is idle for more than 14 minutes your manager will call you & start questioning you. Micromanagement to the fullest.

review_title: Go Elsewhere, if you Want to be Appreciated
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Kingston, NY
pros: They are hiring...ALL the time.
cons: Threats on attendance, will terminate employment if you miss ONE day, pay is lower than other HC insurers, health care ben is horrendous, no sick benefits and a $2200 deductable each year. There is no communication by employers, favorites are played by others. Even the technology tools meant to make UNH "paperless'" do not work on a daily basis. Rather than fix them, their IT dept just rolls out something "new" that totally screws up everything.

review_title: They think they are a technology company, but fall down on the basics of software development.
pros: In my area there are opportunities to learn new technologies.  Because of the association with United Health Care they do have access to significant resources when purchasing technology.There are some very intelligent people that are leaders in their particular fields.
cons:
they are owned by United Health Care which has the some of the worst health care ever experienced.  Ingenix unfortunately is stuck with UHC health care, which has huge deductibles and is not friendly to families.   UHC is not a technology company, but pushes their technology standards down onto Ingenix when they really are two very different companies with vastly differing needs.
Ingenix does a lot of software development, but for some reason can't seem to get the processes down.  Methodologies that have been used for decades by other software development companies are either non-existent or are still being "discovered" at Ingenix.

pros: The company contributes $1000 per year into your Health Savings Account.
cons:
Average benefits, very high co-pays on drugs which is why you are given a $1000 contribution.  Even for generics.  This is a former PacifiCare site which was acquired.  A lot of those old guard are still here and there is always culture clashes between the way things used to be done versus the UHG way.  Some teams average 1-2 resignations per month (this includes the managers and supervisors).  Some departments have entire staffs who have all been there less than a year.  

Do not think this is the kind of organization where you will be retiring from.  I'm not above working hard, but your hard work will not be appreciated.  It will be taken for granted until you leave and they bring in the new crop.  There motto is 'we eat our young' because you come in for one to three years, they take all they can from you then discard you.  If you are older with a family be advised.  Life work balance is somewhat discouraged.  Sick kids, etc. are career killers.

review_title: Work with Business and IT to improve process and workflow in IT system.
pros: Positive/giving culture, flexible schedule, wonderful benefits, casual attire, supportive team members, job security, and multiple career growth opportunities.
cons: Pay isn't competitive (at least not comparable to other large corporations in San Diego). The company has too many competing priorities, which potentially causes conflicting project focus issues. Also, some projects require a more robust project management structure; including defined and updated timelines, strategic milestones, post-implementation metric plans to measure project success, cross-functional project change communication improvement efforts.

review_title: Been there for a long time currently under Optum Insight division.
pros: There used to be good reason to work here, although benefits and pay were not the greatest the flexible work schedules was worth staying around for. Unfortunately all the meaningful perks are being taken away which leaves low pay and minimal benefits not as appealing.
cons: Micro managed to the hilt. Now implementing spy ware on every computer. Work from home perks a few days a week were greatly appreciated for years, but upper management is taking that away even though profits have been record breaking. Wish management would consider how the cost of driving into the office a few extra days a week while gas prices continue to rise will impact the pocket books of all these underpaid employees. Raises seem to come biannually and typically less then two percent when they do come. Management is oppressive, employees are not treated respectfully.

review_title: Complete incompetence from the management down to the agents
pros: very few positives about this company. Due to poor operations management some agents get loads of overtime to meet service levels and to fill gaps to to high turnover and attendance issues..
cons: Poor compensation, terrible healthcare benefits (unless you are one of the lucky VP that management the business but fall under the Optum benefits structure) most of the agents on floor qualify for Medicaid which ends of being providing better coverage the company benefits.  New senior added within last year have no clue of how the business works.

job_title: Licensed Agent/Customer Service Representative Representative in Jeffersonville, IN
pros: Coworkers are very nice people and for he most part they are very willing to help each other out.
cons: They will make promises about their benefits when they hire you, change them without telling you and you end up with nothing. I was promised that we were accumulating PTO from day one but come to find out they miss understood optums policy and you do not start accure PTO until you become an advocate. First its was 90 calendar days to become an advocate then they changed it to 480 hours worked, then they file the paperwork and it takes over a month to get it processed (at least with me this is how it happened). Some of us have been there for 7 months and still are NOT an advocate which means no PTO, Insurance, of holiday pay.

job_title: Medical Management, Concurrent Review in New York, NY
pros:
Established company 
Great coworkers 
Good orientation
cons: Realistic expectations are listed below

pros: Can’t think of any at the moment given the circumstances
cons: Worse and extremely expensive  health benefits for employees from, ironically, a health insurance company, regardless of what plan you choose. Poor communication with HR regarding benefits for Short Term Disability. Employees left with no income for months.

review_title: Cold work atmosphere. Employees are not valued.
pros: UHC has flexible schedules for my job position. There are opportunities to progress through a number of job positions. Potentially good opportunities for international workers or those interested in transferring to other locations because UHC has a number of locations across the United States. It could be easy to stay under the radar of some management and get by with doing little work, depending on position. Many meetings are held over the phone and/or Internet, so working from home is an option for some positions. If you just want a paycheck, UHC may not be a bad place to work.
cons: Poor communication within and between teams at UHC.  Information is hard to find. There is little face to face interaction since most meetings are held over the phone, including meetings between teams in the same physical location. There are many little messages that people are not valued at UHC. The primary focus appears to be performance as a company. Although there are efforts to change the culture of UHC, it will take years for this to be effective. Health insurance for employees is more complicated and includes less coverage for employees. Do not expect a warm atmosphere or any team building activities.

review_title: Worst company I have ever worked for in my career.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Cypress, CA
pros: You get health insurance when you work for them. Its not great but its something.
cons: Where to start? Bad management, terrible morale, most folks are walking around as though someone died.  They try to hire as many non-U.S. born Filipinos as possible so that they can take advantage of their work ethic and tendency to abuse without complaint or wage increases.  Poor management team that implements half-baked best practices that ultimately fail and they then blame the employee.  I have never worked with so many obese people in my life and I think that contributed to the weekly call of the ambulance and paramedics.

pros: Great people, learning opportunities for growth
cons: Purchased so many companies with different systems, they may clash in transition and SOPs causing headaches. Not streamlined, but company is working towards this, but not fast enough due to monies. Projects still go through, might have to wait a year though. The company uses six sigma, however the concept does not always fit every aspect and the company needs to also factor in ideas more.

pros:
Working Remote
Making record profits especially with the latest tax reform
cons:
Doesn't share the wealth with employees.
Raises are basically non existant
Management is so clueless they don't communicate well.
The health insurance they provide to their employees is horrendous, these used to be discount plan for employees that is long gone.
Mandatory overtime, with no communication from management.
CEO sent out a memo talking about about the federal tax bill being reinvested into the work we do everyday, yet no employee has received a bonus or raise from it.
Comments on said memo include many employees asking about what they are doing for us fell on deaf ears with no response.
The only positive comments on the memo are from people who are 2 or 3 levels below the CEO per the organization chart.
 
If your company was recently bought out by Optum/UHG hit the bricks and start looking elsewhere.

review_title: Good company for work from home benefit
pros:
Work from home is a very good option provided by this company.
Overtime is provided even for development team (usually other companies provide for operations or call centre employees)
Allowances for night shift employees

Work quality is based on the project we get.
cons:
No parking facility
Worst HR team. They don’t inform everything at the time of joining like they didn’t inform about the parking problems and eligibility  for hike for that current year. 

Company has started cost cuttings and has removed many employee benefits like internet allowance and they don’t provide 100 percent variable pay for 5 rating employees too. 

Hike percentages has consistently started decreasing every year

Rating is never considered based on performance. It is always based on the bell curve 

3 months of notice period which is very high. No company will consider when you try to change your job because of 3 months notice

review_title: If you're over 30, don't get too comfortable. If you're over 40, get out while you can and while it's still your choice.
pros: Great coworkers.  Fairly good place to work until 2017.  Downhill ever since.  Nice initial attempt at creating positive culture and  corporate values, but the catch phrases are now cliche.
cons: Incompetent managment in IT, toxic work environment, blatant age discrimination,  profit and growth above ethics.  Proprietary bulky process has replaced Agile and has created gridlock and frustrated employees. Optum is quietly compiling all of our PHI and racing to put it in the cloud, something that has become an obsession, despite serious concerns about data security.

review_title: Helping everyone live healthier lives except the Employees
job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Free covered parking.  Fair pay for entry level positions.
cons: There is a demand for "mandatory overtime".  The attendance policy is such that I worked for 3 days before going to the doctor to find out I had H1N1. When I called in on Monday to say I wouldn't be in, my boss told me that it would be counted against me on my attendance and adherence because it is January.  I came to work anyway (sorry for spreading my illness) Customer service is less important that how fast you take a call.  If a customer has deep issues regarding their medications, you must rush them off the phone because the clock is ticking.  The rewards they give for a job well done are things you would expect in a junior high school; candy, pizza and such.   If you have a sick child, you are not allowed to take time off to care for their needs.  You must work, unless you are lucky to be employed in California where the laws protect parents who need to care for their sick children.

job_title: Filialleiter Hamburg / Einkäufer in Atlanta, GA
pros: The pay is higher than other organizations especially for an administrative phone job. The position is pretty mundane so you know what to expect each day. Some friendly and nice people you meet and work with.
cons: Management, health benefits, organization on employee development. The organization does not promote work life balance. When the snow storm came many were stuck in the office over night due to their anxiety for us to take calls. They don't care about you, your family or how much you dislike your job and want to grow. All they care about are numbers and money going into their pockets as top executives. If you have an education, are professional and have years of experience, run for your life!! The turn over rate is unbelievable which speaks for itself. Even on vacation expect a phone call from work that could have waited until you returned. Not worth the money to work here.

review_title: A great place to work because of the great people that you work with.
pros: Very professional, intelligent and caring staff.
cons:
The company does not really care about it's employees.  Very poor increases using the economy as an excuse, even though their stock is through the roof.  Very poor bonuses even though they advertise up to 20% of salary,  A good review equals 0 bonus in 2014.  Prior years were also dismal with the same excuse.
Benefits are horrible.  Anyone with a choice, such as a working spouse, would choose healthcare benefits from the spouse.  You would think that a healthcare company would offer good healthcare benefits to its own employees, but you would be wrong.

review_title: Constant and unrelenting change. A BIG negative!!!
pros: My immediate supervisor is excellent.
cons:
Many. 

The amount of change that constantly occurs for my job is staggering. Three people couldn't keep up with it all...let alone one. Think of I Love Lucy, the episode where she's at the chocolate factory working on the conveyor belt line. If you know this episode, and what happens, you know what it's like to be an employee at United Health Group. Upper management constantly initiates change that they have no idea how it really effects those "below" them.

This company drives its employees extremely hard and ultra high expectations. Unrealistically so.

review_title: A once great company ruined by UHG/Optum and clueless senior managers and executive team members.
job_title: Clinical Support Team & Medicare Appeals in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Working remotely & many great nurses and doctors who genuinely care about patients and providers, unlike the executive team.
cons: No room for growth, UHG/Optum micromanagement, senior managers that didn't have a clue about the healthcare field (specifically the appeals department), executive team members who say one thing to the employees and the exact opposite in closed door meetings. This company went from being compassionate and caring to dysfunctional and reckless. They had 3 massive layoffs and are still trying to force others to leave via attrition. Most work is being sent overseas to the Philippines, where the workers make less than $1 an hour and the office is dirty/not maintained. The result has been a lack of quality in products and clients have definitely noticed. The only thing keeping the company on its' feet at this point is that it has UHG/Optum to fall back on for money at any time.

pros: They have telecommuter positions and you have some good people overall in the company.
cons: Work life balance.   Over work employees  working too much overtime. Inexperience Mgrs  being hired from outside without proper training on UHC culture. Depends on the entity, UHG has many entities of the company to work for so every department can't be compared.  The Supervisors salaries isn't compensated enough especially working tons of overtime and no pay for it.  Direct employees get paid yearly more than supervisors. Direct employees  act like immature kids causing issues and problems, some managers won't back up the supervisors at all. Very difficult to transfer. Oh, working for an insurance company you would think the healthcare insurance would be great here and it's horrible for employees.

pros: I have been working in and around this field for 20 years and as with all giant corporations the high level management talks a great game, at the end of the day it is all about numbers and production, whether done right or not. I am blessed enough to have wonderful direct supervisor and manager that focus not just on corporate goals but about the employees under them and how to work with you and make accommodations as much as possible when things happen in your personal life.
cons: Working for one of the largest insurance companies in the world you would think that your benefits would be great, awful options , especially if you have a family to cover. Awful prescription coverage.

review_title: Job was ok, treated like a disposable employee.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Overall, company mission is good. They treat non-call center workers very well. Call center employees were barely allowed 30 secs between calls and dont even think about a bathroom break.
cons: Manager only liked suck ups. She would take credit for any ideas you had.  I left the company without being on a CAP (Corrective Action Plan). They recently pursued me for a position that I am more than qualified for. After jumping thru their hoops the senior recruiter had not contacted me. I contacted the person who pursued me for the position and was told "your re-hire status is showing ineligible for rehire per Human Resources since you was a prior employee for United Health Care." Bad grammar aside it would be nice to be made aware of their internal workings so as not to waste my time and theirs.

review_title: Telephonic CM in Richardson, TX location
job_title: Telephonic Case Manager in Richardson, TX
pros: Very comparable benefits; nice to work on phones; all employees (nurses, administration, trainers, executives) invested in excellence and good rapport; training extensive, fast paced; nice environment: well lit, comfortable, mostly quiet, lunch area, restaurants close by, work out facility close by; safe location of PBGT; lots of different areas available for nurse to work within the company.
cons: Metrics seem unrealistic: you can't work from home completey until you meet metric number; this number depends on how many contacts you make with live person per day.  This means that not really a 40hour work week; more realistic for 45-55 hours to meet metrics.  Need to like working in afternoons and evenings, even if original sign up for days...you get the most people after they get off work.  Sales oriented focus...you have to meet metrics; get praised for metrics.  Have to have audit reviews with outside customers; sometimes brutal process.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Houston, TX
pros: getting paid each week and benefits.
cons: upper management seem to be lack luster when it comes to assisting reps on the floor. how can have a title of supervisor but dont even have knowledge regarding a benefit question? but you guys want us to break our back and necks to service callers efficiently. HA! and all that mumbo jumbo of moving up in the company is quite the biggest lie I have ever been told in the past 10 yrs of me being in the workforce. if you are a CCP dont think you are going to be moving all over the company besides that is a big dream, they will deny your application because they need you for "business needs" aka we dont have enough workers and have alot of callers so now you have to suffer and be stuck. get out while you can!!!

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I don’t have any too many great things to say about UHG, my opinion being the largest health care Company.  I think they should find better ways to look after their employees and Insured, because that’s who helps this company. : (
cons: Especially for APIPA, AZ unorganized their CS dept. wheel snack carts all day long and manager is playing either his floor golf or WII with his favorite Supervisors and CS agents. While calls are backed up, claims don’t get paid due to most agents are not well train or don’t have enough time.  Calls are transfer because they don’t know who can answer the customer’s questions currently?  Sorry but that’s the true.

review_title: I've enjoyed my time here, but this is a part time contract position.
job_title: RN, Case Manager in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Great experience as a case manager for an insurance company working with a variety of different types of people who have various conditions.   I get to use my assessment skills as well as providing the clients with education related to their conditions and I also like the aspect of the position that allows me to provide clients with assistance to help them with many different situations they may be facing.
cons: The referrals are not at a steady rate because it is only part time.  I only get to see the clients one time; I don't know if they are successful in managing their health for the long term.   This is a contract position.

job_title: Clinical Administrative Coordinator in Maryland Heights, MO
pros: Benefits, Hourly Pay, Work at home, PTO availability and the opportunity to purchase UHC stocks at a discounted rate (15%).
cons: This is a sales, cold calling job. You sit at home and talk on the phone for 8 hours a day- and you cannot get the chance to take a breath between calls. If you don't have enough enrolls or your metrics aren't meeting satisfactory you will be put on an action plan. Its very easy but demanding. No work life balance as the shift is in the middle of the day. (10:30-7pm CST). No room to grow. They don't work with you if you want to go to school. "Tuition reimbursement" is only applicable if the class you are taking pertains to the job you are doing, for example: you pretty much have to take a class on something you already do for them to reimburse you.

pros: I can't think of anything
cons:
RUN. This place is a joke if you are trying to grow content experience or even management experience. DO NOT and I repeat, DO NOT work for Lewin as a level 27 (RC) if you have had experience working elsewhere first. They lump you into levels based on your education and work experience. If you have anything less than 3 years of work experience and a masters then they will put you in with the level 27s (most of whom are all fresh and bright eyed out of grad school with NO/minimal work experience). 

You will be treated like a secretary for the most part. You won't learn anything since most of their work is technical assistance and scheduling/writing meeting notes. If you don't want to do much with your potential then sure...work for them. 

Everyone looks miserable here all of the time. I left as soon as I could. Promotions are not based on merit but on whether or not your manager likes you. Also if you don't have a car, the commute from DC to VA is HORRIBLE and they are not flexible with you working remotely.

pros: Extremely flexible, family friendly environment. Decent pay. Telecommute. Close, family-like teams.
cons: It started with unorganized training, most in which has nothing to do with your specific job role. It's information overload and impossible to retain.  It moved on to awful software. We can't do our jobs because the software won't work.  The upper level management is unprofessional and out of touch. Things are more difficult than it has to be.

pros: Easy hire and dicent pay
cons: Unreliable resources. No sure how to answer customer questions in certain cases because different people give different answers. Discriminates towards Hispanic employees and no diversity. Company hires anyone even if they have no prior experience resulting in unskilled and unprofessional employees. Trainers have never worked in certain departments and cannot relate to the information they are teaching. Management do not take responsibility for wrong answers given to customers even if they provided the answer to the agent. Quick to blame employees for terrible outcome of incorrect information given. They do not update their list of in network doctors and constantly give customers doctors that do not take the insurance resulting in higher call back rate. Cheat customers by claiming certain things need prior authorization when they do not even when things are listed as a benefit in their benefit summary. Managers encourage employees to transfer to the state for any reason when they can resolve issue themselves, this results in the state getting mad and threatens to cancel government contract. Lack of communication. Supposedly they update policy but never communicate this properly to agents. Promotions do not consist of better pay just change in responsibilities.

review_title: Good starting point, not a long-term career
pros: The work environment is laid-back, with a lot of autonamy and independent work. Employees are given the opportunity to work at their own pace, from home, or at random hours, as long as the work is completed on time and is of high quality.
cons: The compensation for lower level staff (non-management) is not comparable to other consulting firms in the area. For graduates right out of undergrad, the pay is not bad, however, for those coming out of graduate school or looking to start a career in consulting - the experience/education is not reflected in the salary. In addition, the type of work given to lower level staff does not reflect their experiences or desires, but is rather what is needed at the company. While this is a hallmark of consulting in general, after enough time has gone by without interesting or relevant work, it is hard to see ones self continuing at The Lewin Group as a viable career.

pros: My favorite thing about my job is the team envirnoment. While employed with connextions I have worked on multiple accounts in different departments and no matter where I work or with whom I work, there is always a great team environment. We have a committe dedicated to holding events for use (free popcorn day, cookouts/carnvials in summer, easter egg hunt for you and your family and many, many more). As far as compensation/benefits, you are eligible for full benefits (major medical, vision/dental, 401k, life insurance everything) after 90 days, rates are comparible to other company planes. You start earning PTO (vacation) time immediately and can use (when approved) after 90 days. The compensation is slowly getting better, bonus' increasing, opportunities to raise hourly rate, but over all for a very minimal physical activity jobs working on computers, the pay is great.
cons: Buildings are very large, wear comfortable shoes/heels (business casual dress code, no HIGH HIGH Heels, your feet will be killing you). Need a bigger lunch area, my location has 600+ employees, we have 4 refrigerators and 5 microwaves.

pros: Great benefits and pay, nice people (at least easygoing on the surface), interesting insights to healthcare.
cons:
There is a general culture of fear, and treating people like objects, because it's such a huge corporation.  It's sort of like a, "Minnesota Nice," version of Wall Street - lots of competitive battles for territory going on.  It's hard to make a general review of Optum/UHG because it's such a huge company.  The business unit you work for may be wonderful, or it may be terrible - it all depends upon your specific leadership.

Generally, I think the long-term outlook for the business is amazing...they will likely become one of the top three largest companies in the US, because healthcare isn't going to get less expensive, especially with an aging population, which will drive up costs.  That being said, being that UHG is so huge, there may be political backlash when they move from being the country's 6th largest company to the country's 2nd or even 1st...that will not sit well with the public when your largest company is an HMO and it starts making headlines.

review_title: Long term employee at a successful yet conservative company.
job_title: Senior Reporting Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: UNH is a challenging, successful, yet friendly company to work for.  I am a long term employee.  I have enjoyed my time here and have had many positive experiences.
cons:
The company is financially very conservative.  Great company to own stock in.  Every year the company seems to meet/beat Wall Street estimates.  Despite the company's financial successes or your own achievements, you may find yourself fortunate to receive a 1-2% yearly salary increase.  As a long term employee, those consistently frugal salary increases can have a negative impact, particularly if the cost of living increases more than your salary.  

Good company to work at for a couple years but unless you are in upper management or you continue to climb the corporate ladder, I would not recommend staying beyond a few years.  The frugal salary increases and inefficient benefits will force you to search elsewhere.   I have seen many talented folks leave the organization after just a few years, only to be successful somewhere else.

pros: Decent base pay but good luck getting more than a 2% raise no matter how good your performance review is.
cons: Management picks favorites, and even if you are the favorite you will still be exploited. They consistently cut employee benefits while bragging about creeping up the Fortune 500 list.
