Senior Leadership is tone deaf and not clinical-minded which is a shame because that's what the job is supposed to be about. Everyone I worked closely with at the company is super nice but even the Directors have no sway over the Senior Leadership who make strange and selfish decisions on a dime. Even if you're an excellent performer you will never get a meaningful raise or bonus despite how well the company is doing. I quit for a 40% pay increase and I can't believe I stayed at Optum so long without realizing how much more valuable I am on the market than where they had me.

review_title: Optum is great, Department is not
job_title: Recovery Resolution Subrogation in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Great building with lots of amenities. Caribou, Tea, Cafeteria, and a convenience store. Mail stops and dry cleaning. Health, HSA, 401k, all the usual office type benefits.
cons: Don't work in subrogation. If you want a work environment where computer calculated metrics are the only means to demonstrate how good you are as  an employee, then this place is the best. If you like an environment where you keep your head down, push the buttons, and don't question things, this is the place for you. Do you like to be micromanaged? Then subrogation is the best department to be in for you. They will provide all the micromanaging you can desire. You may meet their required number of tasks per day, or exceed them, but if your computer shows you are idle or away for longer than about 45 seconds, that's a ding. Does not matter your performance.

pros: The pay is ok, close to home, hours are ok 7:00 to 3:30 M-F
cons: Management staff are micro managers and not open to how the job is really done. Seems to have learned the job out of a manual and that is the ONLY way to do it. Would love to have the opportunity to work from home but employees are not trusted. No flexibility in schedule ever. No flex time ever. Bad managers back up bad managers and supervisors. No opportunity for advancement. Employees are belittled when the manager gets an attitude then manager runs around buddying up to the staff. Bad vibes all the time. All staff are afraid to say anything for fear of being forced to quit. Work is controlled and daily quotas are TO BE MET or be written up and termed.

review_title: Decent Pay and Benefits, Poor Management
pros: Health insurance HMO plans are very affordable, $25 a month biweekly for a family if you utilize their Rally for Health credits (up to $1200 per year), matching 401k standard, dental benefits are some of best on market (covers 80% of major services), short term disability, paid parental leave including adoptions
cons: Poor management and high overturn, NO sick days only vacation days that just be approved well in advance.

pros: None absolutely nothing that's good.
cons: Not recommended if you are a person of

review_title: Getting better, but still a ways to go!
pros: UHG offers a good PTO program in that most jobs start with 23 days a year.  The downside is that if you leave the company you don't get paid out for your PTO time accrued, however if you have used more than accrued you pay the company.  Seems a little one-sided to me.  The other thing I like about UHG is that there are always plenty of advancement opportunities within the company.  They are sometimes hard to get because you are competing with other internal and external candidates.
cons: Work/Life balance has not always been a priority, but it is getting better.  Our medical benefits are less than desirable.  Charge me a little more for good coverage and I'll gladly pay it.  Wearing a "choke collar" all day is a thing of the past for people that sit in a cubicle all day.

review_title: Depends on where your work and most importantly the senior mgmt you work under.
pros:
Within the IT division there are lots of opportunities to learn technologies again depending on where you work within the organization.  Mgmt (again depending on where you work) is very supportive of things within their boundaries of control.

The CIO to his credit does have a good thorough understanding of not only the healthcare but IT and it's role within it.
cons:
The company is absolutely littered with project managers, who through no fault of their own are faced with unrealistic deadlines to complete various initiatives that are issued down from senior mgmt.

Senior mgmt (director level and above)is filled with individuals who are more metrics driven that have little understanding of how the metrics are captured.  Also, very often to an annoying degree, some of their direct reports are more into appease their senior mgmt than telling the actual truth.

review_title: If I could give this negative stars I would
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Greenwood Village, CO
pros: The poor agents that have been duped by the "$25.00 an hour" lie.  We are all there just to make it to a different job and need money until we can find it
cons: Do not believe the ad that you will make $25 an hour. There is no way to get that amount.  We have great salespeople that are experienced licensed agents and they can't make that amount.  They do not care about the poor customers that are calling trying to figure out how to get health insurance.  One of the supervisors is not even a licensed agent, yet talking to customers about plans and getting paid a 'bonus' on what the team sells which is clearly against Department of Insurance rules. Believe the previous posting about them asking for people to come in early and not getting paid.  It's true.  This is the worst company I have ever worked for.  I know you may be desperate for a job (I was) but if you can hang on and find something else, do it.

review_title: UnitedHealth Group treats you like a number, a terrible number that can be easily discarded.
pros: There is a lot of PTO available to employees so you are able to take time off if your department policy does not prevent you from taking it.
cons: The benefits are completely subpar. Medical insurance with super high deductibles and high premiums. When you see the testimonials about the insurance exchange rates, you wish you were able to purchase any of the policies there. When you do actually have a valid claim, they will try everything in their power to deny it and you will have to fight tooth and nail to get them to pay what is right up to and including filing complaints with the state. They do not care. When I resigned, they did not pay me my last check and gave no reason other than they would investigate even though they were in violation of state law. They didn't care. You may like your team or your department but the operations of the company is terrible. No one will give HRDirect glowing reviews.

review_title: Definitely a good place to be
pros:
I have joined here as a fresher and have been working here since last three years.
- Work from home. This becomes a boon only if you have a great manager and a good team. Otherwise you might not get chance to really utilize it fully. 
- You get a laptop even as a fresher. This is one of the rarest things i have seen in IT industry in India
- Brand value. It's Fortune ranking is #6 and that is definitely not something easy to achieve.
-Work life Balance is good
- Compensation is good. But it is exclusively good if you join here with experience.
- If you have joined here at a higher grade you can definitely consider giving this one a long shot.
cons:
-Less onsite opportunities.
- Sometimes the projects can be very demanding. At that time working from home can prove to be a bane as it can distort your work life balance. 
-Not much technologies to learn here as a fresher
- It is highly manager oriented company. So good luck if you get a bad one

pros: They have a good benefit package compared to most medical and insurance companies. It is a well known and successful company, so it will look good on your resume if you decide to move on.
cons:
I worked with the same group  of people while it was owned by Monarch for several years and I felt honesty and caring personality. As soon as the company was bought out by Optum I could feel the pressure and negative back stabbing culture entering our work place. People left or got fired left and right. You will find many people in the company who will smile to your face and shake your hand and follow the procedures when and how  it works for them. 
If you don't care about what happens to the person next to you and if you believe in the law of jungle this might be a good fit. 
I believe the culture of a company will always be judged by it's personnel. Like when water trickles down the wall.

pros: great manager,  8 paid holidays, no weekends, telecommuting
cons: Personal time and sick time are not separate, but placed in the same bucket.  Unplanned days carry a penalty a full year from the day it was originally taken.  If you have computer issues that continue for 4 hours, then you must take an unplanned day which you are penalized for.

pros: Working from home, salary is pretty good
cons: Constant micromanaging, little to no leeway with unplanned occurrences if a child is sick, vital signs lead to minimal change, inconsistent communication between departments, inconsistent training (too much tribal knowledge and he/said she said. Each department has different ways of doing things, needs more consistency in processes and communication between business partners needs major improvements.

review_title: Ok employer that offers alot, but does not deliver
job_title: Provider Phone Representative in Southfield, MI
pros: Having a job and fair benefits.
cons: company offers tuition reimbursement of $5250, but later says you have to be going to school for something dealing with your current position well if I'm going to school for Health Services Administration and I work in Customer Service, all of this deals with insurance. Also, UHC does not believe in hiring from within; they will go to the outside and you will not even get an interview. Several people have asked management why is it so hard to get a promotion after you have earned your tenure, and management give the old oke doke lines, we want the best and just hang in there.....So the way I see it is there is no tuition reimbursement or advancement opportunities.

review_title: Masters of Saying one Thing and Meaning the Other
job_title: Claims Processor in Eau Claire, WI
pros:
Open to new ideas
Encourages asking questions and questioning processes
Shared learning and process improvement encouraged
Frequent Team Building activities
cons:
Verbally emphasize quality over quantity, subliminally emphasize quantity above all else
Encourages employees to be vocal in their ideas, but throws heaps of red tape at ideas when they are voiced.
Hesitant to change if it has any possible negative effect on employee production
Recognition and employee metrics systems set up so that you're either earning awards for working above and beyond, or you're at risk for termination.
Promises excellent opportunities for advancement, fails to deliver on that promise.
Suggests employees grow their skill set to make themselves more valuable resources, then offers no avenues for them to do so.

pros:
This company grew from one location with about 500 employees in one state to now having 11 locations across the I'd hate ntry and thousands of employees in a very short time frame.  You don't do that without making some mistakes.  Every year I see improvements and am excited about how the organization is positioned in the industry.  Those who want more than just a job get more than just a job, they get a career.  Funny thing is that those who are complaining that there is no advancement are upset that they didn't get promoted after being pretty good at their jobs for 6 months.  It's unrealistic.

I'm starting to see a real culture shift with new management at the site.  Expectations are set and people are held accountable to a certain standard.  I'd hate to work at a company that didn't have a standard.
cons: Communication is often a challenge.   This causes rumors to circulate when you don't get in front of it.

review_title: Stay away from Medicare and Retirement division!!
pros: Working for this Fortune 20 organization will help you get a better job with a better run company. They utilize some cutting edge software and systems for analytics that are years ahead of most in the industry.  Most of what you do and are tasked to accomplish come with little to no support or direction this reality will hone your problem solving and creative skills.
cons: If you feel reporting to "yes men" is something you enjoy then Medicare and Retirement is the place for you.  In a middle management role you will be completely responsible for results yet have zero authority to design or receive the tools needed to achieve them.  Its a one way street where do as I say and not as I do rules.  A third of your compensation will be based on a goal you will never achieve so don't look for honesty or corporate integrity here.  Deception and threats are the are the pillars of upper level leadership.

review_title: A Healthcare Company That Offers Poor Benefits
pros: Our management staff are among the best to work for.  They communicate with their team on a regular basis and try their best to maintain a positive work environment.
cons: Here in The Rhode Island Office, we are offered no real opportunities for growth.  Any position offered to the Technology Support Center in Rhode Island is a lateral position only (meaning no pay increase).  Despite receiving excellent job reviews, salary increase has been a total of $1 per hour over five years even though the state minimum wage will have gone up 25% within 2 years on January 1st.  If you are looking for healthcare benefits, the benefits offered to employees are in name only and the cost goes up each year to equal at least the 1.5% pay increase you received the year before.

pros:
1. Very stable company.
2. In Technology every employee get the Laptop for Work for home (W.F.H).
3. Less work (it Depends on your Project).
4. Personal life is easily manageable.(It Depends on your Project and Project Manger).
5. Contractors Employee will be permanent after 6 Months (Depends on your Performance or your Manager) mostly 90% chance of conversion with UHG as a Full Time Employee[F.T.E]
7. Providing CAB's from Door To Door for Pickup and Drop with 1,500 Per Month.
cons:
1. I am working in technology. 
2. Not satisfied with the salary. 
3. They are just partiality with Technology and Operation.
4. As comparison to Technology, in Operation is very good salary and hike as well. Not in Technology.
5. If you are technology part then you did not get better hike and good salary. you will get avg salary that is the worst part of UHG. 
6. There is No onshore/Onsite for USA. There is only 10% chance to go USA in UHG.
7. HR part is very Ridicules. They are not responding your emails.

job_title: Senior Consultant in Falls Church, VA
pros: Some very smart and talented people.  Several departments were very good at winning grants and contracts.  Office atmosphere was nice and low pressure.  Budget/finance staff was excellent and helpful as were most of the admins during grant writing season.
cons: The managers did not give much mentoring or grooming to new people.  You kind of had to figure out how to navigate the company on your own.  When United Healthcare took over, morale went down considerably.  There benefits were horrible and expensive considering they are a health company and office atmosphere became very stuffy and corporate and we wasted a lot of time at "what Color is Your Parachute" type meetings.  Business Dev. person was awesome, but time was pulled way to thin for her to help all of the people who needed it and weren't getting it from managing consultants.

job_title: Member Service Representative in Frederick, MD
pros: It's a job to pay the bills, nothing more nothing less.. bonuses if you meet your metrics each quarter. Being someone to rely on for the members..
cons: Management is very childish and unprofessional they sit around talking about employees and their personal issues, Instead of doing their job. Human Resources isn't any better, as much as you complain no action is taken. They Claim to have an open door policy but instead will do almost anything to get you terminated. They intentionally put things in your file so that if you quit or are fired, you can't be rehired or get temporary help. Favoritism is big!!! They talk to you as if you're a child. Oh! yeah they email personal employee info to everyone on the floor. Even if you do your job well if they don't like you they will do anything to get you OUT. Also, to work for the company the health insurance is not great ,high deductible plans. For all the work we do we could be paid a lot more or at least get better health insurance for their own employees..

pros:
Work life balance, Work from home, Flexible timings.
Its not necessary to complete 9.5 hours. I used to work for 6 hours at most.
cons:
1. No work available
Absolutely no work was there in my portfolio, they                  hired saying work will be on MVC havent seen any code since my joining since past one year.

2. People who have dependency will treat you like a fresher eventhough their technical knowledge is garbage.
Politics is embedded here. Work wont help you untill you broadcast it. You have to fight here to make yourself visible.

Despite of the politics the thing that concerned me was the lack of work. If you are a fresher its not good for you to join this org. as you might not learn anything and end up being institutionalised. Good for experiened professional who know how to keep themselves up to date.

Variable salary - 15%

pros: I love to work from home
cons: Supervisor has no uhg values

review_title: Overall quality of management is very inconsistent
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: If you contribute to the bottomline of the organization, then you are likely to receive reasonable compensation. For example, my combination of the PMP certification and the ability to drive projects to completion - convinced my direct manager to increase my salary and to submit my name for an annual bonus even though I was part of the PacifiCare acquisition.
cons:
Contractors often receive more advance notice (2 weeks) than regular employees (usually limited to 1 week) in regards to staff reductions. 
Bonus and merit increases are limited to the top tier employees so it is a highly competitive work environment.
Most legacy Pacificare employees are very worried about their jobs. The former PacifiCare CIO left the organization in May 2009 and it is a resource-constrained environment for the PacifiCare IT employees. 
The organization includes highly educated and talented individuals, but they often do not have the support to do the right thing - employees are given their marching orders which are often counterproductive.

pros:
The 401K employer match (up to a certain percentage). 
Ability to telecommute if your manager will actually let you. 
Employee stock purchase plan.
Somewhat flexible schedule.
cons:
Considering this company is owned by United Health Group which owns UnitedHealthcare, the insurance package offered is shockingly lousy. One would think some of the best packages UnitedHealthcare has would at least be offered to employees of their sister company. Not the case. High deductible plans are all that are offered and the cost of the benefits doubled this year if you don't complete an annual health screening and pass the minimum requirements in order to receive "discounts" on your premiums. 
Short staffed and overworked. Additional responsibilities are always being added to your plate even though you are already doing the work of multiple people. Mandatory overtime which makes the pay more attractive but hinders with work/life balance. Management seems to be apathetic to your heavy workload because of the overtime. They don't seem to get that all of the responsibilites cannot be completed regrdless of how much overtime is worked.

review_title: About what you would expect.  Meh.
pros: Advancement opportunities are there if you properly politic, brown-nose, and drink the kool-aid (must live in MN tho).  If you are in a high demand area and like your direct upline, it is bearable.
cons: You truly are just a number.  The benefits are not what you would expect, and the raises are minimal.  Record revenues =/= decent raises to employees.  They use any possible upcoming negative to cry "Austerity!" when it comes to pay increases.  Human Capital may as well be named Human Chattel.  Offshoring is rapidly increasing, layoffs are becoming routing, but the the culture is changing!  (to a culture of fear).

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Cypress, CA
pros: They kept training me to do more and more platforms and skills. Learning to help members more and more in very difficult areas.
cons: If it took longer than 2 minutes to help them, you would get a Verbal or written warning for your time metrics going up. There is just no way to give quality help in 120 seconds. I took my chances and gave quality help and was fired for my time metrics. I helped people fix problems that employees trying to beat the 2 minute time criteria created and helped a great many people. (members were finally able to get Chemo meds) TOTALLY WORTH IT. At the end of the day it isn't how fast you work, it's how many lives you touch.

review_title: Great To Be King, Not So Great To Be A Peasant.
pros: There are some great people here that make the experience of working in a call center bearable. Some good opportunities for the best of the best. if you make the numbers, you can move from account to account during seasonal ramp ups and draw downs. IF you can get yourself promoted, it can almost be a fun place to work!
cons:
The job is completely about numbers. How many? How fast? And while they are promoting the quantity over quality model, they still use the quality against you if you are otherwise making numbers. 

Connextions takes its HIPAA regulations to an extreme that makes working there.. almost impossible. The quality of life on the floor is low. Morale is generally low. Management has managed to chase off many quality people over the years so the over-all quality of your co-workers is.. low.

pros: Salary. Paid Time Off. Education.
cons: No work life balance. Telecommunicator. Unrealistic expectations and metrics. Poor software systems for documentation. No back up for vacation or sick time. Poor Management. Cliques. Micromanagement. Usage of Optum and Avia call monitoring and Time tracking. Creates anxiety and poor patient care. After working for 8 years informed my calls were of no value. Program I worked for placed multiple employees on CAPS with >5 years employment. Before leaving. Exit interview withdrew from my intranet web site.

job_title: Business Process Analyst in Orlando, FL
pros: Most of the managers I've had have truly had my best interests at heart. They take my opinion seriously and I have a direct impact with the work that I do.
cons: I am underpaid in my field, and due to internal promotion I only get bare minimum increases, even though my manager tells the group I perform at four levels above.  I'm still paid at just above entry level after four years of service.

review_title: Great Company, left because of building
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: UHG itself is a great company, there is so much opportunity to grow and advance once you get into the company. My co workers and superiors were great to work with.
cons: I worked out of the 12125 technology drive 2 location. My advice to you if you are applying to the company is find out if the position you are applying is at this location. There is no cell reception at all in the building. There is rat traps down by the EMPTY cafeteria that is not being used. The building is super empty most of the time because everyone just wants to work from home as much as possible. If you get to go to any of the other locations within the twin cities it just makes you more upset that you work out of the technology 2 location. I was so excited to get a job at this company and day by day at this location drained every ounce of enjoyment I had until I finally decided to move on.

pros: In  2016 cab facilities were good but in 2017 it degrades to temo
cons:
First you won't get feel that you are associate with fortune 14 company. Senior manger don't listen to employees. Mangers doesn't know how to speak English. If you want to improve your Telugu then you must join it. No personal life. 
 I think highest working hour in hyderabad. 
Work pressure, no one knows how to talk to each other,  mangers doesn't have convening power to convince their employee, people are leaving everyday coz of mangers pressure.
This company is for who didn't get job any where will get job in Optum.
  One day I asked to my manger why you didn't hire good people, he told if I hire better than me they won't listen to me. They do their own. I simply smiled n laughed on my destiny.

job_title: Senior Provider Services Representative in Ridgeland, MS
pros: Excellent Benefits Package; Great Focus on Team Building; Excellent Training Opportunities; Work Load can be heavy, but is simple; Upper Management can be iffy, but they mean well, and stay in constant contact with your department.
cons: Shift Selection is unfair and unreliable; You get blamed for system issues that are out of your control by upper management; Terrible Growth Opportunities; Talent Acquisition Department does a very poor job in their selection and hiring process. You can be the most qualified candidate, have references, and even internal referrals, and they will still hire someone less qualified with no explanation. I saw this happen constantly, which is why many people eventually quit.

pros: Flexible timing. Lots of learning
cons: Too much work to do

review_title: UBH as a managed care organization is a broken system.
job_title: Care Advocate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent pay and decent benefits.  It is better than being unemployed.
cons: Licensed mental health professionals employed by UBH are treated like line workers.  We are micromanaged and treated punitively.  There are no bonuses and no reward programs for good performance.  Benefits are at the 50th percentile though we are expected to perform at the 99th percentile.  We don't even get a cost-of-living raise!

review_title: Great pay and benefits for you, horrible work environment depending on department
pros: I can say that I love the amount I get paid, and I have good benefits. The parties are great as well, as the President is the one who coordinates. However, he has no idea of how some of his directors treat employees, and on what ground people are promoted.
cons:
If your manager likes you - you're a shoe-in!!! If you do your work quickly (never mind the mistakes - someone else may be able to cover them up depending on who you are) - you're a shoe-in!!! If you kiss major booty and act like you know everything without actually knowing anything and can pass the buck every chance you get and take the credit - YOU ARE A SHOE-IN!

Basically, be as fake as possible. Also, the benefits are only great for employees - your family cannot be covered for a reasonable amount unless you are a Director or Senior Management. But that may be any job today...

review_title: If you want to grow as an employee, this place is not for you
job_title: Billing and Eligibility in Oldsmar, FL
pros:
pay is competitive for the local marketplace
community involvement/volunteerism
definite discipline process
annual background checks 
It takes ALOT to get fired
cons:
benefits are expensive and offer little coverage with maximum out of pocket
paid time off is difficult to get approved
managers micro-manage, constantly look over your shoulder
compensation (annual raises/bonuses) are not consistent
systems are out-dated
managers are so worried about the big picture, they fail to realize its the day-to-day stuff that gets them there
no room for advancement
They don't care about the employees, only they have a warm body in the chair
Will hire anyone, regardless of education, skills, abilities or professionalism
impossible to work with management/recruiting on career advancement, its who you know not what you know
if you don't "go along to get along", you will be pushed out

job_title: Radiology Technologist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: I love my job! I don't know what else to say? This is the most positive cultured company I have ever worked for as a Rad Tech. Upper mgmt is always encouraging us to strive better, complimenting where due, and my co-workers are awesome! Lots of PTO time and it has always been approved, as they want you to enjoy your time away from the workplace. You cannot carry-over more than 40 hours at the end of a year. They offer a lot of other benefits that I have not seen in previous positions. Managers and supervisors are superior in my market-keep it up!
cons: This is a very hard company to get into. My advice: keep trying. It took me MANY times to get where I am and now I see why. They don't just hire 'anyone!' Insurance isn't the best as far as co-pays, but they've got you covered with a few different choices to meet your individual needs. Premiums are tiered based on your salary, so that is fair. There is no 'sick' time accrual. You only get PTO.

review_title: UHC does not care about its employees
job_title: Service Account Manager Associate in Roanoke, VA
pros: Great if it’s your first job in a call center, if you don’t have any children, if you’re not ambitious and don’t want to climb the totem pole of career advancement. Lots of team building events. The company focuses in on compassion unlike any other for their demographic
cons: If you want to go where you’ll be appreciated, this is NOT the place. This company works their employees to the brim while not at all paying a competitive wage. The medical benefits are awful, there’s a 3k deductible for just myself alone this year making each provider visit about $150 an appointment. Leadership will often have focus groups to have us voice our concerns, but often focuses on the more menial tasks when looking to make improvements. A previous supervisor of mine had several cases for harassment out and nothing was ever done. They don’t truly protect from retaliation. As far as career advancement, they will tell you 1 year and that is a lie 90% of the time. If you move into this company, start above entry level as they treat even their tenured employees with disgrace. No work life balance as schedules are assigned every 6 months with RARE exceptions.

review_title: Worked as app. developer in the provider services division. Very bad developer environment.
pros: Good benefits and telecommuting options.
cons:
1) Extremely behind the times as far as development goes. If your aim is to work with, and learn newer stuff (i.e.new methodologies, tools, frameworks, etc.,) steer clear of their provider services team. 
2) They place managers with little to no coding experience in charge of developer teams. 
3) They invest very little in employee continuing education
4) They routinely remind developers about "offshore assets", a veiled threat that you can easily be replaced by Indian software developers. UHG has a huge presence in India. 
5) The telecommuting hardware/software environment is very much overly "big brother"-like. The supplied computers are chalked full of spyware, keyloggers; they watch and record your every move....and non-move..

job_title: IT Systems Analyst Consultant in Hartford, CT
pros: Initual salary offer is decent but be prepared to be overworked .
cons:
Aftet you atr hired You will work so much overtime with no compensation either in form of money or comp time. Very stressful. Layoffs are common. You may go years with no salary increase. There is No pension but thy offer 401k. If you dont take a bus, you will pay to park your car., in hartford up to 200.00 a month. You may not be allowed to occasionally work from home even  even though your management works from home full time .
The employee medical plan is marginal and expensive.  They do provide free coffee to keep you awake during those 10 hour days.

review_title: Not the company it used to be...
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Overland Park, KS
pros: I worked on the specialty side at OptumRx.  It has (had) great benefits, and so long as you made your numbers and specialty was a really easy place to work and get along...before the merger.  Since then, it's been about what you would expect from a big company after a poorly-executed merger.
cons:
Since the Catamaran/BriovaRx merger, benefits have gone down, management has started serious micromanagement, even when it's not necessary, regardless of department, and regardless of an employee's production.  Benefits and incentives have been reduced, and most of the company's promises regarding pay and benefits have turned out to be empty.  Over half the original employees left 
 (50 minimum) over the course of a single year.  The new system they've  adopted is poorly designed and unnecessarily complicated

pros:
- The amount of PTO you get from the start is great
- People that work here are nice
- Seems to run like a well oiled machine
cons:
- No room for innovation
- The companies organizations aren't making money so you have to justify every expense or software.  This leads to some organizations not letting you use the technology that they have available.... never had this experience in a company until coming to UHG.  Teams telling other team members/ teams they can't use what their team paid for even if it should benefit the clients and/ or patients
- Yes, everyone I have worked with is nice.  None of them seem to know how to advance in their careers.  They are "stuck"
-  The compensation agreed to was changed at the last second from the recruiter...

review_title: Big Opportunities in a Tangle of Red Tape
pros: A mature, large organization with stability, resources, and capital. Opportunities abound if you're willing to move to other metropolitan areas, primarily in the Midwest. Senior executives make an honest attempt to communicate frequently with staff on current events within the business and industry.
cons:
UnitedHealth Group is a bureaucratic nightmare. Approvals to do anything require complicated forms (usually found online after days of searching), requesting the approval of managers scattered across the country and maybe around the world. If the non-business units -- Accounting, IT, HR -- aren't creating new and more complicated processes and forms to use resources, they are demanding you provide details about existing business practices for 'audits.'

Senior executives' use of frequent emails to highlight trivia or administrative tasks, -- volunteer opportunities, employee surveys -- turns minor issues into 'must do' actions at the expense of focusing on the core business operations.

review_title: Good company, but oh my gosh the burn out rate is pushed under the rug (big ol' secret)!
job_title: Health Advisor in Green Bay, WI
pros: Decent pay, opportunities to move up in the company if you are motivated to do so. Great training department. Decent health benefits. 401 k and stock options. Travel/relocation options. Work at home options.
cons: Your shift switches every 3 months!  hard to plan long term. Not enough employees, too much (mandatory) overtime. I have been on mandatory overtime for over a year and a half. I miss my family. Lack of Communication of direction from management at times. Hard to get a shift that ends prior to 7 or 8 pm with all of this overtime.

review_title: Physicians (and everyone else) do not work here
job_title: Physician Advisor in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Free parking other than that, free coffee? For now at least. Horrible coffee.
cons: I wish EHR would have rescinded my offer - to the 100's of physicians who were affected: you are better off! This place is a nightmare. Pay was very low and no one ever received the full bonus thanks to UHG's magical 'target numbers'. I worked with physicians who are 'eligible for board certification' but who are not board certified. I also worked with nurse letter coordinators (who actually do what everyone think I do) who barely spoke English and I spent most of my time correcting their grammar and/or falling off my chair laughing. The company has cut a lot of their work force. Some positions were eliminated due to cost-control (such as outsourcing nurses to the Phillipines), others due to lack of need, such as the implementation team. A lot of very talented people were let go, but if your company is not growing and not acquiring new business it is understandable. For the few employees who are left, I would suggest that EHR wise up to the fact that the economy is not as bad as they think and the competition pays more.

review_title: Physician Advisor conned by Cocktails and Conversations
job_title: Physician Advisor in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Nothing. Absolutely nothing. I'd be lying if I said anything.
cons: Position is nothing like what was described at the C&C. There is no freedom, no stress-free scheduling. I had to schedule a small window of time to get up from the computer and take the dog outside. if you pause for a minute, the command center calls you immediately to remind you of the expectations for case turnaround time. It feels like Big Brother. Even after I packed up for the day, I was a nervous wreck and had trouble relaxing because it felt like someone was still watching my productivity and I would get yelled at for watching tv. Other employees were treated poorly as well. Employees in IT told me they hadn't received raises or bonuses in years and their time was scrutinized down the minute of arrival and departure.

review_title: This company has one thing on it's mind.....process claims---no matter if you understand it or not!!!
job_title: Claims Processor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits were ok.  They do provide healthcare,  After training you get to work flexible hours and it becomes somewhat easier.
cons: It seems that UnitedHealth Care has grown quite a bit in the last few years.  That is good in one sense but, along with the sudden growth it has brought confusion and an air of "factory worker mentality".  In training you are taught to process claims no matter what.  The information is literally thrown at you.  You always feel like you are about 2 weeks behind and always trying to play catch up.  This was the most confusing job I have ever had anything to do with.  My advise would be don't even apply if you do not have some experience in medical codes and/or terminology.

pros: If you like being abused, then you will love this job.
cons:
Leadership/management lack basic understanding of the job the employees are doing.  Focus is on making the "reports" look good.  Company does not live its mission/vision/values.  Extremely high staff turnover rate, average tenure of employees is three years.  Services sold to clients/consumers are not what is being delivered.  The word, scam is a good way to sum it up.  Working for an insurance company one would believe there would be reasonable benefits coverage, not true.  

You do NOT want to work for this company.  You will HATE it.   This has been the only employer In 35 years that I ever considered quitting by walking out, no notice.  This was on way too many occasions to count.   The employees need to organize, get union protection..

review_title: transition job not a life long place to have a full career
job_title: Intake Counselor in San Francisco, CA
pros: There can be nice people to work for depending on the group you are with.  You have autonomy once you have been there for awhile however, you always have big brother looking over you.  It is very clear on how you stand since all of your calls are recorded and scored which they give you access to so you can learn and improve. It is a good transition job.
cons: The job itself can be VERY boring and redundant.  It's difficult to move up in clinical positions without your clinical license.  Even though you are technically in a clinical role you are more of a customer service representative then anything.

job_title: Care Advocate in San Diego, CA
pros: Honestly, nothing at all.  Nice external environment for breaks.  Coffee/tea station.
cons: Low salary compared to similar companies and position.  Equipment does not work, so neither can you.  Computers are down, telephones too, headsets not working.  Management is super controlling and micromanaging.  Constant abuse with threats of termination right at the gate on Day #2.  Communication with other departments nearly impossible.  Non-responsive HR.  Necessary passwords for mandatory programs not available.  Cult-like atmosphere.  Staff walk around like Stepford Wives.  The most morally depressing, robotic milieu anywhere.  Very punitive management.  Mandatory "training" (hours and hours of it) nothing more than adverts for company.

review_title: Expect less and hope for more.
pros: Great people and work/life balance.  Have worked here many years and have seen very little turnover.  Some of the best most talented people I have ever met.
cons: Loss of human factor over the years.  Sr Leaders are only concerned about bottom line.  Town Halls will speak of massive record breaking profits and offer 1.3% merit increase and 65% participation RRP.  Tons of re-org of senior leadership loves using snappy terms such as Agile, collaboration, Synergy.  When the staff just wants to perform their job responsibilities and provide an excellent customer experience.

pros: salary, benefits, bonuses, 401k match
cons: EMR is awful, charting often takes >8 hours for one note (yes, for one note!) and charting until the wee hours of the morning to get the monthly patient load done constantly, short term patients are very complex and the amounts of charting and frankly ridiculous paperwork associated with them is getting more onerous by the month, there is great pressure to treat in SNF rather than send to hospital for patients that are very ill and should in no way be kept in house and my colleagues and I often worry about our licenses, if you send patients out you likely will not get a bonus, new benchmarks for bonuses will make it nearly impossible to get them, unethical mandated lab work on patients to survey for diseases that treatment for makes no difference in this population but it's all about the Benjamins baby. Most clinicians take this job because of the flexibility but now they're even taking that away and want clinicians to be in the SNFs from 8-5. There is literally nothing good about working for Optum Care now, sadly. You will feel professionally humiliated by the unethical mandated lab work and your soul will be crushed from having turned from a clinician to a glorified data entry processor.

review_title: If your main objective is to help senior management look good, this is the place to be!
pros: Middle management does a good job of recognizing employees for their hard work. There is lots of flexibility as far as working from home or taking time off to care for a sick child.
cons: There is very little opportunity for personal growth. I took a position that l believed held lots of potential for advancement, but three years later, after lots of hard work, great suggestions for improvement, and kudos from middle management, I'm still here. Senior managment does very little to recognize and reward good employees.

pros: i don't see any good from this company.
cons: This company says they hire equally.  This is unture.  They hire based on sex, race, religion, gender, rather than based on experience and knowledge. They also are very political.  They recently were awarded the TriCare West Government Contract. Prior to this award, they did not care about Military personnel in their company, or anywhere. Once the contract was in the award process, they started political stuff to say they support military and are giving money to wounded warriors.  They are so fake, it's pitiful. If you are considered a minority by everyday standard, then you stand a chance to succeed in this company.  If you are smart, driven and want to suceed and make a difference. Don't go here. They won't let you succeed!!

review_title: Flexible work arrangements, benefit extremely poor
pros: Was able to work from home.  Great people, culture, and ease of navigating.  Lots of work to do.
cons: After just under 2 yrs, was laid off due to a restructure.  I took a pay cut to go to UHG - they wouldn't even match my previous salary.  Gave out bonuses for projects well done, but pay increase was horrible at around 1%.  The biggest downfall believe it or not was the poor health insurance package.  You would think it would be better for employees, but the high deductibles, no co-pay plans forced me to take an extra $250 per paycheck out for my HSA just to cover deductibles - and that doesn't include the premiums.  Totally not worth it to work here.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The culture and the network of teams. Availability of nationwide and global placements. Diversity isn't just a word, from the leadership to the front line, there is diversity in working styles and skillets. They promote within and externally (good balance) and have a great recognition program.  Good benefit package and many folks have an ability to work from home, which helps with work-life balance or busy cities to avoid loss time during commutes.
cons: Some, but not all departments are dealing with antiquated technology resources for a fast pace changing industry.  Lack of available mentors for career development  resources to branch outside one's common role functions to grow in new areas.

pros: Nothing at the moment, thanks...
cons:
I (62) work here. I pay for family insurance out of my paycheck like everyone. For two months the whole family was given coverage. Then the HR team here told me that they were going to need to see a marriage license to prove I was married to my wife (59). We were married in Lubbock, TX in 1977. Getting the marriage license took time, but I got it as soon as we could and within the time limit. HR rejected it, saying that too much time had passed. This was even after I provided proof that we were within the time limit. 
So... what really happened? Scandal and ageism. 
My wife has no serious ailments, but she does have those commonly associated with someone her age. My youngest children (19 and 22) are both covered. I am still covered. However, knowing they would not get more than a few years of employment from me, and knowing senior (or almost senior) people need more healthcare, they refused my wife. It's a FAMILY PLAN FOR ONE OF THEIR OWN EMPLOYEES! 
If I were looking at working here or being insured here, I would want to know how unethically they treat their own people.

pros: The Monday-Friday off before 6pm schedule was amazing! The company perks were decent.  The possibility of career advancement was also good. Pay was ok for someone who is just starting out.
cons: I worked for the TX Medicaid, & it was horrible. No one was on the same page. Took over 10 minutes to get answers from your peers because not much management or floor support is available that may or may not be correct. Since the providers called daily, they always received conflicting information making it harder for you to do assist them because they want to know why you say one thing & the previous rep said another. The outsourced callers were the worse, attitude wise. Strict attendance policy, so not quite flexible if you’re a single parent with little to no additional support for your children.

review_title: Great company if you want to looking for long run
pros:
1. Ample amount of quality work
2. R&D is in it best form as you are free to do any type of research and also will get support. 
3. Superb work environment and friendly colleagues (including director and vp)
4. Work life balance, free food, free cab
5. As all teams are sitting under one roof you can communicate easily for any situation without creating any type of ticket.
6. Descent hike for avg ratings(8-12%) but sky-high hike for upper end ratings (18-25%)
7. Every year 2 people are chosen from every campus(from Bangalore jp Nagar location out of 300 people) for service hero, who will get 4 days vacation outside India with other service heros all over the world sponsored by company itself.
cons:
1. Food quality
2. Longer period of time for r&d
3. Listen to your other employees ideas and thoughts who are not that much talented than your star employee in a team.
4. Make email conversations mandatory for any type of changes in prior requirements.

review_title: A solid company where you working alongside very smart and dedicated people.
job_title: Associate Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
* Great talent, you learn from interacting with very capable people 
* At the forefront of telecommuting opportunities, flexible work schedules and the like
* Great communication system keeping employees throughout this $90B company closely connected
* Excellent PTO allowance (23 days + 8 legal holidays)
* Decent pay and solid medical benefits (including a generous discount if you pass a yearly biometrics test and get wellness counseling for those you don't pass)
cons:
* Poor on-boarding process, very little training (sink or swim approach)
* Some managers (being brought up in the sink or swim environment) do not develop their people well
* Expectations are high but many times resources are severly limited and the right tools may be available, but either your boss doesn't know about them or no one knows how to use them.

pros: Challenging environment, massive projects, and working in the chaos has been educational which I'm sure I'll put to good use later in my career.
cons:
So called "important" or "critical" projects have their funding cut often; sometimes in the beginning but often in mid-project.

Figure out if your manager is human or not before you express your belief that family comes first.  Not all managers are like this, but it is better to figure out before saying anything.

So many layers of management and red tape it can be a fulltime job just deciphering who you need to talk to.

Some leaders are under the impression that steamrolling people is how you get the job done, I always thought that was accomplished by earning respect through ones actions.  At least the good managers I've worked for believed that and it seemed to work for them... until they were run out.

Standards?  What standards?

pros:
There is plenty of opportunity to pursue.
Flexible hours and work locations.
The pay and benefits is fair, and can be good if you deliver; but its still up to you to play-the-game to get the most for your work.
cons: If you have specific career goals, formed without consideration and an accurate view of the organization and opportunities, you will be frustrated.  There are cliques (and their corresponding realms of control) that are virtually impenetrable.  This is a HUGE, highly political organization.  There is a great deal of movement in terms of people, organizational structure, and responsibility; this is a source of much of the "Pros" opportunity I mentioned above.  On the flip side there are other opportunities that could be yours to be the next to fail at.

review_title: UHG is a great company but in my opinion, is getting to big.
pros: The people (coworkers) are pretty great once you get to know them.  When you initially join the company or a new team, it can feel pretty cold and isolating.  However, its a big company and you continually run into people throughout your career here.  Time-off is good and management does take care of their employees when it comes to family and personal issues.  Depending on the department, work-life balance is pretty good.
cons: Finding a good to great manager to work for is really hard to find.  I've had micro managers, managers that dont care how much you work and are told you need to work more; or managers that are very cold and heartless.

review_title: Inconsistent professional env, bad co-workers and mgmt, terrible communication
pros: Free snacks, some nice employees, general friendliness.  IT is good.  Can work from home.
cons:
Tries to retain its "startup" atmosphere, but it just encourages co-workers to be too informal with each other.  So, the sense of professionalism is inconsistent across company, and lines do tend to get crossed.  I have been unlucky to work with a lot of this.  Even your nice managers and the "friendly" co-workers that train you can be untrustworthy.  Some pretty shady things go down in this company, for better or for worse, in secret.  This also applies to the management and their decision-making.

Also, real work and knowledge are centralized in the core members of the company, the managers mainly, but so much so that transparency, training, and communication are not forthcoming.  Most people don't know much beyond their team about what's going, and for the most part, they are ok with that, working in silos.

review_title: Terrible Insurance, but okay place to work.
job_title: Senior Pharmacy Technician in Sugar Land, TX
pros: The job itself is super easy. I don't know how some people think this is a difficult job. Pay is decent.
cons: Management. Hands down the management is awful. Awfulllllll! There has been so much turnover since we got a new manager. Next, the insurance is just trash. The plans have no copay until you meet your expensive deductible, so if a dr wants to charge you $500 to see them, that's what you'll have to pay. Who works at an insurance company that has awful insurance?! That makes no sense. Also, they hire anybody. Some people have no computer skills, yet they hire them and wonder why they can't succeed. Plus the job is all based on numbers, how much you put out, how fast you put out work. They need to hire people who actually know how to use computers and speak English.

job_title: Lead Cumstomer Service Representative in Overland Park, KS
pros: PTO, match up to 6% on 401K plans and fully vested after 1 year, you get to really help people and coworkers are the best.. A lot of people work from their home (after 3 years I have never been approved to though)
cons: Not family friendly. Mandatory overtime in Jan-March every year. You have to meet ridiculous metric to bonus and the more work you do to help the patients the less chance you will get a bonus at all or a good ranking for the shift bids that happen every 3-6 months. So your schedule is always changing unless you cut your calls short or refuse to help people.

review_title: Just another robot for the company
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hooksett, NH
pros: Love my team mates, we support each other because we all know we’re all treated the same and management does not care.
cons: Very fast paced call center. Not enough resources to manage your calls, confusing system to locate members benefits. Co-Workers are good support system but not management. Very few get the opportunity to advance up the ladder unless you know someone or suck up. New hires are offered more money that what tenured reps are currently making. Management wont even address it beside stating be grateful you have a job. No room for errors, quick to write you up, no matter how good you are at your job and an asset to the company. They are too concerned about making their numbers and looking good to upper management. Work/Life balance is limited. Very difficult to take time off and needs to be well in advance or it will be an occurrence. The benefits are terrible, most of our members have a better package than they offer the employees, yet we are supposed to be empathetic to their needs and concerns.

job_title: Community Health Worker in New York, NY
pros: Telecommuter. Mainly work from home and the rest you are doing field visits to members' home, hospitals and other healthcare facilities. It's great when you impact a member's life in a positive way.
cons: Constant changes. Higher up are always coming up with ideas that are usually poor in quality to impose on us to do. CHWs' are the backbone and do the majority of the work and get majority of the blame. You feel  more like a robot rather than a human being. Lots of changes from Optum and UnitedHealth care and massive layoffs going on. Pay increase is by merit only once a year usually $0.25 more per hour. Less flexible hours unlike a year ago.

review_title: If you want large enterprise experience, this is the place.
job_title: IT Operating Systems Consultant in Plymouth, MN
pros: Most of the people are great (non-managers and 1st line managers). The large IT environment is fairly quick paced and changing for a company of this size so it's a great place to get exposure to a large enterprise environment. Flexible work from home policy (but it was never "official" so I felt like it could go away at any moment.)
cons: They pay a lot of lip service to placing employees first, when in fact, money is the driving factor in all decision making processes. This meant low starting salary, low or no raises, no decent training, horrible benefits, old PCs and other office equipment.  It was even hard to get a decent monitor or keyboard.  With the exception of my first line manager, I never felt like anyone at the company really cared about the employees.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Green Bay, WI
pros: Pay is ok, but that's pretty much it.
cons:
Where to start....Managment is a joke, just ask numerous employees, or maybe you should refer to letters that are sent to directors and nothing happens to the managers at fault.  Basicly laugh it off and move on.  Or maybe you could get hired and get promised things such as advancement oppertunities and have them taken away for absolutely no reason at all.  But maybe I'm wrong, maybe if your  stats get better that gives managment a reason.  TENURE, hey hey it doesn't matter what you do statisticly, if your here for 5 + years, your golden!  So if you don't work hard, and plan on being in the same position your entire life, this is the place for you!!  Managment is the key problem here, as you will find out if you get hired with this company.  


Just throw people under the bus, make up lies and you'll be fine!  People reading this post may think that i'm just upset about some situation and am blowing this out of proportion.  I really am not, take my word for it.  Good Luck Everybody!!

review_title: Bad management; unsupported, overworked, stressed employees
pros:
Good salary
Innovative product development - new approaches to managing healthcare
Guaranteed book of business - most customers come from parent company, UnitedHealth.
cons: Fear-based organization.  Very high turnover.  Senior Management operates in a command-and-control leadership style.  The bloated ranks of middle management are focused on proving their value to Sr Management. The result is a culture of micro-management - serving middle managers - so that they can report up on their staff's activity.  Lower-level and client-facing employees are left on their own to navigate e complex and confusing organization in order to meet the needs of the clients.  Without the United Health book of business, OptumHealth is not competitive.  It's top heavy and would collapse under its own weight.

pros: Hourly pay wasn't bad, daily job tasks were easy enough, lots of choices in shift availability
cons: The Health Advisor role was a horrible fit for me. While the job involved easy tasks like answering member questions and reviewing benefits for members, there were too many flaws with upper management and standard operating procedures. Supervisors take absolutely no responsibility when it comes to helping their team members with escalated members. Health Advisors are expected to de-escalate members or offer to have a supervisor call them back in 24-48 hours.. Which they never do, they make the HA call the angry member back! I would never go back to this company to do anything where I was forced to interact with members and be reprimanded when an irate member threatens us or hangs up.

review_title: Depends on the location; Great in Phoenix, not in Eau Claire, WI.
pros: There's plenty of openings now, as opposed to when the recession hit. If you network correctly, you can move up fairly fast.
cons: In the Eau Claire office, there's a culture problem that's become an issue. Some departments are hiring qualified people to lead teams, some aren't, and hiring middle management based on how well they know the person and not their qualifications to do the job. A supervisor had incorrectly given low yearly reviews across the board (which were used to determine our pay raise-if we qualified), once it was pointed out, it took a few months to correct. People (myself included) went from a 2 (under expectations) to a 4 (above expectations) but did not receive a pay raise. If you received a 4, that was supposed to merit a raise. It hasn't.

review_title: Not a good job for a manager
pros: Work was interesting, downtrodden managers and staff were very nice people.
cons:
Managers have 100% of the responsibility and no control.  Executives need to approve any request for PTO and arbitrarily deny vacation.  Replacing positions require approval from some nameless group that doesn't meet in December.  Profit is created by the vacancy rate which extends to three months.  No excuse for not getting the work done however.
Accrued PTO is lost the second the employee gives notice, so a smart employee takes vacation (or sick leave if they do not want to go through the bureaucracy) and comes back to work for one day to give notice and clean out their desk.  
Have been a manager for 25 years and have never had so many executives micro manage the work......

pros:
It's been great working at UHG, and the one thing that actually motivated to be the company for long was the colleagues in the team. 
Onsite Project Managers and Program Managers were the best part of the job, they mentored and motivated very well and working with them was really a great experience of my life.
Work life balance was really good.
Good Cab Facility and night shift allowance was paid as per the band.
Good employee engagement programs conducted by the internal team on occasional basis.
cons:
Due to massive employee strength, very less scope to add value to your career as your work scope is limited.
Salary hikes reduced year on year.
As the employee strength started growing massively, the space constraints was a issue which limited people from working during the meeting calls.
Earlier it was an admin and data entry job but that changed after a very long time.
Managers biased towards specific subordinates during review.

pros: Company highly values ethics and integrity, company strives to stay current with technology (see cons), generous PTO, many levels and layers of support for various needs of assistance from manager to HR to compliance hotline (to report violations), very willing to accommodate family needs, perfectly willing to spend a boatload of money non-standard computers (developer laptops, tablets, etc) IF a valid business need can be demonstrated.
cons: High deductibles for health insurance, management tries too hard to do more with less, company is so large that it is eternally behind in technology, policy over results, obnoxiously insane computer security measures, tough to advance without time off for outside training for a completely different role unless you happen to be in the right place at the right time (because we have NO time to waste on career advancement training during the workday), too much emphasis on diversity/social responsibility.

review_title: Great work/life balance.. Not good benefits
pros: Your experience depends on your manager.. I have a great work/ life balance, flexibility, a great manager, gym and cafe on site, wonderful co-workers. I like coming to work, and enjoy my job even when it's challenging. Great career growth opportunities and lots of cross training available to us.
cons: Our benefits are an embarrassment. We pay way more for much less than many of my friends in similar types of jobs and I work for the Health insurance co.. Very frustrating and expensive to see a doctor. It's a better deal for me to buy my meds online and see docs online than to use my insurance the deductibles are very high.

job_title: Regional Account Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Overall benefits package are pretty good. They offer different PTO level depending upon your salary grade and years of employment. Max is about 34 days PTO. They offer discounts for different companies such as Apple, AT&T, etc to name a few. Plus tuition discount and tuition reimbursement with participating accredited colleges.
cons: Medical coverage are very high in deductible. Even the most expensive, is still high out of pocket. They offer HMO but only in certain locations. Management will always say that they are listening and put the values of the company as something they are working on. Recruiting process is hard. Recruiters basically hold the power of you even making it to an in person interview. Very low yearly raise. In the cents. Only time you get a good raise is if you get an internal promotion to a higher position. They do not take care of their good employees. Would rather spend time and money hiring new employees.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: WFH is the thing i can think of as positive point... nothing else
cons:
1) Unprofessional Managers(Atleast mine surely is)
2) Extremly dirty polictics 
3) Managers openly ask you to give him a good rating in his vital signs (Manager's feedback or 360 feedback) or else suffer.
4) 20% of your pay is variable which you get if and only if you can maintain "Yes Boss" attitude.
5) At the time of appraisals managers openely tell you that he/she has to maintain a "bell curve" so can not give a high rating. Rating has nothing to do with your performance
6) Sir/Madam culture is followed, no one works on first name basis. If you dare to call your manager by name, he wont say anything... he will just screw you inside out at the time of appraisals.
7) Coming to facilities, the most basic thing that one can think of is a right to park your car. Please dont expect that in UHG. There is no such thing as first come first serve. Only managers and above get parking sticker people below managers dont have the basic right of bringing car at office.

pros: It's a job.Telecommuting is allowed, depending on manager's preferences (this can vary, even within a small group).
cons: Where to start?  The company is good at buying other companies, but terrible at integrating them.  Result:  constant conflict on the department and individual level. We have archaic systems, and yet the company constantly brags about how innovative we are. Work/life balance is laughably nonexistent. Employees are poorly trained. I work in an area where documents are reviewed by numerous individuals, and few can handle Word or PDF documents. Responsibilities are poorly defined between groups, leaving considerable overlap, and employees often end up expressing opinion rather than contributing anything substantial.  In my immediate group promotions go to friends of the director. Company has been on a cost-cutting binge for the past 5 years, so compensation is minimal. Health benefits are worse than the much smaller non-profit I came from. The office set-up is a huge cube farm. This makes for a very distracting environment. The company expresses very lofty corporate values, but they are completely aspiration.  No consistency among members of work groups in how jobs are performed; this also leads to conflict and confusion in interacting with other work groups.

job_title: Physician Advisor in Newtown Square, PA
pros: Work from home. Great work/life balance. Good training on the front end. At first, fellow employees were very willing to help and give advice on case reviews. Team leaders were slow in answering questions and following up on cases but were nonetheless helpful and willing to offer their guidance on difficult cases.
cons: Poor management. Little potential for advancement or lateral moves as the company's business deteriorated and client hospitals pulled out following changes in Medicare admission guidelines. Multiple layoffs occurred at all levels of the company. Executive and mid-level management either did not correctly predict the impact of Medicare guideline changes on the company's business or were not honest about what they foresaw when talking to lower level employees.

review_title: OK, but lots of room for improvement
job_title: Care Coordinator in Overland Park, KS
pros: They offer a lot of flexibility in scheduling your workday. No one bats an eye if you leave for awhile to pick up your kid from school or run to a doctor's appointment.  Generous amounts of PTO.
cons: Salary inequity.  Social workers with master's degrees and 10, 15, 20 years experience are being paid significantly less money to do the exact same job as nurses with a fraction of the education and experience.  Men are paid more than women.  Supervisors and management have, for the most part, all been promoted to their level of incompetence.

pros:
Access to great employee tools for work, career, etc
Decent insurance if you take advantage of all discounts - can be hard to tell your spouse to also jump through all the hoops.
cons:
Sub par pay, no raises, vary small bonus unless you are an executive level.
Many workers are hourly compared to other career profiles at large companies
Poor leadership in the lower levels.
People are looking at tiny benefits and making them sound wonderful to make up for short comings.

pros: Great supervisors. Good place to be if you're still trying to figure out your career path and don't mind grinding for about 3 years.
cons:
You may find yourself "pursuing other opportunities" with absolutely no warning to you whatsoever . 
You may find yourself making $5 less than your co-workers for the exact same job. 
If you see a posting for  a helpdesk position offering  $15/hr. You're recruiter is lying to you. Four of my co-workers were making $20/hr and  Three were making $13/hr  for the exact same answer-phones-all-day-pretending-to-be-3-different-queues position.
You may find yourself with  outdated hardware that you will have to deal with for 3 years before you're "eligible for an upgrade" This is reasoned as "The IT department doesn't make any money for the company." Maintenance doesn't count.
Advancements are offered to FTEs, so be prepared to grind for a bit.

job_title: Enrollment and Eligibility Representative in Hooksett, NH
pros: Desks that can be raised and lowered for comfort. The job function itself.
cons: Supervisors and managers who are either inexperienced or in the wrong job. Essentially the teams are managed by fear- fear created by being  ridiculously micromanaged. Managers have created an environment in which the reps are fearful to speak up in meetings let alone approach their supervisor. Everyone wants to “stay under the radar” even if what they have to say isn’t critical. Reps are encouraged to send out kudos through and internal system. Yet as  many that get sent online (hundreds during a month) there is no evidence  of camaraderie in team or department meetings or in the department as a whole.

pros: The company is relatively flexible when it comes to telecommuting.  If you are looking for mobility, there are opportunities in various geographic areas.
cons: I've worked for a few organizations and this has been the worst by far. If you enjoy working extremely long hours and being treated poorly, this is the organization for you. The management brings Dilbert to life.  In the area I worked, the employee satisfaction scores were extremely low.  The management had employees volunteer to develop solutions.  After several fair and reasonable ideas were presented and rejected, management basically forced a department potluck.  The employees had to have it after work hours and they brought the food.  The CEO took home over $150 million in 2 years but they couldn't even offer employees a hot dog or a cookie.

review_title: Overall a great company (Optum), industry leader and lots of challenges despite the red tape
pros: Industry leader.  Some of the best technology and people in the business.  Compensation is in line with industry and top performers are usually rewarded.  Generally a good culture and programs in place to back this up.  I worked in a distributed workforce with many telecommuters which made this more difficult.
cons: Management shuffles lead to RIFs so that new leaders can make an impact on bottom line without thinking about investing for the future or the employees that got them there.  I became an employee through an acquisition and continued to receive top ratings for a couple years and when a new Sr. Management structure took over I was let go as part of a RIF without given an opportunity to find a new home.  IT projects move at glacial speed due to red tape.

review_title: I enjoyed the people I met and the things I learned-that's about it.
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Sunrise, FL
pros: I learned so much about Medicare and health insurance in general. I can honestly say that the work life balance was impeccable. I was in nursing school and every semester my schedule changed--my business manager accommodated each change until she could do no more. Even though the pay was much lower than that of competitors, we did receive raises every so often. in a 2.5 year period I went from 12.98 to 13.22 to 14.33 to 15.14 per hour.
cons: Supervisors and trainers are hired without knowledge of tasks assigned to their employees. Upper management is clueless to what CSRs are going through. More of a popularity contest.

review_title: Difficult to navigate, but it's getting better...
pros: Good work/life balance, competitive pay, and a very generous amount of PTO immediately.  The senior leaders of the company really do care and are trying to make things better internally.  There is a strong focus on member NPR scores and employee satisfaction surveys.  I'm just reaching my one year mark, and things are now clicking.
cons: Coming in to the company at a higher level is challenging.  I posses the skills required for the job, but the company speaks its own language and has a multitude of levels, and every group works in their own silo.  It is the epitome of a matrix environment with roadblocks at every turn.  There is a mentality that self preservation is achieved through conflict and making issues more challenging than they need to be.

review_title: Good people, but bureaucracy gets in the way
job_title: IT Systems Analyst in Minnetonka, MN
pros: Excellent benefits, including vision and dental. Great people to work with in my department. Company does not expect you to work long hours or excess overtime. I received several bonuses and 'spot' awards in my career. Employee assistance program is robust.
cons: Due to size of the company, it's sometimes or often unclear who does what and which department is responsible for which tasks. There is a noticeable 'silo effect' due to the company growing via acquisition - e.g., there was a significantly worse culture at the NH location compared to the MN location. Company increasingly cracking down on spending including travel and training. However, you can still get approved for a lot of e-learning courses and tuition reimbursement.

pros: New building was really nice. Had a laptop you could take home. Overtime hours were in abundance if you are OK with working overtime, all the time. Generally nice co-workers and a bunch of young people. Very structured and focused work environment (could be good for some).
cons: Pretty much required to work overtime. Low salary with an "implied requirement" for overtime. They don't make this very clear when you are hired. Health benefits are awful considering you work for a health insurance company. Growth is possible, if you are a 12 hour a day person, you will likely find ways to move up. If you want to work 8 hours, this is not the place for you. Senior management leaves you to fend for yourself unless you are not satisfying them- then they come to you immediately.

review_title: Love the position but HR involvement makes it very difficult to move around in the company
pros: Work from home, rewards for doing a good job,  flexible schedules, excellent pay, great immediate supervisor, supportive team, good training, feeling of accomplishment.
cons: Healthcare benefits are ridiculous for a risk aversive, health conscious company. I applied for a another position within the company and HR treated me like I was an outsider despite excellent references from management.  HR scheduled me for a screening interview and made me wait three weeks just to do that initial piece. Then I received the "thanks but no thanks" rejection email. Would have respected an honest approach from the beginning. If you are not interested in me for whatever reason be up front and transparent.  Don't call me and schedule me to interview for a position that you clearly have no intention of considering me for.

review_title: Commited to the company, turns out it didn't really matter. If you can find a sweet-spot, hold on to it.
pros: Complete your metrics and you'll be good to go! Usually monitored by a supervisor in another state that you'll never meet. If you aren't in upper management, keep your head down and ideas to yourself, they already have their plans in place so save your energy.
cons: Upper level management changes constantly and getting laid off by a newbie that really has no idea what you do is painful. But at the same time, you can then get a job where you feel like you matter.

pros: I loved the job that I did. I worked hard and earned the privilege to work from home. As with anywhere, I had great, supportive, and knowledgeable leaders as well as those that were very biased and liked to micromanage. It is what you make of it. I am hoping to return in my position and continue my career with UHC.
cons: The benefits, for a major health insurer, were less than average for employees. Pay is a bit lower than the other two major insurers in the local area.

pros:
The Company strives to help People who have insurance become informed to make good health decisions. Whether it's using a health program to stop smoking, lose weight, manage their stresses, or having an acute problem triaged, or a long term problem followed by a Case Manager, United Health Care aims to team up with the client to become a more informed sophisticated health care consumer.
This is a noble aspiration.
cons:
Many workers work telephonically, trainings are often very short with limited time to practice and rehearse the skill before one is responsible for it. Often Supervisors have many hats to wear , perhaps streamlining their job description will give them more contact with those they supervise.IT changes are frequent and do not always seem or feel well thought out.  They often initiaillydecrease our efficiency when implemented.
