The company is always trying to improve and be more efficient in their work, I value that commitment to Total Quality Improvement.

pros: The members are generally nice to work with and help but focus on number, calls,  production makes making a difference difficult. Your co-workers will feel your pain of micromanagement but it is hard to get to know them as socializing discouraged.
cons: Do not necessarily believe what you are told when hired. Every minute is counted, doesn't matter if a top performer or not your raise is pitiful and bonus sad meanwhile salary and compensation over 14 million for CEO and big bucks for those at the top. Questioning is not encouraged, communication top down, creativity stifled, HR/UHC recruiters blowing smoke on this site. Expect end of summer manager niceties and just when you think culture will improve everything will be worse than before once the Vital Signs are over. Employee and member's personal information is being sent to other countries as are American jobs.

review_title: Good for stock holders, bad for employees
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Overland Park, KS
pros: Work-life balance, industry leading healthcare company
cons: Lower end on pay scale, medical benefits are horrible (and this is an insurance company!), medical, dental, and vision premiums are very expensive, very low raises compared to the market, unorganized with little structure, horrible systems with little response to issues, management lacks necessary leadership skills.

review_title: Stay Away from the FallsChurch, VA, the Lewin Group!!!
job_title: Senior Consultant in Falls Church, VA
pros:
Lots of free parking
Free shuttle from metro station
Free coffee (cheap business incentive)
Free bagels Tuesday
There exists a few qualified and skilled managers
Stock options
cons:
The Glassdoor LewinGroup Review has been merged to the parent company UnitedHealth Group. Management simply wishes to wash out the negative review in the bigger pool. 

The “reputation” of the Lewin Group in healthcare consulting business precedes the company, thanks to those unhappy Lewin current or previous employees. 

Impotent management level, with neither subject matter expertise, nor sufficient management skills. Yet the Lewin Group becomes more and more like a world of lying, backstabbing and dirty tricks.

Billable hour model hurts the Lewin Group the most. Unethical managers tend to keep project hours to boost their own performance with minimal efforts. The lower level analysts get to execute the most project activities, due to their cheap hourly rate.

Jobs Ads were no longer posted at the Lewin Group’s page, but instead at Unitedhealth Group’s page.

For Grade Level 26-28, there exists no sense of being valued as an employee or a person,

Be aware of the annual vital sign review, it is NOT anonymous! People got themselves fired because of telling the truth in the survey!

review_title: Great hours and I work from home
job_title: Physician Advisor in Newtown Square, PA
pros: I've worked for EHR for a little over a year now, and I really enjoy it.  I work a 40 hour week, which is a huge change from the hours I was working in the hospital setting. I now have the ability to work from home which has eliminated my commute time completely.  Because of this I am now able to spend more time with my family. For the first time in my career, I am home when my kids get off the bus.
cons: Because I was used to being surrounded by people in the hospital, it was hard for me to get used to working 5 days a week from home.  It did take some adjustment time, but now I can't imagine fighting traffic during my commute each day.

review_title: Best day of my life was when I left this place
pros: Only pro is that it is a job. There is nothing good about this place.
cons: Pay is horrible. Even with a BS in IT, I was on the floor for 3 years. I never received a promotion or a raise. Hours get cut and layoffs happen all the time, but the company is constantly hiring. Benefits are so unreasonable. Not enough space for all the people that are actually staffed to work. Very hard to accrue PTO. Constant schedule changes leaving no time to be a student, a parent, or have a hobby.  Schedules are very unreasonable and upper management is not willing to work with anyone on scheduling.

pros:
1 year Rotational program for the Technology Development Program is a great start for the recent college graduates. Supervisors are generally nice and don't expect you to know everything right away.
Optum part of the UHG is growing very quickly and there is a wide range of projects to be engaged with.
Compensation is competitive for the industry.
cons:
This is a big company with a lot of people working from home,other cities or India - this might be a bit tough to handle at first but it gets better. 
Bonuses are dependent on the manager's reviews who are frequently too busy to check in with you to see how much work you are actually doing.
You will spend a lot of time in meetings, sometimes the majority of the day...

pros: Working with great people, relaxed dress code, liberal time-off and telecommute policy, and job security.
cons:
Lack of standardization in data exchange with external sources, customized one-off client implementations, and minimizing operational overhead leaves little room for true innovation. What this means is that career seekers with a passion for information technology will soon grow bored with a job that's too routine and compartmentalized. 
In all fairness, this probably has more to do with the state of the healthcare IT industry in general rather than this particular organization, and how much these cons matter depends on the individual.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Houston, TX
pros: I like the opportunity to work at  home. Generous PTO. Good ESPP, AND 401K.
cons: My dept offers very little flexibility or work life balance. They monitor your every keystoke, they question idle time more than 3 min, they micro manage their nurses in my dept, so even if you meet their production requirement and get 100% on your audit,  if you have excess idle times they will reprimand you. Their HEALTH insurances for employees is a high deductible plan, that makes you avoid seeking healthcare for any reason, and excludes bariatric surgery as a benefit.  So basically if one of their employees seeks medical treatment you will pay for the first 2800 out of pocket.

pros: The ability to Work remotely
cons: Near impossible to advance.  They say you are moving up by giving you more work but no compensation.  Management is not honest about the goings on within the department and how it will impact employed.    Raises are not performances based.   The amount of time missed with family during major holidays is not compensated for appropriately.   The expections are too high and the company continues to move hand chosen staff to other areas while leaving other extremely hard workers not being able to keep up.  I have even been spoken to very inappropriately by a very high up staff manager above supervisor level.  Health insurance benefits are terrible.  Every year we are surveyed and every year they get worse.

job_title: Claims Adjuster in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: If you are looking for a position that will allow you to work a standard schedule and no weekends this is the job for you
cons: There are little to none advancement opportunities/healthcare options are horrible to say the least/pay is horrible/but you can look forward to hearing all the leaders speak on their family trips to Italy (go figure)/you get claims wrong and your job is in jeopardy yet if you work too slow your job is in jeopardy/definently a quantity over quality position with the time being allotted per claim/occurrence system is used/business required overtime

pros: I do feel like my opinion is respected and my work is appreciated.  I feel the compensation package is fair, and am satisfied with my salary.
cons: Because it is such a large company, it is often hard to find the right person who handles a particular task or job.  You tend to get to know the people within your small area, and a few contacts in other areas, but it can be a challenge to find subject matter experts when its an area you haven't dealt with before.  Also, I find that when a problem is identified, no one wants to volunteer to fix the problem.  Everyone stands around and agrees there is a problem and looks at each other but doesn't say "I will take the lead to fix that".

review_title: Decent place to work if you have a good manager/department.  Emphasis on efficiency can make some like sweat shops.
pros: Competitive benefits, facility I work at is good though not what it used to be due to facility maintenance staff reductions.  The company does try to continuously improve and simply processes, which is important given the large size of the company.
cons: Remote offices often mean almost no opportunities for advancement.  Strong emphasis on efficiency is sometimes overdone, use of time is very regulated.

review_title: Things are changing for the worse
job_title: Senior Director IT in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Pros are disappearing very quickly
cons:
Backing away from telecommuting after many years of hiring based on promise of telecommuting.
Many 200+ RIFs happening in IT and the business.
Decent leaders are leaving.  What's left are those who are out for themselves.
Many good resources RIF'd because they lived in the wrong city or state
"Cost Challenges"
Required overtime.
Bonuses shrinking every year
Raises next to nothing
A really selfish culture emerging among remaining executive management in IT.
Make sure you know what you;'re getting into.

pros: The only good things about this place is the benefits. And also the help you get when you need help with a problem
cons: The pay. We were required to learn and operate new systems within a very short amount of time or we will be penalized. They also never informed us when anything would change ex: our members would call about additional info on special offers the company was offering at the time for free and they never informed us on those benefits so when  the members would  call we would not know what they're talking about because the company never told us so we can inform the members when they call in about it. It was a mess and we had a lot of disappointed members and it wasn't our faults but had to take the blame

pros: Have the option to telecommute if work performance meets expectations.
cons: benefits are not in the least good.  No family values.  Supervisor and Managers are pretty much the people that begin in the training room with yourself.  And will get the higher end  positions due to their friends who made them, themselves.  They will state accidents can be prevented, as they do not sand or plow their parking lot, as cars are sliding into other cars.  As people have fallen and broke their legs.  Following the notice, an email out be sent letting us know that the accidents that have been happening can be avoided.   If your child is in the hospital sick, you will get written up.  If you think you may be sick, supervisor needs to be informed before 3:00PM that day, upon if the vacation schedule is open.  If on a Friday, you would need to let them know also by 3:00 pm you may be sick on Monday.

review_title: less hikes , no promotions, cost  cuttings, no employee benefits
pros: Nothing is left over. It used to be good around 2013. But all those benefits gone.
cons:
I worked for around 5 years. It used to be good when I joined in 2013. Now.. read it on...
No onshore opportunities as it is offshore driven
so much of cost cutting started so that employees facing issues related to budget
Team/Employee recolonization awards will be given from employee variable salary
I worked in Hyderabad location office and work desks are just like B.tech college computer laboratory desks. 

If employee availabing the compay trasport then their 3/4th of the day will be at office. Cabs do not start when your shift ends. You have to wait for 20 minutes to get started. and for pick up also you will be coming to office 20 minutes in advance.

pros:
Hard to find any pros in Noida/Gurgaon/Hyderabad/Bangalore.
Please note that in India, it is Optum.  UHG is the parent company. It was a good company when it was UHG, but now it is Optum. Please be careful & don't fall into trap of name UHG.
cons:
Look at some weird policies of this company - 

You cannot bring your car inside company premises if you are below grade 28(manager).  You will not be issued a parking sticker, and you will have to park your car 1 km away, and you need to walk that distance even at midnight, without any lights on the road.

promotion to a higher grade is taken back after 2 years of that promotion, without giving any reason, for hundreds of people.

Cabs will be provided ONLY if you leave office after 8:30 PM.  

You can get WFH facility only when your manager, senior manager, associate director, and director, all agree to it.  

Almost zero onsite travel opportunities.

Variable component of salary paid only at the end of year. So, if you leave in between, you will get 0 amount of your variable pay ! 

90 days notice period.

review_title: It looks good on your resume.
pros: Its a great place to have on your resume. In my division, we work hard but have a reasonable work life balance.
cons: Pay is average to low for most positions. Recognition does occur but related compensation is low. Project capital is frequently cut but instead of cancelling projects, they strip functionality to the point of being a worthless release. Sr IT leadership appears to be a good old boy netwrok with recent promotions and consoidation of rolls that are traditionally checks and balances (read CIO/COO) it is leaving various divisions in an extremely precarious position. Questioning, even in a constructive way, is met with hostility and, often, backlash. Sr. IT management of certain divisions lead by fear.

job_title: Customer Service Advocate in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Great Co-workers
Great trainer
Great coaches
Assisting elderly and sick patients with their medications
cons:
Very very sales driven environment
Lack of actual care for patients (sales are what's important)
Lack of rewards for employees doing job correctly
Everything is a sale (more like telemarketers than an actual pharmacy)
Micromanagement

pros: Fellow Nurse Case Managers, a few were very knowledgeable, compassionate.
cons: Requested Accommodations, denied repeatedly.  Metrics matter, patients do not. Ridiculous case loads. Harassing, retaliatory environment. Humiliated repeatedly in front of peers by management and the medical director, who doesn't even have an active license. Insurance benefits terrible, forced to buy prescription meds through the company pharmacy at their prices. Managers lie to HR and are unaware of their own policies and procedures, ADA and EEOC guidelines. Patients complained of their insurance claims not getting paid or denied, even though they sought care the company instructs the nurses to advise the patients to seek out for basic health maintenance needs, resulting in poor relationships with patients at a detriment to the patient's health care needs. Disgusting to make money off of human suffering. Profits in the billions, however nurses were denied bonuses, told no money for them.

review_title: Be prepared to work hard and long.
pros:
UHG pays its employees well. When I first started it was very accommodating when I requested time off. The equipment it issues is first class. 

The last VP and director I worked for knew how to balance work and life outside of UHG. He did not overbook his team with meaningless projects.
cons: UHG buys a lot of smaller companies. The employees from the smaller companies tend to form cliques. It was hard breaking into the cliques.  The cliques have group think so if you are a new employee with new and diverse thoughts, it takes a while to be heard.  If you want a promotion make friends fast. It's all about connections at UHG.  But, the culture was slowly changing just before I left UHG.

pros: (OptumRx) There are lots of opportunities for advancement, as long as you don't have a specific plan on where you advance to. Lots of overtime if you want it, especially during ramp up and beginning of year.
cons: (OptumRx) Change is constant, sometimes it isn't always change for the better. No sense of clear direction, changing emphasis for advocates constantly. Health benefits package is not good, especially considering we work for an insurance company. Does not take advice from employees seriously, even those who propose solutions.

pros: 200,000+ employees makes it easier to move around within the company until you find something you like.  For people still taking their actuary exams, there is an actuary program which rotates you into new positions every several years to give you experience in a variety of departments.  Health conscious and family friendly company to work for.
cons: I was really enjoying the position I had in one of the actuary rotation roles, but my current position lacks challenge, and I feel my peers outside the program are gaining knowledge and skills at a quicker rate because their role demands it, where as mine does not.

review_title: Medical Assistant with Cassidy / Optum Care
pros:
Benefits are decent 
The pay is comparable to other MAs in the area
cons:
Work load
Lack of appreciation 
The employer as a whole has a lot of potential and great benefits but they are currently trying to expand and in my opinion taking on too much at once. I work within Cassidy Medical Group and it seems like we are not very important to them as individual employees. There are many things we have asked for to help with our heavy work load and it seems like they keep adding too it and promising to take things away but it never happens. This is why I am looking for other employment after being a dedicated employee prior to them taking over our medical group. There are many employees doing the same thing.

job_title: Utilization Review Nurse in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Numerous opportunities to work at home and internal job transfers are available.
cons: Even though you work at home, there is software that tracks your every move and you are timed in a heavy production like atmosphere.  As a professional, this often feels like an assembly line to get the UM reviews done as fast as possible.  Case load is over 60 and expected to do 12 reviews a day, even though upon hire it was 10 reviews and caseload of 40.  Company seems to be trying to save money by not replacing staff in some depts.  Lots of stress in a performance, unrealistic metric driven environment.    Pay is stagnant once you are hired!

review_title: Not a good choice if your looking for stability,advancement or respect.
job_title: Licensed Insurance Agent in Charlotte, NC
pros: Friendly coworkers. Nice building, convenient to interstate 77. The middle manager "coaches" for the most part are easy to work for. ineffective personnel dept but they do try to make employees feel like a team.  If your a good worker they will try to keep you on after the account your working on ends but expect a pay cut.
cons:
One of the worst pay scales for licensed  insurance agents I have seen any where in the USA. Constant lies and shortages  when it comes to your commission. The WellPoint account lied to agents saying
positions were  permanent when they were not.  Employer hires anybody so the co workers during ramp up times are not the type of people you would want to work with. Theft is rampant. The dedicated employees suffer for this in the way of crack downs and brow beatings.

review_title: Culture is deeply infected with an illness of incompetency and racial discrimination
pros: Job security evenif you don't contribute anything because contribution is not expected by the leadership. Flexibility too because your manager doesn't know what you do.
cons:
To succeed, you need to know or quickly learn the art of manuvering within the corporate politics and even if you learn, it won't help if you aren't able to be one of them. Everyone in my department, clinical, sales, IT knew that I deserved a promotion but because I didn't bow down to the leadership, I was never promoted. 
The benefit structure doesn't change even though the company wide Vital Sign survey does indicate that to the leadership about it every year since past many years.
Most incompetent staff I have ever worked with. Every department has 1 or 2 bright individual who have to lift the weight of their whole department or team. There are dramatic and phony initiatives such as the Executive Leadership Program, Spot Awards and Talent Management Program, etc. are thrown as a carrot (a very small sum of lunch money) to individuals who are bright.

pros: The start out pay is very good, starting close to $16 an hour in the call centers. You get paid training and you can go to your management team for help. The open communication is a plus. You also have a set schedule and PTO, which helps when planning for things like doc appointments or occasions with the kids.
cons: The phones can ring nonstop with people already waiting in your que before you log in for the morning depending on your department. Some subjects that are more complicated should get more attention during training. Your supervisor playing your calls in a meeting and critiquing you in front of your entire team is unprofessional.

review_title: Say & Do are poles apart, mid management crisis
job_title: Project Lead- Testing in El Monte, CA
pros:
- Good facilities.
- Some teams and projects offers great learning.
cons:
- Too much of unrest among employees due to the HR policies, almost all of them are on the discretion of manager, HR basically has no role to play, even if you remove that function, this organization can run smoothly

- Mid level management has ruined the culture of the organization.

- Good resources leave early, because of the disgusting culture.

- Work balancing is badly done, some resources are dying of work and some  have absolutely nothing to do

review_title: Mediocre at best. Much better entry level positions elsewhere.
pros: The co workers are nice. Pretty good PTO plan. Insurance is cheap, although not the best. Lots of positions available.
cons: To begin with they lied out of their teeth to get me in the door. They will say whatever they want to get you on board and then once you are working they hope to keep you in the same position for as long as possible even though the recruiter and interviewers, admittedly, lied about promotions. Supervisors are ZERO help and do not want to speak in person, e mails or IM only even though they sit ten steps away. Secondly, the pay and benefits are sub par. The pay is extremely low with no raises instead of trying to retain people they dispose of them and hire ten more either in the USA or the Philippines. The medical, dental and vision insurance are pretty bad as well, although fairly cheap.

review_title: The bad reviews are totally accurate
pros: Great insight into the pharmaceutical business, and met some decent people working there.
cons:
- If you don't come from a pharma background, you will be treated as if you know nothing. 
- No training program in place for new hires, unless you're a PT or RPh.
- Favoritism - employees treated differently within the same group.
- Treated like children and management tries to force you to hang out together - after spending 8 - 10 hours with people I don't care for, why should I be forced to spend my personal time with them as well? Isn't that what 'personal' time means? It's MY decision, not yours.
- NUMBERS, NUMBERS, NUMBERS - it's all a numbers game and if you can't figure out a way to meet their unreasonable expectations, you'll be threatened with termination.

review_title: Used to be a great job...
pros: The best reason to work there was the friendly ambience and coworkers. This was a relaxed, enjoyable call center in which empathy for customers was encouraged & we had time to make sure their concerns were handled appropriately. Unfortunately, as the office became more production-driven and "corporate" in nature, it became a dog-eat-dog atmosphere.
cons: They were trying to make it into a metrics-driven call center but forgot the heart and soul that were once what we enjoyed bringing to the job. Discipline became inconsistent and encouragement less frequent, resulting in low morale. Tension abounded as everyone tried to look good in the face of extreme scrutiny.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Shawnee, KS
pros: The 401k is basically the only good thing with this company. Basically is matched by the company.  Otherwise read cons...
cons: Oh boy where to start? First this is for the call center work. The complete unorganized process of training? They randomly change your time of training because the trainer doesn't want to work mornings. They switch you to another department with no notice except that you go to training for it for a couple weeks. Do you have to use the restroom? That's fine just take that time out of your break time. Would you like to be treated as a human and not a robot? Not happening here! Want to be monitored the whole time you are there? Perfect place for you! Want to have minimal training and thrown to the sharks? They have you covered! Heaven forbid you put in a two week notice. They then let you go midway through the week. I would HIGHLY advise not working here. Of all the people I met the most senior person was 4 years. Super high turnover! Stay away!

review_title: Too big for their own good
job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Concord, NC
pros: Reasonable pay (but don't expect an increase) and generally nice co-workers. Did allow some telecommuting (but minimal).
cons: Pay increases are very low 1-2% if you get anything - 0% is normal and then you read their reports bragging about their profits. Bonuses don't happen for the working class - only the execs. Many projects get cancelled mid-stream. Poor management and planning. No training opportunities. When they do their annual major layoffs, they just tap you on you shoulder and tell you to pack up because your position was eliminated - there is no notice or time to turn over anything you are working on (they don't care.)

review_title: A Company going in the right direction
pros: The amount of jobs that are available for telecommuting.  The company really supports employee volunteerism.
cons: The health benefits are expensive and many prescriptions are NOT covered and don't count toward your deductible.  So for me, I am spending almost $3600.00 for my son's asthma medicine for the year.  They point out at the town hall meeting how they realize it's the number 1 employee complaint, but so far they don't have the incentive to change it.

pros: Benefits, stock, 401k, Pto. Chances to move o other areas. Good starter job out of college. Resume builder
cons: Lots of CYA work. Happiness is based on management. Years of service do not matter. Things change fast, if your not used to change not the job for you. Lots of meetings that could be emails. Some micromanaging. If your not getting along with management change jobs internally or get out. Salary set at employment, it’s not going to move much unless you jump grade levels. Don’t be a scape goat. The culture set by corporate is not followed. Sad to move on, but necessary if you want to further your career.

job_title: Accounts Receivable Clerk in Carlsbad, CA
pros: They eat all the time
cons: Unorganized workflow, software delays, communication sucks, customers complaints go unanswered: customer service department not organized and English is not the staff first language so understanding system notes is very difficult. None of the departments are on the same page. 90% of the work is sent overseas to work, so good luck on comprehensive task being completed.

job_title: Customer Care Professional in Tampa, FL
pros: Pay is OK, location is good.
cons: Goals are very unrealistic. Once after training, they expect you to meet your goals. You are expected to go to meeting and focus groups regarding these goals and to reach higher then the average goal every month,never satisfied. You can have perferct attendance, or even have great reviews from customers, but if you dont meet your goals on a daily basis, then you cannot move around the company. Very high preassure. Every meeting and focus group telling you that your not meeting your goals, but not telling you how you can meet those certain goals.

review_title: Worst nightmare one could expect as mid-level professional
pros: Compensation is ok, WFH option is available but restricted to manager's will! Nothing else!!
cons:
The employees are treated like slaves to their immediate boss and the offshore management will blindly follow onshore orders them. Still they force employees to do useless work as new approach without detailing it to onshore. The management will come with organizational and process changes frequently regardless its useful or not .Hell lot of politics and you will get sick of that.
The compensation to the lower level employees are very very less.You don't even know how your performance is measured. No transparency on anything.
The HR people don't know anything other than recruitment and once you are in they don't even know that you exist.
No job security. I have seen people disappearing from the office suddenly. If the senior management don't like you , then you are screwed. !!

review_title: Work here at your own risk!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Miami, FL
pros: 401k, espp, I have a job, work at home option, learning abt medical, some employees are great to work with!
cons: Stressful environment, metrics that are hard to meet, insurance benefits are horrible, supervisors and management don't really interact, it's micromanaged, hard for growth within the company, the pay raises, you have to bid for your shift based on you stats, back to back calls by upset members all day long!!! The list goes on...

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Irving, TX
pros: I Met some really great people working here especially since it was my first job I had worked at since moving to Texas from another state . They had  different lunch everyday of the week , and if you do good in training you get a good schedule working Monday through Friday
cons: Breaks to short , not enough managers that is willing to help it seemed like everytime  you asked for help in an escalation call nobody wanted to help you out so you had the member on the phone for like 30 minutes to an hour waiting for Ben to hang up or a manager to come to the line

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Really great company! In the short time I was there, I saw many positive things, including the way they treat their employees. People seemed happy with their jobs and pay there. There were ample opportunities to provide feedback during the training.
cons: Unfortunately, this job was a bad fit for me. Even though I have had a lot of customer service experience, it had been years and years since I have work in a call center. I love customer service, but not in a call center environment. The trainers were really hell bent on getting as much information down you as possible so you can get out on the floor. This is why I ended up leaving. I would love to work at this company again, but in a different area!

review_title: No Diversity - Stay in your place or else......
pros: The salary is good and I had an opportunity to earn a bonus.
cons: No matter what I did and how hard I tried, I could not get promoted.  If you are a full time telecommuter and don't go into an office, the you chance of being promoted is slim to none.   If you don't look like them, think like them, and act like them then you are considered a liability. However, I have worked with many managers and directors that are not intimidated by this.  Instead they use it as an opportunity to grow and excel in their own personal lives and professions.

pros: United Health Care is  about the same as any other Health Care Job.  The one thing to remember is the majority of times the problems exist with the supervisors/managers not the company. Most healthcare insurance company jobs are not about the care for the people...its about the stockholders that have invested into the company and the money they make off people being sick. The more money they make the more companies they open in other states the more they invest and the richer they get.
cons: I worked for United for 3 years under some questionable management. On one particular Friday at 3 pm we were called into the office and told that our entire department transferred to Texas from Arizona. Free healthcare is great to have but for us employees that pay for it insurance premiums can be could be ridiculous expensive.

review_title: Worked on Finance team for subsidiary
pros: Can't think of any except that I received a paycheck.
cons:
Hostile work environment created by 2 Directors in Finance.  Their supervisors will not take responsibility to correct the problem.  
Hire overqualified people to do mundane work.  Lie to candidates in interviews regarding the work they will perform.  
Management makes excuses when employees quit.  They lie to staff as to the reasons employees choose to leave.  
Implementations of new systems are constantly pushing deadlines.  Staff is expected to perform their daily tasks and end user testing for months with no end in sight. 
Management threatens staff with longer hours and working weekends when they don't get their way.  
Too many unproductive meetings.  
Management makes a lot of bad decisions at the expense of the staff.  Management is out of touch with the employees.  Focus too much on surveys instead of actually speaking to the employees.

pros: Work remote, PTO, co-workers
cons:
The first few years there were excellent, I really enjoyed working in the office with my co-workers. However, once Rob C. sold the company to UHG/ Optum whatever we are now, everything went down hill including Management. There are constant negative changes thrown at us at any time. We used to receive quarterly bonuses but that was taken away and replaced with raises (not much at all) They used to treat us to lunch once a week, that was taken away. We used to have company events that showed appreciation for the employees, but surprise surprise they took that away also. Management needs to get it together or no one will be left working there. They expect us to give 110% and we get treated like dirt in return. The job duties are not the stressful part, it is the upper management that causes my gray hairs. I know many co workers who are very unhappy but are grateful to have a job. 
Not much room to move up.
Benefits are horrible, which is pretty sad considering we work for UHG.

review_title: UHG is a good place to work
job_title: Business Analyst Consultant in Minnetonka, MN
pros: Generous PTO granted upon hire, flexible work schedule, WFH options, lots of opportunity to move around the company, professional development is available for those who seek it, generous bonuses for those employees who work hard, nice 401K match.
cons: The company is still very siloed and certain groups aren't willing to work with other groups, the health insurance is average at best and very expensive, in my particular team it was hard to move up pay grade levels, you had to be one of the favored in order to advance, sometimes you felt swallowed up by the big corporate company that UHG is.

pros:
It's a large office and a big company, so there are loads of different opportunities and software technologies to work with.
One team I was on was fantastic, very interesting work, great team, great product, learned about agile.
cons:
It's a gamble joining the TDP program. 
There is a lot of luck involved with getting on a solid team.

pros: None at all. Nothing that I can think of.
cons: All that matters at this company are the Executives and their Salaries. This company is full of excuses when it comes to it's employees. No good raises at all. This company believes that Executives deserve it all. Although they don't do enough. Everyone else is considered to be highly dispensable. In comparison to competitors this company lacks diversity. There are little to no minorities in senior leadership or management for that matter. There is little to no opportunity for minorities to advance. This company does anything to stay on top. There are so many restrictions in place on various things and many cuts are made just so the Company stays ahead of the competition. The cuts are never made at the Top, only at the Bottom. The longer you work here, the more you will start to see this company's conniving ways. There are foul things going on here.

review_title: Expect to Work on Weekends and on Your PTO
pros: The company is growing so job security is there. Employee retention is poor so new positions are constantly cropping up.
cons: When I started they advertised that the position was a 40 hr per week job. In reality you should expect to work on weekends and on your paid time off. Don't expect work life balance here. Don't expect compensation for the long hours. You will be on salary and they will take advantage of that fact every way that they can. Clients are allowed to walk all over the company like a door mat, even at the expense of the staff's personal lives. If it wasn't for the recession most of the staff would quit in a heart beat. The jobs just aren't out there right now. A lot of people are just waiting.

review_title: I would not recommend this company to my worst enemy
pros: You get paid every week (who does that?). Company is becoming Optum.  Could bring on positive change. If you want a raise, the only way to do it is to threaten to quit ( you will get a raise and a job title change).
cons: Most will stab you in the back if given a chance. Most do not tell the truth.  Most are out to blame someone. Immature management. Many do not know the difference between your and you're or their and there.  ( that is some VPs). There is no annual review process; therefore, no annual raise. The benefits stink and are over priced.  No 401k match.

pros: Stable company with many quality employees.  Love my colleagues however discouraged with bureaucracy of large company.
cons: Company benefits misleading. High out of pocket insurance never really kicks in for the average family.  Tuition reimbursement misleading only valid if courses apply to current position. Doesn't help you progress your career. I'm having to pay for my own advanced degree to get to the next level.  Had an excellent review and denied merit increase because my annual compensation considered too high - very disappointing.  Merit increase budgets stay at the top of the org and don't filter down to employees doing the work.  Highly political company and difficult to navigate career path progression.

pros: Good work life balance very less work. good for the people who want to enjoy their life at the cost of growth and who are good in politics
cons:
No good quality work, if you want to destroy your technical skills go there. 
No Growth if you have a good repo with your director then only you will get promoted. No respect for your technical skills or your good work.
They are using decades old technologies.
Managers and directors are dumb. Dont expect growth neither technical nor your position.
Situation is worse as IJPs are fixed, just a show off thing. Bright idea is fixed. several times managers took the credit of what I have done on the name of bright idea.
No Role of HR, Support teams are lethargic, you will need several months to get a software installed.

The worst thing is notice period is 3 months they will spoil your all offers as you will be asked to serve full 3 months notice period. You will be rotten one day if you are not good in playing politics

pros: Pay was ok.  Some co-workers were AMAZING!  CUSTOMERS!
cons: Merged without getting proper docs from the company they merged with for 3 mos.  Tough to service insures with a lack of information.  Constant "upgrades" in software.  "Co-workers" advanced because they came in early even though they had multiple NEGATIVE SURVEYS.  In other words, they came in early to DO POOR WORK and were promoted for it.  Questionable.  Meanwhile, had bonuses not paid for being a few minutes late due to a personal crisis.  Also, for company systems issues on multiple occasions.

pros: The work from home policy has become a lot more flexible, mostly due to the fact that real estate is fixed, but the number of hires has increased creating the need for encouraging employees to work from home and share space with others.
cons: While it is encouraged to explore new areas that you are interested for your own career development it is hard for management to let go of employees to these opportunities especially if they feel they just can't "lose" you; compensation is decent, however, managers won't sweat it to pay considerably more to keep their staff around even - may seem lucrative, but this is at the expense of an employee's desire for further career development especially if all efforts to achieve that within your current role have been exhausted (short-term solution to a long-ended need).

pros: Good pay, shift differential for working after standard business hours, good co-workers
cons:
1.) little to no transparency from management on anything.

2.) any and all questions are answered with cookie cutter corporate responses.

3.) micro-management via work force management. (Going to the bathroom could be met with questions of "what/why were you away from your desk?"

4.) harping on metrics that they don't understand themselves.

5.) (in some cases if you were working after standard business hours) being told you have to cold call members' homes after 8pm.

job_title: Applications Development Consultant in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Flexible work schedule overall.   Nice work site.   Ability to telecommute on during inclement weather, illness, special occasions, and etc.  Overall management is good to work for.
cons: Since I work over the phone with team mates in India, Connecticut, and California it would be great to telecommute full time but due to mandatory office occupation policy I can only part-time telecommute even though I rarely work with others face-to-face at office.   Processes are often highly bureaucratic and slow since teams are no longer self-sufficient (i.e. there is no embedded infrastructure, DBA, or networking support within development teams).

pros: Working at Lewin will provide a great learning experience.  The company is a great place for new grads especially those interested in health policy.  You have the opportunity to work with intelligent people as the majority of employees went to ivy schools.  Benefits and pay are competitive for the type of firm.  Work life balance is ok unless you have a deadline.  The hours are mostly 9a-6p.
cons: The company on the whole has been through transition.  Upper management is poor with a lot of VPs burning budgets and acting as dead weight.  The new parent company is Uinted Health Group which creates a huge conflict of interest for any consulting work.  The firm has a culture of cronyism where brown nosing gets you somewhere and hard work is not rewarded.  The organization is overly academic and has no/weak consulting talent.

job_title: Business Analyst II in Glendale, CA
pros: Flexible work hours and good amount of personal time off. There are many good people that work in my department. However the overall atmosphere is negative.
cons: The pay and the raises are horrible. If you decide to take a job here do not plan on getting decent raises at all. Most years three percent is for absolute outstanding performances which are impossible to get since managers are not allowed to give the top score for reviews. Also the company has a policy of requiring all departments to give a certain amount of zero raises and bonus no matter how small the group or how good your review. Managers often decide who gets the zero based on who they like best not who does the most work. The environment is very political and many people get ahead based on who they rub elbows with and not what they know. This causes a lot of positions to be filled with completely unqualified workers in management positions.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Cypress, CA
pros: The people you work with become friends
cons:
Training is rushed and not spend on the tools you need once you hit the phones. 
Direct Management hands are tied and do not know the job their C/S reps perform.
No tools to help you once you get on the phones and the resources they give you are never there to help.
Vacations request denied often & and hard to get time off for Doctors appointments - So what good is insurance if you cant use it
For a health Care Company the health Benefits are not good. 
Pay is low
Sad as you really want to help those who call in, but if you are not taught the answers or given recourses to find the information, you cant give correct information out. - Hurst employee moral and upset UHC customers.

pros:
Flex time is the best part of the company.  Set your own hours and no punching in or out...if you work hard, you have flexibility of building your personal life around your work.

Stock purchase plan is a great benefit plus PTO package is pretty decent.
cons: Very corporate / depending upon the dept, some places have solid interpersonal relationships but overall, the company has a very strong culture of work, work, work...not that I'm here to socialize but it's nice to not feel like the place you work at is warm and friendly.  Anyway, UNH spreads their employees very thin since they operate efficiently at an FTE level...you will be so busy you won't have much time to make friendships.

review_title: Chaos! (Optum Technology, Product Engineering and Data Solutions)
pros:
RRP bonus program is nice for senior employees and managers

Work/life balance easily achieved as there are flexible hours and working arrangements

Large profitable company with decent compensation and budget for the latest tools and technologies
cons:
Wastes large portion of IT budget on chasing unproven technologies at the cost of neglecting proven projects and teams.

Significant portion of IT team is underutilized, demotivated while other groups are overextended chasing unobtainable goals.

Career opportunities are limited as the minimum qualification for most jobs is to already have that job somewhere else.

Leadership holds many town halls but their actions do not support their communicated vision

Reliance on offshore resources and now offshore management

Minimal raises (pool is usually 1.5%, some get higher but most get lower or nothing)

review_title: For a healthcare company they lack good coverage
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: A good portion of the people are great to work with.  I found that at the individual division level and below, people function quite well and work together quite nicely.  Once you move to the broader senior leadership, things start to fall apart.
cons: Bad economic times lead to massive cuts but they still expect the same level of work.  They should split the company back into its individual lines of business.  They have their fingers in too many pots to keep a singular vision going.  The one part of the company that I'm most worried about is UHC--they are going to drive the whole thing into the ground!

job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Flexible work hours, 
Ability to telecommute, 
Good maternity benefits,
cons:
Competitive,
Often operating on extremely tight budgets,
Management has high expectations and give you little help,
No really great opportunities outside of Minnesota or Hartford, CT
Middle management is often clueless about commonplace procedures (like obtaining legal approval on documents, or specifics about available insurance products),
Benefits package (health insurance, particularly) is kind of meager, considering we are a benefits company.

pros: Large company with a lot of resources.
cons: Political positioning, looking good rather than actual results oriented.  Submit or be labled a trouble maker and possilby squashed.  Leaders running business segments they know nothing about and then caving to the demands of their leaders, who also know nothing about running that particular business segment.

review_title: Poor leadership and wasted health-care dollars
pros: Paychecks, although small (for performance-level employees), arrive on time and don't bounce.
cons:
Health benefits are poor, and vision benefits are even worse.
Instability, poor planning, and continual outsourcing resulted in employees arriving at work to find their jobs were transferred to India overnight.  
Countless incompatible computer systems are loaded with bugs and data discrepancies, due to UHG buying up every small competitor to become a near-monopoly.
Bottom-feeding to hire the cheapest possible employees, and then promoting from within, has produced the expected (poor) quality of middle management.  
Paying over $50,000,000 to "key" executives while scrimping on employee compensation has resulted in a situation where a bumbling "Beaker" can report directly to a COO.
Turnover was unexpectedly high, due to new employees leaving as soon as possible.

review_title: Dramatic variance by site, role, and manager.
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Hooksett, NH
pros:
* The benefits and pay get a lot of flack on here, and some of it deserves it, but I found the pay to be comparable to other companies and some of the fringe benefits to be quite helpful. The tuition reimbursement is generous and when I had an interview with a competitor, the benefits were verbatim the same. The people I know who came from other call centers, especially from collections, don't complain much about pay. 401(k) with some matching, 18 PTO days, all solid.

* At least in the department I have spent most of my time in, the next few levels of supervisors have been strong. They do a lot of good and are, in my opinion, asked to do way too much. This may go off the cliff once you get above those few levels, but I was very lucky to be on a team where the 3-4 levels above me were filled with compassionate, professional, fun, and caring individuals. Likewise, most of the peers I work with are caring and dedicated to their work.

* If you are a go-getter and strong at your job, there are definitely opportunities for advancement. In the two years I had been in my role, I would say a conservative estimate of 15 people in a department of 50-60 people were promoted to a variety of different positions. This isn't to say promotions are easy (see the cons) but this didn't represent a dead-end role to a lot of people. 

* They do care about training and professional development a lot. Depending on the role, there was 8-13 weeks of training to begin with, and then usually an hour of professional development weekly. Even if you end up disliking UHC, it's very easy to take what you learn there and move elsewhere with it. Many people do.

* Work/Life balance after your shift is over is great. You're not taking work home with you, what happens at the office stays there. Mandatory OT in my department was very rare and limited. It isn't as true in other departments but the money is also really good for those overtime hours.
cons:
* This is, at its core, a call center job. I felt like it was probably among the better call center jobs you could ever get (attainable metrics rooted in logic, largely pleasant customers, functional systems, etc.), but you are really subject to what any call center is subject to. That is more negative than positive. You will be sedentary for 8 hours per day and have limited personal time. They have a strict attendance policy and if you need to leave mid-day, there are ramifications for it. Your work can feel very unappreciated, and the errors you make will scream a lot louder than all the good you do.

* I am very, very lucky to be single and childless. There is little understanding for those who have to take care of families, particularly in regards to the rather draconian attendance policy. Those who are in attendance trouble are nearly exclusively those who need to use days off to take care of sick children, and I've seen several exemplary peers leave because they needed a more flexible job. Likewise I mention a lot of promotions above, but I find most of those people to be childless. This is not discriminatory but rather a somber truth that the attendance policy does not work well for those with kids. 

* A lot of your fate is in your manager's hands. If you have a poor relationship with your direct supervisor, your career at UHC may be done before it starts. The stats are your baseline, but there will be a lot of people who make their stats. Those who get plum projects, promotions, and acclaim in the department are those who best work with their managers who will put their names out there. Usually, there's 2-4 people per "team" who get that kind of push, to the detriment of others. I was very lucky to have the skills to get in that position. Other very strong peers never get that shot. With the way feedback works, you often find out what you did wrong when it is too late to fix it for the opportunity you wanted.

* Promotions. As I said above, there are opportunities. Just a few things to know up front. The general rule is that it is a year before you can "post-out" to other departments. That is true, but most people who get promoted don't see it until they're a couple years in. If you go in thinking that you'll put in your year with the headset and then find a higher up role...good luck. Additionally, competition is very strong and there is a lot of luck involved throughout the process. Your promotion may hinge on finding the role quick enough, getting the right interviewers, etc.

* Feedback and Fixes are a long process and a problem. There is a once a year survey that doesn't seem to affect much change, feedback isn't well received and any process or protocol changes are laborious to get done. The second another department or a really high level manager needs to get involved, the hope of change dies out.

* It can't be a UHC review without mentioning the health insurance. Yes, it's all high-deductible health plans. You can leverage those to your benefit, but the main perk of the plan is that it is very well subsidized. There is no higher premium/lower deductible option any more.

job_title: Benefits Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros:
If you get in early, you'll get an okay schedule 
Good teamwork and rewards given 
Okay facility 
Pays the bills
cons:
Micro managing 
Worst employee benefits ever 
Tell you one thing but will mean another 
Expect an occurrence for everything 
Core value is compassion but upper management lacks this

pros: Plenty of work, overtime available, fairly flexible in scheduling, excellent benefits available, great facility, work from home opportunity, bonuses, holidays, lots of training, goals and milestones identified
cons: For a healthcare company the health benefits are not stellar, work is solitary though management tries to build a team atmosphere, sometimes overtime is mandatory, advancement is minimal, skills learned are not portable to jobs at other companies as all the software and systems are in-house

pros:
High starting salary
Work from home
cons:
Isolating environment
No opportunity for advancement 
Little/minuscule raises and bonus despite being "high performer"
Expensive and poor health insurance (our members have better insurance).
No recognition for innovative ideas, just stolen by your peers or manager to make themselves look better than what they are.
All talk no action. Will talk so much about how they value high performers and turn around and give you a 2% raise and $600 bonus like this is good for you! They will reiterate how many performers don't get a raise at all and how we should be thankful to work from home. No, how about I worked my patooty off and you should value your employees. Do not waste your talent with this company.

job_title: Executive Account Renewal Manager in Cypress, CA
pros: United is a great company to work for in this role.  They really push their technology and you utilizing this tool with your brokers and to utilize online resources, which helps makes your job easier.  This is a position with high pressure, but you learn a lot about everything. The rewards are commission and base and building your network, technology and start to great career.
cons: The cons are long hours, high expectations and UHC doesn't want to pay a good commission for the West Coast AM's??  Not sure if they understand the market, so the commission structure is adjusted downward, to force a renewal person to upsell way more additional products to meet a decent commission.  Thus pushing the burden on you..

pros: The pay is decent. The atmosphere is pretty friendly. The option to work  from home and or the office is a good benefit.
cons: There is little room for growth in many areas of the company. The forced top down culture and values do not work and are only verbally supported by management.  Lay offs with no explanation or damage control stifle the workplace. Low to no raises. Bonus' and raises promised to be based on your performance are often not only based on your performance alone.

pros:
Ability to work remotely which would offer better work life balance even for managers handling large span
Competitive salary
Very good culture, supportive leaders, puts the welfare of their people first
cons:
Confusing organizational structure - HR team are assigned to specific leaders which results to non calibrated policy implementation and some leaders being left out of communication. Leaders are based in other countries which is challenging for employee touchbase. 
High management position assigned to handle small teams which results to waste of talent and lack of learning opportunity for that manager
Average healthcare coverage - I was expecting very good HMO since this is a healthcare company

review_title: Great people to work with; call center metrics almost impossible to reach
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Hooksett, NH
pros: great coworkers; job does have the potential to positively impact customers' lives; direct supervisors were good; training is good if you are willing to ask for help; decent opportunities for advancement
cons: very stressful call center metrics; emphasis on being "compassionate" on every call but not much follow-through from upper management to adjust call metrics; difficult to obtain raises and bonus because metrics were so difficult to achieve

review_title: Awful Place to Work as an Acquisition
pros: Can't think of any other than "it's a job" if you can tolerate it.
cons:
As an employee for a company acquired by UHG/Optum:
1.	Company is WAY too big, the right hand doesn’t know what the left hand is doing.  Decisions are monumental events, too many people have to be involved and too many meetings have to take place to get anything done in a reasonable amount of time.
2.	For a health care company the benefits are pathetic, completely company-oriented. Worst benefit package of any large org I've been employed by. Useful only if you don't need them.
3.	Salaries are too low. Annual increases for a “good” review don’t even cover the benefit increase costs. Bonuses are non-existent for anyone below director level while those for senior management are outrageous.
4.	 No advancement opportunities.
5.	No concern for the employees of companies they acquire. Long term (10+ year) employees being let go with 2 weeks severance and escort out the door. All the talk about culture and values, not practiced nor apparent.

job_title: Senior Billing Analyst in Harlingen, TX
pros: Great schedule, exciting work, great people, good place to learn and grow.
cons: Honestly, I enjoyed the experience so much, I'd go back again forever if my position still existed, I would be there.

review_title: Not bad but not great either
pros:
Typically you can find a group with flexible working arrangements, e.g. flex scheduling and work from home.

Paid parental leave (4 weeks).

Can buy/borrow/donate PTO.

Generally - a decent "feel good culture."

ESPP (Employee Stock Purchase Plan) is very generous.

Annual raises (caveat - see below)
cons:
The benefits package is NOT that good.  Although they are piloting some primary care plans that aren't terrible.  401(k) is not matched until first year of service.

Bonuses vary.  I was told "management NEVER gets their target."  This was surprising as the company is doing very well financially.  

Raises DO come annually - however, they are 1.6% on average.

review_title: Extremely disorganized, nonexistent communication, unrealistic expectations, cold robots.
pros: Job with benefits and a paycheck. Work from home is available sometimes.
cons:
Zero training, what little training you receive is not at all helpful for the actual job. You have to read instructions, with some important steps missing, and hope that you are a mind reader to figure it all out. No one is available to help you. They are too busy having every millisecond of their own performance micromanaged and evaluated. You are on your own. Competitive negative coworkers don’t help. 
There are web conferences and interesting meetings, but you aren’t allowed to attend them, you get in trouble if you do. You are ALWAYS being evaluated, every single second.

pros: I have worked for a lot of companies and this is by far the best.    Decent health insurance, sick leave, vacation and consist schedules.  The management I work for is very supportive.
cons: You cant save the world and make every customer happy.  Some people are just not happy no matter what you do.  They take their frustration out on the person wearing the headset.

pros:
Decent enough paymaster when compared to other service based .(Ofcourse CEO is No.2 in most OVERPAID CEOs list) 
Work from home facility 
Some good future plans to diversify into various technologies
cons:
No respect for an employee inside the organisation.This IT unit runs with BPO processes . Treats employees like Kids.A US based company running even pathetically than Indian IT services.
No proper infrastructure. (No Seats, NO PARKING, Pathetic cafeteria,Illogical transport department) .
No proper IT processes ( No transparency in Hiring,Ridiculous Releiving policies , Aimless Appraisals)
No HR at Hyderabad site.
Work environment and work culture is based on your luck.Depends entirely on your manager.

*****
Personal opinion:
Do not Join if you are a fresher. 
If you are a lateral, join only so that your package improves.
Healthcare reforms will only worsen the things.Cost savings will come more into picture.

pros:
United Healthcare is flexible when coming to taking time off for personal use or vacations. There are some good policies in place with training on the job and the directors looking out for their employees.

I would work for United Healthcare in a different job or title.
cons:
Too much work to do all at the same time, expectations are too high. This is also with some Sales department United Healthcare.
Cut back on all the paper work, we should be more paperless than spending time filling out all these paperwork when we can help out customers/brokers.

pros: UHG has the standard offerings of any large company, one of the best is their training programs on LearnSource. Also they work hard to recognize employees who do a good job. Managers are engaged monthly to support employee retention.
cons:
The company is very big and there are redundant teams across the various business units. Each team has a different approach to accomplish the same task. Long-term UHG employees are adverse to process and structure, they like to talk more than do. Add the dirty politics along with the screaming VP from IRM and you've got a morale killer. 

The health benefits are horrible for a company who provides health insurance.

review_title: Probably the right place for the right person
job_title: Product Consultant in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Great benefits and PTO, smart and hardworking colleagues, competitive salary.
cons: During the time I was there we went through multiple rounds of layoffs with little to no communication around why or what was going on, which contributes to a culture of uncertainty and mistrust, and makes employees feel like they have no value. I also felt like many leaders just wanted 'yes-men' working for them, or people with a certain type of personality - if you pushed back or stopped mindlessly agreeing with how things were being done, you were pretty quickly pushed to the sidelines. It felt like we were being re-orged every five seconds, and it became tough to get on board with any new structure because it would probably be completely re-done again in four months.

job_title: Administrative/HCSA Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: An okay company to work for.
cons: Company states the promoting of wellness, while the place is filled with sick people on a daily basis & while they say to stay home if your sick, you are penalized if you do so.The pay is not equivalent to the work load & there are no perks or incentives.as employees we brought millions of dollars into that company & that was just the Nevada region & we got absolutely nothing, but pot lucks, not even a company holiday party, a healthcare company with awful medical benefits, pay for regular employees not compatible to cost of living & high copays & out of pocket cost on benefits. It was like working in a prison with you being the inmate, way to much favoritism & micro management, not a family wor lifestyle  related company at all, the Nevada regions social responsibility always racked very poor.Overall this company is not what they appear to be at all.

pros:
Telecommuting
Nice people in most of the company

Unfortunately the company is cutting back on telecommuting and many of these nice people may be soon looking for new jobs.
cons:
After working two decades for a wide variety of companies I made a big mistake and took a telecommuting job with OPTUM.  The pay is below market and initially you THINK you will be receiving training to balance out the low pay and terrible benefits - but after a couple of years you realize that it was all a sham.

HR Human Capital is completely useless - don't expect them to stand up for the employees - they are too busy blowing smoke somewhere.

Management is top-heavy and is always being shuffled around while the company pretends these lateral moves will improve the work environment.  

Managers are ill trained - no real business or management background and most promotions are due to cronyism, e.g. a database manager becomes 'friendly' with upper management and then they are elevated to a director.

IT departments are intentionally under-staffed and struggle to fulfill their SLAs.

Overall low level of technical knowledge within the company - most good people leave for better paying jobs.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Lincoln, RI
pros: Flexible, benefits, job, great people to work with. I gave it 3 stars because overall good company to work for. But if you end up in a bad division it could make all the difference. If I was rating my division I would be giving it a -1 star.
cons: Executive managers allow divisional managers to do what they want to their employees. After many many years I (and the rest of the sales team) am getting a big pay cut that will not look good to potential future employers. For that reason, I need to start a job search. Sad after so many years. It just shows that the company doesn't value hard workers. Don't be successful or you will be punished.

review_title: Nurse practitioners doing home visits for Optum/UHC
pros: flexible  hours, work out of home, fair pay and benefits
cons: This job is very unsafe. I was sent to dangerous areas, also remote areas with bad roads, experienced inappropriate advances by male pts.  Have to carry heavy bag with supplies, computer, scale... to 3rd floor apt....hours of charting on my own time. Purpose of the job to up-code so ins can bill Medicare at a higher rate. Not really to care for pts. EMR system very bad. Insurance was expensive even though we were working for an ins company.  Contracts change all the time. Lay offs or try to transfer.  Very difficult to transfer. Also this job will tear up your car.

pros: The pay was great
cons: The benefits are above average cost so although it pays well you might not see most of it. The position is supposedly a read and report system but then you are told to take action when helping the provider. There is no way to look up claim denials so if there is a denial that you don't know what it means, which is often, you have to rely on your team or Sup to give you the information. The problem with that is they don't have access to the information either so there's so much ambiguity regarding something that is so important. My training class was a joke, our trainer cared more about bragging how young she was vs actually helping us. The people she had come into the class were always joking and not actually helping.

review_title: Unrealistic expectations and impossible work load, pressuring management to disregard employee mental/physical health.
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Duluth, MN
pros: Amazing supervisors and co-workers, decent benefits and opportunities for horizontal movement around the company, unfortunately supervisors are also pressured to literally disregard employee mental/physical health.
cons: Over worked and under paid. Management is terrible to the employees in that they expect them to live and breathe UHG. Employees are expected to not have a life, family, or social life outside of work. Mental and physical health of employees is literally disregarded. They don't care about the employee.

review_title: Toxic culture disguised as supporting, doesn't pay out PTO
pros: large name recognition, bonus potential, scope of organization
cons: does not pay out accrued PTO to states where it is not required by law, bonus structure is highly subjective, culture is toxic and borderline unethical

review_title: Learning opportunities for early in your career
job_title: Finance Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Company does promote *some* individuals very quickly all the way up to the senior management level, regardless of the persons age.  Opportunities to learn the business and have exposure to all levels of management and take on new responsibilities.  Good paid time off and work/life balance.
cons: Many acquisitions over the years means lots of outdated systems that are not integrated which make for what seems to be a straight forward request for data to become a huge, time consuming task.  Constantly asked to innovate, improve processes, and a greater level of detail in financial reports...yet our systems/tools again make the process time consuming, tedious, inefficient, and prone to errors.  Health benefits offered to employees are the worst I have seen at any company.  In an effort to continue to improve profitability, constantly squeezing expenses out meaning office is pretty bare-bones and seems like such a huge request to get basic office supplies.

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Duluth, MN
pros: I am allowed to telecommute, which is a wonderful perk, and the hours are definitely flexible.  Stock plan is the standard 15% lower than the lower of the buy/sell, so you can't lose on it, and the benefits are extremely substantive.
cons: United is the classic corporate atmosphere for a very large company: you are just a cog in the machine and if you don't squeak very loudly, you will never be given special consideration.  The company basically encourages you to either come in at a very high salary for what you do, or else leave and come back after getting a salary boost elsewhere.

review_title: Good IT Mgmt selectively invested in employee, Poor Benefits & Compensation
job_title: Senior IT Business Analyst in Irvine, CA
pros: If you're on the "good" list, IT management supports you well and is more invested in your growth.  Generally they're very good about work-life balance, certainly more than on the business side which is more busy during "peak" season  (forcing you to work during holidays).  Many managers are highly supportive of the individual as a whole.
cons: Benefits package and compensation are overall not competitive and are worse if you try to move internally.  The poor internal compensation creates environment of discouragement, driving employees to leave the company.  Training time is tough to obtain because schedules are project-based.  Corporate structure is too rigid.

pros: Good place to work for, good work life balance.  Healthcare benefits are not that good.  Depends where you work,  a  lot of exposure to senior management.
cons: As the company headquarters are in MN, there is no that much opportunity after you each certain level.  I can tell you that over the past 2 year, there have only been 2 jobs that I could apply for in finance.  And those jobs usually are for people that have already been selected.

Two weeks training in TN, that was a great experience and allowed me to meet and learn with others who were going to be doing the same thing. Overall, it was a great experience learning and even once I got on the field, everyone in my team was friendly and helpful and guided me through the processes making sure I was comfortable.
cons: The work does become a bit stagnant after a while. You definitely gain a lot in the beginning, but after a while, things started becoming a little more mundane. The other issue was it was hard to get in touch with everyone in your team because you're in charge of multiple providers, so you don't spend a lot of time with them or get to know them too well outside the office.

Good work life balance
Work from home facility available in most projects
Flexible timings 
Structured work based on Scrum methodology and sprints
Compensation way higher then Service based companies (TCS,Infosys,TechM,Capgemini)
Friendly managment and less pressure from management
cons:
Its a captive centre and there is no Onshore/Onsite model. Some of teams based in India fully.
Its not service company so no chance of Onsite , B1 may be for couple of weeks
Even if requirement is there they will hire directly at Onsite, they wont process H1 or move employees from India to US even if you are very experience in your project
Difficult to move from Technical to management roles , people with more than 14 also in hands on role. 
New projects are rare it being captive so difficult to move up, only when someone leaves there is movement

review_title: What was once a great place to work is now horrible. Stay away unless entry level or unemployed.
job_title: Senior IT Systems Management Consultant in Rocky Hill, CT
pros: Flexible Work Schedule,  Work remotely via VPN,  Plentiful free parking, good 401K matching, Employee Stock Purchase Plan, Easy to travel to, pay cafeteria on site,
cons: Constantly in a state of re-organization and change,  poor healthcare benefits, little to no investment into training for IT employees, no career path options, expected to go way above and beyond job description and grade level without financial compensation or authority to perform role  (in an individual contributor role, I was expected to manage a team with 8 direct reports and 25 subordinates), expected to manage your managers and manage up, senior management talks the talk, but does not walk the walk with regards to the Optuminsight code (Integrity, honesty, etc).

job_title: Business Process Analyst in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
- Flexible work schedule and location (working from home supported)
 - Decent pay (see cons for caveat)
 - Many opportunities
 - Some benefits are very good (see cons for caveat)
cons:
- Raises are non-existent (average 2%)
 - Bad employees are passed around and not coached/let go
 - Worst health insurance in the world - low premiums but insanely high deductibles
 - Churn and burn attitude - if you don't like us, leave: we can find 10 more people willing to fill your shoes

pros: I enjoyed working for UHG...great team spirit, decent wages and PTO policy.
cons: The pressure of meeting metrics, both production and quality.  Most that meet production on a month after month basis are not doing due diligence to make sure that claims are processed accurately.  To meet production they sacrifice quality.  Since only a sampling is taken for QA you can still pass quality, even if you let the system deny claims in error instead of taking the time to make it right.  So these claims come back...hit another processor that will do it right, but then their numbers fall while the culprit that touched the claim initially pays the price for taking production time to make sure that it doesn't come back because of errors a third time.

job_title: Project Manager in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Chances for advancement are plentiful if you’re good at what you do.  Expect lots of competition for the jobs, however.
cons: Starting pay for entry level positions is substandard.  Expect to never make as much money as you are truly worth if you are good at your job.  You will likely move to another company to truly get a good pay bump.  There are often times when you will be overworked due to poor planning for growth and increases in work coming in as membership grows.  Work is constantly being outsourced overseas, so people with good knowledge onshore are few and far between.  Management can range from caring and helpful to outright hostile and clearly inept.

pros: Work from home and PTO was nice
cons: No work-life balance, bullying by managers, horrible insurance, verbally abusive behavior, too many projects, lack of communication, no raises. My manager liked to play mind games and pinned employees against each other. UHG received large tax cut and  didn't pass it on to employees. They will work you to death (someone in my department died) and others went out on medical leave. They make all the money and don't pass it along. Its a shameful greedy organization and I will never work it again.

pros:
-Endless opportunities for advancement
- Challenging work 
- Generous PTO allotment
- Most managers are supportive and really do a great job helping with career development and mentoring
cons:
- The absolute WORST health benefits I've ever dealt with, and I've worked in the health insurance industry for many years. HIGH per person and per family deductibles with 80/20 coinsurance after the deductible is met. Anything not a very basic preventative service is subject to these deductibles and coinsurance rules. 
- Flexibility is based on who your manager is. Some are downright old fashioned 9 to 5 for everyone type managers while others allow telecommuting for entire teams. 
- Incompetence is unfortunately not dealt with properly.

review_title: Definitely has its ups and downs
