pros: Ingenix employs really solid talent. My colleagues, co-workers, management are all a very solid group of well educated and stellar professionals. There is a phenomenal talent pool here. The sense of team is very strong too. This is definitely a great family to work with, albeit a little dysfunctional at times.
cons: Expectation to do more with less. Everyone is doing way more than their job requires. Nobody is afraid to work hard but the volume of work and staffing to accomplish it is not reasonable. Bandwidth is a huge challenge and the goals everyone is expected to attain are not insignificant!

pros:
good if are looking for a job that Pays the Bills
 
You will be on the forefront to learn about the latest bordering close to unethical cost cutting practices of corporate america 

you will learn about how many persons work you can do and stress you can take
cons:
no growth in present job function.

company expects you to keep moving job every year, due to various reorgs, pet initiatives , cost cutting, offshoring, decommissioning, outsourcing. Expect to be kicked around like a football.

unethical  hiring practices - recruiters and managers play games to get you at the lowest possible grade and pay despite making sure you are over qualified. 

Branding wise they have good advertising and PR agency .. top fortune co, etc culture wise too much politics.

I remember the quote - elephants teeth one for showing and one for eating.

job_title: Tracr I/Claims Representative in Springfield, MO
pros: I get paid better than minimum wage for a no  brainer job. I got two or three weeks vacation from the get go. The benefits are middle of the road,  acceptable but not brag worthy.
cons:
The management has teased my department for a decade with a pay grade reassignment which has never materialized.  The only input they take is through a yearly employer survey which our division head explicitly told us he wasn't going to address. There are no meaningful incentives,  their "pay for performance" means you'll never even match the rate of inflation even with bonuses and what raises they do give to exceptional performers. 

Overtime is inflicted at random without warning; evenings, weekends and sick days you work from home because the office closes and other departments clock out. 

HR is mysteriously unable to get in touch with anybody who files an official complaint and closes your case without ever bothering to contact you.

There's no promotion path,  no transfers,  no meaningful raises or bonuses.

review_title: UHG...making sure you are miserable every day.
pros: Able to work from home. They supply pretty much all of the equipment needed to do your job. Did I hit the 20 word minimum yet?
cons: The micromanaging is unbearable. There is no transparency within the organization. Two managers, and I'm pretty sure they never communicate with each other. The day is filled with miscommunication, frustration and confusion. It is clear you are very easily replaced. After working my behind off every single day, never taking a sick day, I was rewarded with a .57 per hour raise.

job_title: Senior Product Consultant in San Antonio, TX
pros: They have an excellent Employee Stock Purchase Program and they let you work remote/telecommute.
cons: You fall under UHG IT policies and they are more strict than the US Army is during wartime. You can expect multiple, sudden and unannounced forced restarts that will ruin your day and your productivity. You cannot use your work laptop to access email. Even though you are part of the United Health Group, you can expect to pay top $ for your United Healthcare Insurance, no freebies here

pros: Great PTO as a new employee
cons: Turnover rate is very high; Once was a good place to work; now new manager is liar. Micromanaging is ridiculous. Watching down to the second what you are doing according to what is showing in the call log; they assume if you are not making a call you are goofing off and accuse you of just sitting there.  Nurses are quitting left and right, not because of the work but because of how nurses are being treated.  The culture and values that the company advertise is not at all what they follow.

review_title: Think wisely before Joining this place
pros:
Settled life. No matter whether you work or not you will get your paycheck and no matter what people tell you can never be laid off. 
Good work life balance. you really do not need to do anything in office
cons:
Lot of bribery and commissions between Prime Vendors and some of the Managers there

No growth for good people. Somehow the people in the Middle Management have created a vicious group and only their bootlickers can grow to better positions. All of the people below need to work as bees. Do not ask questions. Just keep doing things even if you know they are going to fail.
You can never grow here into more meaningful positions but it can be a very nice place to settle. No matter what you do nobody can remove you. It can work very bad for you as a leader but is a bliss when you want to sit and relax.

pros:
Pay is great compared to area. No experience needed they give you plenty of training. Job is secure number 14 on the fortune 100 list. Lots of career and advancment opportunities. Can work from home if you wanted after a year. Plenty of ways to make extra money quarterly bonuses 
Free lunches gift cards ect. They care about employees being happy so always try and make things fun.
cons: Repetitive work after a while. The direct call center where you receive incoming calls you sometimes get really rude angry not so intelligent people. They are really strick on attendance and you don't get sick days mostly without it counting against you.

review_title: Don't Believe Anything They Tell You
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Town of Tonawanda, NY
pros: decent starting pay, very long easy paid training, charitable
cons:
BAD EXPENSIVE HEALTH INSURANCE FOR EMPLOYEES!  They don't take care of their own.
The burden of constant turnover falls on front-line employees despite it being the fault of management, there are no RIGHT ANSWERS to be found for MANY daily situations, Mandatory overtime year round, despite being told otherwise in training and interviewing, The very long & easy paid training doesn't prepare you for the job, ever-changing metrics / performance goals with little to no notice of the changes or time to adapt, conflicts of interest EVERYWHERE (families and couples working together,), unprofessional leaders (dishonest, breaking smoking rules, not leading by example, no feedback), coaches dating supervisors, coaches dating agents, rules apply only to some, micro-managers of all the wrong things, encourage deception,

job_title: Bill Review/Customer Service in Norristown, PA
pros: No micro managing, laid back, flexible schedule. No one really bothered you. Stayed to myself. Overtime. Most employees were nice.
cons: Training was terrible. Only two reps in department would get slammed with calls and no one would assist. Supervisor was lazy. Job description should be a little more detailed.  Reps could not participate in anything because the phones would always need coverage. Call center activities were for everyone but the customer service reps which was a major issue for me.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: Steady work, great coworkers, job security
cons: Work at Optumrx for 2 years, constant changes from day 1. Information overload workers have no time to absorb anything. Company just care about numbers, uses metrics to micro-managed. If you care too much about customers you will not succeed.  Upper management does not know or care what customers rep does. 'System is always updating and yet we are suppose to be perform at 100%.  Workers complaints just fall on deaf years,  Don't care about employees just overwhelming all the time. All about numbers, numbers and more numbers. Customers are also mean

pros: - I got to keep SOME of the perks from the company
cons:
- Bought our company, made changes that made no sense for our care model 
- They never had any answers in the transition process before, during, and after
- They reclassified positions even though they have exact equivalents in the UHG system. A ploy to not pay what their matching positions offer? YES.
- There is no transparency or honoring of written promises 
- There is little means OR help with advancement. Especially for those with post-grad degrees; INVEST IN STAFF AND THEY WILL STAY
- Generally their plans are trash and they don't have people well-trained to have the answers. They also took our plans off of the exchange and drastically increased premiums so we had a huge decrease in enrolled patients, which means less access. This was a bottom line decision. 
- There was no adequate training with transition

I honestly wished I had switched jobs when the transition was announced. Those five months with UHG were the most painful

pros: Work from home. Pay is ok, but not great
cons: Been with the company 5 years and wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. Every key stroke is monitored. Process 400 plus prior authorizations in a month each with multiple data points that have to be validated and/or entered. Yet the scoring is so punitive its it's incredible. Make one mistake and your quality score for the month is destroyed. And that mistake follows you for three months. Dont even think about talking to anybody outside of your team.....that's a major infraction. Keep your head down, do what your told and keep your mouth shut. That's the culture. If you want to get ahead, the only way is to drink the cool aide and spout the company line.....no matter what you really think. Supervisors play favorites and retaliate in very passive aggressive ways. Dont bother to call human resources with a problem, they will refer you back to your supervisor. This place is horrible.

review_title: If you don't care about your profession and are satisfied collecting a mediocre paycheck, this place is for you.
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Irvine, CA
pros:
23 PTO days
40 hours/week
Some talented software engineers.
cons:
Was promised a project manager opportunity, but it was never fulfilled even after four project managers subsequently quit within a two week period.
There's a culture of NOT promoting from within.  They fulfill leadership positions from outside.
Company was making record profits, but gave no raises or bonuses to the employees taking advantage of the bad economy.  How's that for "profit sharing"?
Had to turn in my resignation letter to get promoted and a raise.
Middle management and senior management of internal web development are extremely clueless of project management, technology, and people management.

review_title: It is a large company and it is very difficult to matriculate. It is all based on " who you know, not what you know"
pros: If you are a go getter and a hard worker you will sustain. Work life balance is great. The ability to telecommute is great and really can save time and gas and increase productivity if given the opportunity.
cons: The employee driven promotion culture is a joke since it is about who you know. You are a grain of sand in the sand box. The company is large and has a diffcullt time with propering training when it comes to the managment teams.

review_title: So-So, despite being able to perform my duties and give suggestions and plans to Sr. Management - gender & age won out.
pros: A Large company with a history in the industry and opportunities to relocate to other parts of the country; also, multiple departments in which to transfer. Company keeps you updated with mandatory  trainings in all aspects of the industry.
cons: Although it is not easy to prove but it appears that this company has two major problems- Agism and Gender issues. My experience there was frustrating regarding attempting to get a promotion, although well qualified and experienced with a successful background in the field, it was evident that all promotions were given to attractive women no older than 40yr. ,with a License to practice in the field but min. experience or no exp. as a manager.

pros: Option of working from home once you hit your year mark and if your "metrics" are all on point
cons:
Terrible, terrible work culture. They do not condone getting to know your coworkers on your own time, that is reserved for the annual company picnic or monthly townhalls, otherwise... no. 
Terrible work life balance.
No sick leave offered- penalized if you don't let them know you will be sick a day in advance. 
Asked to take on extra training and responsibilities after a few months with no compensation and affects you negatively if you turn it down. 
Watched like a hawk on every angle. Don't take too many bathroom breaks or you WILL be questioned about it. 
There is a power struggle between supervisors and everyone else since the supervisors role seems to have very arbitrary responsibilities. 
Unless you are upper management, you are NOT treated with any respect. 
Insurance packages are a joke. I opted out of everything. 
Very strict with time and absences. You get put on "warnings" for being late or an "unplanned" absence. 
People are constantly laid off/fired without warning. Supervisors will call a quick meeting, and boom. It's all done.

review_title: Kaiser Permanente should demand better treatment at their Sales Center
job_title: KPIF Licensed Plan Specialist in Centennial, CO
pros: It's a job with a subsistence-level paycheck. The company pays to keep our health insurance licenses active in 9 states. This year, since OPTUM bought the company, the 401K money-matching is a step forward and stock options in UnitedHealth Group are now available.
cons: No pay raises, no promotions. Morale amongst the licensed health insurance agents is extremely low and 99% of us are looking for employment elsewhere. The lucky ones have already found new jobs and left. We are now down to a skeleton crew of demoralized agents just biding our time. Most of the licensed agents have been working here for 2 or 3 years without a single annual review or pay raise. We stick around because the job meets our minimum needs for now and the job market is tight.

review_title: Optum Analytics division a booming business with a fun team
pros: Business is thriving at Optum Analytics, the division of UnitedHealth Group that acquired Humedica.  The Humedica team is fun, motivated, and extremely productive.  Good company culture and a positive work environment filled with mutual respect and trust.  Management that knows when to let it's team do the work without interference, allowing ideas to bubble up from the bottom into process improvements and new tools / components.  True sense of community and feeling like a cohesive team, from the executive level down.
cons: Management can be overly hands off at times.  Resourcing sometimes feels unfairly skewed with some teams, which hire heavily while others see little growth.  Little emphasis on career development and growth.

review_title: Best company to work for! I love my job.
pros: A lot of telecommute options, really great people for the most part, open and honest (not secret driven), great salaries and bonuses for hard workers, "culture, value and, goals" driven, I pretty much always know what is going on or what is coming.  I have no fear of losing my job as long as I do what I'm supposed to.  Over time is NOT encouraged but definitely rewarded.
cons: A few people are stuck in the old ways and don't want to change, Some departments are "silo"d but it's getting better.  The health benefits (considering it's a health insurance company) are not that great.

pros:
WFH. that's too if manager agrees.

u need to be lucky to get a cool manager, and if u got one. job in uhg will be the best in ur life
cons:
Well i joined just 6 months back. and i am moving on.
lets start
1. Noida Location is such faulty even Uber , ola does not Ply after 7.
2. they have 9.5 hour shift and their transport makes it 12 hour daily . u feel like a labour
3. there are no HR in this company. manager is the king. even a print request goes to manager for approval.
4. managers do not have any planning. unrealistic timelines. nobody has knowledge of application.
5. meeting meetings and meetings all baseless. building castles in air.
6. no work life balance for me. worked everday 14 hours for a month and then manager says justify ur OT.
7 . they trap u on money dont fall into trap. its fortune 6 only for money. they are nothing in other fields when i talk about IT

pros: Given the position you are in you may get to telecommute (most Optum IT jobs) but then you end up being expected to work more like on weekends.
cons:
Management treats you like you are of no value. (most of the management seems this way). I have seen a few departments where management and teams have good synergy but it is rare.
Management and their directors need some training on being leaders and people skills.
In the past few years despite hard work they have not given any of my teammates raise or a bonus.
Employees feel expandable as they lay off when they are not needed and hire contractors in place sometimes.  People with 20+ years at the company have been given layoffs.
Great company to get on your resume as it is Health care but there are flaws.
They make a big deal about the company culture here but some of the management including mine is all about the work first then employee respect later.

review_title: People are what make it great
pros: While the size is HUGE and continues to grow it just means that we will continue adding to the team which already has so many wonderful people. The people we have here are what make it great and the continued focus from senior leaders down on focusing on people first, on each one to one interaction we have with others, creates such a sense of pride and faith that the positive growth will continue.
cons: While the people are great, there are so many channels to navigate. It takes time adapting to know where and how to navigate to what groups to help know where best to get what you need.

pros:
The salary 
The paid time off 
Paid holidays 
No on call phone 
You get to work from home immediately
cons:
No overtime.
They chose your vacation days by denying the days you chosen to take off and reccomending a different set of days that “works better for the team “. They over work you, you will never be “ caught up “ with your work. If you get close they will give you the work of someone else to do. You will be a salaried employee but When you look at how many hours you actually put in you will discover that you make less than minimum wage. Taxes are astronomical here you would think that your wages have just been garnished.

pros: Pay is decent, bonuses are great.
cons: This company is extremely sexist. Its culture is an old boy network to the core. At first, I thought it might be limited to the unit/division I worked in. However, after many years, many promotions, and many job changes at different areas of the company, I am certain that this is a defining characteristic of UHG. I have had my ideas stolen and being credited to others on a daily basis. I have been paid less than others doing jobs lower than mine. I have been asked to do jobs to make others look more successful (primarily men). If you are a man, this place will probably be awesome for you. If not, look at the Glassdoor reviews and understand why UHG ranks so very low despite being a top 10 Fortune company.

review_title: UnitedHealth Group is a dishonest company
pros: You do have the opportunity to learn many new skills because you are required to do so many things without proper training and you have to figure out how to get this done.
cons: The management. They are dishonest, disrespectful, unethical, have no value to the customers much less employees. It was very challenging working for a company knowing they were violating laws and regulations that impacted consumers but yet if you made mention of this you were in jeopardy of losing your job, reassigned to work as a "punishment" for speaking out, degraded and humiliated to your peers by management.

review_title: OK, but far from being the best place I've worked
pros: Stable and growing company providing some job security. Salary is comparable, or slightly higher,  to other organizations of the same size. Admirable mission. Employees are able to work from home. Some flexibility in work hours.
cons: Top-heavy in management (my dept alone has 3 levels of management!!!). Poor work-life balance - employees expected to work evenings and weekends regularly, with no "comp time" (My dept has been told they're expected to put in 50 hours a week!). Divisions within the company work in silos, causing some duplicate efforts, as well as confusion and mis-management. Too many managers who shouldn't be! (One recently-hired manager was let go from a previous employer for poor performance.) Health insurance benefits are the worst I've ever seen, and get worse each year. It's getting to the point that I can't afford to work here.

review_title: Leadership not hiring the right talent!
pros: Great company to work for. Many locations across the country. Diversity in the company.
cons:
Great company with some departments being run by clueless leaders. Senior management is not in touch with the reality of the work being done by line workers nor has the skill to direct/guide the workers. Your success depends on how much you are ready to forgo your individuality and agree to everything that your manager has to say. Health plan and benefits suck.
Hiring and attrition are both high. Hiring is done with total disregard to what the person can bring to the table and contribute. It is rather based on who in management knows that person.

pros: Starting salaries tend to be higher than at most companies.
cons: Yearly salary increases are minimal for most in non-management positions. Nor is someone able to negotiate increase when obtaining an Internal position at a higher grade level. The health insurance options are very poor and place a heavy financial burden on the employee. New employee training consists of 80-100 hours of online courses, much of which is outdated and irrelevant to a person's position. Managers tend to be extremely overwhelmed and lack organizational skills. They have little time to spend effectively managing their staff/department.

review_title: Poor executive leadership at plan level made disturbing business choices.
pros: My peers were great people and hard-working. I was able to build lasting relationships while there.
cons: Executive leadership was disengaged and made terrible business decisions at the plan level. These decisions damaged the state relationship that was once so strong.  Morale was so poor.  The company put very little money into the local plan, did not hire to fill open positions that were contractual and vital to the plan's success.  The little staff left was over worked and under pressure to maintain the operations of the line of business with very little/no support.  Strategy was always reactionary and did not work well for a Caid/LTC plan under great scrutiny during RFP time.  Everything is about profit and not the members.

review_title: UHG has a lot of opportunity if you are smart and work hard.
pros: There are many opportunities within the company. I suggest quickly building your network and don't get stuck in one role for too long. Unless you are getting the right opportunities within the existing team, I would suggest moving to a new role every 2 years. Great benefits and the culture is getting much better.
cons: As you move up the ranks, you will get sucked into corporate politics. Most of the time it is an interesting challenge, but sometimes you can find yourself on the losing end and looking for a new role.

pros:
Work from home; but even that is debatable at this point.-
Supportive and caring supervisor and co-workers. however, I am fortunate as not all are like mine.
cons:
Everything else. Really.
Upper and middle management's only concern are numbers. Unfortunately,
this has pushed too many nurses over the edge and have left, are leaving and will leave. Too high case
loads, poor system management from top to bottom. From distributing patients from provider to TENS(triage)to nurses, to what focus needs to be (changes daily and will be 3 different "musts" same day), to flat out lies on case load max, etc. Phone system, VPN and computer failure constant. Not only is it not fixed but it is not even acknowledged in meetings. Heavy hands, hard hearts. New company Optum terrible insurance. We pay own internet and measly reimbursement for mandatory phone/fax lines. What once was great company has sunk to all time low. Stayed only to see what new company may do to help.

job_title: Call Center Representative Pharmacy Help Desk in Jeffersonville, IN
pros:
Decent breaks.
No matter what you do, you'll almost always have a job. 
You learn some serious patience.
Company always hires good food trucks every day.
cons:
The pay isn't really worth it.
For 10$ an hour:
You handle a lot of personal and information.
Deal with callers that scream at you for things you cannot control.
Are micromanaged.
Have to handle all your calls in under 4 minutes which in many cases is impossible.
Bonus is easily taken away.
No sick days.
Minimum breathing time between calls.
Constantly getting switched between departments for the same pay.
Promises of schedule changes and raised pay that never happens. 
Bi-weekly pay [used to be weekly]
Expensive insurance with little coverage.

pros: The management that I worked with recognized hard work and voiced their appreciation of it.  They would be much more accommodating with those that had proven they had a good work ethic.
cons: The one exception would be their time off and late policy.  Regardless of if you would make time up, the time off policy is very unforgiving.  You would get written up after only a few absences.  If you were sick and missed a day, you had to stay away until you knew for sure that you wouldn't miss again because if you did, it would count as two absences.

pros: Challenging work, good tools, fairly stable environment.  Get the right management cadre and it can be a fun place to work.
cons: UHG is universally known as "a great place to be from". A double edged statement if erver there was one.  Within much of IT, the management style promotes a shark tank mentality that encourages taking credit and ducking responsibility.  Don't count on your managers to pull you out from in front of the bus - more likely to ensure you receive blame for any action not in their best interests.  Less opportunity to innovate. Compensation on the lower end of range for large IT organizations.  Excellent profits for shareholders does not trickle down to employees.  Call center and payment processing areas are sweatshops.

pros: Overall very knowledgeable and intelligent talent within the company.   The company so large there is an expert on just about everything somewhere. In general people are helpful when you reach out to them directly. Have learned a lot in the company.
cons: Company can be hard to navigate because it is so big and sometimes fragmented or siloed and is constantly being reorganized. Employees rely on building and maintaining relationships to get things done. The further you go up the company ladder the more it is about bottom line and less about the members receiving healthcare.  Understand that there is, of course, a central financial drive, but believe the company needs to do a better job emphasizing both overall.

review_title: Was able to get promoted after a year
pros: Can earn $3600 in bonuses/ year.  Can work from home after a year in same position if meeting metrics. Don't have to deal with people very often, promotions are possible. Great training programs. Great up training and continual support after training ends. Ridicule and criticism is strongly discouraged. Can find really supportive leaders and mentors.
cons:
Arrogance is confidence without merit

10 hours/week MANDATORY overtime (never ends). Pay could be better. It's common for supervisors to have no clue about the job function of their team. It's mandatory to keep a super distracting instant messenger open. The corporate office in Wisconsin seriously does not care about our site (my office is full of people who are so fat that they could keel over any second. We had a deal with a local gym that would allow employees to pay a special rate of $41/ month and UHC would pay an additional $20/month. UHC backed out. I know we're just poor hillbillies over here, but we're still employees that work really hard for this company. After promoting to a job adjusting claims, I still make only $15.15/hour. Going to the gym keeps my back from hurting and keeps me sane). Some of our leaders promote and favor employees that are horrible to their coworkers, make terrible decisions, and spread bad information. Year-end raises are an insulting joke (mine was .17/hour. They didn't hesitate to remind me that I should be grateful).

pros:
Wfh (depending on manager)
34 leaves ( very rarely people get to use all)
Cab facility (morning bus shuttle is there only cab is provided post 7pm)
cons: Worst company I have seen in ages. No sense of future direction. No learning curve at all. You work for projects which are either shut down or have no clarity what has to be done.  Lately a lot of senior manager have quit. Leads are here to send mails to and lick mangers feet. Leads have just one work to sit and assign work and notice when are u coming to office and leaving.  Whole of management after lead level till director has a buttering 8titude and have become used to it.

pros: Good work life balance for those who can telecommute and good culture
cons: The pay is for the birds. no cost of living increases and the "merit" raises each year are less than the cola adjustment SSI recipients get. It doesn't pay to be loyal to this company

review_title: Company in need of new leadership
pros: UHG/UHC is flexible with employee work hours and allows employees to work remotely (from home). It's great to be able to flex your schedule around rush hour and work from home as needed.
cons: 1) Communication within the company is poor. Senior management tries to give the "appearance" of communication, but there is no trickle down of communication by department management. 2) Employees are not valued-they are treated like a commodity. Creativity and competency are not encouraged. 3) The company's ethics are questionable.

review_title: Just say no to any platform of United Health Group
pros: When I first took the job I was lead to believe it would be for advancement opportunities and knowledge. It truly is only for the knowledge you receive and work experience.
cons: The management is extremely passive, and uninterested in the well being of his or her employees. Trying to get time off for medical and or an emergency situation is impossible. Compassion is not something known to anyone at UHC.  Working for United honestly caused me a great deal of stress, and left me constantly looking over my shoulder wondering, "What is going to go wrong next?"

job_title: Customer Servicer Representative in Southfield, MI
pros: Decent for an "entry level" position. This is a great job if you are satisfied with a boring job where you get yelled at several times a day by unhappy members and providers, you don't mind inconsistency of information from management, being held to near impossible metrics, and constantly being reminded to WOW everyone! Its a great "stepping stone" position.
cons: They say there is tons of room for advancement, but unless you are hired into another department, you can toss that "dream" aside. Pay is ok, compared to most places, about $13.25/hr with the chance of a very small raise yearly.

pros: Compensation was fair. Work-Life balance was nice, some positions allow working remote either part of the time or fully remote. Company provided adequate formal training for my position.  Co-workers were friendly & my direct supervisors were approachable, fair, & nice.  Advancement opportunities were good, until recently.
cons: At first it was faced paced, business was growing, and morale was high - over the past year it has been slower paced and employee morale was at an all time low.

pros: Definitely the big kid on the block - which has pros and cons. Rapid growth through M&A in the last decade. Economies of scale are offset by integration challenges. Still - tons of opportunity here.
cons: Benefits are awesome as long as you don't need them. Worst benefit package of any major matrix org I've been employed by. It's a slap in the face because their salaries are on the low side on top of it. Retention is a constant problem and it's not hard to understand why.

review_title: As good as a non-technology big corporation can get
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in West Valley City, UT
pros: Great benefits. Well, the healthcare isn't great. It's okay. ESPP works well, and the 401k is decent. They are very flexible with your work hours. I'm expected to do my 40+, but I can move them around to meet the needs of my family.
cons: It's a big corporation that focuses on healthcare insurance. It wants to believe it is a technophile, but it is kinda bad at it. It likes to re-invent at a high price what is already available commercially at a low price (cloud and storage infrastructure). The tools for development are *profoundly* restrictive (OS choices, user rights to administer your machine, available software tools, and even having to use remote control to SSH to development machines.

pros: Its a good paying job, with industry standard benefits.
cons:
The location in Oklahoma City is identical to most call centers, there is nothing special or advanced about it. Like most call centers you have long hours mandatory overtime and a micro management regime.  Advancement is through networking, most management is easy to read, compliments and questions that make them out to be the expert (like it was their idea) is the best route to take. When it comes to incentive raises it is 50% your performance and 50% perspective and assumption, so try to appear you are happy and know what your are doing. 
But like I said its a call center, the managers go to leadership training and retreats not to learn to become better leaders but how they can act like a better leader. But don't be mad all call centers are the same.

review_title: New UHC medical plan is horrible
pros: Decent management, and good respect for employees.  Communcation is good, and there's a lot of support for community volunteering, and a good focus on innovation.
cons:
UHG rolled out one of their own health insurance plans, a high-deductible plan that lets you save generously to an HSA, and kicks in their own money to that HSA, more if you're healthy - all good things.  But prescriptions and non-well-health care are paid by YOU at 100% until you reach a very high deductible, and then it pays only about what a 'normal' plan would pay (ie - not much reduced).
 
This is easily the worst medical plan I've had my entire career, and w/ maintenance prescriptions it's THOUSANDS of dollars a year out-of-pocket.

review_title: Frustrating experience, computer systems don't work well, not web based
job_title: Team Lead in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The building is really nice
Regular, dependable paycheck
Poor healthcare benefits are better than no benefits
cons: Company always talks about transformation but never tells the employees what is really going on until the moment the changes go into effect.  They never discuss the goals or the "big picture" with us and instead engage in a lot of corporate double-talk when discussing "transformation".  Mgmt is very critical over workers loads even though team members have not been replaced for some time.

review_title: Lots of changes, but good people
pros:
Parent company, UnitedHealth Group, is strong. They bring in a lot of business, and OptumRx implements the pharmacy benefits. UHG is on the forefront on healthcare and supports lots of businesses.
Fun, caring people to work with. There is a commitment to community service, giving, etc.
The annual surveys to gauge employee satisfaction are taken very seriously and things do actually get follow up upon. It isn't just lip service-- they care about employee satisfaction. 
New CEO is great
cons:
Lots of inefficient processes, lack of commitment to improve broken areas. For as big as they are, the systems don't work well. This could change with the new CEO. 
For being a part of UHG business, this segment gets treated the worst from the other businesses.

review_title: Happy to be resigning next week after 7 years
job_title: Customer Service Team Lead in Sunrise, FL
pros: Good PTO, work at home, employee stock purchase program
cons: Constant management changes.  By the time your mangers get to know you, they're laid off or reassigned elsewhere, and you're back at square 1 again.  Mass layoffs are very frequent at UHC Medicare and Retirement, especially in the Spring.  Health Insurance has very high deductibles and out of pocket limits.  The education reimbursement benefits is unusable: It can only be used for courses directly related to your current position, and cannot be used to prepare for a promotion or career advancement; however, when you take a course to help your "current position" they won't approve it because they wouldn't have hired you if you "weren't sufficient at that skill".  FMLA routinely denied, even when you have surgery and completed doctors forms they'll deny it it due to doctors explanation not been detailed enough.

job_title: Senior Treasury Analyst in Minnetonka, MN
pros: Depending on the area that you work in the work life balance can be great! Vacation time is a plus since you start with 23 days.
cons:
Depending on your job function this is a very difficult place to advance. The company has grown too quick, and is leaving many of its employees behind. If you fall under a corporate role, be prepared to be overworked and under appreciated. 

Salary and bonuses are only discussed once per year at review time unless you do lots of digging and present lots of evidence why your salary should be adjusted.

The company has taken a turn the last few years, and no longer offers any appealing benefits beyond the stock purchase program -- if you can afford to participate.

pros: I'm a community and state claims processor, and really love this job.  My supervisor is incredibly supportive and encouraging, and we are always encouraged to move up within the company.  Competitive wages with quarterly bonuses available, excellent benefits, and generous paid time off even in the first year.
cons: It can be a bit hypnotizing at times, as it's very quiet in the office and it's a very sedentary job as you're processing claims all day.  As long as you get up and move around a bit and bring some ear buds for music though, it helps a lot.

pros: Decent benefits, great pay, lots of areas to move around
cons: Supervisors can treat you however they want and get away with it. HR will not support you, and the employees don't want to risk their WAH job with great pay and benefits so they won't say a word either. I didn't want to leave UHC,  but it stopped being worth it when i was worrying more about my job than i was my family.  Sadly, it wasn't the job itself, it was the lying, manipulative supervisors.

review_title: Large company but not a great place to work
pros:
- Able to become a manager with no degree
- Very relaxed work environment
- Opportunities to work from home
- Gain experience in the health care insurance
cons:
- Horrible pay scales - does not pay a living wage
- Each department abides by their own set of rules so no consistency
- HR does not help the employee at all and even with reported Ethics violations HR looks the other way
- The mission and value statement are all just lip service as supervisors and managers only care about making money and not about the customer or their healthcare1

review_title: Optum-The Red Headed Step Child of United Health Group
job_title: Claims Quality Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Remote work, 401k match, stock purchase options
cons: Many departments within Optum are told on a daily basis that they provide no value to the company at all, despite the work you do, your education, your certifications.  They pay you based on where you live-not your qualifications.  You are pushed daily for productivity at the sacrifice of quality. In addition, not so great medical plan options.

review_title: Gain alot of experience in managed care pharmacy but not compensated well for it
pros: At Prescription Solutions under United Health Group, a pharmacist can get the opportunity to gain alot of experience in managed care pharmacy by given the chance to work for various department such as prior authorization, client managment, clinical services, and industry relations.  The pharmacist can then be a valuable asset for himself.
cons: The biggest down side of working for this company is that employee is under paid.  United Health and Prescription Solutions don't even match what the market is paying.  Heck.  United does not want to give any of their employees pay raises this year because the company has alot of fines to pay.  Pretty pathetic.

review_title: People who has procrastination can join here
pros: Good Pay, Nice work culture, Flexible working hours, will enjoy working here
cons: You will loose your Technical skills if you are not in right project, very less onshore oppurtunities, As usual manager is God here, it is employee driven company, No HR's. No proper channel to escalate your issues.

pros:
1) Lot of things to do here apart from the regular 
2) you will mix mixed age people. so culture becomes more diverse
3) good spending on the employees benefits
4) above average increment process
5) healthy HR process and policies
6) I remember I used to take 2 weeks off in every 5-6 months and had many trips all over india. 
    (before leaving the company i knew it wont be possible in other organization. that came out      to be true.)

And I do miss my time spended in uhg and frns i made there.
cons:
1) very static on the technical job wise. It will be rare that you will get a chance to work on something else from the your project.
2) Technical work is not good here lot of process are support and repeatative

pros: UHG is one of the most competitive employers in the Twin Cities when it comes to compensation, PTO, work from home capabilities. As important as all of that, it is a company that actively encourages periodic movement within the company and that goes from the executive levels all the way down to staff in their first and second professional jobs.
cons: As a result of the ongoing implementations of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), the organization has been forced to do more with less in support of keeping the administrative costs down. The strong find a way to work more effectively and more efficiently. And those that don't want to work in that sort of environment somehow find their way on to alternative employment scenarios. In the end, the Company needs to add value to shareholders and maintain its position as the trailblazer in the industry and they continually march to the beat of that drum, successfully.

review_title: Competitive starting salary + benefits but quick burnout (OptumRx)
pros: Good benefits, stock options, competitive starting salary, steady work stream, horizontal and vertical mobility, bonuses for above standard performance, donations to non-profits matched by company through company's giving program, paid time off
cons: Raises are only handled through end-of-year review and can be negligible, constant upskilling without increase in compensation, too much top-down communication without consultation from employees it affects, focus on negative reinforcement almost exclusively with very little incentivising, mandatory overtime during peak seasons, minor mistakes can result in loss of bonus and raise opportunities, programs and websites affecting production can and will crash or lag often, frequent updates to work procedures

pros: Salary commensurate with experience and abilities, NP's were a good team-supportive of one another.
cons: Not enough NP's frequently,heavy workload, a lot of computer work after hours, travel to Rochester,NY from Albany/Troy, NY in same day for all day conferences q 2-3 mos. (Took away overnight reimbursements for hotel stays even tho travel time was 4 hours!) A lot of traveling between nursing homes to cover for other NP's.

pros: There are a lot of great and friendly  co-workers that are always helping one another.  The environment is good and spacious at times.  They show employees appreciation and gives incentives.
cons: They expect too much out of you to meet goals.  Customers comes first but they are not lenient on emergencies or sick days.  Must request PTO days a month in advance; and that is never a guaranteed you'll have it off if they are not meeting their numbers.  Mandatory work on holiday at times.  Get reprimanded and occurrences if breaks and lunches are not on time.

pros: Really smart people motivates you to keep up and challenge yourself.  Opportunity is continually created through M&A and through the constant organizational reshuffling.  Huge company with resources that are unmatched in the industry.
cons: You are always one organizational alignment away from being fired.  It doesn't matter how much great work you have done for the company, they will cut you at the knees without looking back.  If you are not at corporate, it is difficult to advance.  The health benefits are embarrassing considering who the parent employer is.

job_title: Medical Data Entry Clerk in Minnetonka, MN
pros: Interview process went great over the phone and in person.
cons: Verifications contacted me Friday evening stating that I could not attend New hire orientation the following Monday because education/employment info was still pending after 2 weeks, they also sent me 3 emails confirming everything cleared, allowing me to complete the drug test a week before orientation. After missing the first week of training, I was later advised over the phone that the offer was resended and I had 3 days to appeal. I'm still receiving benefit info on a position I no longer hold.

review_title: The worst job I ever had
job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Kingsport, TN
pros: We had some pretty good potlucks?
cons: Management is passive-aggressive and unresponsive on a good day. My supervisor would berate or antagonize the same few employees on my team over and over for having questions, and they were too nice to stand up for themselves. I was not on the receiving end of this, but watching it happen was really uncomfortable and demoralizing. If you have a problem, good luck, because my supervisor would *literally ignore us* when we emailed her with questions or situations that had arisen, then send out an email ten minutes later about whether or not we wanted to have a team lunch. You are left high and dry on a daily basis. It's a toxic work environment, and I would not recommend it to anyone.

pros:
Casual dress code
Flexibility of work timings
Bravo recognition rewards
cons:
Cost cutting everywhere after optum branding
Poor infrastructure
Call centre type seating, gets all noisy in evening calls with onshore
Cafeteria vendor 'loots' in the name of food festival every month
Home cab pickup is removed
Manager centric 
Overtime allowance policy only on paper.
Have to followup for timesheet hrs with project managers whereas that is the task of leads and managers in the other companies 
Rare chance to move to other projects unless you are kicked out in current one
Bad shift timings
Hardly any relevant technical trainings
Old technology stack - primarily mainframe
Work from home - depends on manager
Rare onshore opportunity 
Average hikes
Location based favourtism as most upper management is based in Gurgaon
15% variable pay payed annually
Unnecessary no of calls in the name of agile implementation

pros: Part of United Health,  a few nice people
cons: Culture is a facade,, it is not lived from the top down. Survival of the fit,  Poorly managed  growth  Silos across the organization , poor management , poor client value, only focused on making numbers , not solving client business problems.  Employees are young and inexperienced , folks have been drinking the cool aide , not interested in Innovation although they speak about it from the top down. Is more like a big four than the Brand they are trying to promote.

pros: At UnitedHealth Group, they provide several types of pension and welfare benefits. Countless companies in the United States, like UnitedHealth Group, sponsor group health plans, through which a large percentage of each worker's health insurance premium is covered by their employer. These contributions are tax deductible for companies and tax-free for employees. UnitedHealth Group provides health, dental, and vision plans. UnitedHealth Group also provides short-term disability insurance for accidents or illness, long-term disability insurance, group life insurance, and death benefits, which cover certain causes of death. Employer-provided retirement plans help to secure a dependable stream of money later in life. UnitedHealth Group offers defined contribution pension plans. With a defined contribution pension plan, companies help employees save and invest for retirement.
cons: They do everything they can to make sure you don't qualify for a raise and the company operates like high school, if your not a favorite you can not get promotions or interviews.

review_title: I'm not sure this organization knows what they want to be when they grow-up - they have a bad case of schizophrenia
pros: I like the healthcare environment and the unique challenges within the industry
cons:
The organization supports 360 annual reviews, but you don't get to see what others have written about you or how they have evaluated your skills.  Next, the information collected on the actual colleague evaluation forms bares no relationship to the MBOs or development goals.  When someone completes a project there is no project evaluations.  

There was just a mass hiring and yet there were employees already on the 'bench' waiting for an assignment to projects.  Effectively use the people you have on staff!!!

review_title: Do not work at Executive Health Resources as a physician
pros: Health insurance is offered at part time status.
cons: Overly demanding culture with ethical issues. The concern of this company is making money at any cost.  Senior physician executives treat the lower tiered physicians as if they are medical students and the evaluations reflect a tone of superiority.  There are promises of bonuses which never materialized and are based on production.  The quota to produce cases compromises the quality.  In addition, there is a lot of secretarial work that you have to do as a physician.

job_title: Dedicated Client Service Manager in Chico, CA
pros: There are many very good people with the company, management and below. Starting from entry level you absolutely can quickly be promoted. Including up to a fairly decent point without a degree.
cons: Recent reorganizations have removed a large amount of management, upper and lower. Many Managers, Supervisors, and Team Leaders nationally now have so many direct reports that they cannot effectively manage. These decisions came from the very top, and I find it very concerning as the company reached an all time high stock value this week.

review_title: Awesome job as a credit resolution account analyst!
job_title: Resolution Recovery Analyst Senior in Houston, TX
pros: Very cool job where you just go into your assigned hospitals, identify the accounts that have the largest overpayments, and work the math problems and do the paperwork to turn in so that the appropriate party gets their money refunded. Pay was decent, coworkers were fantastic and benefits were good.  You must be a people person and know how to build and maintain good working relationships with the hospitals at which you contract.
cons: Once in a while, you'll have a "team-member" who may try to steal accounts to work out of your assigned account queue.  You just have to watch for this and report it to management to keep things fair, otherwise, you're letting your coworker pretty much steal money that would be yours. The only other cons were the layoffs we had in 2009 and 2010.

review_title: Difficult to advance or change positions
pros: If you like sitting in one spot continuously at home, then the work at home option is for you. There is no flexibility, it's actually depressing. You are are a prisoner in your home.
cons: Difficult to take time off.  Customers yelling at you and no support from management.   They have disability plans that will never pay you, do it really isn't a benefit. The health insurance is the worst. Sedgwick should be put out of business, they need just one person we it a rubber stamp to deny your benefits.  Management is not truthful, once you have already quit your prior job, they tell you to quit if you do not like it. A former fellow employees and now manager told me how they get people to quit their jobs.

job_title: Customer Service Representative for Caremark Healthcare Services in Concord, NC
pros: Big lunch area and good bathrooms...that's it!
cons: It was like working in a giant room and there were 6 accounts in that room. The bad part was the micromanagement. The pay was  $10.00 hr but they are slave drivers and will harass you till their particulars are met.  I pride my self on professionalism. But it was so bad that I was getting headaches and the start of an ulcer and it never happened before. I excused my self from my shift on my last day after almost two years and said thanks but no thanks. They paid me but they said I did leave the equipment (headphones) which are useless anywhere else and they are very cheap. No yelling no screaming just got up and left. I have never been more relieved. Oh and by the way they refused to give anyone a raise. Period. Noisy lunch room.

review_title: Very great company to work for!
job_title: Customer Service Supervisor in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Great environment and very fair employer. They are really focused on balancing work life and home life, and provide plenty of opportunities to work from home. Actually, a lot of their departments push for you to work from home, but it isn’t mandatory. So, if you’re the type that would benefit from working from home, or just would rather work at home just because it’s convenient, then I would recommend UHC. 

Besides the opportunities to work from home, they really have competitive pay. They also offer bonuses that I think are really generous, especially if you’ve had a great month/quarter. I enjoy working for this company and I would definitely recommend UHC as a great place to start a career.
cons: The only thing that I think could be better are the health benefits. They do offer some okay low deductible plans, but it could always be better.

review_title: Work life balance is a joke
job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Tucson, AZ
pros: Team members are mostly nice
cons:
Poor Work life balance
Management
Supervisors
Forced overtime
Bad benefits

review_title: Not for long term career growth
job_title: Worked At Both UHG and Optum in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Reduced stock price, 401k sharing, new parental leave benefit,  sometimes depending on area you can work from home
cons: Inconsistent workloads between groups, most IT is offshore and/or done with H1B consultants/employees, lack of ability to move up or to different departments

job_title: Oxford Provider Services in Oldsmar, FL
pros: It helps pay the bills
cons: If you do too good of a job you will never ever be promoted. You watch others around you get promoted that are doing half the job you are

pros: Health insurance, co-workers, values
cons: Not competitive pay, false promises, management doesn't deliver on core values.

review_title: Take this job if you really need a job.
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Hooksett, NH
pros: The best reason to work for this company is the cheap benefits and job security.  If you do your job you will not be let go.  The people that work there are very friendly.  Short term this job is good.
cons: The hours are very strict.  They have a vacation calendar that limits how many people can be off on a specific day.  Days after holidays are not allowed off.  The management serves as more of a cheerleader rold.  They do not help much with career development.  There are no pay raises this year.  The job gets really boring in the long run.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Rocky Hill, CT
pros: Flexible work schedule - you can work any 12 - 14 hour time period you choose and can work from home.
cons:
MOST employees are promised the world as they are being hired but the Dream Job they are promised and the comp never materializes
Sr. Management is completely incompetent.
Previous management screwed things up so badly that much of the talent has left and the remaining employees must do two (OR MORE) jobs just to keep things afloat.
Every client seems to be upset with the service they receive and the quality delivered
A direct quote - "People (management at Ingenix) don't want to correct problems they just want things to work well"
Moral is horrible - many employees are only there because the economy is so bad
Back stabbing to get ahead culture

review_title: A company that changes and moves quickly but no thinking
pros: flexible time, some positions offer telecommute status
cons: This company is stuck in tradition.  They do not believe in investing in technology.  Most applications or systems fail or receive errors on a daily basis.  Lack of training and supporting documentation.  The internal departments do not work together instead work against each other.  No real accountability.  You may work in California and your manager could work in New York, which could pose a problem with time zones and lack of communication.   Everyone is spread out throughout the US and overseas.

review_title: Okay company to work for  but not long term
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Miami, FL
pros:
Competitive Pay
Bonuses/Raises based on performance 
The ability to work from home 
They're always training you on something so You learn so much which gives you a better career opportunities with other health insurance companies 
Great PTO
cons:
Very horrible health insurance for its employees 
There is no proper leadership at the Miami site. 
No room for advancement 
FMLA hrs are restricted to 480 hrs per year other companies provide their employees with 1250hrs. 
They train you to do so much but offer no pay raises which is why so many people have left to seek opportunities elsewhere. 
(Users)

pros: Good Package. A fortune 13 company. One can learn the healthcare domain well. Work from home options provided  if your manager agrees. Decent hike.
cons:
Hell too much of politics from the management. Promotions and hikes only for people who knows to butter their managers. HR is virtually useless. your concerns are never taken care of.
Office facilities are good but the biggest problem is that there is no "Cubicle" concept. All have to sit in linear lines like in  a call center. Very few onsite opportunities and even if you manage to travel onsite for a short period, there are no additional onsite payment or salary provided.So no scope of saving any money.

job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Greenville, SC
pros:
Salary - at or above average
Med Bennies - great if you take advantage of the HSA and matches.
Office technology/tools (webex, Video meetings, online chat)
cons:
The model, for Project and Program Managers is designed such that you are over allocated on workload and unless - or even if - you work 60-80 hrs a week some of your portfolio projects will suffer.  There is no control over the project Intake process - if the deliver teams can do it, it gets assigned regardless of whether a PM is available.

I've seen some of the worst behavior in managers in my 30+ years.  No training, mentoring, feedback - probably a symptom of the inhuman workload and stress.

job_title: Senior Research Analyst in Falls Church, VA
pros:
Travel perks if you're off site 
Some really smart folks at all levels 
Free bagels and coffee in the office
cons: Lewin is in a weird spot because they're owned and used by Optum but don't want to admit it. This leads to terrible communication and expectation setting. Management had no impact, especially middle management, so all you get is a lot of lip service. Compensation is highly sub par as compared to industry standard and grade levels and promotions are based strictly on a set of qualifications rather than merit, which to me is a huge sore and point of contention for many staff.... Especially the good ones. High turnover rate but no one seems to care because resources are looked at as replaceable. All in all, wouldn't recommend.

review_title: Unfortunately, the worst place of work that I have experienced thus far
job_title: Project Lead Cum Manager in Noida
pros:
Good flexibility
Really appreciative onshore team 
Great exposure to the Optum world
cons:
They say you don't leave your organisation, you leave your manager - that's the case here
Too much politics
Over promising during the interviews and not fulfilling those promises
Promised a market correction, on site opportunities, a senior role where you will have people reporting and nothing was even entertained 
It went up to the extent of as if the employee demanded money. Really unfortunate that a company like UHG can be taken down by certain people 
Abusive language being used
Casual calls by your manager at whatsoever time post work hours 
Manager - Highly demotivating. Does not appreciate a new style  of working that is effective. If it's not according to his thoughts, often changes them without even trying to rationalise 
Talks differently to different people - no consistency
A high lack of transparency

review_title: Don't expect to move up unless you're one of the favorites!!
pros:
-Great pay and benefits
-shift bids are held twice a year (this can also be a con)
-ample space at your cubicle
cons:
-lack or coordination
-poor management with highly unrealistic expectations
-If nobody knows the answer to something, you're left to deal with it on your own but don't let quality catch you!! You won't hear the end of it if you give "wrong info" even if it's accidental or if the wrong info was given to you by a leader. 
- Extremely difficult to move up or to earn a bonus
-They will cross train you every month on something new and not pay you more for all the extra work
- you don't actually get sick days. You still get an occurrence if you dare to get sick.

job_title: Inside Sales Account Manager in Schaumburg, IL
pros: Great pay, flexible with hours, PTO is more than fair.  Health benefits are expensive but try to make up for it by contributing to HSA.
cons: Management plays favorites and if you are good looking you will get a promotion regardless of performance.  Advice is to literally overdress for success and schmooze with directors to get a promotion.  They tell you everyone is set up for success but certain territories are more lucrative than others based on plans that can be filled.  If you make a good impression from day 1 you can get one of the good territories.  Also, no one is able to work from home even top performers.

review_title: There are a lot better places to work.
pros: If you can work in the system you can earn a decent living.  The rewards were much better when their stock was a high perfomer.  Salaries are below maket, but the benefit package is ok.  If you can fit into their system there are opportunities to advance by moving between departments and divisions.
cons: Management is ruthless and has little regard for employees.  It is definetly a "results at all costs" organization.  The Human Resources department is really just a computer program.  The bonus programs they have are very confusing, and typically you have no idea how to win in the system.  Goals come from the top down with not logic.  The goals tend to be extremmly high and very unreasonable.  They justify this by saying "it's what our stockholders must have!"

pros: Larger companies typically mean more growth opportunities.  There a plenty of opportunites here.  Local leadership, from my recent experience, is supportive and very encouraging about advancing.  UHC is a leader in change within the health care industry, and it is very well communicated and displayed.
cons: The health benefits, by far, are the worst I've ever dealt with.  Paying high premiums, as it is, on top of high out-of-pocket expense at the doctor's office or hospital, is very frustrating and burdensome.  It's more like having a discount program rather than having a majority of the expenses covered by the insurance company, and UHC employees are insured by UHC.

review_title: This Company Needs to Learn Basic Project Management
pros: Nice pay and benifits. A few decent people.
cons: Constantly being yelled at, expected to perform miracles. When you provide a reasonable timeline and estimate of time to complete work (reviewed by 3 other people I might add) and ask to discuss options for completing the work. Instead of adjusting timeline, providing additional resources, or any type of contingency plan, you are left with 5% of what you need then they wonder why it is not complete or correct. You spend 3 months working on a project to have them scrap it to start over elsewhere, after belittling you for not creating an entire application out of thin air alone. Do not work here unless you want to work yourself to death and then instead of thank you, they will belittle you. I have worked long term (4 years at one place, 8 years at another) I have never been treated so poorly.

pros: The training is very thorough and beneficial. They teach you everything you need to know before you are officially on your own. They also have good hours. Usually Mon-Fri 8a-5p but in some cases you may have to work as late as 7pm depending on the state you are servicing. Usually very few stay that late. Eventually you have the opportunity to work from home, which is a plus!
cons: I hate their interview process. It's very long. Usually you have to do at least 2 or 3 interviews. They consist of the questions like, "tell me a time when" and "how did you handle this situation"..Also it's sometimes very hard to get time off depending on how many people service your states. My friend and I serviced the same states and we could never take the same days off to take a trip together..

pros:
Being able to full time telecommute or work at home when you 'want'; good PTO bank.
Ability to accurately forecast completions because supervisors/management has no idea what you do anyway. So there was a lot of time to do your own thing
cons:
I am writing for their Duluth office. It needs to be closed down. Management is completely incompetent and is replaced at least once a year. In 5 years I had 8 supervisors. None of them knew anything about me or cared less. I was never able to get into the secret handshake club because I wasn't a lead cashier at Target but the more I volunteered to try to learn something new or try for a new position I was ignored and shoved in the corner to do monkey work. Gave up working and just focused on finding something else. Which I am going to be extremely happy with. 
No camaraderie whatsoever. Just a number regardless of past education or experience. Horrible.

pros: The ability to work remote can be a fantastic plus. I worked in the corporate office in Seattle and was able to move to an area with a much lower cost of living the following year. There are opportunities to move up, and good performance is rewarded with bonuses. If you maintain a positive attitude and are the type who genuinely likes helping others, this could be a fulfilling job.
cons:
It's call center-type work, although not nearly as soul-crushing as similar jobs may be. That said, the job is not or everyone and there can be a lot of turnover. The work itself isn't difficult, but there can be times of monotony.

Our company, Alere, was recently bought out by Optum, so there have also been some issues with transitioning into a much larger company-- IT issues take much longer to resolve and there's more structure to the attendance policy, for example.

review_title: Good company with lots of opportunity
job_title: Client Relations Manager in Columbia, MD
pros: Huge company so there is pretty much a place for anyone and there is the opportunity to really learn and grow with the company. Employee stock options are amazing and 401k is great. This company really promotes working from home and this is always a nice convenience. I love my job.
cons: Some of the mid level managers need to be replaced. They usually call this level of management site leaders. UHG tends to diversify and grow through mergers or acquisition of smaller companies and sometimes it takes a while for the ethics and culture of these small mom and pop type companies to reach the ethical standards of UHG as a whole.

pros: The company is amazing! I love the company I love working for United Healthcare. Great Incentives, PTO, Great People, We are basically a family here. The pay is great and I have learned a lot through my 10 months of being here.
cons: There are to many changes. If I come in Monday and do something I'm told, and come back on Tuesday and do the same process I am now wrong because of something that has changed over night. It is very impossible to accomplish your job when you are always faced with changes. I maintain and continue to do my jobs but I have went through so many changes its ridiculous.

pros: Work life balance and co-workers were great. Tuition reimbursement program very beneficial
cons: Pay is ridiculous - raises never covered my health insurance premium increases, as a supervisor I earned less than some of the people I managed because I was internal promotion that HR told me I would have been offered more if I had come from outside the company, health premiums are decent but the coverage offered was poor especially for a health insurance company. I applied for similar job to the one I have now outside of Optum and my pay doubled, I get monthly bonuses, and my healthcare insurance is better

review_title: Good infra with good leave policies but bad work and VERY high variable pay
pros:
WFH
Leave policy - You can easily get leaves as and when required unless you exhaust your leave allowance.
No work pressure as such
I was hired for developer position but I was put into DevOps and they didn't change it due to which I had to switch companies within 2 months of joining.
cons:
No cutting edge tech,
Majority of the work is just to migrate the already built applications from one framework to another.
No/very less growth.
Good for senior employees or for those who want a relaxed life without much growth or without being challenged technically
Very high variable pay. Even companies whose CTC is much lesser than UHG will give a better in hand salary,

review_title: Hostile work environment, unless you're in the cilque'
job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Franklin, TN
pros:
Generous PTO, but you will need it to stay sane
Great Employee Stock Purchase Program
Work from home two days a week
cons:
Worst health care insurance benefits I've seen, ($1,500 co-insurance per year)
Hostile work environment unless you are in the clique'
Queen Bee Syndrome is rampid in middle and upper management
Work load is overwhelming, dictated by highly unorganized managers
Work is mind numbing, and boring; coding robot; query slave.  Prepare to be dumbed down.
Unfair treatment by managers between team members.
Manager lies to you and about you to his upper managers.
'Growth' is touted, but there is a freeze on hiring and travel. Growth is likely touted to keep you there.
Upper management works from home or MN and is completely out of touch and dependent on what is reported to them by onsite managers.
Loads of gossip, jealousy and calumny.
Unskilled people promoted into management positions simply because they have friends.
Lots of good qualified people either laid off or fired since aquisition.
Highly unprofessional.
UHG/Ingenix/OptumInsight ran AIM Healthcare into the ground
Company seemingly sinking fast.
I'm not a disgruntled employee, just an honest evaluation.

pros: Great flexibility and time off!
cons: Quality and production or you're out the door. This company cannot keep supervisors and we watch them come and go. I've watched at least 30 people get fired or quit in the last 5 years and I've been left to regret wasting my time with this company. The whole system is a mess. The new people coming in are not trained to do much at all and it has caused much discontent. Training is horrible. Quality gives "errors" for the most ridiculous situations that have no impact on the payment of a claim. A lot of times Quality makes mistakes when giving "errors" and this could cost someone their job. I would not want a family member or good friend to take this job. Run as fast as you can in the other direction!

review_title: Good work opportunities; but dreadful insurance choices, and good luck getting a raise.
job_title: Senior IT Systems Analyst in Minnetonka, MN
pros:
As such a large corporation, there are a lot of different areas in which to work. I believe that the greatest factor in your experience will be your manager. Some are terrific, and very supportive of your career (even if it means a loss to their own team). Some are, shall we say, not so great to work with.

But loyalty is rewarded, and you may find yourself following your manager as he or she takes on new responsibilities. If you're more focused on the success of the team than you are on making yourself look good, you'll likely be an outstanding employee and very happy with being there.

There are also a lot of truly brilliant people working for this company. As there are often projects that are broad in scope and not necessarily well-defined, there are many opportunities to shine, especially if you're willing to learn new skill sets.

Work-life balance is encouraged; though again, your manager will be the one who most strongly influences your ability to be successful in this. In many positions, the company offers telecommuting options, which can be very positive as long as you have the personality for it (i.e., can work without supervision and won't be distracted by things at home). As the MN weather can be challenging in Winter, even the non-telecommuting jobs will generally allow employees to work from home when needed.

The paid time off policy is quite generous in comparison with other places where I have worked; depending on your position and length of time with the company, you can get up to 26 days off per year. This includes sick time; but as indicated above, if your job allows you to telecommute, sick time isn't nearly as much of an issue as it would be at most other companies.
cons:
First: Salary. Have an interview with a manager? Does that manager discuss a salary with you? Do you agree on a reasonable amount? Well, guess what - it doesn't mean a thing. The HR department (known as "Human Capital") has a de facto stranglehold on the amount of your initial salary. Then, as you progress with the company, there are also rules limiting the amount of increases which you can receive at annual reviews (it's based on a percentage of salary). If you change from one position to another at the same grade level, the likelihood is that you will have no increase in pay, even if the new position has a much higher responsibility level. In other words, the people who make the final decision about your pay don't know you - they only know what's on paper. And neither you, nor your manager, nor their manager will ever be able to change anything about that. And it's a *great* shame, because I believe that the compensation overall is fair against the marketplace; but their complete inflexibility means that you will likely be dissatisfied with the experience no matter what you are paid.

Second: Insurance. I have *never* worked for a company with an insurance division (UHC) that offers such poor medical insurance choices to employees. As I speak to friends who work for other companies in the same geographic area, they are shocked to discover the terrible plan design of our health insurance. Not only that, but they only offer three plans; and all three plans are EXACTLY the same, with the exception of the deductible amount and the cost of insurance. I have the best plan available, and I have a $1700 annual deductible for in-network... and *everything* goes toward that deductible, including prescriptions. You can get an HSA, but make sure you have a boatload of cash if you need treatment early in the calendar year. Every year, UHG takes a survey of what is good and bad; and every year, employees complain about the insurance; and every year, corporate says that we should save the amount we aren't paying in insurance premiums so that we can pay our medical bills. They're missing the point; employees are looking for options. We're not idiots, we know that high insurance plans have lower premiums than traditional insurance. We just want to have at least SOME of the same choices that other employers offer.

For me, these two factors (which could be easily addressed) weigh so heavily against the positives that I do not recommend that people seek employment with the company. Why? Because these are over the direct control of the upper-upper management. All of your positive experiences will be at the local level; but where the corporation has the opportunity to prove itself as caring about its employees, it fails. That said, I work here, and I will continue to do so; but I do my very best to disregard our annual survey. Repeating the same requests over and over again with no results leads to nothing but frustration. If you're going to ask your employees what can be improved, you must maintain an open mind and allow for the possibilities that their concerns are valid. If not, don't bother sending out the surveys.

job_title: Senior Recovery/Resolution Analyst in Des Moines, IA
pros: Lots of innovation on the Optum side.  Company not afraid to purchase new technology.  Very intelligent coworkers with great ideas.  Generous PTO.  Decent benefits and 401k match.
cons: Tehnological issues take a long time to resolve.  Something as simple as a blocked Web page takes a call to the help desk with long hold times and then up to 5 days to get fixed.  Lack of communication between different pillars.  Several groups have overlap in duties.  Always chasing after the next big thing which sucks resources from existing contracts.

job_title: Claims Adjuster in New York, NY
pros:
I had reviewed my previous position on here, but I have changed jobs so I figured I would update my review.
