The differences in my job satisfaction between my former customer service position and my position now are polar opposites.  I work in claims now.  Amazing work/life balance, option to flex on holiday weekends (leave early and make up the time), great communication with direct supervisors.  Great team work, easy to get things done and fixed.  Nothing like my previous department where I felt alone, there was no usable escalation system, etc...  This department has got it's stuff in order!  Makes life and conducting business so much better.  
Great pay, great benefits - especially since they added an option for a supplemental accident plan that is similar to Aflac.  In addition, the opportunity to work from home is a real blessing.
cons: I really wish all departments at UHC could be like the one I am in now.  I accepted a job offer outside of the company and got this position at the last minute before my 2 week notice was up.  I had no trouble finding multiple job offers outside of UHC, but only was able to get 2 interviews inside of the company.  There needs to be a better system for promoting from within based on ability.

job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Miami, FL
pros: The best reasons to work there would be for the pay. Entry level pay is decent and you are given raises often, based on performance.  I was terminated due to retaliation and favoritism. I am not playing victim if I was wrong I would admit. My former supervisor had personal issues with me and she harassed me everyday that I came to work.
cons: Challenges are not being bi-lingual. Learn another language, preferably Spanish because it's seems that's who they favor. It's also a very competitive company when it comes to promotion , once again learn Spanish.

pros: Since Optum is under the umbrella of Unitedhealth Group, it has a great company mission statement. Its principal teaching about integrity, compassion, relationship, innovation and performance is inspiring and makes you want to believe.
cons: However the training for a customer service position is nonsense and does not prepare you well for the floor. Once your on the floor, your treated as a robot and not as a person. The managers say they value you, but they value more production. You feel like you are part of a production plant and less like a team member. While you make some friends, everyone walks around like they have one foot out the door. In many years of work, I have never witness so much drama, immaturity, lack of professionalism as this place.This place is a revolving door and it does not matter how long you been with the company....your always walking on thin ice.

review_title: Micromanaging and no professional freedom, but you can work from home
job_title: Care Advocate in Maryland Heights, MO
pros: *After 6 months you can work from home.
cons:
*Being on a timed queue, the focus is entirely on the metrics. 
*If you are scheduled to take lunch (not by choice, you're scheduled) at 11:30 and you get a call at 11:25, it will obviously take you longer than 5 minutes to assist the provider. Your adherence goes down for not taking your lunch at the scheduled time of 11:30 OR you can miss a call and that is negatively reflected in your metrics. 
*There is no being treated professionally. If there's an emergency or crisis, you MUST take a half day, no exceptions. (Disclaimer: I have heard in other departments that this is not the case.)

review_title: It's an OK place to work
job_title: Dedicated Client Service Manager in Chico, CA
pros: Working for a large company allows you many options for advancement. There are many fields one can pursue. The office I am based out of is very social and provides ample opportunity to participate in community and charity functions.
cons: Benefits package is sub-par. We are in an area that doesn't have an HMO network, and with high deductibles, it is hard to find motivation to want to seek assistance for any medical issues. Also, lack of communication and support leads to frustration. For a company that encourages promoting from within, hiring two new supervisors extrernally was a bit of a slap in the face for an internal employee who really wanted and was highly qualified for the job.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Recognition programs for employees who go above and beyond
At one time had amazing leadership
Sadly the pros are very minimal
cons:
Lack of consideration for the code of ethics a nurse should follow
Quantity versus quality is preferred at this organization 
Will not compensate properly once you are hired 
Men make more than women who do the same job with significantly less experience 
Displaces good leadership for profit
Encouraged with financial incentives to short the customer
Retaliation when reporting legitimate concerns 
Minimal anonymity when reporting concerns
Employees are forced into extremely unethical practices unknowingly 
Creates exaggerated value to customers

review_title: 10 years with company and still going
job_title: Claims Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The ability to work from home is one of the best things about the company. Managers and Supervisors are easy to reach and are for the most part caring. Work-life balance is very good. They do offer benefits, great pto you are encouraged to use your pto time before the end of the year. you do get to roll 40 hours over to the next year.  Expect change some good some not so good.
cons: Some positions are very micromanaged. Pay could be better for some positions  Benefits could be much better, very high deductibles. people think because you work for a healthcare company you would have the best benefits. Expect change some good some not so good

review_title: Old-School, Out of Touch, Soul-Killing Environment
pros: Good salary and some good, kind, high-quality people.
cons: Cliques, extremely poor communication (my manager literally ignored many of my emails), old school management style, lack of respect for employees as individuals.  They do not live up to any of their promises about wanting employees to be able to do their life's best work - in fact, my manager seemed to actually be offended when I began searching internally for a role that better suited my skill set.  Nobody needs that kind of spirit-crushing environment.

review_title: Friendly coworkers, stressed people, slow to promote, slow to pay raise, bad review system
pros:
Flex hours
Friendly coworkers and atmosphere
cons:
It doesn’t matter how hard you work or how well you perform on your review. If you don’t have a manager that is prepared to put effort into an argument to higher management why you deserve that promotion or raise you are not going to get it. Makes you think wonder why you work so hard.

People are commonly asked to work on multiple projects which leads to a loss of efficiency and quality in work. Also people are expected to hold multiple positions without any compensation and this is stressing.

Leadership is clueless about IT and the processes.

Projects are run by bean counters which means no resources even when needed. This means stresses.

Very slow to promote. Very slow to reward.

pros: The position was flexible at first which is what I needed coming from having two children and not working for a few years.
cons: Promoting and/or filling positions of incorrect people. I feel that UHC should explore their talent within more than from hiring from the outside. If a company is going to so than make moving around the company more obtainable.

review_title: Overall a bad experience that pays well.
pros: Benefits are okay.  Good time off, health insurance benefits weren't great, dental was okay at best.  They do pay a decent salary though.  Co-workers (not managemet) were great to deal with.
cons: Management can be very "cliquey" and the overall morale in most departments is extremely low.  Management is very out of touch with their employees.  They can be rude and disrespectful.  Personally I wasn't even given an end of year review last year b/c I was on loan to another department for 3 months..even though I was at my desk and still helping my department the ENTIRE time.  Very little room for advancement and very few raises.  3/20 people recieved raises last year in my department and they were people who had been there 20+ years.

review_title: Technology company owned by an insurance company
pros:
Great benefits and compensation
Good people to work with
Focus on mission
cons:
Over reliance on metrics and data for customer satisfaction that can be manipulated
IT has no customer satisfaction methodology for business building services (i.e. running servers, integration with outside vendors, etc...)
Employee reviews are based on a bell curve.  So even if you have a great team, the performance review has to have a bell curve.
Make goals attainable - every quarter/year doesn't have to be a big hairy goal.

review_title: A company that could care less about the employees
pros:
Pays very well compared to other health related jobs
Great colleagues
cons:
Initial training is highly ineffective and entirely too short
Hours are not flexible
Upper management with no field experience
Driven by numbers and not relationships with clients
No opportunities to move up 
It takes an act of congress to telecommute
Very low team morale which adds to a very unpleasant work environment

pros: Company offers large company buying power and stability. Facilities are always well kept
cons: Inter team work is frowned upon. Broadening technical horizons is highly discouraged. Work is only to be complete as long as it falls into a stovepipe  that you serve in. Management depending on which team you fall under does not encourage free and analytical thinking and often micromanages to the 15 minute time interval for some workgroups. Work is strictly controlled through management and ability to shine is taken away by task assignment.

job_title: Senior IT Architect Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Working from home is the norm instead of the exception. UHG has really figured out how to do it the right way. Technology is cutting edge. Management is receptive to new ideas and getting away from the "old way" of doing IT and setting the curve instead of following it. This leads to some of the cons below, but those will improve in time. I am the most excited I have ever been about IT in a long, long time.
cons: Change is hard and painful. Lots of long hours and uncompensated overtime. UHG is a large company and moves at an iceberg pace like any other company of its size.

review_title: They do not call it work because it is fun. It is a job.
pros:
Able to work from home almost immediately.
Great training. Plenty of time to learn their system.
Engaged supervisors who really pay attention and are helpful.
Very structured environment. 
Expectations are well laid out, but high. [90%] This can be met once you get used to it. Working from home makes meeting the compliance easier as there are fewer distractions.
Massive company, no fear of closure.
cons:
The structure can be oppressive if someone is not used to it. [Read: even potty breaks must be accounted for.]
The 90% expectation needs to be met weekly.
I never call out or go to work late, but I have to say their time and attendance is one of the toughest I have seen. This is not the place for those who like to mosey in late or call out. 
Poor health insurance. HSA and high deductible.

pros: Possible career advancement, but the organizational structure is quite complex.
cons: High deductible health insurance costs employees much more for premiums and out of pocket expenses. Employees are paying much more out of pocket than a traditional HMO/PPO plan. The average office visit is $150 out of pocket versus a $40 copay. Prescription costs are literally 5x higher than a regular prescription plans linked to PPO. UHG is extremely profitable by nickel and diming it's employees with these less than popular high deductible health plans.

review_title: Not a bad company or industry to be a part of right now
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Good benefits. Rapidly growing industry due to the Affordable Care Act.  Promotions tend to be based on merit from what I've experienced and observed.
cons: The company has gone through a great deal of reorganizations.  The company tends to clean house ever year or so managing to a specific head county only to go out and replace/fill these positions a few months later.  Being promoted to manager or above tends to be a double edge sword.  The more senior the position, the bigger the target on your back when the company fails to meet wall street's expectations, particularly if you are part of a shared services group.

pros: Optum IT, a subsidiary of United Healthcare Group has a strong industry reputation. Everyone is nice and extremely professional. When you first come into Optum, you feel  sense of prupose and proudness.
cons: After a few years, it (what I mentioned in the Pros)will quickly erode. You find yourself with no clear career path and Sr. Leaders don't or can't offer any direction. Optum IT is transforming and with that transformation comes CHANGES. People are being asked to do task, they are not comfortable with. Work intake is not balanced among resources. Too many non-technical people, trying to make decisions Optum IT. Optum IT is changing their infrastructure technology platforms. Lifecycle work is "stacking" up, and is not managed correctly.

pros: Large company with strong financial results.  Many teleworking opportunities.  Emphasis on improving company culture.  Strives to be a driver for healthcare and healthcare technology.
cons: Annual compensation done via archaic forced-ranking.  Reviews are based on predetermined allocation of "permitted" ratings.  Raises in 2017-18 for the highest performers is not even keeping pace with US inflation.  Senior Management ignores recommendations for improvement to outdated process.  Offshoring jobs to India is still a priority.  Healthcare plan is terrible.

review_title: Beware of roving Icebergs when steering the Titanic
pros: Working for United looks great on your resume, similar to a Microsoft or other sweatshop. You will get great experience in crisis management, death march projects, working with massive capital cuts, mediocre co-workers, micromanagement and conflict resolution.
cons: Speaking only of the technology organization(s), there is a severe myopia regarding what technology will deliver versus what business needs. Most projects are so late, pegged against unrealistic dates, tied to budgets that get cut all the time, and finally deliver product so thin in its functionality due to all the above reasons as to be worthless. Technology is supposed to be a service to business...not business being and excuse to build technology.

review_title: "VISIBILITY" the mantra for success in UHG
pros:
It's all about the facilities provided and none related to the personal development.
Being a semi-product company, stability is always going to be there apart from which few other facilities are working from home and also the paid cabs.
cons:
Terrible place for freshsers knowing that you will not learn or improve your technical knowledge as long as you are with this company.
It was always much less about how I could become a better engineer and much more about my need to improve my visibility among other managers.
If you were on a team of 10 people, you walked in the first day knowing that, no matter how good everyone was, 1 was going to get a great review, 8 were going to get mediocre reviews, and 1 was going to get a terrible review, which leads to employees focusing on competing with each other rather than competing with other companies.

pros:
The company has great trainers to give new employees the information they need for their hired position. 
Lots of room for growth.  The company encourages employees to broaden their knowledge by taking company based courses (ULearns).  Some courses are required, but there are tons of courses available to any employee to take to broaden their knowledge base.
Vacation depends on your grade level and on how many years you've been with the company, so your veteran employees will receive more vacation time than new hires.
Nice 401-K company match.
24 hour hotline available to employees to report technical issues.
24 hour Nurseline is a nice benefit for employees.
Employee medical/dental/vision benefits are good to average. 
Many (but not all) positions available to telecommute (work from home).
cons:
Insurance premiums are high, especially for their own employees.
Some departments seem to have a very high turnover.

review_title: United HealthCare is a Fantastic Company!
pros: I hope I can stay here for many years. This company has made a dramatic turnaround in culture. I'm new here but the veterans tell me this was a different company just a few years ago and I'm so happy to be here now.  The culture is one of integrity, trust, compassion, relationships and valuing people. Managers here are real people who understand that to get the best results, you need to treasure your employees and help them be successful. Flexibility in work hours and working from home when you want/need to, good salaries, fitness centers, cafeterias, friendly people all around -- just a great company in Minnesota. I hope this company continues to grow.
cons: Cost of and coverage of health insurance benefits. Disappoint match for company 401(k) contributions.

pros: Good benefits, friendly coworkers, ability to work from home
cons: Working at this company for nearly 3 years there were no raises or additional incentives given despite company growth and success.  More complexity and responsibility is pushed onto the CST department and they are still expected to meet the same productivity and again, without additional incentive.  Responsibilities that were once something the much higher paid physicians had to do were given to the much lesser paid Case Coordinators while still expecting the same productivity.  Employee lay offs were issued when there were multiple meetings the same month as the lay offs specifically to explain how "safe guards" were in place to avoid lay offs.  Seems like the company is becoming more and more money driven to the point where it is effecting employee morale.

pros: Work from home, flexible hours, can take time off easily.
cons: 0 appreciation. They do not care about all you do. Favoritism towards male employees. If your a male, you'll probably make it big and make way more money. Did I mention 0 appreciation?

job_title: Member Services Representative in Miami, FL
pros: Nothing. Nothing.  Nothing.. Nothing
cons: Management is clueless and some don't even have a high school education.  People that recently came from Cuba are promoted to supervisor positions and they don't even speak or write English just because they have a family member in the company.  Veteran member service reps are overlooked for promotions.  Constant harassment by unqualified foremen walking up behind you twice an hour to see what you're doing.  All calls are recorded.  12 hour shifts and 30 minute lunches.  Total slave conditions. Forced overtime hours.  If you're late they threaten to withhold payment for your work for the whole day.  Totally incompetent management.  Don't ever apply here.  it's awful.

pros: There was on the job training.
cons: The pay was $10.00 an hour. Several employees had work there for years and they were still making $10.00 an hour. Management promised to raise the pay to $15.00 an hour but employees only received a 75 cent pay increase. I purchased the best health insurance available and the deductible was to be $1000.00. It was actually $1850.00. I had to pay $1850.00 before any COPAYS went into effect. Very difficult to pay $1850.00, when one is making $10.00 an hour, and the company knows that. So basically, you had health insurance, but could not even afford to use it. Very sad for an insurance corporation to not "really" give their employees health insurance. There were cameras on the refrigerators because employees stole other employees' lunches. I left my food in my car, so that I would not have to worry about it being stolen. I would not advise anyone to work for United Health Care, United Health Group, Optum RX or any company that UHG owns.

pros: Flexible schedules and  taking time off is a breeze. Employees are appreciated in some form weathers its your birthday or a weeding. including a lot feedback and team building activities. Your not taking back to back calls , Only out bound calls. Pot lucks and celebrate holidays. The work is easy along with the training. Great employee discounts and programs.
cons: The pay is bare minimum according to the annual starting salary of other health care companies. Changes happen like everyday and you have to remember them in order to keep your quality score up.  They do not offer over time. The benefits are not that good since its suppose to be a health care company. More like highway robbery with the benefits. Too cheap for yearly raises.

job_title: Project Manager in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Decent pay for the industry.  Exciting work.
cons: Lack of transparency from management.  Frequent layoffs.  Sub-par health benefits from a healthcare company.  Suffocating governance practices and approval mechanisms

review_title: Employee health and wellness not a priority for healthcare giant
pros: Opportunities to grow within the company
cons:
When you sign on, you agree to work overtime. The problem is, the overtime is all the time. There is ALWAYS a crisis going on that requires extra hours on your normal days and often extra time on your days off as well. It wasn't unusual to get texts at 8am on Saturday and Sunday asking me to come in and work. There were times when the team I was on ended up being required to do our job in overtime because service level was bad and management needed people on the phones during our regularly scheduled programming.

Furthermore, management provides no support to average workers on this. The company line is, "That's just the way operations works." They have no interest in trying to change things to reduce overtime or manage employees' time more efficiently. There just isn't any respect for employees' time. It's difficult to have a life outside of work. Basically, the company is run like an Industrial Revolution-era factory.

review_title: Your experience depends on your manager
pros: UHG offers a very competitive benefits package, and in certain offices very nice and handy amenities. Attention is given to work/ life balance. Some managers really go out of their way for you to assist you. You do get enough free time to make some cool projects on your own at times.
cons: It is a large organization. Some managers may not even know what you do. Look up "matrix organization" to learn what you will be in for. There can be very little accountability and most decisions will end up being decided through politics. Network with leaders, look for movers and shakers, or count on your career stagnating.

review_title: Not a bad company, but direct management is terrible.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Very flexible, great PTO policy, room for growth, company encourages volunteering and giving back.
cons:
Management at supervisor and director level are extremely unprofessional. It makes you wonder how they acquired/maintain their position. Lots of gossip and negativity in the work place and management encourages employees to "work it out amongst each other" when there is clearly a need for authority to intervene. It's very distracting to those of us who are just there to work and not fuss with office politics and drama. 

Very disappointing in the lack of compassion from direct management when it comes to family death/illness. You will take your granted 3 days bereavement will show back up to managers acting as you didn't just have a life-changing tragedy.

pros: In my experience UnitedHealth Group takes innovation and process improvement very seriously.  It is a great place of out of the box thinkers to identify problems, suggest solutions, and move up based on merit.  Even when it gets difficult and feels like nothing is happening usually someone is taking note.
cons: The company is gigantic and bureaucratic.  Trying to work toward improvement can some times feel very difficult in certain situations.  Try to mitigate by working around difficult areas and persevering through the difficult patches.    Make sure you come in at a competitive rate it very difficult to overcome pay gaps, even when you take new positions as an internal employee.

pros: Pay was good. Benefits was decent
cons: Consistent pressure to do more.  Once you meet a goal, they move the finish line.  It didn't matter that you exceeded expectations or not.  They never gave employees enough credit for the hard work that they did.  Management would come in one day and fire the entire team without notice.  There was always a influx of new people.  It was a revolving door.  Promises of promotions to keep you there but they never happened.  When you tried to transfer to another department, it was blocked by management.  So the only alternative was to quit.

job_title: Provider Data Specialist in Richardson, TX
pros: Some of the staff seems really dedicated to hearing people out & wanting to help you do your job. The culture for the most part is nice. Benefits are decent.
cons: Training is poor. There is lack of organization, no consistency especially in regards to communication especially amongst the upper management & subject matter experts, lack of preparation, lack of planning, & the worst part is upper management say they want to do what they can to help you succeed but they do not listen to what is needed to succeed from the consensus.  Pay could be better. Metrics tell you that you're doing great but management  will tell you otherwise

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Competitive pay, great PTO balance, tons of work-from-home flexibility, management encourages you to spend time learning as well as working (and funds that learning).
cons: Zero executive leadership, mediocre benefits that require jumping through a lot of hoops to receive, frustratingly slow-to-react office culture, tons of re-organization, reviews don't reflect performance and are seldom performed by the manager you had during the majority of the year

pros: That Iam no longer with this organization.
cons: Abusive policies and work life balance only benefit the organization. Stressful and mis- management of priorities. Under educated leadership in the field itself. Bonus program is the biggest fantasy and joke that is offered when your hired. They have internal process that doesnt provide disclosure of how to even attain it and nobody gets their bonus amount promised nor disclosed on how to earn it. IF they promise in offer letter 17% of salary for bonus expect 1% if you burned yourself out and went above and beyond. That will only be achieved if your in the favoritism group this company is known for and dont expect HR to have any credibility and fairness. They are the strong arm of leadership to enforce the abusive behaviors.  Open mindedness are not respect but fall in line and shut up atmosphere are otherwise you will find yourself targeted.

review_title: Was a good company to work for.
job_title: Filialleiter Hamburg / Einkäufer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Could work from home. I worked from home for almost 8 years. You earn more PTO the longer you are there. I always had amazing direct supervisors who really cared.
cons: Terrible Health benefits. (The Worst) The last few years the company has had a bad shift from being a caring, people based company to being all about their numbers. Not just their earnings. But their employees production numbers. very micro managed to the point that its stressful to work there. They laid 100's of us off unannounced without any notice.

review_title: I loved working here until I was laid off
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Newtown Square, PA
pros: I worked in a small department, had the best boss and coworkers.  We had a terrific team with great communication.  I will miss this job!!  Quarterly bonuses were nice as was the accrued time off.  It was about 6 weeks a year for my pay grade.
cons: The benefits are mediocre considering the company is now owned by UHG, but the perks of matching on the 401K and stocks made up for it somewhat.  Never got a raise in the 3 yrs there, not even cost of living.

review_title: Typical large insurance company, poor management, too much bureaucracy.
job_title: Discharge Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: I made lifelong friends at this job which was meaningful and significant. It was easy to get hired at the time, and those that were in charge of keeping up company morale put a lot of effort into it, even if they weren't 100% successful.
cons: Frequent layoffs and a fast turnover, however, they did not replace employees that left. Therefore workloads were increased but not met with matching salary increases. Very small raises, few bonuses. Too many virtual employees. Didn't feel valued. Management did not work well together.

pros: Very large company so there is opportunity to advance. Starting salary is good.
cons: You are expected to do the job of 2-3 people and work lots of overtime. There computer system is from the 1980s and hinders your ability to do your job. The training is terrible and you are punished because their outdated computer system breaks down so often and you can't meet your quota. They do not give raises based on merit and find reasons not to give you an increase.  Although you get a decent amount of vacation time it's rare that you are able to use most of it because they let so few people off per day. Your manager probably has had little training themselves and can't help you during your day to day work

pros: They have a culture change program that is trying to make the company more united.  Attendance at the culture training program has been mandatory for much of leadership.
cons: Very siloed company. Business units work against each other.  Doing anything at a unified enterprise level is impossible.  While the culture training program is trying to change this, it is completely ineffective.  Most leadership will verbally espouse the principles of the culture training, but when it comes to putting it into actions, they simply act as they always have which is to sub-optimize the overall enterprise for the short term benefit of their immediate organizations and their own bonuses.

review_title: Poor management on the appeals side.
pros: In the past we received quarterly bonuses under the original CEO
cons: The present appeals leaders don't know anything about the appeals side of the company. A large contract was signed with large hospital chain. Then there was a layoff. Then the appeals teams became busy. They had difficulty rehiring workers back. So the decision was made to dissolve a small functioning team then to 're-train them to do hearings to make up for the void on the government teams. The two in charge IGNORED opinions from the team and it's direct supervisors.

review_title: Great people, management, and atmosphere...competitive pay Lacking.
pros: The vast majority of the people you will work with are true professionals and do a good job.  Overall people are friendly and make sure you feel part of the team.  The company as a whole strives to put the customer first and is the best in the market for their niche business.  Almost everyone is long tenured and welcome new ideas to push the company forward.
cons: There are definite silos between some of the departments which hinder communication as well and slow the overall growth of each area.  The pay in many cases is not competitive to market (includes average benefits)

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
You will meet many nice people who are trying their best and working hard - most of them do not receive acknowedgement for these efforts.

Many of the jobs are telecommute.
cons:
Some of the worst management you have ever seen.  Lies, lies, and more lies.  The company has all sorts of good intentions listed in emails and town-hallls but that does not reflect what you see day to day.in the workplace.

I agree with other reviewers that it depends on the department and the people you are working with - before you take a job here, ask about retention.(after one year employees can switch departments) and ask if the department has won any awards for their work.

The company is VERY cheap - worst laptops and equipment is provided, pay is low, benefits are so-so and the pay raises are below the cost of living.  Basically unless you are on food stamps and have no other choice - avoid this company like the plague.

pros: Pay is not bad for a call center . PTO is good.
cons:
Very disorganized systems and management. 
Major issues within the systems that upset providers are not fixed. 
You are just a number until you kiss up to the right person which is even hard to do because you are constantly on the phone. 
75% of the callers you talk to are outsource people who have no idea what they are doing and he over 25% are usually upset or angry providers . 
It's very hard to move into another position because they constantly need bodies to answer these calls .

job_title: Desktop Support Supervisor in Orlando, FL
pros: I had a great manager and team. PTO could be used whenever you wanted. I was a mid level employee and didn't have to punch a clock.
cons: My company was acquired by Optumrx and everything went downhill. You become a number not a person. I was forced to travel and had to work long hours even though I was a salary employee and was not compensated for overtime. HRdirect is a disaster. Getting my newborn on the medical policy was almost impossible. The health benefits were the worst I ever had even though I now worked for the provider. Overall, my company being acquired by United health was the worst thing that could have happened. No one on my team likes the job anymore. They are all looking to jump ship.

review_title: Corporate employee - great environment and benefits
pros:
-- My department has a great corporate culture and management definitely takes an interest in the employees' lives outside of work.
-- PTO accrual of 23 days for corporate entry-level positions. 28 days for corporate manager-level positions.
-- After full medical insurance incentives are earned, I pay less than $15 per paycheck (bi-weekly) for a well-balanced medical insurance plan. (This will vary based on plan that you choose)
cons:
-- Some times of the year can be very busy and 50 hour work weeks are not uncommon. (This may be only for certain departments, such as Finance/Accounting)
-- In a company of over 200,000 employees, you will hear many differing experiences from employees at all levels of the enterprise.

review_title: Place where you can make a difference and have fun if you’re comfortable with ambiguity and turnover
job_title: IT Project Manager in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Great people to work with who are enthusiastic and smart and want to make a difference. Interesting work where you can make a difference. Great values and vision.
cons: A lot of reorganization going on so not very stable; benefits are less than stellar; high emphasis on performance and a lot of beaurocracy

pros:
Flexible Schedule
Opportunity to work from home
Opportunity to earn bonuses
cons:
POOR WORK/LIFE BALANCE 
- Possible mandatory overtime- Up to 15 hours per week which can last for weeks, or months
 Some supervisors force you to share your personal life with co-workers
You get an occurrence any, and every time you call in sick
Constant change
It seems as though no body, on any level is on the same page (Always getting conflicting answers)
Benefits are disappointing- especially medical
Not everything they "grade" you on is based on your knowledge or abilities
It's hard to trust all levels of management because sometimes it seems like they tell you whatever they think will make you happy.
100% of the work is computer based and the system issues are frequent (daily) and because you are out of "production" time while you try to resolve the many computer/ system issues, your numbers/ metrics go down .

pros: UHG seems genuinely interested in working with employees to enable us to do our job proficiently. Technology is up to date and works well, and there is good IT support. Completely self scheduled, hours and days with minor limitations like no days can be longer than 10 hours, and we must start after 8 AM.
cons: Communication to middle and upper management can be challenging. No real career path. Middle and upper management positions are rarely available, and not well advertised to existing employees.

review_title: Satisfaction depends heavily on who you report to
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Work-from-home opportunity, 401k, Stock purchase options, I can split my paycheck into 3 different accounts (makes saving easier), I can borrow from my 401k in an emergency (and I have), I can decide what to do with my investments through the company,  PTO that increases with tenure, discounts at local businesses and national (Apple, AT&T, etc) companies.  The advantage of the company size is that you can explore all kinds of career options and, if you're fortunate enough to have a manager who is invested in you, you can look into other options, take assessments, partner with someone already doing the job, etc. Our United Culture is very much in place and is growing, and the annual employee survey is taken seriously.  The work-life balance on my team is excellent.  In fact, I'm having to use some FMLA time to take care of an aging parent and my boss is extremely supportive in that. I'm coming up on my 20th Anniversary and I have no plans to go anywhere else.
cons: No day care offerings, production expectations can be stressful.  I no longer work in UHC, where everything is about number of widgets per hour, but I know that there is a big brother feeling there and a no tolerance policy  for working extra time (some people have been working mandatory overtime for YEARS).    Happines on the job is heavily dependent on who you report to, unfortunately.  There are people in management positions who don't belong there, and attrition from the teams should be able to help pinpoint who those people are.  I had the boss from hell for awhile and she had it in for me (don't know why).  Fortunately for me, I was able to move from UHC to Optum, which is a big breath of fresh air - no one throwing me under the bus, a manager who is excited to have me and thanks me often for the work I do, a whole lot of people living the United Culture / our Values and Principles.

review_title: 13yrs with UHC and all I got was this unemployment check
pros:
•Fair Salary 
•Remote roles
•Volunteer match program
•Individual Health Insurance is really affordable 
•On-site health clinic 
•Online Learning
cons: Mass layoffs are far too frequent-while many other companies CEO’s are forgoing their million dollar salaries to minimize RIF, it’s just not the case with UHC. Most recently an entire segment of roles was eliminated, only to have the same roles be posted for applicants with  several days later. Using layoffs to meet their bottom line is just not a culture that values people.

review_title: A very rewarding place to work, if you work hard!
pros: I really enjoyed my time at UnitedHealth Group. The trainers were very knowledgeable and were always there to answer any questions that I had. I worked as a Claims Associate for just a few short months before being promoted to another department. I then went on to work from home!! Only left this company because of personal issues not related to my job. Great place to work!
cons: The only con was that it was pretty difficult for me to attain a position with this company. I applied at least five different times over the course of several years before I was finally given an opportunity to interview. Once I had my interview, it was smooth sailing but it just took a while to finally get to that point.

review_title: More should be there for the People Managers
pros: one of the leading Payers in Operations.
cons: The People getting Promoted inside are not getting the same treatment as the people who are hired from outside and are not that much verse with the Domain, Still they get better perka and salaries and The Person who has cleared the IJP for the same position will not get the same benefits as the person from the outside does.

review_title: WORST COMPANY EVER TO WORK FOR
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Oldsmar, FL
pros: um, u get a paycheck
cons: hard to get time off, you get written up if u missed work-even if you were admitted to the hospital as an emergency, supervisors and managers do not care about you only your numbers-I was put on medical leave-strict bed rest and not once in my entire time off did anyone in mgmt email me or call me to see how I was doing or when I was coming back, this is the worst company I have ever worked for and I am so glad I left there-I do not recommend this company to anyone unless you are truly desperate.  They expect you to get off the phone within 4 minutes to take more calls so you can meet your metrics every month instead of helping the customers, you can't get any help from the supervisors because they haven't a clue as to what they are doing, you dont get to move up unless you brown nose it...............run as far away from this company as possible

review_title: I would work there again under the right circumstances
pros: Many good managers who are supportive, good place to use experience and possibly gain more, depending on the area the culture is more cooperative and less political.  Very good managerial training.  I would recommend this company to a friend, but only with caution.
cons: Too many reorgs and therefore it's difficult to accomplish goals.  They will speak of career development but it might be difficult to gain, especially when there are many manager changes.  There have been lay-offs lately and a freeze on most hiring, and I'm unsure why there are so many non-citizens working there (could be a lack of skills in the industry or that the salaries are cheaper, not sure).

review_title: A company with degrading employee care
job_title: Senior IT Quality Analyst in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
Work from Home
Cab facility
In house canteen
separate cubicle
cons:
Promotion opportunities are poor  - they will rather hire external candidate.
Low learning , Not recommended for freshers.
Appraisal mechanism is poor.
Variable payout is given at the end of year, if employee leaves mid year he is likely to loose all his variable component.
Poor increments even after company is growing beyond 105 Billion Dollars revenue - UHG is not ready to share its profit with India employees.
Sr management at offshore is not raising the concerns for its employes, seems they are more interested in their bonuses only.
Poor communication with Employees.  No town halls from last 1 year :(
No established mechanism to take feedback from employees.

pros: UnitedHealth Group have a lot of employee growth potential. They offer many self training courses.
cons: Each time they restructure you may change managers several times for the same position. Depending on the team there is no training you must already know what you are doing or rely on the team that has been in the department the longest to know the culture. The Medical insurance is consumer driven, no copay, you have a very high deductible.

pros: If you don't fit wth the in crowd or the click you are worked against Most are working to move up and want to prove themselves and will step on anyone to get there. You get alot of time off but family responsibilities are not a priority...even if your production  and voluntary ot is way up. It's corporate america. Worked there almost 4 years remote and still alot of politics forced to leave a job that was dreamed of. So sad no respect for employees
cons: Dog eat dog and make a few mistakes you are pushed to leave. Even if something major (as a family death) has occured

review_title: Great if you want an easy job with little accountability
pros:
If you're forceful, you can work on virtually any contract you'd like within your practice group. 

There are pretty decent professional development opportunities if there's alignment with a project, if not, good luck.

Bagel Tuesdays?
cons: Leadership is virtually non-existent, does not come to work or works remotely. I had 5+ managers including project managers. Many of which didn't know what I was doing for weeks (sometimes months) at a time. Echoing sentiments from other reviews, there are incredibly bright people here,  but there is absolutely no culture. By that, I mean that often no one says 'hello' in the office, there are virtually no work events - and when there's a team dinner, you pay for yourself.

review_title: Great learning experience and who you get to meet along the way
pros:
- many different opportunities within different sectors that an employee can switch to/try out
- many people that are willing to help you achieve your objective 
- competitive salary 
- good benefits
- good time off
cons:
- as everywhere there are those individuals that dont really want to change tgeir ways or ways of doing things and that impacts your relationship with them and your ability to deliver results 
- there are number of important initiatives that there is no buy in for from the executive level that really impacts the company
- high turn-over

pros: Plenty of capital for projects and programs thanks to the explosive business of healthcare in America. Good experienced and proficient architects across enterprise, operating under radar. Good remote work opportunities. Competitive pay. Polite and professional.
cons: Healthcare growth skyrocketing resulted in very toxic and nebulous politics at leadership levels. Very management heavy, EA Capital Governance reported up through several leaders without architecture experience. Job role completely changed after joining from in-office governance of over 2000+ multi-million dollar projects a year to 100% travel consulting during Affordable Care Act in order to capitalize off inexperience of state implementation.

pros: The work was interesting, fast paced and fun. I enjoyed the work I was doing very much and I the team I was on. The team worked very collaboratively and was supportive of each other.
cons: The company values are up to the interpretation of the director and manager you have, along with things like work life balance. One of the corporate values at UHG is compassion. I would say my department was low on that particular corporate value.

job_title: Technology Development Program in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros:
-Great pay: (75k+ starting w/ 10k signing bonus)
-Generous PTO: 23 days
-You can work on what you want, you can say no to work that does not interest you
-Work life balance (flex hours and work from home)
-Good culture
-No dress code
cons:
-So little work that some people work 10-3 and play video games for 4 of those hours (no joke)
-No development of truly important skills that can be transferred over to bigger and better companies
-Some management and subject matter experts really know nothing about their technologies
-Massive company, you are just a number
-Low office moral

job_title: Business Analyst in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: Co-workers and team manager work well together to deliver quality work
cons: The fraternity old boy network that manage and run the payment integrity division of OPTUM, a division of UHG have zero idea what the word integrity means.  Leaders trying to push payment denial edits out across lines of business that there is zero sourcing for or payment policy for.  The greed of this company is unreal.  Even if you exceed  your performance goals for the year, upper management will lay out 20 reasons you are no going to get a bonus or a merit raise.  Zero job security and your salary will never keep up with the rising cost of living.  And don't ever think there is any opportunity to move up with this company unless you are a man..........

review_title: A great company in which to start an actuarial career in California.
pros: The people are laid back, the work is reasonable, and people generally seem happy. The training I was given was excellent, and everything else I needed I learned on the job.  People in the firm were very friendly, and always willing to help each other out when there were questions or problems.  Despite having multiple buildings spread over several blocks, there was a sense of collegiality and employees made efforts to go to lunch with coworkers in other offices.
cons: The firm is very large so you may get lost in bureaucracy.  Also, since the work you do is usually part of a much larger goal or objective, it is easy to lose sight of the larger picture.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Overland Park, KS
pros: Excellent benefit package. Good environment for upward mobility.
cons: Knee jerk reaction to employee complaints. Unprofessional disability "qualification" standards. (information gathering responsibility is placed upon the ill employee with no employee advocate provided). Too much emphasis was placed on "hitting the target" at the cost of "genuine" interaction with the customers/patients. Profit sharing was totally imbalanced. Delaying or denying claim payments to providers and patients.

review_title: It has been a fun laid back year
job_title: Tier II Agent in Centennial, CO
pros: people I work with are really nice.  My coach Paul Larson is fun to work for.  All the free coffee you can drink.  Half hour lunch makes day go by fast.  Company pretty much leaves you alone and trusts you as an adult to get your work done.
cons: Pay could be better.  I believe Tier II Agents should be getting $20 an hour vs $15.25.  Bonus structure is fine.  You can easily make $300-400 a month which gives you enough money to buy something nice for yourself.

review_title: Very Structured, Metric Driven, overall good place to work.
job_title: Human Resource Advisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great company, Very nice corporate location. All of the employees are top notch people. The compensation if well above average.
cons: The Senior management is very cold. Movement within the company is almost impossible unless you know someone. The call centers are very structure and almost robotic. Opportunites will only come if you " Sell your soul". People have great background and great skills but you will easily be passed if someone has 0.01 metric higher than your metrics.

review_title: The Worst, most Sadistic Company Ever !!!
pros: Unfortunately, there are no pros to list. None at all.!!!!
cons:
The supervisors and managers (mostly women) actively develop,plan and implement policies which are designed to increase pressure, stress, and in general to make the work experience (processing cases), as miserable as possible.
Productivity is the main focus, but everything is done to make it difficult or impossible to meet the productivity goals...thereby giving the supervisors and managers (who do little except watch what case coordinators are doing, always on the lookout to get people in trouble.  They seem to thrive on developing programs designed to make everything an unpleasant experience.
The department, CST is 95% female, and the recruiters seems driven to hire only females...which of course is illegal.

pros: Salary possibility is high and great benefits package and a large variety of perks.
cons:
Company has a terrible HR department that services the entire suite of companies underneath the umbrella. It took 3 months of me chasing down HR to finally get someone to finalize my hiring. Background check took 60 days because they could not communicate that I needed to force my old company to verify employment. 

Company is also notorious for pulling offers. 3 former colleagues had their offers pulled the day they were to start. Their practice is to go dark and not communicate. No compassion. If you hiring takes longer than a week, run back to your current job. Chances are you are about to have your offer pulled.

review_title: They do not promote from within
job_title: IT Architecture Consultant in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: WFH and lots of challenges/problems to solve.
cons: Outside hires are brought in at 30-40% higher salary vs internal. Very, very sick. True leadership is not rewarded, only the biggest mouth to tell the story. Opportunities for advancement are limited to jumping around the organization and applying internally. Pay differences vary drastically and is all based on your initial rate when hired. There is a huge lack of commitment from Sr. Leadership to grow talent organically; what they say vs what they do are much different. The focus is always on what makes the bottom line this quarter for my leadership bonus.

pros: The benefits start on your first day, no waiting, which is a major benefit. The insurance was being switched to a tiered plan with HSA when I left. Projects were always team based and typically had lots of great input when brainstorm sessions were held.
cons: When new ideas came to the table the newest employees' ideas were held with little regard. The hours are terrible, however now you can pay your babysitter appropriately when you work an 18 hour day. The department management teams were lacking in cohesive skills. One would know the answer to a question but not want to share. During conference calls the teams were left with bare bones for troubleshooting.

review_title: Your just a tool to be replaced
job_title: Associate Director Informatics in Santa Ana, CA
pros:
Challenging and rewarding work.
A few great people still around from good days.
cons:
Low pay for amount of work.
Smart and knowledgeable people are not retained.
Hostile environment due to overworked employees.
Typical corporate culture "you are replaceable".
High turnover.
Alway need to be available for call.
No personal life balance.

review_title: Salary is your only pay (Parent Company)
pros:
Plenty of work
Good people at your level 
Learn a lot 
Many to network with around the business 
Commute is short
cons:
Regardless of company performance, “merit” is still ~1%
Performance is not based on your own merit
Work like a dog for minimal increases - going on 3 years now
Computers are new but working from home always has issues
Benefits are pitiful for a healthcare company of this magnitude

review_title: Good place to work with focus on customers, need to compensate employees better
pros: Good customer service seems to be a priority.
cons:
Managers cannot compensate employees fairly.  Corporate gives you a percentage of employees you are allowed to give an "exceed expectations" in your department. One year I had one more employee than I was allowed to give an exceeds to, and had to decide which one was going to be downgraded to a "meets expectations"  which gives them a lower raise in salary.  This was unethical in my opinion, and I didn't like it or think it fair.  One of the reasons I left.
Maybe this has changed since I left, becaue there's a new CEO. I hope so!

job_title: Pharmacy Tech in Overland Park, KS
pros:
Consistent pay
Most fellow employees are good folks
Good choice of health insurance options as well as retirement and stock purchases
cons:
Don't ever EVER have a sick day - unless you've planned it and submitted time off
NEVER talk with your fellow employees; keep your head down, keep silent and work work work
They do not promote from within
Rules and regs are subject to change at a moment's notice
Employees are encouraged to "tattle" on other employees but do become penalized when they bring wrong-doing to management's attention
Strong "do as I say and not as I do" management style
Consistently being watched and bullied by leads to "ensure you are working"
Look down on those who use the restroom more than once in a 2-hour timespan - seriously
Not a place I'd recommend to work

review_title: Employees are just numbers buired under layers of management
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Pay and benefits are average.  Good place to learn how health care works.  IT appeared to have good processes in place for portfolio management, development and testing.
cons: I worked on the Corporate business side with many layers of management.  In many cases no clear concensus of who is is the decision maker.  Very high turnover when you count employees leaving UHG, contractors leaving and employees moving from department to department seeking sanity.  Management appeared to have very good technical or operational skills, but their people skills as manageers was dismal at best.

review_title: My first call center experience--good environment, good managers, good pay
pros: My managers were reasonable people and cared about their team members. Obviously no one is perfect, least of all me! The company provided a decent work environment which I enjoyed for over 2 1/2 years. The pay was good, and I was able to earn Pay For Performance incentives as well as Most Valuable Player awards. The health benefits were reasonable.
cons: Tight on bathroom breaks - 10 minutes; and no cell phones at the desk. But they have to have rules, and I didn't have a problem with either of these. Some micromanaging by some managers but even that wasn't unbearable for those who did their jobs correctly and didn't slack on company time. This job isn't for people who can't deal with angry customers!

review_title: UnitedHealth Group   There are worse places to work!
pros: This company does strive for work/life balance with it's employees.  There are multiple opportunities for community involvement (or not), professional development  and career advancement  if you take advantage of it.  Safe and clean work environments, benefits selection and advanced educational reimbursement if requirements are met.  I would return should the right opportunity present itself.
cons: Somewhat political, very corporate in structure including the red tape that goes along with a large company, some pockets of cliques among management, company values are strong but not always evident in all facets of the company.  Technology is not on the cutting edge, although they do try to stay current.

job_title: Business Analyst Consultant in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: It's a large company with lots of opportunities to grow your career. There are offices throughout the US. Leadership shares their vision with the company. You get a nice amount of PTO as soon as you start. There is a generous Employee Stock Purchase Program. Though the industry is rapidly changing, UHC is a leader in the industry and has had better results than competing health insurance organizations. The company values are honored by employees and leadership.
cons: Because the organization is so large, sometimes you feel lost in the shuffle or detached. The health plan isn't great (only offer high deductible options). They don't match 401k until after the first year.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: There are NO good reasons to work there!
cons: By my 5th day I realized this was the most unprofessional company!  Management treats you like dirt and speaks disrespectful to you in front of other employees.  When I asked upper management if this was normal I was informed that I didn't understand the "relationship" there.  There were roaches in the vending machines and a snake in one of the cubicles.  During training they make new hires listen to calls with "used" headsets.  VERY UNSANITARY!  The pay is incredibly low for how much knowledge they expect you to have in order to do your job.  Very GHETTO!  Very few people are there for 1 yr and even fewer for 2 or more years.  The attrition is through the roof!

review_title: Worst Company But They Don't Want You or the Government To Know
pros: Don't have any at this time.
cons:
They do not care about the Physicians or the beneficiaries.  They do not care about their employees.  They want contracts, but can't work out the kinks.  If you are a hard worker, there is no reward but more work and no appreciation.  But if you are a slacker and don't care if physicians get paid or the beneficiaries are stuck with a bill, they love you.  The new VP over us is good, but the VP still standing in a market in the continental U.S. near us is an idiot and people not even in his department do his job for him.  

Worse Benefits package I've ever seen for a "big" healthcare company.  

They want robots working for them.  This company is not ethical.  They talk the big talk, but can't walk it.

pros: the pay is very good, it is chalk full of incentives for different things. Your metrics, Your performance you get things called Bravo points and they help you get gift cards and certain things that can be bought.
cons: because the pay is incentive based you are paid per your performance if you go to many years or months without making your numbers you re not eligible for a raise so people that have been at the company for less time than you may be getting paid more than you.

pros: Culturally diverse, they allow many positions to telecommute, pay is competitive, great opportunities to move up and they offer excellent benefits.  Terrific work/life balance!
cons: The interview process takes awhile.  This isn't really a con but info for anyone applying.  It took about 3 weeks after I first applied to get my first digital interview.  A couple of weeks after that I got an invitation to do a group interview with 4 managers.  2 weeks after that I had another interview with a team of about 15 designers.  I received my verbal offer about a week later and then the background check started.  This process took probably 3 weeks and then I started.

review_title: Very poor customer relationships hinged on inferior software development.
job_title: Senior QA Analyst, Software in South San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits were good, but you never knew if you were an optum360 employee or a united healthgroup employee.
cons: Very slow responding infrastructure in a dynamic medical industry. It took 6 years for sales Personnel to get optum360 email addresses from the old buyout company's name.  There are little to no accountability metrics established. in my last year, nobody kept track of the $500,000 + per year subscription projects we worked on, everyone in our group was assigned.ating aof 3 out of 5. As a client, don't be disillusioned  into thinking that they will solve all your medical revenue cycle problems, because they wont.  I think Ron Jones, CEO will milk the cow indefinitely, until in about 2020, they finally realize he has no vision to be a CEO.  His emails were merely financial reporting.

pros:
Decent pay rate
Overtime
That's it
Nothing else
More cons than pros 
No cafeteria 
No morale
No compassion
Mangers do what they want here no structure
cons: This company is the worst. They laid our dept off and among the affected, every single white person was offered a job within the company while several black TENURED people were not hired. This company has open racism and really doesn't care about blacks in terms of any kind of advancement. Blacks are set to stay on the production level while whites are elevated even if they have no type of secondary education.

pros: Hourly Pay is OK!  Bilingual Pay is a 'extra" Major Medical/ Dental Benefits Plan are included even if your a temp. contract and  can help in "times" of need. They'll also pay you Severance 3 weeks Pay when they "Lay You Off!"
cons: Will "Cut you loose' in a "heartbeat" even if they "trained and paid for your "licensing" your positions is "still" at risk. They invest in 100s of Health Licenses and 100s of Employees Training in their College of Insurance.  It's "hard to believe" then they "Lay-U-Off" which it's a "loss" for the Company, but a "gain" for the employee. I don't get it?

job_title: Regional Account Manager in Houston, TX
pros: New manager was a breath of fresh air. Good vision benefits, good amount of pto, possible work from home option. Ok pay. Good commission/bonus IF YOU ARE ABLE TO MEET ALL OF YOUR BUDGETS & GOALS
cons: Difficult to get promoted or move forward within company. Difficult to meet budgets & goals with unrealistic expectations form upper management-which makes the job extremely stressful. Bonus is based on productivity therefore it is not a "bonus" but commission. In this role you are expected to provide a level of service to the facility and optum, however time does not always permit these things to be done but optum doesn't care. They still expect you to preform no matter what. Leadership has no real ideal what all this job includes therefore they are unrealistic.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Pay is slightly above average. Nice building. Nice grounds. Cafeteria is nice, self serve vending machine options. I’m trying to come up with 20 words.
cons: Nightmare clientele. The calls are related to people with their medications and home delivery medications. Every person that calls in is a nightmare. Half the callers are addicted to their Lyrica and Xanax so when they call in they are belligerent. The system used to handle these calls crashes on every single call resulting in ridiculous call times. Everyone working in the call center gets attitudes with the customers like it’s cute or something. I hated this place so much then again it’s like every other call center for large corporations. The number one goal for this call center is numbers. They could care less if the patients are getting the right service they need as long as the cal is wrapped up in 3 minutes.

pros: Flexible timings and work from home option.
cons:
I have been working here since 5.5 years and it was good till 2016.
1. Flat 20% of your variable pay will be cut down straight away and there is no guarantee that you will get it back at the end of the year.
2. 15 % of your CTC is a variable pay for below 26 grade 20 % for above 27 grade.
3. Your CTC would be high but you will get less.

review_title: Execs can’t even look you in the eye
job_title: IT Senior Director in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
Good place to get some entry level experience & leave
If you don’t know how incompetent you are leadership will clarify for you at review time
cons:
Executive leadership - it’s all about the money (for them ...not you)
Chaos - priorities always changing to the point there are no priorities
Constant org shuffling - so you’re always a stranger to your manager at review time
Finance runs IT.  
Not a fun place to work.  Fun is relegated to scripted activities for no more than the first 5 minutes at the beginning of a meeting.
Constant fear of layoffs for no apparent reason other than random “cost challenges” from the “business”
Constant fear of layoffs justified because of constant layoffs (that they try to hide)
HR so busy cutting costs, they don’t have time or interest in actually helping human employees.

pros:
Most of the teams had flexible working options. My manager never questioned me for taking WFH . As long as deliverables are on time, nobody bothered.
High Job security for full time employees . Never seen any layoffs in India and rarely heard any in US team.
Helpful onshore counterparts and SME’s.
Great place to learn US healthcare domain.
Technologies and projects  can be changed if extra effort is being put.
cons:
No fixed place to sit. Every quarter your desk is changed which is also not dedicated. 
Noisy environment as calls were taken on speaker.
Politics in onshore opportunities, driven by Gurgaon Management.
Cash awards were made part of the yearly RRP, which was highly demotivating.
Hikes and RRP decreased after Optum branding.

pros: Opportunity for advancement is pretty good if you like to try different positions because it is a big company.  Opportunity to work from home.  There are bonus opportunites for very high performers.  If you like alot of change, this is your company.
cons: Pay for similiar jobs I've held compared to competitors is lower.  Being an insurance company you would think the health insurance would be great but it simply is not.  There is constant struggles with production standards and quality, leaving a person regularly frustrated.  Pay increases frozen for 2009.  Forced overtime for years on end in some departments.  Company is too big and hurts communications and problem solving through different departments.  Seems like something is always changing with this company

review_title: Company a nightmare to work at.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Rocky Hill, CT
pros: It's easy to get to when traffic is bad.  There is plenty of sunshine in the building due to the open window and cube space, and there is free coffee that is ready to be made every morning.  The refrigerator is cleaned biweekly by caring employees who have a great concern for hygene and the carpet smells good.  Bathrooms are clean also.
cons:
Management does not uphold unwritten promises to employees, backbiting is common place, and as a nursing mother I was treated shabbily.

Work/Life balance seems to not be taken into consideration at all.

Compensation is used like a hammer to try to get you to perform above your paygrade as if you don't deserve what you work hard for.

Managerial Bullying seems to be part of the culture.

review_title: A job with a minimal paycheck
job_title: Customer Care Professional in Green Bay, WI
pros: Some great training regarding current health care insurance plans and how the system works in the US.  Met some life-long friends while working there.
cons: When I worked there, I was forced into a lateral "promotion" in which I was to be stuck in for 1 year w/no pay increase.  I was given no choice.  You are pretty much just a number in this company and all they do it track you and micro-manage you as much as humanly and technologically possible.  ALOT of favortism.  If you don't kiss ass, you'll get a "lateral promotion" with no pay increase.  Not very friendly to move up in the ranks if you come from a diverse background, other than that which exists in WI.

review_title: You get good package in pocket but no place to sit and no parking to park your 2/4 wheeler
pros: Good package in the industry.
cons:
IDC is a big flop and cloud implementation is a comedy show. Managers still try to come up with some stupid ideas just to survive and to shoe that they are working on some thing innovative.
The time i joined, IDC worked on so many POCs. You can see maximum employees working on POCs not on actual projects.
No fair policies. Management does not respond to main problems like parking, place to sit.
Not even fair in mid term reviews. funny is same grade(3) for all the employees, irrespective of their work done. From this year it  won'r even give hikes properly as their is no budget and no ROI(Return on Investment)

pros: Opportunity to telecommute if approved.
cons: A lot of favoritism regarding promotions, access to educational funding.   Dictator approach to managing employees.  A lot of programs created at the corporate level are not support by management.  The parent company UHG is very disconnected with the other business segment.

review_title: Valuable experiences but you better be in the right place, or else.
job_title: Infrastructure Support and Analysis in Minnetonka, MN
pros:
- Great use of current and cutting edge technology.
- Overall an exceptionally run company.
- Great place for some techonologists, primarily the non-skilled straight out of college types.  Build-up your resume and get the heck out.
cons:
- Your manager will make or break you, if you don't get along or disagree with your manager you best leave now.
- They have great work from home policies but as a result they don't provide for a good work/life balance.
- They use a managed services business model which means they can hire cheap non-skilled labor and lay you off once you become too expensive.

review_title: This place USED to be a great place to work.
pros: Work from home, decent pay
cons: Empty promises of jobs, dead end departments, no raises, decreases in bonuses becasuse of how other people do their jobs not based on how well you do your own, suggestions fal on dead ears. Little by little since Optum/UHG has taken over everything that was great about this company has disapeared. Most of us are extemely surprised and bewildered each time as to how they keep making the best of list.

job_title: Customer Care Professional in Green Bay, WI
pros: Co-workers are great, the only thing enjoyable about working for UHC is the employees, not managers.
cons: The management is a joke, there is no support for customer service reps.  There is a ton of training but they don't actually prepare you for how the phone calls are.  The metrics are horrible, they listen to your calls, tell you what to say, then tell you there is no script.  If you don't say exactly what they want you fail your call, if your tone is not perfect you fail your call.  They have the nerve to tell us all that we need to start treating our members like "humans" and with "compassion", yet they treat the CS reps like crap if we don't act like robots.  The managers don't treat the employees as "humans" or with "compassion".  Its a  call center, you take calls and you don't matter.  The benefits are terrible also, you would think an insurance company could afford to offer better medical benefits.

pros: The sheer amount of resources the organization has at its disposable can be incredibly helpful.
cons: I started with M&V in its' infancy and although UHG is a massive organization, this particular product line was essentially like working for a small start-up.  As stated in the pros, they have a significant number of resources....the con is that they didn't know how to leverage them to fulfill this contract.  It was utter and complete chaos for months on end.  Not what you would expect from a leader in the healthcare industry.  They underhired for several sections which resulted in: 1) the mass hiring of temps who received very little training and 2) TONS of madatory overtime!  Given the clientele they are supposed to serving I definitely expected more.

pros: After the initial trainee and probabtion period you can look forward to an increase in pay. They are quite flexible and understanding when it comes to childcare.
cons: It takes ages for human resources to get things down as they are based in England. If its not  gonna make the company money then its not a priority

review_title: Good name for your resume load of work experience
pros: Great benefits. Good technology. Work life balance. Good place for a self starter.
cons: Site policy. inexperienced people who are there just to fill a seat on many areas. If you work hard and do things you end up being the only one working and lifting other team mates weight.  Immediate leadership's at technology don't know what they are doing. No vision for the employee. You LL do fine if you are a parasite.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros:
- Collaborative environment
- Work from home option available
- Great colleagues
cons:
- Too many layers of management
- They hire external talent but do not take their advice. Too many tenured people and "We are Optum" and this is how we do things over here
- Poor to bad health benefits
- Lack of communications from leaders 
- Drip of lay offs over the past several months has eroded trust in the management.

review_title: They don't care about you even when you have a disability. Optum a revolving door of dung.
pros: When I quit working here.
cons: Management is rude to their employees, giving them a false sense of being able to move up through the company. The shift bid here is horrible, my class was lied to about the shifts they gave us after the first week of training . After training we had to change our schedule again. The first day on the floor you receive no help from "poets" which makes training a joke. It last 7 weeks and they barely help you through training learning the two most important programs.  They mistreat you even if you have a pre existing condition disability and will not give you any accommodations telling you to pretty much do your job or you can get out.

review_title: A Fortune 6 company that doesn't want to give bonuses and raises.
job_title: RN Case Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Large company with many positions to move and grow. Corporate culture that is innovative, and seems to value praising each other.
cons: When hired,  recruiter says my position qualified for a bonus of up to 23% . Well,  I'm not so naive to believe that meant people at my level, but no bonus at all!? This is a Fortune 6 company, who just got a huge tax cut, whose stock is soaring, and a 1% raise is ok? Thank goodness I am invested in the 401k, and Employee Stock Purchase Plan.

pros: My site is wonderful as is my direct manager.. it's a big company with history so you don't worry about it going under. 401k matching, cheep benefits though not the best they're not the worst and pto you accrue from your first day.
cons: They do everything they can to make sure you don't qualify for a raise and the company operates like high school, if your not a favorite you can not get promotions or interviews.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Very prominent company at the time to work with. They were solid with job security and offered many ways to really get up financially and ethically. Paid attention to you and your integrity and exemplary solid work ethic and honor.
cons: Not honest on changes and policies and activities which resulted in unfair departure and ending of what could have been continued greatness which UHG really did have., until they unfairly let me go. I have several years of honored and exemplary service. At least this what I had been told and acknowledged upon with my coaches and management team. I wish our site had not been sold. I went to a department who I believe was not honest with me. I was there only 90 days and I experienced very cold and negativity from some of the new department co-workers. They would complain and they lost all 3 of us new hires for various reasons. My situation was I received surprise call from senior executives that I had failed my annual background check for 2017, where I had passed all background checks both annually and ethically and had solid 3-4 year tenure with solid service. There was no reason for them to just oust me on a technicality which I spoke with the consumer advocates who conducted all of our annual background checks which had been the same company UHG has used my whole tenured time. Why suddenly was I failed? If I fail one background check, I would have failed all others. Where I have not. Before and after this incident, I have passed and had exemplary background. I do not break the law at all. I make mistakes indeed, breaking the law is not one of them. They have betrayed my trust and violated my respect for them by for what I believe they let me go for much more than I just failed my annual background.
