I saw my consumer report which was alledgedly used for my annual for 2017. There was only one thing on it which stated decisional. Also on the initial application process when I applied back in 2014. It asked in the past 7 years were you charged or convicted of any crime of any kind. I answered honestly;  NO! And this was honored throughout my tenure with Connextions which became Optum INC. All of these truths followed me as it should have continued to do currently.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I do not see a good thing to highlight.
cons: Unied Health is trying to show off both externally and internally as a company with values and principles. Unfortunately I have seen all they preached were just mimics for employees. They do not care for patients -thier customers- nor their employees:  that matters is making money and taking advantage of both. When you get to the bottom of it there is no respect and no adherence to pricinples in the line of management. Even the office that oversees wrong doings is rotten and a puppet of mangement.

review_title: OptumHealth on its way but not there yet!!!
pros: We have the ability to work from home which is great with gas prices.  We get to work with cutting edge information, and new ways of managing diseases.
cons: I have a manager that is a MICRO-Manager no one seems to care or wants to support the staff.  Optum hires managers without looking into their background and their exp..  Inexperienced managers equal dissatisfied employees with no inspiration.

review_title: Medicare and Retirement Dept the Worst
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Roanoke, VA
pros: telecommuting, local management ok, I am not able to come up with 20 words to describe anything good about this department.
cons: Pay and benefits are terrible, earned bonuses aren't paid, atmosphere stifling, totally incompetent corporate management who refuse to even communicate directly with any of us. If anyone openly disagrees with any decree handed down by corporate, they are actually threatened with termination if they don't shut up. Funded by the federal government; CEO of United HealthCare (UnitedHealth Group is parent company), Gail Boudreaux, got a 79% pay increase in 2012, making her salary 10.9M (according to the Wall Street Journal). Our raises were capped at 2%. Our dept makes more money than all other depts yet have less benefits and make less money while the average pay of corporate execs is $10M plus per year. If this department wasn't subsidized by taxes, it would have been bankrupt several years ago.

review_title: OptumRx Review from one individual contributor viewpoint
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Minnetonka, MN
pros:
Premier pharmacy benefit management company - has won multiple awards for customer service and prescription fulfillment capability.
This division of United Healthcare is large enough to have many areas, departments, teams where a person can develop their careers.
Pharmacy benefit is a growth market and a still maturing industry.  Joining OptumRx team brings a person into a mature organization within a growing industry.
cons: Mentoring is not always available in all areas.  Growth comes from a person applying to a new position and pursuing a new salary grade, depending on the team and the management style.

review_title: Very dedicated team of professionals with a strong culture of collaboration
pros:
Collaboration  - willingness to partner across organizations
Strong market presence - client relationships are strong and repeat business makes working with clients teams easy - the trust is already there
Leaders are accessible and listen - gaining consensus to make changes or develop new capabilities in easier than at many other companies
cons:
Navigating a large organization where some of the ownership to capabilities/focus get blurred
Organizational change - transitional period as the company becomes one Optum - it is not a Con as much as individuals working at Optum need to be self-starters - aggressive with reaching out and identifying the right people to work with.  
While gaining promotional opportunities is easy to do if you are a seasoned and dedicated - upping the salary commensurate with the increased responsibilities and title is not easy to do

pros:
Great company as far as how they treat their employees.  Very positive and they want you to advance and they provide
opportunities to improve your skills.  Good starting salary
cons: The database software they use is an Oracle software= they call it IRIS .  It truly sucks for taking prescription orders and all that it involves.  Absolutely designed by an idiot.  Too cumbersome and tedious to work with.  Everyone there hates, it causes 30 percent or more of the agent's frustration and aggravation.  The rest of the frustration is a poorly designed and overly redundant process.  You have to work feverishly to do 10,000 things for taking one order for prescription and to give the order status it's like playing hide n go seek for the final and correct status.  The poor customer has to stay on the phone for 30 - 60 min when there is a moderate problem to resolve.  One customer - a young person -said the Optumrx web site is a pain to just set up your username and password.  Every username he put in the system rejected it.  He got tired or trying.  This is over security - you can't even sign up.  They need to pay $16.00 per hour for the sheer aggravation of the job mechanics.  Customers call in upset and agents and pharmacist poorly notate the account - so it is a challenge to give a logical progression of what happened to the order.  You have to look high and low and around the block for answers and then if you can't find the info - they want you to read training modules and bulletins- all the while the customer is on the phone waiting for a status on their order.  If you still can't find it you can call someone to assist you.  It's like the agent have to ride a broken bike to do the job.  Ridiculous - but it's a job.  Even our trainer and trainer assistant said they were in part motivated to become trainers because they wanted to GET OFF THE  PHONES.  For a insurance company they need to invest money in not fixing the broken system but redesign it with professional and non experience testers to have a better system.  Optumrx does not have a state of the art system nor a 6 sigma work process. Most days can be very overwhelming trying to dodge the bullets.

pros: In my division, telecommuting is encouraged. As long as my team members are meeting their goals, we encourage it. Also, very flexible work schedules with flex start times and 4 day work weeks. It really depends on the department you are in and how much that leadership supports home-work balance. Work is challenging, and leadership is supportive.
cons: Internal promotions are capped at 10%, so they don't do much to retain their long time staff. We can hire somebody off the street at significantly more pay than we can offer current employees at annual review time. I have good people making $5 less an hour than new hires, because they have stuck with the company for so long.

review_title: Make sure your follow the company policies!
pros: Company is good to work for if you want to put in lots and lots of hours.  They promote within and they find programs for you to work on if one ends.
cons: Too many HR issues.  Your a number, No one is accountable for the work they do not complete so you have to wait forever to get anything done.  Training needs to be better.  Must follow all policies to a tee.  That is not bad, but they try to find something wrong

job_title: Service Account Manager in Minnetonka, MN
pros: Great training and experience. Resources available for every aspect of the job. Low level management is supportive and directly accessible. Metrics for productivity are attainable. Some departments offer quarterly incentives that range from $300-$1000.
cons: If you do not have prior experience, your salary will undercut the market by 25-40%. Turnover is higher in service departments due to 6-8 months mandatory overtime (2hrs/day). Pay is notably lower than other insurance providers. It's more worth your while to start at UHC, get a job at one of their competitors, and come back after 1-2 years. Benefits are okay, but not on scale with other Fortune 500 companies. Most of our clients have better health insurance than we are offered.

pros:
- The coaches are amazing, if you get lucky to be assigned the ones that know how to help
- It's a cubicle job. Plug your headphones in, keep your head down, and meet your goals
- If you meet your VPH goals, get bonuses and perks. If not, you better figure it out real quick!
cons:
- Trainer was inexperienced, felt unprepared when arrived on floor
- Lots of meetings daily once on floor, micro-managed by software program (log in breaks, etc.)
- Lots of stress when they tell you take your time but have to meet your goal
- You either understand how to do this job or you don't, you'll quickly realize why the turnover is huge

pros: great people, good pay with bonuses. I love the people we communicate with on the phones, the providers are really good people
cons: Company is all about statistics and not about customer services. they want first call resolutions but you better do it in good time even if there's lots of claims to do with one provider and if the call runs over your break time don't take your break or you get a red mark for adherence even if you are working at the time. Should be called United Health don't care.

pros: No one pressures you, it's a relaxed atmosphere. Because you are working approval and denials you're not on the phones much at all.
cons: Pay structure is horrible- no raises AT ALL you stay at $13 an hour because they want you to make bonuses based on how many claims you do every 3 months. Training is a joke and when you get on the floor there is so much you don't know it's pathetic. Also, some of the practices they are allowing on how claims processes is unprofessional- they work on an honor system that is a failure and I truly can't understand how it hasn't caught up with them yet. Because there are no raises the turnover is tremendous

review_title: Good pay, good benefits, the provide extensive training to get you ready for the job, training varies on department.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Supervisors are understanding and compassionate, in M&R department there is no AHT. Compassion is the most important value and what we focus on. We get the schedule that we want for the most part. Paid holidays. Time and a half if we work holidays! Great support throughout the site. Raises and bonuses every year if you do your job!
cons: For the most part the managers understand that there are emergencies but you can't miss a lot before being on a warning or final, be sure you talk to manager if you can't be at work and they can usually override so it won't count against you. Other than that, good company to work for!

pros: most of the managers that i've come across are awesome. i've had some wonderful opportunities to visit other states and to meet other team members in those states. (i've worked for UHC for three years).
cons: where to begin. i'm lucky that i have the option to have a flexible schedule but most don't. the benefits are expensive when you think that we work for the company that provides said benefits. depending on what state you work in depends on job growth. not much advancements in my state. just a very cold sterile enviroment. no face to face time with team members as you are all hiding behind 5 foot tall cubicles (yes its a cube farm) working

review_title: Was afforded opportunities to grow my skills and gain exposure to multiple aspects of the business.
job_title: Operational Training Manager in Jeffersonville, IN
pros: Annual reviews with potential for raises and bonuses. Many options for medical, dental, vision, 401k match, HSA and wellness programs with employee discounts. The employee recognition program is also very unique and allows leaders the ability to recognize their teams easily and often.
cons: State of the business was in constant flux and never really felt any stability

pros:
Pto
Excellent systems compared to other carriers
Great place to learn industry and then move on
Flexible work from Home schedule 
Can learn from very smart colleagues.
cons:
Low pay in relation to industry
Yearly bonus is variable. Can depend on politics and if director likes you.  Around 3-6%. 
Generally low merit increases 1%
Large company. Can be hard to get things done. This is not a problem that is unique to UHC. 
The less said about Hartford, the better. 
Employees stayed thru the recession due to lack of opportunities. Now leaving in droves due to UHC “ arrogance” . Touts place in fortune 10 list and opportunity due to size. 
Sadly this is not a reality.

review_title: Lot of remote work opportunity , descent pay, fishy partnerships
pros: Plenty of remote work opportunities and overall big company with many internal jobs if you want to switch
cons: Beauricratic and old school feel company.  While an employee I wrote to HR asking why  the company offers tuition discounts specifically to for profit college that have all been accused of being diploma mills - never got any response. They have a big program with University of Phoenix where they specifically send UHC employees to get their degree - which is really odd why instead of the many good local state schools you would instead form a partnership to a for profit school with a horrible reputation.

pros: Full Time Hours, Remote Location,
cons: Micromanaging, Unorganization, Bad Benefits, High Expectations , They  occasionallly offer overtime  to a certain extent , No floor support

review_title: UHC does not put their members,  customers and especially their employees first.
job_title: Can't Disclose in Eau Claire, WI
pros: A few coworkers I get the pleasure to work with since we are not allowed to speak or message anyone unless absolutely necessary.
cons: Only care about production numbers and the bottom line.  Management is super hypercritical, too busy for their employees and don't seem to care about what we think or feel, making us feel more like numbers than people. They are not fair between the employees on their teams, have favorites they give more benefits to and will take credit for the work of their employees at times.  There is no training given but yet if you mess up in any way you still get written up.

review_title: Mixed - very dependant upon the business segment and leadership of the department
pros:
- Certain areas of the company are very exciting and working on innovative solutions in healthcare
- Good people with an authentic concern for the heath of our members and the work we do
- Large company with professional growth opportunity because of its size and diversity of job functions
cons:
- Health benefit coverage is the worst of any employer I've had which is ironic - not a perk for being in the industry
- Management focus on employee coaching comes once a year around review time - too little too late
- Navigation of career path options and growth is tricky and challenging

review_title: OptumInsight is not a place to work if growth is important.
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Franklin, TN
pros: The PTO given once you have 5 years of experience is great, 28 days. Management is very flexible in regards to time off for family/personal needs. Some telecommuting is allowed. It is an easy place to work if you are a high performer, as you will be able to outwork the many mediocre people here in 10 to 15 hours per week.
cons: There is no longer any business growth, so advancement opportunities do not exist. Many of your peers will be completely incompetent, so you will be asked to fill in the gaps that they create. Management does not hold incompetent people accountable, but they will micro-manage high performers.

review_title: Growing so fast - inept people become leaders by default without leadership skills.
pros: The compensation was good and it's very process driven. I learned a great deal of process management and how change control was key to ensuring stability.
cons:
The leadership, from middle managers all the way up the chain, play politics.  There are too many people required to make a decision which results in a lack of accountability and ownership of your business.

The company is so large in IT that the culture is non-existent. Employees are a commodity.

review_title: I really enjoyed my staff, peers and leadership of the company. I loved my job.
pros: Company mission statement, the integrity of the customer service, and the work ethics of the entry level to mid management employees.  Salary, all other benefits except medical benefits.
cons: The upper leadership was more worried about the stockholder and the board of directors then the employees that were making the company successful for the stockholders and board of directors. The company became too corporate like the banks are. The amount of money the top 10 employees of the company make way too much money, compared to their workers.

job_title: Senior Healthcare Economics Analyst in Franklin, TN
pros: Depending on the department/length of employment: flex time, 8 hours of accrued paid time off/pay period.
cons: Depending on the department, getting a manager that supports continued skill and career growth can be non-existent. There's no career growth after hitting a certain grade level. When open positions on a team become available, outside candidates are offered 20-50% more in salary than internal candidates. The only way to move up is applying for open positions.

pros: The abilities to branch out within same corporate  umbrella . The stock purchase , 401 K, competitive  wages
cons: The bureaucracy, being innovative is a good headliner but not much practice. Cooperate environment when subdinates quickly learn not  to "question the way things have always been done " poor work life balance , stretching human capital, along with shortcuts to make the bottom line may back fire

review_title: Insurance company pretending to be a technology one
pros:
Stock purchase plan, 401k is decent. Starting pay for a fresh graduate isn't too bad.
If you are in one of their "big bet" products you will get a lot of money thrown at you.
cons: Growth is very limited. Bonuses and pay raises are extremely low. The company is just layers of managers and useless committees. This company is run as an insurance company not a technology company. Everything is locked down with no flexibility to innovate. If you aren't in their big bet products, they just let all their other products slowly wither away.

job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Kingsport, TN
pros:
Co-workers are good people
Large personal workspace
Holidays off
cons:
Insufficient pay for the amount of work you are expected to do
No PTO is ever available, and they will not work with you on days you need off for personal or medical reasons even if you ask weeks in advance
Little to no coaching or guidance, let alone encouragement
Training is inadequate and poorly organized
Supervisors have clear favorites that get more opportunities and time off the phone
Insurance benefits are not that great

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Miami, FL
pros: You get a 401k some companies don't match at all these days. That's about it all other benefits are no Bueno.
cons: The downside is micromanagement, favoritism, not really being able to move up within the company, then the medical benefits are horrible being that we work for a health insurance company.
